byline: {'original': 'By Louisa Thomas', 'person': [{'firstname': 'Louisa', 'middlename': None, 'lastname': 'Thomas', 'qualifier': None, 'title': None, 'role': 'reported', 'organization': '', 'rank': 1}], 'organization': None}
keywords: [{'name': 'subject', 'value': 'Books and Literature', 'rank': 1, 'major': 'N'}, {'name': 'persons', 'value': 'Tesla, Nikola', 'rank': 2, 'major': 'N'}]
snippet: In this novel, a chambermaid strikes up a friendship with a guest, the dying inventor Nikola Tesla.
lead_paragraph: The inventor Nikola Tesla is a historical novelist’s dream. He was the brain behind alternating current, radio, wireless communication and remote control. He was a friend of Mark Twain and a foe of Thomas Edison. Like Alfred Nobel, he had the hubris to believe he could invent a weapon that would ensure eternal peace. He tore up a contract with Westinghouse worth millions. After he died, destitute and forgotten, an F.B.I. agent wrote that the government was “vitally interested” in his papers. Tesla believed he had communications with Mars. He was extremely fond of pigeons. His every action gleams with a kind of guarantee: strange, but true.

keywords: [{'name': 'subject', 'value': 'Books and Literature', 'rank': 1, 'major': 'N'}, {'name': 'persons', 'value': 'Murakami, Haruki', 'rank': 2, 'major': 'N'}]
snippet: Haruki Murakami’s novel features two sisters, one in an enchanted sleep, the other up all night.
lead_paragraph: Should the aliens ever descend in their sleek ships and train their great scanners on our population centers, capturing our deeds and dreams for transmission back to cosmic headquarters, let’s hope they show us the patient tenderness of Haruki Murakami, the Japanese novelist, who himself is not wholly of this world. In a dozen books on our existence here — not in Japan or any special nation but as children of gravity, as earthlings — Murakami has done as good a job as any contemporary writer of pleading humanity’s poignant case before the court of whoever may be out there. Have mercy, oh interstellar lords. We’re lonesome and small and we know not what we do, only that we’re obliged by God or nature to bathe, dress, eat and keep on doing it.

headline: {'main': 'Angels With Attitude', 'kicker': 'Books in Brief: Fiction', 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Angels With Attitude', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}
byline: {'original': 'By J.d. Biersdorfer', 'person': [{'firstname': None, 'middlename': None, 'lastname': None, 'qualifier': None, 'title': None, 'role': 'reported', 'organization': '', 'rank': 1}], 'organization': None}
keywords: [{'name': 'persons', 'value': 'Sosnowski, David', 'rank': 1, 'major': 'N'}, {'name': 'subject', 'value': 'Reviews', 'rank': 2, 'major': 'N'}, {'name': 'subject', 'value': 'Books and Literature', 'rank': 3, 'major': 'N'}, {'name': 'creative_works', 'value': 'RAPTURE (BOOK)', 'rank': 4, 'major': 'N'}]
snippet: J D Biersdorfer reviews book Rapture by David Sosnowski; drawing (S)
lead_paragraph: It seems that there actually are angels in America -- not only on the Broadway stage, but in inner-city Detroit. And these aren't the wistful greeting-card cherub variety or the swirly seraphim found peeking from the inspirational-book racks. The winged humans in David Sosnowski's wry, dry first novel are angels with attitude. RAPTURE (Villard, $23) starts off with Zander Wiles, a small-time Motor City drug dealer who one day feels a strange itching and weeks later finds himself with a pair of nine-foot black wings growing out of his back and an increased magnetic field emanating from his chest cavity. Zander eventually heads for New York, gets himself an agent and becomes the first angel to go public. However, the angel epidemic is on the rise, as is public awareness. A college student named Cassie O'Connor cross-references her symptoms at the campus library to find that she might have ''the flu, food poisoning, AIDS or that new, weird one -- Angelism.'' The novel's allegorical structure allows Mr. Sosnowski to skewer the whole spectrum of modern culture as he chronicles a newly self-aware minority going through all the trials of joining a suspicious society. Congress encumbers them with legislation and religious pundits weakly rationalize their existence, but the Angels go on to gain that true pinnacle of acceptance -- their own mainstream marketing niche. The Feathered Nation soon has its own bars, movie theaters (featuring ''perch-style seating''), support groups, bumper stickers, pop slang and militant factions. As the book's plot kicks in, the alert reader will figure out that Zander's flight path is destined to cross with Cassie's, and the witty, arch angel banter they engage in as their romance unfolds is one of the book's greatest delights. J. D. Biersdorfer
abstract: J D Biersdorfer reviews book Rapture by David Sosnowski; drawing (S)

keywords: [{'name': 'persons', 'value': 'Sorel, Edward', 'rank': 1, 'major': 'N'}, {'name': 'subject', 'value': 'Reviews', 'rank': 2, 'major': 'N'}, {'name': 'subject', 'value': 'Books and Literature', 'rank': 3, 'major': 'N'}, {'name': 'creative_works', 'value': 'JOHNNY ON THE SPOT (BOOK)', 'rank': 4, 'major': 'N'}]
snippet: Adam Liptak reviews book Johnny on the Spot by Edward Sorel; photo (M)1
lead_paragraph: The great political caricaturist and magazine artist Edward Sorel has also illustrated children's books for years, and lately he has taken to writing them as well. His latest collaboration with himself, JOHNNY ON THE SPOT (Margaret K. McElderry, $16; ages 5 to 9), is an exciting yarn set in the old New York of radio serials, when gangsters toted machine guns in violin cases. Sorel's vivid and engaging illustrations include some big urban tableaus that capture the romance and innocence of the era. The plot is just as lively. When young Johnny's radio conks out during his favorite program, he takes it to Dr. Zaga, the mysterious and eccentric inventor (is there any other kind?) who lives downstairs. Dr. Zaga zaps it with ''a small charge of electrostatic magnetism,'' which causes the radio to broadcast not today's news but tomorrow's. This allows Sorel to present, in quick, deft strokes, some of the usual paradoxes and moral quandaries of time travel. Dr. Zaga tells Johnny that they must not interfere with the future, but he does not explain why, and in any event they do it anyhow, in various ways. At first Johnny merely takes pictures of a bank robbery and sells them to a newspaper, but soon he is rescuing a girl in a burning building and hanging out at the race track, placing bets. (''It's not gambling,'' Dr. Zaga explains to a reluctant Johnny. ''We know which horses will win.'')
abstract: Adam Liptak reviews book Johnny on the Spot by Edward Sorel; photo (M)1

keywords: [{'name': 'persons', 'value': 'Brautigan, Richard', 'rank': 1, 'major': 'N'}, {'name': 'subject', 'value': 'Reviews', 'rank': 2, 'major': 'N'}, {'name': 'subject', 'value': 'Books and Literature', 'rank': 3, 'major': 'N'}, {'name': 'creative_works', 'value': 'UNFORTUNATE WOMAN, AN: A JOURNEY (BOOK)', 'rank': 4, 'major': 'N'}]
snippet: Etelka Lehoczky reviews book An Unfortunate Woman: A Journey by Richard Brautigan; drawing (S)
lead_paragraph: When someone takes his own life, it's tempting to interpret everything he did and said near the end as a kind of warning. Such compulsive reductionism is particularly difficult to avoid in reading AN UNFORTUNATE WOMAN: A Journey (St. Martin's, $17.95), a book-length work Richard Brautigan completed a year before his suicide in 1984. In it, Brautigan creates what he calls ''a calendar of one man's journey during a few months in his life'' that, though labeled as fiction by its publisher, reads like memoir. The title refers to a friend who had killed herself and whose absence is the book's organizing force. Under the shadow of this event, Brautigan's familiar mix of wry stories and observations takes on a persistent mordancy. There are certainly moments here when he revels in the absurd, as when he relates his determination, while visiting Hawaii, to pose for a photo with a chicken. More often, though, he adopts a subdued tone that will surprise fans of his famously playful novels. After devoting so much thought to the question of individual freedom in a corrupt world, Brautigan seems here to concede, finally, that some things are inescapable. He dedicates his introduction to another friend who had recently died from cancer. It's possible to read countless other elements of the book as intimations of mortality, from Brautigan's compulsive traveling to his habit of concluding many sections with a date and the word ''finished.'' But just as evident, though overshadowed by subsequent events, is the author's determination to resist the bleak certitude of death. ''Life cannot be controlled and perhaps not even envisioned and . . . design and portent are out of the question,'' he notes at one point. Such a statement -- along with the rest of ''An Unfortunate Woman'' -- can be read as an expression of Zen-like peace or of helplessness verging on despair. Etelka Lehoczky
abstract: Etelka Lehoczky reviews book An Unfortunate Woman: A Journey by Richard Brautigan; drawing (S)

snippet: Marilyn Stasio reviews following books: Pursuit by Thomas Perry; Smuggler's Moon by Bruce Alexander; Retribution by Stuart M Kaminsky; Walking the Perfect Square by Reed Farrel Coleman; and Echoes of Lies by Jo Bannister; drawing (M)
lead_paragraph: The game's afoot in Thomas Perry's dazzling new thriller, PURSUIT (Random House, $24.95) -- and the contest isn't checkers. The key players in Perry's deadly sport are James Varney, a sociopathic hit man whose handiwork has left 13 people dead in a Louisville, Ky., restaurant, and Roy Prescott, the professional manhunter hired to track him down by the father of one of the victims. The odds seem to favor Varney, who is young, strong, disciplined and fearless. Lacking a conscience to slow him down, he is a finely tooled killing machine, ''a superior being'' who isn't quite human. But the odds even out when Prescott makes his moves. Like one of those scary action figures beloved of 12-year-old boys, he's ''a man who would not give up, could not call for reinforcements and would not stop coming.'' It's a perfect match.
abstract: Marilyn Stasio reviews following books: Pursuit by Thomas Perry; Smuggler's Moon by Bruce Alexander; Retribution by Stuart M Kaminsky; Walking the Perfect Square by Reed Farrel Coleman; and Echoes of Lies by Jo Bannister; drawing (M)

snippet: Scott Anderson’s “Lawrence in Arabia” traces many conflicts in today’s Middle East back to World War I.
lead_paragraph: Scott Anderson’s fine, sophisticated, richly detailed “Lawrence in Arabia” is filled with invaluably complex and fine-tuned information. This demanding but eminently readable account of the Middle East during World War I is certainly no hagiographic T. E. Lawrence biography, as the tiny nuance (“in,” not “of”) coloring its title makes clear.

lead_paragraph: Here's the scenario: It is the immediate future. North Korea invades the South. Russia and China are at war. A right-wing general takes over Russia and uses nuclear weapons. China retaliates with its nuclear missiles. The general thinks they are American and launches 1,000 of his own against the United States. America retaliates. A weak President is impeached on the floor of the Senate, which is now located underground. There is a surprise ending, sort of.
abstract: Here's the scenario: It is the immediate future. North Korea invades the South. Russia and China are at war. A right-wing general takes over Russia and uses nuclear weapons. China retaliates with its nuclear missiles. The general thinks they are American and launches 1,000 of his own against the United States. America retaliates. A weak President is impeached on the floor of the Senate, which is now located underground. There is a surprise ending, sort of.   It's harrowing stuff in Eric L. Harry's first novel, ARC LIGHT (Simon & Schuster, $23). Learn all about how and why nuclear bombs work. Shudder at the devastation they cause. Follow a large cast through all kinds of adventures. Trace the political maneuvering of American and Russian diplomats. Wonder if the world will survive.

lead_paragraph: I REMEMBER BALANCHINE: Recollections of the Ballet Master by Those Who Knew Him, by Francis Mason. (Anchor/Doubleday, $15.) The author interviewed more than 85 of the choreographer's colleagues and friends, ranging from Rudolf Nureyev to a men's wardrobe supervisor at the New York City Ballet. "This book is less than a biography, yet it catches more of the man than any of the Balanchine biographies to date," Alastair Macaulay said here last year.
abstract: I REMEMBER BALANCHINE: Recollections of the Ballet Master by Those Who Knew Him, by Francis Mason. (Anchor/Doubleday, $15.) The author interviewed more than 85 of the choreographer's colleagues and friends, ranging from Rudolf Nureyev to a men's wardrobe supervisor at the New York City Ballet. "This book is less than a biography, yet it catches more of the man than any of the Balanchine biographies to date," Alastair Macaulay said here last year.   THE SATANIC VERSES, by Salman Rushdie. (The Consortium, $10.) The novel that earned its author a death sentence has at last been issued in paperback. When the book was first published in 1989, the Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini of Iran denounced it as blasphemous to Islam and put a bounty on the head of Mr. Rushdie and all those associated with its publication. The offense lay partly in the author's retelling of episodes in the life of Mohammed from the perspective of one of his characters, who experiences much of the novel's action in his dreams. The author, who at first opposed a paperback edition of "The Satanic Verses" in hopes of softening the decree, has since endorsed the venture; an anonymous group calling itself the Consortium has backed it. Three years ago our reviewer, A. G. Mojtabai, said, "What lives most vibrantly, for this reader, are the scenes that are grounded -- the places where magic doesn't overwhelm the realism -- the moments when Mr. Rushdie looks 'history in the eye.' "   LOST TRIBES AND PROMISED LANDS: The Origins of American Racism, by Ronald Sanders. (Harper Perennial, $13.) This book, now with a new foreword by Michael Dorris, explains that Western Europeans' attitude of superiority toward other cultures and races can be traced back as far as the Middle Ages. In 1978 our reviewer, D. B. Davis, found it "studded with fascinating details, well-told anecdotes and bold speculations."   SCUM, by Isaac Bashevis Singer. Translated by Rosaline Dukalsky Schwartz. (Plume, $9.) In this novel, the Nobel Prize-winning author examines the dark side of Krochmalna Street in Warsaw, his own boyhood neighborhood. "The plot of 'Scum' is simple," our reviewer, Bette Pesetsky, said last year, "but Mr. Singer twists it until its vision is new and unexpected."   ANGELS' VISITS: An Inquiry Into the Mystery of Zinfandel, by David Darlington. (Owl/Holt, $10.95.) The book's title derives from a quotation by a 19th-century California horticulturist, who observed that the best zinfandels were similar to angels' visits: "few and far between." But this book is about more than the United States' only indigenous fine-wine grape. "It weaves history, geography, wine and some of the fascinating people who make it into a downright enthralling tale," Frank J. Prial said here last year. Also for oenophiles -- and perhaps soap-opera fans -- is the best seller NAPA, by James Conaway (Avon, $12.50). Here, you can read all about the Mondavi brothers' fistfight and the marital problems of the couple who used to own Inglenook. In 1990 our reviewer, Richard Flaste, called it "a strong insider's view of this astonishing valley."   THE NEVER-ENDING, by Andrew Hudgins. (Houghton Mifflin, $9.95.) This poetry collection, a finalist for the 1991 National Book Award, ranges in inspiration from the sacred to the profane, sometimes mingling the two. "In all the best of these precise, controlled poems," one critic said, "the tone is by turns furious and affectless, and the subject both elegant and grotesque."   THE WORK OF NATIONS: Preparing Ourselves for 21st-Century Capitalism, by Robert B. Reich. (Vintage, $12.) A Harvard economist argues that Americans must improve their own skills to compete successfully. In a new afterword, he also examines the effect of the Soviet Union's demise. Mr. Reich "wisely warns against a zealous economic nationalism that would not help us and might hurt the world economy," Robert J. Samuelson said in The Book Review in 1991.   HOW TO MAKE AN AMERICAN QUILT, by Whitney Otto. (Ballantine, $5.99.) A young woman about to be married observes the intricate interweaving of the histories of the participants in her grandmother's quilting circle. Last year our reviewer, Jill McCorkle, called this first novel "remarkable," adding that "it is an affirmation of the strength and power of individual lives, and the way they cannot help fitting together."   CONSCIENTIOUS OBJECTIONS: Stirring Up Trouble About Language, Technology, and Education, by Neil Postman. (Vintage, $10.) In 18 essays, the author deplores, among other things, the adoration of popular culture at the expense of the written word. His commentary "is as funny as it is thoughtful and well argued," Andrea Barnet said here in 1988.   THE FACE OF ANOTHER, by Kobo Abe. Translated by E. Dale Saunders. (Kodansha International, $11.95.) This novel by the acclaimed Japanese author consists of the notebooks of a scientist who has been terribly disfigured in a laboratory accident. He invents a way to fashion a new face for himself, only to find it assuming an identity of its own. In 1966 our reviewer, Edward Seidensticker, called the book "an intricately contrived fantasy."   THE TOMCAT'S WIFE: And Other Stories, by Carol Bly. (Harper Perennial, $9.) Hypocrisy and cruelty run through these eight stories, which examine rural lives that have surrendered to mediocrity. "James Joyce's 'Dubliners' comes to mind sometimes," Louis B. Jones said here last year, noting that "everything from symbol to diction works to effect."

snippet: Margo Jefferson On Writers and Writing column discusses So Many Books: Reading and Publishing in an Age of Abundance by Gabriel Zaid; focuses on how technology and business can better serve readers and how readers can help define culture in fluid,...
lead_paragraph: CAN we really keep blaming television and our image-driven culture for the decline of reading? In ''So Many Books: Reading and Publishing in an Age of Abundance'' (Paul Dry Books), Gabriel Zaid observes that since 1950, when television arrived on the culture scene, the world population has grown by 1.8 percent a year and the publication of books has grown by 2.8 percent a year.
abstract: Margo Jefferson On Writers and Writing column discusses So Many Books: Reading and Publishing in an Age of Abundance by Gabriel Zaid; focuses on how technology and business can better serve readers and how readers can help define culture in fluid, inventive ways; drawing (M)

snippet: Unknown
lead_paragraph: DREAMER, by Charles Johnson. (Scribner, $12.) The story of a poor man whose striking physical (if not spiritual) resemblance to Martin Luther King Jr. lands him a job as a stand-in for the civil rights leader becomes an exploration into the soul of inequality and a probing inquiry into King's life and times. ''Johnson takes bold creative risks,'' Dennis McFarland wrote here in 1998. ''He delivers a lively tale that leaves the reader with enormous concerns to contemplate.'' Scribner has also reissued Johnson's first novel, Faith and the Good Thing ($11), a philosophical ''Pilgrim's Progress'' fable about a black girl's search for the Good Thing in Hatten County, Ga. In 1974 our reviewer, Annie Gottlieb, called this ''a flawed yet still fabulous book, at its best a many-splendored and ennobling weaving-together of thought, suffering, humor and magic.''
abstract: DREAMER, by Charles Johnson. (Scribner, $12.) The story of a poor man whose striking physical (if not spiritual) resemblance to Martin Luther King Jr. lands him a job as a stand-in for the civil rights leader becomes an exploration into the soul of inequality and a probing inquiry into King's life and times. ''Johnson takes bold creative risks,'' Dennis McFarland wrote here in 1998. ''He delivers a lively tale that leaves the reader with enormous concerns to contemplate.'' Scribner has also reissued Johnson's first novel, Faith and the Good Thing ($11), a philosophical ''Pilgrim's Progress'' fable about a black girl's search for the Good Thing in Hatten County, Ga. In 1974 our reviewer, Annie Gottlieb, called this ''a flawed yet still fabulous book, at its best a many-splendored and ennobling weaving-together of thought, suffering, humor and magic.''    GREETINGS, Carbon-Based Bipeds! Collected Essays, 1934-1998, by Arthur C. Clarke. Edited by Ian T. Macauley. (St. Martin's Griffin, $16.95.) Just in time for the new millennium, this collection serves as an intellectual autobiography of the author of ''2001: A Space Odyssey,'' showcasing his early advocacy of space travel and many other ardently promoted causes. ''Arguably, Sir Arthur (he was knighted in 1998) has done more than anyone in the 20th century to explain science to the multitude,'' Gerald Jonas wrote here in 1999.    IN SIBERIA, by Colin Thubron. (HarperPerennial, $14.) A seasoned chronicler of the former Soviet Union journeys alone to Russia's vast, desolate northern plains, dropping by former labor camps, abandoned laboratories and other outposts that dot one of the most inhospitable places on earth. The author ''is a sensitive and observant traveler who clearly respects the Siberians for the hardships they have endured,'' Ken Kalfus wrote in the Book Review in 2000. The same publisher has restored to print Among the Russians (originally published in 1984 as ''Where Nights Are Longest''), an account of Thubron's journey by car to western Russia a decade before the collapse of the Soviet empire. ''A subtle and humane writer, Thubron is able to capture the fleeting words and gestures that define a culture,'' S. Frederick Starr wrote here. ''This tourist-author offers a harvest of insights that would be the envy of any sociologist.''    MEMORIES OF A PURE SPRING, by Duong Thu Huong. (Penguin, $13.) This darkly poetic novel tells of a Hanoi composer whose marriage to a celebrated singer unravels after he is mistaken for a boat person trying to leave Vietnam following the war with America. Duong ''employs flashbacks, multiple points of view and a haunting interplay of narrative and interior voices to construct her sadly beautiful tale,'' Philip Gambone said here last year.    THE NEW NEW THING: A Silicon Valley Story, by Michael Lewis. (Penguin, $13.) The new-capitalist entrepreneur Jim Clark is the subject of this profile of an anti-Organization Man whose drive to shake up the old order transformed Silicon Valley -- and perhaps the American economy. The result is ''a splendid, entirely satisfying book, intelligent and fun and revealing and troubling in the correct proportions, resolutely skeptical but not at all cynical, brimming with fabulous scenes as well as sharp analysis,'' Kurt Andersen said here in 1999.    GIRL WITH A PEARL EARRING, by Tracy Chevalier. (Plume, $12.) This novel's 16-year-old narrator goes to work as a housemaid for Vermeer in the Dutch city of Delft and is invited into the artist's studio, where she learns to grind paints and sits for a portrait. ''Chevalier's exploration into the soul of this complex but nave young woman is moving, and her depiction of 17th-century Delft is marvelously evocative,'' Ruth Coughlin wrote here in 2000.    THE BOOK OF REVELATION, by Rupert Thomson. (Vintage International, $12.) A young choreographer is abducted in Amsterdam, imprisoned and repeatedly raped and sexually abused by three masked women. After his release, his career and self-image are shattered. The novel's premise is ''made terrifyingly real by a hugely talented writer,'' Anthony Bourdain wrote here last year.    THE MADWOMAN IN THE ATTIC: The Woman Writer and the Nineteenth-Century Literary Imagination, by Sandra M. Gilbert and Susan Gubar. (Yale University, $19.95.) This feminist study of eminent 19th-century writers like Jane Austen and George Eliot caused quite a stir when it was published in 1979. The authors ''present the first persuasive case for the existence of a distinctly female imagination,'' Le Anne Schreiber wrote in these pages.   Scott Veale

keywords: [{'name': 'persons', 'value': 'AMBROSE, STEPHEN E', 'rank': 1, 'major': 'N'}, {'name': 'persons', 'value': 'Brinkley, Douglas', 'rank': 2, 'major': 'N'}, {'name': 'subject', 'value': 'Reviews', 'rank': 3, 'major': 'N'}, {'name': 'subject', 'value': 'Books and Literature', 'rank': 4, 'major': 'N'}, {'name': 'creative_works', 'value': 'WITNESS TO AMERICA (BOOK)', 'rank': 5, 'major': 'N'}]
snippet: David Walton reviews book Witness To America: An Illustrated Documentary History of the United States From the Revolution to Today by Stephen Ambrose and Douglas Brinkley; photo (M)
lead_paragraph: Stephen Ambrose and Douglas Brinkley's handsome edition of WITNESS TO AMERICA: An Illustrated Documentary History of the United States From the Revolution to Today (Lou Reda/HarperCollins, $35), an anthology of first-person accounts from American history, is an updating of Henry Steele Commager and Allan Nevins's ''Heritage of America'' (1939, revised in 1949). To accommodate the momentous events and social changes of these past 50 years, Ambrose and Brinkley begin with the Boston Tea Party and the American Revolution, eliminating entirely European settlement and colonial life. Gone are the Puritans of Salem, the Byrds of Virginia, Montcalm and Wolfe on the Plains of Abraham. Probably nobody will miss ''A Yankee Approves of Slavery.'' But it is a little startling to see the Progressive era reduced to two articles, World War I to three. Even World War II, in 1949 the longest section with 16 articles, is now down to six; longest in this edition, not surprisingly, is ''The Individual Rights Revolution,'' with 13 selections ranging from ''The March on Washington'' to ''A Chippewa Remembers the Birth of A.I.M.'' Will all these names be as important 50 years from now, for the next edition? Will the cold war still merit as many selections as the Blue and the Gray? Will we still want to read Colin Powell's reflections on the gulf war and Michael Kinsley's on the Clinton impeachment? Will there be room once again for ''Forever Young in Aspen''? Or will these, too, like the Bonhomme Richard, La Follette and the Bonus Army pass into the vales of history? David Walton
abstract: David Walton reviews book Witness To America: An Illustrated Documentary History of the United States From the Revolution to Today by Stephen Ambrose and Douglas Brinkley; photo (M)

keywords: [{'name': 'persons', 'value': 'Ryskamp, Charles', 'rank': 1, 'major': 'N'}, {'name': 'subject', 'value': 'Reviews', 'rank': 2, 'major': 'N'}, {'name': 'subject', 'value': 'Books and Literature', 'rank': 3, 'major': 'N'}, {'name': 'creative_works', 'value': 'ART IN THE FRICK COLLECTION (BOOK)', 'rank': 4, 'major': 'N'}]
snippet: Andrea Barnet reviews book Art in the Frick Collection: Paintings, Sculpture, Decorative Arts by Charles Ryskamp; photo (S)
lead_paragraph: Henry Clay Frick always intended to leave his art collection and sumptuous house at 70th Street and Fifth Avenue to the public. A millionaire by the time he was 30 years old, Frick (1849-1919), who made his fortune in the coke and steel industries, was a bold and discriminating collector. Not only did he acquire some of the greatest Old Masters in the world, as Charles Ryskamp, the director of the Frick Collection, writes, but his eye for contemporary works proved infallible. In ART IN THE FRICK COLLECTION: Paintings, Sculpture, Decorative Arts (Abrams, $60) Mr. Ryskamp has chronicled the evolution of Frick's collection, from the young millionaire's first trip to Europe in 1879, which laid the foundations for his later acquisitions, to his architectural plans for the house and grounds and his purchasing habits, which included living with paintings for months before deciding whether to buy. The museum's curators, Bernice Davidson, Susan Galassi, Edgar Munhall and Nadia Tscherny, have supplied brief though exceptionally lively and informative notes on the history and esthetic highlights of the artworks illustrated. The effect is that of being given a private tour of the museum's masterworks, including paintings by Piero della Francesca, Titian, Bronzino, Rembrandt and Vermeer, Renaissance bronzes, Chinese porcelains and French furniture and clocks. Though few people realize it, the Frick collection is anything but static: at least a third of the paintings now on view were acquired after Frick's death. This is an unusually elegant book that underscores how Frick's style of collecting became the prototype for many of the great American collections. Andrea Barnet
abstract: Andrea Barnet reviews book Art in the Frick Collection: Paintings, Sculpture, Decorative Arts by Charles Ryskamp; photo (S)

snippet: Gerald Jonas reviews following books: Girl in Landscape by Jonathan Lethem; Outpost by Scott Mackay; Signal to Noise by Eric S Nylund; and Child of the River by Paul J McAuley (M)
lead_paragraph: Jonathan Lethem has no patience for rigid genre boundaries. His recent novel ''Gun, With Occasional Music'' (1995) mixed noirish detective fiction a la Raymond Chandler with near-future science fiction to produce an entertainment of delicious irrelevance. GIRL IN LANDSCAPE (Doubleday, $22.95) marries science fiction and the western, but this time around Lethem is deadly serious.
abstract: Gerald Jonas reviews following books: Girl in Landscape by Jonathan Lethem; Outpost by Scott Mackay; Signal to Noise by Eric S Nylund; and Child of the River by Paul J McAuley (M)

keywords: [{'name': 'persons', 'value': 'Barnet, Andrea', 'rank': 1, 'major': 'N'}, {'name': 'subject', 'value': 'BOOK REVIEWS', 'rank': 2, 'major': 'N'}, {'name': 'creative_works', 'value': 'NAM JUNE PAIK: VIDEO TIME--VIDEO SPACE (BOOK)', 'rank': 3, 'major': 'N'}]
snippet: The artist Nam June Paik was described by one critic as a "terrorist of esthetic expectations." It was an understandable label given his antic performance pieces of the 1960's, when as part of the avant-garde Fluxus movement he stunned onlookers w...
lead_paragraph: The artist Nam June Paik was described by one critic as a "terrorist of esthetic expectations." It was an understandable label given his antic performance pieces of the 1960's, when as part of the avant-garde Fluxus movement he stunned onlookers with piano demolitions, imageless films and a now-legendary topless cello concert performed by his sidekick Charlotte Moorman. These days, Mr. Paik's focus has shifted from performance art to multi-screen television installations and global satellite productions. Nonetheless his Dadaist impulses persist, often taking the form of more subtle acts of esthetic subversion, like using magnets to destroy the normal functions of a bank of television monitors, or staging events like "The First Accident of the 21st Century," a choreographed collision between a robot and an automobile driven by a friend. NAM JUNE PAIK: Video Time -- Video Space (Abrams, $49.50) is a lavishly illustrated, highly eclectic survey of the artist's career, from his early Fluxus days in Germany to his experiments with video technology and room-sized video environments in the 1970's and 80's. Rather than presenting Mr. Paik's career chronologically, the editors -- Toni Stooss, director of the Kunsthalle Vienna, and Thomas Kellein, director of the Kunsthalle Basel -- have mixed previously published articles by critics and museum curators with new writings and reminiscences by friends, fellow artists and Mr. Paik himself. The results are uneven, though there are memorable surprises, including a sly interview with John Cage, whose music was a major influence on Mr. Paik, and an evocative essay by the feminist writer Kate Millett recalling the near-utopian idealism of the New York art scene in the early 1960's. Other contributors include the architect Arata Isozaki and the poet Allen Ginsberg. This is a provocative book that chronicles not only Mr. Paik's career but also 30 years of changes in the international art world.ANDREA BARNET
abstract:
The artist Nam June Paik was described by one critic as a "terrorist of esthetic expectations." It was an understandable label given his antic performance pieces of the 1960's, when as part of the avant-garde Fluxus movement he stunned onlookers with piano demolitions, imageless films and a now-legendary topless cello concert performed by his sidekick Charlotte Moorman. These days, Mr. Paik's focus has shifted from performance art to multi-screen television installations and global satellite productions. Nonetheless his Dadaist impulses persist, often taking the form of more subtle acts of esthetic subversion, like using magnets to destroy the normal functions of a bank of television monitors, or staging events like "The First Accident of the 21st Century," a choreographed collision between a robot and an automobile driven by a friend. NAM JUNE PAIK: Video Time -- Video Space (Abrams, $49.50) is a lavishly illustrated, highly eclectic survey of the artist's career, from his early Fluxus days in Germany to his experiments with video technology and room-sized video environments in the 1970's and 80's. Rather than presenting Mr. Paik's career chronologically, the editors -- Toni Stooss, director of the Kunsthalle Vienna, and Thomas Kellein, director of the Kunsthalle Basel -- have mixed previously published articles by critics and museum curators with new writings and reminiscences by friends, fellow artists and Mr. Paik himself. The results are uneven, though there are memorable surprises, including a sly interview with John Cage, whose music was a major influence on Mr. Paik, and an evocative essay by the feminist writer Kate Millett recalling the near-utopian idealism of the New York art scene in the early 1960's. Other contributors include the architect Arata Isozaki and the poet Allen Ginsberg. This is a provocative book that chronicles not only Mr. Paik's career but also 30 years of changes in the international art world.
ANDREA BARNET

snippet: Dave Itzkoff and Laura Sinagra Music Chronicle notes books Ain't Got No Cigarettes: Memories of Music Legend Roger Miller by Lyle E Style, Here, There and Everywhere: My Life Recording the Music of the Beatles by Geoff Emerick and Howard Massey, T...
lead_paragraph: AIN'T GOT NO CIGARETTES: Memories of Music Legend Roger Miller. By Lyle E. Style. (Great Plains Publications, paper, $19.95.) When you've got a name like Lyle E. Style, your only career options are playing point guard for the Kentucky Colonels circa 1973 or chronicling country music, and readers should be grateful that Style has chosen the latter path. In this collection of Q. and A.'s with dozens of illustrious country artists and fixtures of the Nashville scene, he ostensibly recounts the life of the musician and raconteur Roger Miller, of "King of the Road" and "Dang Me" fame, who died of cancer in 1992. But through a quirk of deliberate or accidental genius, what Style has actually assembled is a living document of country music in its hootin', hollerin' outlaw heyday, when the D.J. Captain Midnight ruled the airwaves, Tootsie's Orchid Lounge was the ultimate hangout and everyone, it seems, was on cocaine -- even the mimes. Along the way, Style learns some unprescribed uses for diet pills, discovers that Miller's King of the Road Hotel may have been owned by the mob and reignites an old feud between Tompall Glaser and Waylon Jennings. As Mel Tillis says, "they're all characters or they wouldn't be in the business."
abstract: Dave Itzkoff and Laura Sinagra Music Chronicle notes books Ain't Got No Cigarettes: Memories of Music Legend Roger Miller by Lyle E Style, Here, There and Everywhere: My Life Recording the Music of the Beatles by Geoff Emerick and Howard Massey, The Dark Side of the Moon: The Making of the Pink Floyd Masterpiece by John Harris, Everything I'm Cracked Up to Be: A Rock & Roll Fairy Tale by Jen Trynin, Queens Reigns Supreme: Fat Cat, 50 Cent, and the Rise of the Hip-Hop Hustler by Ethan Brown, Biggie: Voletta Wallace Remembers Her Son by Voletta Wallace with Tremell McKenzie, Chasin' the Bird: The Life and Legacy of Charlie Parker by Brian Priestly, Staring at Sound: The True Story of Oklahoma's Fabulous Flaming Lips by Jim DeRogatis, I'll Take You There: Pop Music and the Urge for Transcendence by Bill Friskics-Warren, Echo and Reverb: Fabricating Space in Popular Music Recording 1900-1960 by Peter Doyle and Classic American Popular Song: The Second Half-Century, 1950-2000 by David Jenness and Don Velsey; photos (M)

snippet: Tova Reich’s satirical novel criticizes the commercialization of Holocaust remembrance.
lead_paragraph: Whether or not a book can be judged by its cover, that’s sometimes where it begins. The cover of “My Holocaust” resembles a child’s board game, like Chutes and Ladders but with sprigs of barbed wire and playful figurines in striped prisoner’s garb. A cattle car sits near an ice cream truck. Hanging from colorful striped poles are the words “Auschwitz” and “Birkenau.” The concentration camp gate, where the “Arbeit Macht Frei” always went, now says “A Novel.”

snippet: In Alan Lightman’s new novel, a man in crisis feels a presence.
lead_paragraph: After blithely picking off the albatross, the title character in “The Rime of the Ancient Mariner” loses his soul to a nightmarish, dice-throwing figure called Life-in-Death. The seaman’s true life-in-death begins once his fantastically ghastly voyage ends: he’s doomed to repeat himself obsessively, buttonholing unwitting guests at social events and pouring forth his cautionary tale.

keywords: [{'name': 'persons', 'value': 'COFFEY, MARILYN', 'rank': 1, 'major': 'N'}, {'name': 'subject', 'value': 'BOOK REVIEWS', 'rank': 2, 'major': 'N'}, {'name': 'creative_works', 'value': 'GREAT PLAINS PATCHWORK: A MEMOIR (BOOK)', 'rank': 3, 'major': 'N'}]
snippet: Unknown
lead_paragraph: GREAT PLAINS PATCHWORK: A Memoir. By Marilyn Coffey. (Iowa State University, $21.95.) The novelist Marilyn Coffey has put together an entertaining, insightful collection of stories, combining fact and legend, about her beloved central plains between the mid-1880's and the late 1950's. ''Like a speck on the eastern horizon appears a wagon loaded with Coffeys,'' who in 1885 migrated west to the Great Plains from Illinois. There were 10 of them - great-grandfather James, his wife, Mary, their seven sons and a daughter. The Coffey boys were a raucous bunch who liked a good joke, usually physical, and would try anything once - great-uncle Ben even entered a ''bear-wrassling'' contest and won. Stories of the family are integrated with graphic firsthand descriptions by survivors of the natural disasters that periodically struck the Plains - floods, grasshopper infestations, tornadoes, man-made mischief on a grand scale. Ms. Coffey offers insights on what it is to grow up in Middle America. It ''gives one a different perspective on history than the typical Easterner has, an inside-out view.'' As a child, she ''never doubted for an instant'' that she ''was dead center in the middle of everything . . . a world narrowed by dust storms, bread lines, and Al Capone.''
abstract: LEAD:    GREAT PLAINS PATCHWORK: A Memoir. By Marilyn Coffey. (Iowa State University, $21.95.) The novelist Marilyn Coffey has put together an entertaining, insightful collection of stories, combining fact and legend, about her beloved central plains between the mid-1880's and the late 1950's. ''Like a speck on the eastern horizon appears a wagon loaded with Coffeys,'' who in 1885 migrated west to the Great Plains from Illinois.

snippet: Robin Lippincott reviews book The Symbolist Prints of Edvard Munch: The Vivian and David Campbell Collection, with contributory essays by Peter Schjeldahl and others; photo (S)
lead_paragraph: ''Munch is our contemporary, as he will be the contemporary of our children's children, because his subject is life in the present tense, which may pass in and out of intellectual vogue but will not become obsolete.'' So Peter Schjeldahl, art critic for The Village Voice, writes in THE SYMBOLIST PRINTS OF EDVARD MUNCH: The Vivian and David Campbell Collection (Art Gallery of Ontario/Yale University, $50). Certainly the prints reproduced in this revelatory book support Mr. Schjeldahl's claims -- and then some. But as Michael Parke-Taylor, associate curator of European art at the Art Gallery of Ontario in Toronto, writes in an informative essay, despite Munch's lifetime reputation in Norway and Germany (where he is considered one of the greatest European modern artists), a similar level of appreciation and awareness of Munch's work did not reach this country until 1950, when a retrospective exhibit first appeared. Elizabeth Prelinger, chairwoman of the department of art, music and theater at Georgetown University, writes that it was through his prints that Munch (1863-1944) achieved the Symbolist ideal of fusion between the meaning of the image and the technique used to give it form. She also provides valuable background information on his technique. But Mr. Schjeldahl's essay best captures Munch's achievement. Commenting on the timeless appeal of Munch's best-known work, ''The Scream,'' he writes, ''It is a template of creativity that discovers a way to say the unsayable by giving over to an internal logic of saying.'' Robin Lippincott
abstract: Robin Lippincott reviews book The Symbolist Prints of Edvard Munch: The Vivian and David Campbell Collection, with contributory essays by Peter Schjeldahl and others; photo (S)

snippet: Alice McDermott’s new novel, “Someone,” follows an ordinary girl from an Irish-American family through the milestones of her life.
lead_paragraph: One Saturday morning, as the heroine of Alice McDermott’s quietly exquisite new novel is just developing a classic case of preteenage insolence, her mother summons her to the kitchen for a cooking lesson. It’s all in a day’s work, but the girl, Marie, takes it for granted that her mother has already done the family’s laundry and hung it out to dry. This is a book so deft that even the damp shirts and school blouses on the clothesline have some import. Marie sees them “hung upside down by their hems, their arms waving in a way that made me grow dizzy in sympathy.”

lead_paragraph: (Editors' choices of other recent books of particular interest)
abstract: (Editors' choices of other recent books of particular interest)    LOOKING FOR HISTORY: Dispatches From Latin America, by Alma Guillermoprieto. (Pantheon, $25.) Lucid, elegant repertorial essays, uncorrupted by big thinking, revealing how things actually look in such emotional pressure points as Colombia or neo-Zapatista Mexico.    COME UP AND SEE ME SOMETIME, by Erika Krouse. (Scribner, $22.) Short stories populated by intelligent, wisecracking, bruised women, insecure, white and over 30; finding and keeping love is what they want to do but can't, and Krouse's grasp of dark comedy lets her squeeze them beyond the limits we are used to.    THE ARTIST'S WIFE, by Max Phillips. (John Macrae/Holt, $23.) A novel narrated from inside the selfish, mean, witty head of Alma Mahler (1879-1964), who married, successively, Gustav Mahler, Walter Gropius and Franz Werfel, when not playing around with Oskar Kokoschka, and outlived just about all of her contemporaries.    THE CENTER OF THINGS, by Jenny McPhee. (Doubleday, $22.95.) Marie Brown, the heroine of this engaging, amusing first novel, is an aspiring tabloid writer and quondam graduate student in philosophy of science. Now 39, she still hopes for true love, professional advancement and an understanding of physical reality.    UP IN THE AIR, by Walter Kirn. (Doubleday, $23.95.) This novel concerns a 35-year-old career transition counselor -- that is, he fires people -- whose obsession it is to acquire one million frequent flier miles and who cheerfully inhabits an alien universe he calls Airworld.    HONEYMOONERS: A Cautionary Tale, by Chuck Kinder. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $24.) A production by a close friend of Raymond Carver that projects Carver's alcoholism and profligacy, and even some of his well-known short stories, onto a character called Ralph Crawford in a sort of eulogy à clef for a great American writer.    THE FLIGHT OF THE MAIDENS, by Jane Gardam. (Carroll & Graf, $25.) A subtle, clever coming-of-age and generational-conflict novel involving three girls in England and their families (or the missing members of families); set in 1946, it makes excellent use of the dislocations and deprivations caused by World War II.    THE DEATH OF SWEET MISTER, by Daniel Woodrell. (Marian Wood/Putnam, $23.95.) An unattractive 13-year-old boy, Shuggie, is the narrator of this violent, intense novel set in the Ozarks, acute in its rendering of the boy's incestuous jealousy for his mother and his rage at the men who bid for her attention.    A COLD CASE, by Philip Gourevitch. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $22.) A real-life police procedural in which a graduate of Hell's Kitchen who kills two men to settle an argument is run to earth by patient legwork and an appealingly straight-arrow investigator.

snippet: A lost short story by Stephen Crane about a boy of the streets is reimagined.
lead_paragraph: Edmund White, who captured late-20th-century gay New York in his acclaimed autobiographical trilogy, has now written a novel about desire and betrayal in the New York of the late 19th century. The protagonist of “Hotel de Dream” is the American writer Stephen Crane, who at 28 is dying from tuberculosis in the English countryside. Stevie, as friends call him, lies on his deathbed, struggling to dictate a scandalous novella about a boy prostitute whom he met several years earlier. His amanuensis is his wife, Cora, herself the former proprietor of a brothel in Jacksonville named Hotel de Dream. Cora is foolish, vulgar, tender and perceptive by turns, and her ministration to the dying Crane gives White a frame narrative for this vivid and powerful novel.

lead_paragraph: Arresting, even dangerous images loom large in MEAN HIGH TIDE (Delacorte, $21.95), James W. Hall's fifth crime novel set in Florida and the third to feature the reclusive protagonist he calls Thorn. But the sight that really sticks is the spectacle of two alligators mating in a steamy, sloshy swamp -- an apt metaphor for nature's fecundity and an unnerving comment on mankind's puny efforts to tame this primal power.
abstract: Arresting, even dangerous images loom large in MEAN HIGH TIDE (Delacorte, $21.95), James W. Hall's fifth crime novel set in Florida and the third to feature the reclusive protagonist he calls Thorn. But the sight that really sticks is the spectacle of two alligators mating in a steamy, sloshy swamp -- an apt metaphor for nature's fecundity and an unnerving comment on mankind's puny efforts to tame this primal power.   The theme of righteous vengeance also gets a workout in this pounding action thriller when Thorn's beloved companion, Darcy Richards, is murdered in a bizarre underwater attack by a human predator. Vowing to become "hard and cold and merciless" in avenging Darcy, Thorn takes over her private investigation of various fish hatcheries involved in the experimental breeding of a red tilapia. According to one marine biologist, the amazing procreative capacities of this mutant fish could wreck the entire ecosystem.

keywords: [{'name': 'persons', 'value': 'Menand, Louis', 'rank': 1, 'major': 'N'}, {'name': 'persons', 'value': 'Grandin, Temple', 'rank': 2, 'major': 'N'}, {'name': 'persons', 'value': 'Truss, Lynne', 'rank': 3, 'major': 'N'}, {'name': 'subject', 'value': 'Books and Literature', 'rank': 4, 'major': 'N'}]
snippet: GOING NEGATIVE: The books that make the Times hardcover fiction list tend to be, by and large, review-proof. Nothing Michiko Kakutani or Jonathan Yardley can say will keep Michael Crichton or Clive Cussler or Danielle Steel from claiming a place a...
lead_paragraph: GOING NEGATIVE: The books that make the Times hardcover fiction list tend to be, by and large, review-proof. Nothing Michiko Kakutani or Jonathan Yardley can say will keep Michael Crichton or Clive Cussler or Danielle Steel from claiming a place at this 15-seat table. But what about nonfiction? Consider the hardy book at No. 6 this week, the British writer Lynne Truss's "Eats, Shoots & Leaves: The Zero Tolerance Approach to Punctuation." Truss's book has sat on the nonfiction list for 42 weeks, much longer than any other current title. Her book also happens to have withstood one of the most withering reviews in recent memory, Louis Menand's acid account, in The New Yorker, of the book's own grammatical errors. ("Either Truss needed a copy editor or her copy editor needed a copy editor," Menand cracked.) Truss's editor reacted; he called Menand a name that's not printable here. And in the London newspapers, at least one writer rushed patriotically to Truss's defense, describing Menand as humorless and observing that many of his criticisms are matters "of taste and not correctness." American readers, in love with Truss's breezily outraged tone, haven't seemed to care either way. Her new book, "Talk to the Hand," will be published in November. It is about manners. The suspense -- will she put her forks in the right place? -- is almost too much to bear.
abstract: GOING NEGATIVE: The books that make the Times hardcover fiction list tend to be, by and large, review-proof. Nothing Michiko Kakutani or Jonathan Yardley can say will keep Michael Crichton or Clive Cussler or Danielle Steel from claiming a place at this 15-seat table. But what about nonfiction? Consider the hardy book at No. 6 this week, the British writer Lynne Truss's ''Eats, Shoots & Leaves: The Zero Tolerance Approach to Punctuation.'' Truss's book has sat on the nonfiction list for 42 weeks, much longer than any other current title. Her book also happens to have withstood one of the most withering reviews in recent memory, Louis Menand's acid account, in The New Yorker, of the book's own grammatical errors. (''Either Truss needed a copy editor or her copy editor needed a copy editor,'' Menand cracked.) Truss's editor reacted; he called Menand a name that's not printable here. And in the London newspapers, at least one writer rushed patriotically to Truss's defense, describing Menand as humorless and observing that many of his criticisms are matters ''of taste and not correctness.'' American readers, in love with Truss's breezily outraged tone, haven't seemed to care either way. Her new book, ''Talk to the Hand,'' will be published in November. It is about manners. The suspense -- will she put her forks in the right place? -- is almost too much to bear.    GRANDIN'S ADVENTURES: Books about animals, from James Herriot's memoirs through Elizabeth Marshall Thomas's canny meditations on dogs and cats, have long been staples on the hardcover nonfiction list. Few of these books are as idiosyncratic and involving as Temple Grandin's ''Animals in Translation,'' written with Catherine Johnson, which is at No. 7 this week. Grandin, who is autistic, writes that ''autism is a kind of way station on the road from animals to humans, which puts autistic people like me in a perfect position to translate 'animal talk' into English.'' Grandin knows what she is talking about: roughly half the cattle in the United States and Canada are handled in humane slaughter systems she has designed. Her book got a boost from her recent appearance on ''Fresh Air,'' Terry Gross's National Public Radio program. Grandin was asked whether the fact that she has become ''reasonably famous'' has made her uncomfortable. Her typically blunt response: ''I've seen a lot of people in business, you know, get too big a head. . . . I still do plenty of things where, 'Yep, I got to go out on a job and we got to stay in a really, really junky motel.' And that's just fine because that just keeps my head where it should be.''   Dwight Garner

snippet: Louis Auchincloss has modeled his latest novel on the 1918 American classic "The Education of Henry Adams," whose author a friend once called "the only man  in the world who could sit on a fence and watch himself go by." Writing in 1975  at the ag...
lead_paragraph: Louis Auchincloss has modeled his latest novel on the 1918 American classic "The Education of Henry Adams," whose author a friend once called "the only man in the world who could sit on a fence and watch himself go by." Writing in 1975 at the age of 80, the narrator of THE EDUCATION OF OSCAR FAIRFAX (Houghton Mifflin, $22.95) describes his own coming of age with the same ironic detachment. With one grandfather the Episcopal Bishop of New York and the other the founder of an eminent Wall Street law firm, Oscar receives an education that is less sentimental than perfectly decorous, its lessons encouraging Social Register virtues: tact, compromise, genteel humility, excellent manners. After Yale and Columbia Law School, he abandons his dreams of a literary career to join the family legal practice, following his father's advice that it provides the best arena for his "constant preoccupation," people watching. ("He said it didn't matter in which I took the greater interest: the clients or the law.") And there are plenty of opportunities for social observation: a Supreme Court Justice whose opinions on torts and contracts "read like short stories by Henry James"; a gossipy Hungarian princess who hobnobbed with Proust; a talented bounder who wins a partnership in the Fairfax law firm, marriage to Oscar's sister and national prominence in World War II. There is even a cameo appearance by Edith Wharton, Mr. Auchincloss's literary progenitor, showing off the roses in her garden in France. More a series of vignettes than a novel, the book has a few weak spots: the dialogue can be too starched and frilly, and a Spanish daughter-in-law seems to exist only so that Oscar can deliver opinions on Franco. Yet Mr. Auchincloss's own voice remains a seductive one -- crisp, stately and wonderfully controlled. Donna Rifkind
abstract: Louis Auchincloss has modeled his latest novel on the 1918 American classic "The Education of Henry Adams," whose author a friend once called "the only man  in the world who could sit on a fence and watch himself go by." Writing in 1975  at the age of 80, the narrator of THE EDUCATION OF OSCAR FAIRFAX (Houghton Mifflin, $22.95) describes his own coming of age with the same ironic detachment. With one grandfather the Episcopal Bishop of New York and the other the founder of an eminent Wall Street law firm, Oscar receives an education that is less sentimental than perfectly decorous, its lessons encouraging Social Register virtues: tact, compromise, genteel humility, excellent manners. After Yale and Columbia Law School, he abandons his dreams of a literary career to join the family legal practice, following his father's advice that it provides the best arena for his "constant preoccupation," people  watching. ("He said it didn't matter in which I took the greater interest: the clients or the law.") And there are plenty of opportunities for social observation: a Supreme Court Justice whose opinions on torts and contracts "read like short stories by Henry James"; a gossipy Hungarian princess who hobnobbed with Proust; a talented bounder who wins a partnership in the Fairfax law firm,  marriage to Oscar's sister and national prominence in World War II. There is even a cameo appearance by Edith Wharton, Mr. Auchincloss's literary progenitor, showing off the roses in her garden in France. More a series of vignettes than a novel, the book has a few weak spots: the dialogue can be too starched and frilly, and a Spanish daughter-in-law seems to exist only so that Oscar can deliver opinions on Franco. Yet Mr. Auchincloss's own voice remains a seductive  one -- crisp, stately and wonderfully controlled.   Donna Rifkind

lead_paragraph: WHAT price travel writing? One might have asked such a question in 1987, when for the first time there were more people going in and out of London's airports -- a staggering 57 million -- than actually lived in the whole of Britain. But then, just as travel was clearly becoming a commonplace and the world was running out of new areas to explore, suddenly, unpredictably, the Soviet Union broke up, its ebb tide leaving vast tracts exposed. From Estonia to Mongolia, it was potentially a traveler's bonanza. Ancient cities like Samarkand, Bukhara and Tashkent, free of the bureaucratic quagmire of Homo sovieticus, winked invitingly at adventurous beachcombers.
abstract: WHAT price travel writing? One might have asked such a question in 1987, when for the first time there were more people going in and out of London's airports -- a staggering 57 million -- than actually lived in the whole of Britain. But then, just as travel was clearly becoming a commonplace and the world was running out of new areas to explore, suddenly, unpredictably, the Soviet Union broke up, its ebb tide leaving vast tracts exposed. From Estonia to Mongolia, it was potentially a traveler's bonanza. Ancient cities like Samarkand, Bukhara and Tashkent, free of the bureaucratic quagmire of Homo sovieticus, winked invitingly at adventurous beachcombers.   Appealingly, this would not turn out to be a one-way traffic. For once, the travel writer, sometimes criticized for being a selfish loner evading domestic responsibilities and plundering poorer countries for the glory of his own ego, could be making a real contribution to the country he was in. These new republics needed stories; their people, in the urgent task of finding new identities, needed reacquainting with both old and recent myths. Because of the often dire economics of these places, and their citizens' lack of experience and research tools, it would be foreigners who would start the process -- as well as communicate what they found to the wider world, in the true tradition of Marco Polo.

snippet: THE CONFESSIONS OF MAX TIVOLI, by Andrew Sean Greer. (Picador, $14.) Max Tivoli's misfortune in this novel is to be born in 1871, in San Francisco, with the appearance of a 70-year-old man, and regress through life to physiological infancy. This c...
lead_paragraph: THE CONFESSIONS OF MAX TIVOLI, by Andrew Sean Greer. (Picador, $14.) Max Tivoli's misfortune in this novel is to be born in 1871, in San Francisco, with the appearance of a 70-year-old man, and regress through life to physiological infancy. This curse -- he is born an innocent child in an old man's body and dies a wise man in a child's body -- has one advantage: living in disguise, Max pursues his true love, Alice, three times over the course of his life. As Greer explores his hero's life, "Max's sense of melancholy can be keenly affecting," Gary Krist wrote here.
abstract: THE CONFESSIONS OF MAX TIVOLI, by Andrew Sean Greer. (Picador, $14.) Max Tivoli's misfortune in this novel is to be born in 1871, in San Francisco, with the appearance of a 70-year-old man, and regress through life to physiological infancy. This curse -- he is born an innocent child in an old man's body and dies a wise man in a child's body -- has one advantage: living in disguise, Max pursues his true love, Alice, three times over the course of his life. As Greer explores his hero's life, ''Max's sense of melancholy can be keenly affecting,'' Gary Krist wrote here.    BLACK EARTH: A Journey Through Russia After the Fall, by Andrew Meier. (Norton, $15.95.) Meier, a Moscow correspondent for Time magazine from 1996 to 2001, recounts his travels across post-Soviet Russia. Visiting the ''distant corners of the old empire'' -- from the Chechnya war zone in the south to the polluted industrial city of Norilsk above the Arctic Circle -- Meier paints an unsettling picture of contemporary life in Russia.

snippet: The restaurateur Danny Meyer offers businesses advice on hospitality.
lead_paragraph: Four decades ago in The New Yorker, Joseph Wechsberg profiled Henri Soulé, the impeccable host and owner of two of the last century’s great society restaurants, Le Pavillon and La Côte Basque. A soft-spoken authoritarian, Soulé could deploy generosity like a weapon. When he waived the bill of one fuming customer, Wechsberg wrote, “the unexpected display of noblesse oblige so upset the angry customer that he insisted on paying the bill. He was permitted to do so, but it is doubtful that he will get a desirable table in the future.”

keywords: [{'name': 'persons', 'value': 'Correa, Raul', 'rank': 1, 'major': 'N'}, {'name': 'subject', 'value': 'Reviews', 'rank': 2, 'major': 'N'}, {'name': 'subject', 'value': 'Books and Literature', 'rank': 3, 'major': 'N'}, {'name': 'creative_works', 'value': "I DON'T KNOW BUT I'VE BEEN TOLD (BOOK)", 'rank': 4, 'major': 'N'}]
snippet: Ihsan Taylor reviews book I Don't Know But I've Been Told by Raul Correa; drawing (S)
lead_paragraph: Parachuting into Panama with the Army's 82nd Airborne Division, the unnamed narrator of Raul Correa's darkly comic first novel, I DON'T KNOW BUT I'VE BEEN TOLD (HarperCollins, $24.95), tells us: ''It was like falling through a painting that you see real and in person. It's too good, too much like everything should be.'' Or maybe it was just the mescaline he and his squad had ingested. These kinds of observations litter Correa's coming-of-age story of a military misfit who enlists for lack of a better choice. Stationed at Fort Bragg, the young paratrooper finds camaraderie among a pack of underachieving ''doper scouts'' and their maverick Platoon Daddy, who keeps a casual eye on his unruly unit. It's 1980 and the book zeroes in on the minutiae of military life in peacetime: reconnaissance exercises, cultivating cool nicknames, meeting women in foreign countries. Correa sandwiches this inside a plot about a loosely sketched, ill-fated scheme to steal arms for a man known only as Mr. Big. The plot unfolds in sporadic flashbacks over the course of one miserable night in New York City 20 years later. His Airborne days behind him, the narrator is again a wounded loner, exploring the city's underbelly in his free time. His only comforts are a copy of ''Huckleberry Finn'' and a letter from Paola, a Panamanian prostitute. The narrator's story feels aimless, and he admits as much: ''My Army stories that surround my Paola story are mostly just about walking around places in the world with a weapon.'' Correa served as a sergeant in the 82nd Airborne, and the glimpses of the languorous side of military life are frank and funny. Some of the dialogue has just the right pitch, balancing innocence and savvy. For Correa's narrator, reminiscing is meant to be cathartic, but the story's stream-of-consciousness style occasionally feels as if it's in a free fall of its own. Ihsan Taylor
abstract: Ihsan Taylor reviews book I Don't Know But I've Been Told by Raul Correa; drawing (S)

lead_paragraph: EARTH FROM ABOVE: For Young Readers. By Robert Burleigh. Concept and photographs by Yann Arthus-Bertrand. Abrams. $12.95. (Ages 8 and up) Here are aerial photographs, taken from helicopter height, of such earthly wonders as a camel caravan, terraced rice fields, a hot spring in Yellowstone Park, pink flamingos in flight; each picture is accompanied by helpful commentary.
abstract: EARTH FROM ABOVE: For Young Readers. By Robert Burleigh. Concept and photographs by Yann Arthus-Bertrand. Abrams. $12.95. (Ages 8 and up) Here are aerial photographs, taken from helicopter height, of such earthly wonders as a camel caravan, terraced rice fields, a hot spring in Yellowstone Park, pink flamingos in flight; each picture is accompanied by helpful commentary.    WHAT WOULD JOEY DO? By Jack Gantos. Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $16. (Ages 10 and up) Joey Pigza, that hyperactive cutup from two earlier novels, is on meds, and now his mom has him schooled at home. He's probably the most thoughtful, grown-up person in his family. His dad is back in town and his folks, though long divorced, are still battling, breaking furniture and throwing things. The lighthearted, sympathetic tone keeps it both plausible and affecting.    GOSSIE. Written and illustrated by Olivier Dunrea. Houghton Mifflin. $9.95. (Ages 2 to 5) Gossie is a yellow gosling who has a thing about her red boots. She wears them everywhere and all the time till she loses them. Then she meets Gertie, an even smaller gosling. Enchanting. Their adventures continue in a companion book, ''Gossie & Gertie.''    A LIBRARY FOR JUANA: The World of Sor Juana Inés. By Pat Mora. Illustrated by Beatriz Vidal. Knopf. $15.95. (Ages 5 to 8) Sor Juana Inés de la Cruz (1648-95), a child prodigy and intellectual protégée of the Spanish viceroy in Mexico in the 17th century, built a substantial library in the convent where she spent much of her adult life. She is sometimes called the Mexican Muse or the Phoenix of Mexico, and her image is on Mexican currency. This is an episodic picture biography.    ALPHABET UNDER CONSTRUCTION. Written and illustrated by Denise Fleming. Holt. $16.95. (Ages 2 to 5) The same mouse who appeared in ''Lunch'' is having another constructive adventure building an alphabet with tools: airbrushing the A, folding the F, gluing the G, leveling the L, vacuuming the V. The distinctive, intensely bright illustrations are made from colored rag pulp.    AS THE CITY SLEEPS. Written and illustrated by Stephen T. Johnson. Viking. $16.99. (All ages) The author and illustrator of ''Alphabet City'' and ''City by Numbers,'' two hauntingly beautiful, hyperrealistic depictions of New York City, returns with a strange nighttime fantasy of what might or might not be happening in the dark streets.    HEIR APPARENT. By Vivian Vande Velde. Harcourt. $17. (Ages 8 to 12) A stylish tale addresses both fantasy gaming and censorship. In Giannine's real life there are protests against role-playing games, but in ''Heir Apparent'' she time-trips to a life long ago and far away.

snippet: Ethel Merman’s professional successes and personal disappointments.
lead_paragraph: Couldn’t dance. Couldn’t, for all practical purposes, act. Couldn’t sing with the kind of nuance we expect of singers today. Was only moderately good-looking early, and later became a bit of a fright. No wonder it takes two biographies to try to put across why Ethel Merman was one of the biggest and most enduring stars Broadway has ever known.

keywords: [{'name': 'persons', 'value': 'Presley, Elvis', 'rank': 1, 'major': 'N'}, {'name': 'subject', 'value': 'Reviews', 'rank': 2, 'major': 'N'}, {'name': 'subject', 'value': 'Books and Literature', 'rank': 3, 'major': 'N'}, {'name': 'subject', 'value': 'Biographical Information', 'rank': 4, 'major': 'N'}, {'name': 'creative_works', 'value': 'ELVIS PRESLEY 1956 (BOOK)', 'rank': 5, 'major': 'N'}]
snippet: Eric P Nash reviews Elvis Presley 1956, compilation of previously unpublished black-and-white photographs of Elvis Presley; photos (S)1
lead_paragraph: Two months after Elvis Presley released his first album in March 1956, a photographer for Seventeen magazine named Marvin Israel caught him on tour at the University of Dayton. ELVIS PRESLEY 1956 (Abrams, $17.95), a gritty compilation of dozens of previously unpublished black-and-white photos, was the result. Seventeen probably passed because the photos of the rising teen idol were too raw: the black-rimmed, raccoon-like eyes, the pitted skin and the electric current that seemed to ripple through Presley's spine. We also see his natural charm: a picture of a smiling Elvis, en pointe, knees splayed, cradling his leather-embossed guitar; a gauzy picture of his Pharaonic features that makes him look like a god from ancient Memphis. Portraits of the fans capture an era: girls in their Junior League best with polka-dot bows, and their gape-mouthed, sullen dates; a leather-jacketed Natalie Wood look-alike scowls in front of a 30-foot-tall cutout of Presley at the premiere of ''Love Me Tender,'' his first film, at the Paramount in Times Square. Israel, who went on to become one of the most influential photo editors of the 1960's, commissioning work by Diane Arbus, Robert Frank and Lee Friedlander, had an intimate access to Presley before he became a superstar that comes across in the photos. The text is perfunctory (''in 1956 Elvis was a rocket'') and identifying captions would help, but the images speak for themselves. Eric P. Nash
abstract: Eric P Nash reviews Elvis Presley 1956, compilation of previously unpublished black-and-white photographs of Elvis Presley; photos (S)1

snippet: VERONICA, by Mary Gaitskill. (Vintage Contemporaries, $13.95.) A National Book Award finalist, this mesmerizingly dark novel ponders the relationship between beauty and cruelty. Alison, a former Paris model, is haunted by her friendship with Veron...
lead_paragraph: VERONICA, by Mary Gaitskill. (Vintage Contemporaries, $13.95.) A National Book Award finalist, this mesmerizingly dark novel ponders the relationship between beauty and cruelty. Alison, a former Paris model, is haunted by her friendship with Veronica, an eccentric older woman who died of AIDS. (Alison herself has hepatitis C and cleans offices in California.) Moving between past and present, Gaitskill conjures a series of devastating images: Alison as a young runaway in 1970's San Francisco; her debasement by a relentlessly glamorous fashion world; and her exploration of Manhattan's downtown arts scene in the 1980's. The Book Review named "Veronica" one of the best books of 2005; our reviewer, Meghan O'Rourke, called it "a masterly examination of the relationship between surface and self, culture and fashion, time and memory."

keywords: [{'name': 'glocations', 'value': 'South Africa', 'rank': 1, 'major': 'N'}, {'name': 'subject', 'value': 'Books and Literature', 'rank': 2, 'major': 'N'}, {'name': 'persons', 'value': 'Gordimer, Nadine', 'rank': 3, 'major': 'N'}]
snippet: Nadine Gordimer’s new stories revisit the themes of longing, love and loss.
lead_paragraph: Even at her peak as a political writer, when she has explored the moral distortions of apartheid, Nadine Gordimer has shown a remarkable ability to delve into the more intimate arena of human relationships. In novels like “The Conservationist,” “Burger’s Daughter” and “July’s People,” she has been concerned with depicting the erosion of a society’s values as well as the explosive acts of violence that characterize an unjust political system  but she has always done so by placing an individual, a relationship or a family at the center of her narrative. It is, however, in her short stories, especially those that lack an overtly political theme, that Gordimer has brought the most intensity and imagination to the roles played by wives, husbands, parents, children and lovers, distilling them to an immediately recognizable essence of longing and heartbreak.

lead_paragraph: THE UNREDEEMED CAPTIVE: A Family Story From Early America By John Demos. Vintage, $13. Eunice Williams was only 7 years old in 1704, when her family was captured in an Indian raid on Deerfield, Mass. Her father and siblings were ransomed; Eunice was adopted by Roman Catholic Iroquois. When later given the opportunity to return to her home, she refused. This is "a highly readable and appealing account" of her fate, Linda K. Kerber said here last year.

snippet: I'M DIRTY! By Kate and Jim McMullan. Joanna Cotler/HarperCollins. $16.99. (Ages 4 to 8) A cheery sequel to ''I Stink!,'' in which the authors trade in a garbage truck for a backhoe loader. ''I just love my work!'' says the machine as it inventorie...
lead_paragraph: I'M DIRTY! By Kate and Jim McMullan. Joanna Cotler/HarperCollins. $16.99. (Ages 4 to 8) A cheery sequel to "I Stink!," in which the authors trade in a garbage truck for a backhoe loader. "I just love my work!" says the machine as it inventories all the cool stuff it gets to do all day. The fun includes a countdown of trash piles -- "10 torn-up truck tires, 9 fractured fans," including three "no dumping" signs, gleefully tossed out with the rest. Nothing groundbreaking here, but readers who love large noisy vehicles will have a blast.

snippet: In his brief introduction to SNAPSHOT POETICS: A Photographic Memoir of the Beat Era (Chronicle, paper, $12.95), a collection of nearly 100 black-and-white photographs by the poet Allen Ginsberg, the German writer Michael Kohler characterizes thes...
lead_paragraph: In his brief introduction to SNAPSHOT POETICS: A Photographic Memoir of the Beat Era (Chronicle, paper, $12.95), a collection of nearly 100 black-and-white photographs by the poet Allen Ginsberg, the German writer Michael Kohler characterizes these pictures as "intimate snapshots with the quality of Joycean epiphanies, preserving those instants that express something of the sublimity or sanctity of our experience." Mr. Kohler's claim is not hyperbole; sublimely recorded here is a group, the Beats, and a time, the 1950's. Mr. Ginsberg was not then, in his words, "a big picture taker": he produced only 30 rolls of film between 1953 and 1963. Explaining why he took the pictures at all, Mr. Ginsberg writes that he simply "had a sacramental sense of these friends." Encouraged and taught by such renowned photographers as Robert Frank and Berenice Abbott, Mr. Ginsberg developed into a gifted pictorial chronicler. Among the most appealing of these photographs (each accompanied by a caption handwritten by the photographer) is the "heroic portrait" of Jack Kerouac smoking a cigarette on a fire escape in New York City. Another shot shows Neal Cassady and Natalie Jackson embracing beneath a movie marquee advertising Marlon Brando in "The Wild One." The book also features the now-famous photograph of Lawrence Ferlinghetti and his dog, Whitman, in San Francisco's City Lights Bookstore; portraits of such usual suspects as William Burroughs and Gregory Corso; and several fine, unflinching self-portraits. Snappily designed, "Snapshot Poetics" is an evocative riff on a specific slice of time in American literary history.ROBIN LIPPINCOTT
abstract:

Mr. Kohler's claim is not hyperbole; sublimely recorded here is a group, the Beats, and a time, the 1950's. Mr. Ginsberg was not then, in his words, "a big picture taker": he produced only 30 rolls of film between 1953 and 1963. Explaining why he took the pictures at all, Mr. Ginsberg writes that he simply "had a sacramental sense of these friends." Encouraged and taught by such renowned photographers as Robert Frank and Berenice Abbott, Mr. Ginsberg developed into a gifted pictorial chronicler. Among the most appealing of these photographs (each accompanied by a caption handwritten by the photographer) is the "heroic portrait" of Jack Kerouac smoking a cigarette on a fire escape in New York City. Another shot shows Neal Cassady and Natalie Jackson embracing beneath a movie marquee advertising Marlon Brando in "The Wild One." The book also features the now-famous photograph of Lawrence Ferlinghetti and his dog, Whitman, in San Francisco's City Lights Bookstore; portraits of such usual suspects as William Burroughs and Gregory Corso; and several fine, unflinching self-portraits. Snappily designed, "Snapshot Poetics" is an evocative riff on a specific slice of time in American literary history.

snippet: Book Review editors introduce David Kamp review of Norah Vincent Book Self-Made Man: One Woman's Journey Into Manhood and Back Again (S)
lead_paragraph: David Kamp, the author of this week's cover review, began his journalism career in New York in the late 1980's, when he was a writer and editor for Spy magazine, the satirical monthly. He went on to become an editor at GQ, and for the last 10 years he has been a full-time writer at Vanity Fair and GQ. Along the way he's been co-author of two slim, smart and funny handbooks, "The Rock Snob's Dictionary" and "The Film Snob's Dictionary" (to be published next month), and his book about the American food revolution, "The United States of Arugula," will be released in the fall. He's contributed to the Book Review since 2001.
abstract: Book Review editors introduce David Kamp review of Norah Vincent Book Self-Made Man: One Woman's Journey Into Manhood and Back Again (S)
