snippet: RANDOM FAMILY: Love, Drugs, Trouble, and Coming of Age in the Bronx, by Adrian Nicole LeBlanc. (Scribner, $14.) To create this intimate yet nonjudgmental portrait, the author spent 10 years with an impoverished, loosely connected family in the Bro...
lead_paragraph: RANDOM FAMILY: Love, Drugs, Trouble, and Coming of Age in the Bronx, by Adrian Nicole LeBlanc. (Scribner, $14.) To create this intimate yet nonjudgmental portrait, the author spent 10 years with an impoverished, loosely connected family in the Bronx. Her tale centers on two Puerto Rican girls: one has three children before hooking up with a heroin dealer and winding up in prison; the other has two children by the first girl's half-brother and three more by other men but manages to persevere. LeBlanc's ''extraordinary'' work, chosen by the editors of the Book Review as one of the best books of 2003, is ''a painstaking feat of reporting and of empathy,'' Margaret Talbot wrote here.
abstract: RANDOM FAMILY: Love, Drugs, Trouble, and Coming of Age in the Bronx, by Adrian Nicole LeBlanc. (Scribner, $14.) To create this intimate yet nonjudgmental portrait, the author spent 10 years with an impoverished, loosely connected family in the Bronx. Her tale centers on two Puerto Rican girls: one has three children before hooking up with a heroin dealer and winding up in prison; the other has two children by the first girl's half-brother and three more by other men but manages to persevere. LeBlanc's ''extraordinary'' work, chosen by the editors of the Book Review as one of the best books of 2003, is ''a painstaking feat of reporting and of empathy,'' Margaret Talbot wrote here.    GOODNIGHT, NOBODY, by Michael Knight. (Grove, $12.) Veering between Southern Gothicism and snarky postmodernism, these nine stories focus on people like an academic who is tormented by his children after throwing out his back while vacuuming, and an ornithologist who falls in love with a driftwood whittler after trailing a flock of displaced African parrots to Alabama. ''Knight has that rare power . . . to make a setting breathe, to invest it with a vitality that seems as authentic and intense as the pulsebeats of his characters,'' Jonathan Miles said here last year.    READING LOLITA IN TEHRAN: A Memoir in Books, by Azar Nafisi. (Random House, $13.95.) Recalling her life in Iran from the late 1970's to the late 90's, a teacher tells of a group of Iranian women students who gathered weekly to talk freely about Western literature and their own daily hardships. In the process, she provides a ''visceral and often harrowing portrait of the Islamic revolution in that country'' and ''an eloquent brief on the transformative powers of fiction,'' Michiko Kakutani wrote in The Times last year.    EMMA'S WAR, by Deborah Scroggins. (Vintage, $15.) This account of the Sudanese civil war is built around the short life of an adventurous, recklessly brave British aid worker whose affair with a rebel commander undermines her mission and alienates her from most of her expatriate friends. ''Scroggins brings Sudan's agony to vivid life; at the same time, she gives us a lyrical, suspenseful, psychologically acute study in idealism and self-delusion,'' George Packer wrote here in 2002.    THE SPIDER'S HOUSE, by Paul Bowles. (Ecco/HarperCollins, $14.95.) Less brooding and soul-searching than ''The Sheltering Sky,'' this 1955 novel explores the conflict between the French and the Arabs in Morocco by focusing on the intertwined lives of an American novelist and a 15-year-old Arab boy. Our reviewer, Charles J. Rolo, found the plot meandering and a bit fuzzy, but said the story ''reads for stretches like a first-class political thriller.''    THE MASTER BUTCHERS SINGING CLUB, by Louise Erdrich. (Perennial/HarperCollins, $13.95.) Though Erdrich's eighth novel is set on her home turf in the fictional town of Argus, N.D., this time she shifts her focus from the town's Indian population toward its mainly German, Polish and Scandinavian residents. The tale spins out from the experiences of a German World War I sniper who marries his best friend's pregnant widow and moves to America, where he sets up as a master butcher and eventually becomes entangled with the daughter of the town drunk. The book is flawed, Brooke Allen wrote here in 2003, but Erdrich manages ''to bring a little-known part of the country redolently to life.''    OF MOTHS AND MEN: An Evolutionary Tale. The Untold Story of Science and the Peppered Moth, by Judith Hooper. (Norton, $15.95.) The author examines how the most famous example of natural selection in action -- the population explosion of dark moths in England's grimy industrial areas -- became the most infamous. It turns out the researcher who ''proved'' Darwin right may have seen only what he wanted to see. The result is a ''moving and compassionate portrait'' of scientists undone by myopia and cold ambition, Paul Raeburn wrote here in 2002.    THE SPINNING MAN, by George Harrar. (BlueHen, $14.) A mild-mannered philosophy professor finds his comfy world turned upside down when he's arrested in connection with the disappearance of a 16-year-old cheerleader. As the evidence mounts, even his family has doubts. Last year in these pages, Marilyn Stasio called this an ''elegant and unnerving mystery.''   Scott Veale

snippet: A biography follows David Mamet beyond his fierce early works.
lead_paragraph: The apotheosis of David Mamet comes near the start of the movie version of “Glengarry Glen Ross.” Alec Baldwin  hair slicked back, pocket square peaking just so  unleashes a furious, seven-minute tirade against some underperforming real estate salesmen. “First prize is a Cadillac Eldorado,” he says of a sadistic new contest to increase business. “Second prize is a set of steak knives. ... Third prize is you’re fired.” After insulting his listeners’ manhood, competence and just about every other attribute that can be impugned with a well-aimed profanity, Baldwin caps the presentation by extracting from his briefcase and brandishing a pair of huge brass balls.

lead_paragraph: Reading James Lee Burke is like riding a runaway locomotive -- a big rush, until you crash and burn.
abstract: Reading James Lee Burke is like riding a runaway locomotive -- a big rush, until you crash and burn.   DIXIE CITY JAM (Hyperion, $22.95), the seventh adventure for a hang-tough Cajun cop named Dave Robicheaux, is one of this unruly writer's wilder rides. The demented plot opens with Dave's eerie underwater encounter with a U-boat that sank off Louisiana during World War II. With a Nazi submarine in the water, can "speed-fried Nazi zomboids" be far behind in the narrative?

snippet: In his latest book, John McCain reflects on the virtues that make a true leader.
lead_paragraph: John McCain’s political fortunes may be uncertain, but his literary ones are not. In the past few years, he has been on something of a tear, producing works like “Worth the Fighting For,” “Why Courage Matters” and “Character Is Destiny.” As these virile titles suggest, McCain, like Winston Churchill in his collection of essays “Great Contemporaries” and John F. Kennedy in “Profiles in Courage,” is a champion of the Great Man school of history. And like them, he is a war hero and politician intent on climbing the greasy pole.

snippet: Unknown
lead_paragraph: For years now food writers have been carrying on about how wonderful American produce can be. They rhapsodize about the proliferation of farmers' markets and the new sophistication among people who have the capacity to grow their own at home. The truth is that except for a few precious months and a few golden places, the mouth of the national cornucopia is mostly closed. But now, at last, after an unspeakable winter and a stunted spring, the good times are finally nigh and all that enthusiasm about the freshest and best ingredients is, for a while at least, not just a lot of hot air.
abstract: For years now food writers have been carrying on about how wonderful American produce can be. They rhapsodize about the proliferation of farmers' markets and  the new sophistication among people who have the capacity to grow their own at home. The truth is that except for a few precious months and a few golden places, the mouth of the national cornucopia is mostly closed. But now, at last, after an unspeakable winter and a stunted spring, the good times are finally nigh and all that enthusiasm about the freshest and best ingredients is, for a while at least, not just a lot of hot air.         In the wave of new cookbooks arriving to celebrate the growing season, a standout is one by Alice Waters of Chez Panisse in Berkeley, Calif., the now-legendary restaurant in the forefront of the evolution of American cuisine,  where the signature of the cooking is the freshness and quality of ingredients.  With typical ardor, Ms. Waters's CHEZ PANISSE VEGETABLES (HarperCollins, $32.50) urges you to select vegetables so fresh they "look right back at you!" Ms. Waters's accessible recipes -- whether for a vegetable-rich pasta, soup, tart or corn-bread stuffing -- are almost always brief and often inspired. The mustard greens sauteed with garlic and rolled in prosciutto are, as you might imagine, almost effortless in preparation and yet, in the final analysis, quite complex.  And there is a crunchy, rewarding freshness to her warm cabbage, onion and apple slaw. I also admired her fennel and artichoke salad accented with a bit of truffle oil and Parmesan. The book is organized alphabetically, according to vegetable, and the discussions aren't the blather we too often get, but are actually helpful. On chard, one of the underappreciated greens prevalent across  America, she tells her readers that small leaves are not necessarily more tender than the larger ones and she describes her technique to separate leaf from stem (necessary because the two cook at different rates) by folding the leaf in  half along the stem and then pulling the leaf away.

keywords: [{'name': 'persons', 'value': 'Cosse, Laurence', 'rank': 1, 'major': 'N'}, {'name': 'subject', 'value': 'Reviews', 'rank': 2, 'major': 'N'}, {'name': 'subject', 'value': 'Books and Literature', 'rank': 3, 'major': 'N'}, {'name': 'creative_works', 'value': 'CORNER OF THE VEIL, A (BOOK)', 'rank': 4, 'major': 'N'}]
snippet: Erik Burns reviews book A Corner of the Veil by Laurence Cosse; drawing (M)
lead_paragraph: Laurence Cosse's witty and casually profound new novel, A CORNER OF THE VEIL (Scribner, $23), is about what happens when a hastily scrawled six-page manuscript lands in the mailbox of a French priest named Bertrand Beaulieu. No ordinary letter, this manuscript contains miraculous, irrefutable proof of the existence of God. Those who read it are instantly transformed, and there is hope that the good news will ''lift both human consciousness and human liberty to their highest level.'' Cosse's novel, deftly translated from the French by Linda Asher, takes us on a tumultuous ride through the Machiavellian worlds of modern French theology and political maneuvering. Cosse skillfully reduces the drama to its bare bones; she brings together a group of French Government ministers to represent the various fields of human power and shows us how they react to this startling document. The Finance Minister fears people will have no reason to work and the economy will collapse; the Justice Minister frets about how the absence of evil will affect the legal system; the Foreign Minister foresees international upheaval as other religions denounce Christian fanaticism and the denial of their own theologies. The Prime Minister, who has read the letter, is more interested in roses and his much-neglected wife, certain ''a world of harmony is about to come into being.'' While the politicians haggle, Beaulieu and his fellow priests try to decide how to handle the document, how best to spread the message while at the same time keeping it under wraps until the perfect moment. That the conflict is resolved by a deus ex machina is only fitting; the irony of a greater -- but not the greatest -- agent's intervention is a spectacular capstone for this fin de si cle romp in the fields of the Lord. Erik Burns
abstract: Erik Burns reviews book A Corner of the Veil by Laurence Cosse; drawing (M)

keywords: [{'name': 'persons', 'value': 'MORRISON, PERRY', 'rank': 1, 'major': 'N'}, {'name': 'persons', 'value': 'FORESTER, TOM', 'rank': 2, 'major': 'N'}, {'name': 'subject', 'value': 'BOOK REVIEWS', 'rank': 3, 'major': 'N'}, {'name': 'creative_works', 'value': 'COMPUTER ETHICS (BOOK)', 'rank': 4, 'major': 'N'}]
snippet: Unknown
lead_paragraph: COMPUTER ETHICS: Cautionary Tales and Ethical Dilemmas in Computing. By Tom Forester and Perry Morrison. (MIT, $19.95.) Because computers have made their way into nearly every corner of our lives, the professionals who design computers may unwittingly possess as much control over our future as elected officials. Yet students preparing for careers in computer and software development often receive little - or no - instruction in the ethical problems they will create. Two Australians, Tom Forester, who teaches at the School of Computing and Information Technology at Griffith University in Queensland, and Perry Morrison, a lecturer in computing at the University of New England in New South Wales, offer a provocative look into the moral issues surrounding the world's most powerful machines. ''We argue,'' they write in ''Computer Ethics,'' ''that computer systems by their very nature are insecure, unreliable and unpredictable - and that society has yet to come to terms with the consequences.'' Computer crime could cost each of the top 300 companies in the United States $2 million to $10 million a year, they write, but only 35 percent of I.B.M. mainframes used security software by late 1988. London's computerized air traffic control system failed six times in 12 months. Perhaps even more frightening is the 10-year delay in warnings about ozone depletion; software employed by the National Aeronautics and Space Administration called satellite ozone measurements spurious because they were so low. Mr. Forester and Mr. Morrison have chapters on computer crime, software theft, computer hacking and viruses, computer unreliability, invasion of privacy, artificial intelligence and computers in the work place. While their prose occasionally wanders toward flat assertion, the authors' stated goal is to provoke debate in an area too often dominated by dehumanized logic.
abstract: LEAD:    COMPUTER ETHICS: Cautionary Tales and Ethical Dilemmas in Computing. By Tom Forester and Perry Morrison. (MIT, $19.95.) Because computers have made their way into nearly every corner of our lives, the professionals who design computers may unwittingly possess as much control over our future as elected officials.

snippet: Unknown
lead_paragraph: THE SEASONS OF A WOMAN'S LIFE By Daniel J. Levinson in collaboration with Judy D. Levinson. 438 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $27.50. BOOKS on adult development have attained great popularity during the past two decades because they offer precisely the same kind of reassurance as child development manuals: If my child is throwing temper tantrums, she's just going through the Terrible 2's. . . . If I'm awakened by a nightmare about my own death, I must be entering the Fearful 50's. . . . It's just a stage.
abstract: THE SEASONS OF A WOMAN'S LIFE By Daniel J. Levinson in collaboration with Judy D. Levinson. 438 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $27.50. keywords: [{'name': 'subject', 'value': 'Books and Literature', 'rank': 1, 'major': 'N'}, {'name': 'glocations', 'value': 'Corsica', 'rank': 2, 'major': 'N'}, {'name': 'subject', 'value': 'Draft and Recruitment (Military)', 'rank': 3, 'major': 'N'}]
snippet: A memoir recounts the author’s time as a draft dodger among various fugitives at a romantic Corsican inn.
lead_paragraph: “Corsica is not — how shall I say it — is not well known for its allegiance to the laws of the continent,” the owner of a seaside Corsican auberge tells a young American without working papers, proposing to let him do odd jobs in exchange for room and board and “a little something at the end of the season.” This is precisely what John Hanson Mitchell, trying to deflect the insistent letters from his draft board, is eager to hear. But he’s not alone. Just about everyone in his memoir of the Rose Café in the summer of 1962 is a fugitive of some sort: political refugees, con men, Gypsies, aged members of the underground with “long-distance eyes” — even a shy deliveryman whose father, a scruffy old donkey herder , may, it is whispered, be a mazzeri, a Corsican version of a zombie .

snippet: Julia Angwin has done prodigious digging into the shady business practices and trailer-park aesthetics that have allowed MySpace to tap into the American psyche.
lead_paragraph: There’s at least one story that has never been told on the no-holds-barred social networking Web site MySpace. That story is the chaotic, action-packed history of MySpace itself. Now Julia Angwin, a technology and media reporter for The Wall Street Journal, has done prodigious digging into the shady business practices, trailer-park aesthetics, lucky accidents and borderline personality types that have allowed MySpace to tap into the American psyche.

headline: {'main': 'IN SHORT: NONFICTION;\nThe Posed and the Exposed', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'IN SHORT: NONFICTION;\nThe Posed and the Exposed', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

keywords: [{'name': 'persons', 'value': 'DE LOMBARD, JEANNINE', 'rank': 1, 'major': 'N'}, {'name': 'persons', 'value': 'Goldin, Nan', 'rank': 2, 'major': 'N'}, {'name': 'subject', 'value': 'BOOK REVIEWS', 'rank': 3, 'major': 'N'}, {'name': 'creative_works', 'value': 'OTHER SIDE, THE (BOOK)', 'rank': 4, 'major': 'N'}]
snippet: In the introduction to THE OTHER SIDE (Scalo, $39.95), her collection of photographs of transvestites and transsexuals from the United States, Europe and Asia, Nan Goldin writes that she never saw her subjects (who are also her friends) "as men dr...
lead_paragraph: In the introduction to THE OTHER SIDE (Scalo, $39.95), her collection of photographs of transvestites and transsexuals from the United States, Europe and Asia, Nan Goldin writes that she never saw her subjects (who are also her friends) "as men dressing as women, but as something entirely different -- a third gender that made more sense than either of the other two." Although the photographer insists that she had "no desire to unmask them with my camera," her candid images provide many glimpses backstage -- before the wigs are on, makeup applied, bras stuffed and attitudes adjusted. Whether shot in busy bars and streets or cluttered apartments and dressing rooms, Ms. Goldin's photographs blur the boundaries between public and private, the posed and the exposed. Often details in the background suggest that the photographer's subjects maintain a tense relationship with the larger world: the red AIDS ribbon pinned to Mistress Formica's long-line bra; the police officer who grins benignly at a transvestite while protectively clutching a nightstick; the handwritten signs at a bar advertising drinks to benefit a patron "hospitalized due to police brutality." As Ms. Goldin observes, "It takes nerve to walk down the street when you fall between the cracks." This occasionally somber, often joyous book captures the transvestites' distinctive walk and celebrates their nerve, but never misses a crack.

Although the photographer insists that she had "no desire to unmask them with my camera," her candid images provide many glimpses backstage -- before the wigs are on, makeup applied, bras stuffed and attitudes adjusted. Whether shot in busy bars and streets or cluttered apartments and dressing rooms, Ms. Goldin's photographs blur the boundaries between public and private, the posed and the exposed. Often details in the background suggest that the photographer's subjects maintain a tense relationship with the larger world: the red AIDS ribbon pinned to Mistress Formica's long-line bra; the police officer who grins benignly at a transvestite while protectively clutching a nightstick; the handwritten signs at a bar advertising drinks to benefit a patron "hospitalized due to police brutality." As Ms. Goldin observes, "It takes nerve to walk down the street when you fall between the cracks." This occasionally somber, often joyous book captures the transvestites' distinctive walk and celebrates their nerve, but never misses a crack.

keywords: [{'name': 'persons', 'value': 'Greeley, Andrew M', 'rank': 1, 'major': 'N'}, {'name': 'subject', 'value': 'BOOK REVIEWS', 'rank': 2, 'major': 'N'}, {'name': 'creative_works', 'value': 'ALL ABOUT WOMEN (BOOK)', 'rank': 3, 'major': 'N'}]
snippet: Unknown
lead_paragraph: ALL ABOUT WOMEN. By Andrew M. Greeley. (Tom Doherty/Tor, Cloth, $18.95; Paper, $12.95.) As he did with his 1986 novel ''Patience of a Saint,'' the Rev. Andrew M. Greeley affixes an introductory note to this collection, explaining that its title is less audacious than it sounds. He does not, he says, ''purport to know 'all about women.' '' Rather, each of these 23 stories is about a woman, and in each ''a woman either is or creates an opportunity of grace . . . or is visited by an offer of grace.'' Father Greeley's best story, ''Andrea,'' provides an absorbing and chilling account of an eerie young widow being driven through Arizona by a former Navy officer, who is as captivated by her beauty as he is haunted by guilt over the men who died under his command in World War II. Three other interrelated tales - ''Peggy,'' ''Paula'' and ''Deirdre'' - present the collection's only rounded and convincing character, Peggy Walsh, a woman struggling to resume her life after the death of her husband. Unfortunately, despite the benevolence behind them, the remaining stories in ''All About Women'' contribute to the mounting evidence that Father Greeley's talents are best displayed in his theological polemics rather than in his novels and short stories. Long a champion of a more powerful role for women within the church, he treats them here with a syrupy reverence that itself becomes patronizing. As if to serve as a metaphor for the collection, the Virgin Mary is a contemporary character in one story (passing as Ms. Mary Carpenter), and even she cloys. Father Greeley's women simply aren't real. But then, neither are the pulpy narratives in which they appear. These are cumbersome, antiseptic tales whose sentimentality is reminiscent of Hollywood movies in the 1930's and television comedies in the 1950's. Often narrated with thin sanctimony by haughty priests, many of these stories might be retitled ''Father Knows Best.'' That may be so, but not when it comes to fiction.
abstract: LEAD:    ALL ABOUT WOMEN. By Andrew M. Greeley. (Tom Doherty/Tor, Cloth, $18.95; Paper, $12.95.) As he did with his 1986 novel ''Patience of a Saint,'' the Rev. Andrew M. Greeley affixes an introductory note to this collection, explaining that its title is less audacious than it sounds. He does not, he says, ''purport to know 'all about women.

lead_paragraph: In his ambitious mystery debut, ZIA SUMMER (Warner, $21.95), Rudolfo Anaya, the author of "Bless Me, Ultima," whom Tony Hillerman calls the "godfather and guru of Chicano literature," makes Albuquerque, N.M., sound like the birthplace of life and the cradle of civilization. Other regional writers may feel the same about their own blessed plots, but few manage to express that feeling with Mr. Anaya's passion and lyricism.
abstract: In his ambitious mystery debut, ZIA SUMMER (Warner, $21.95), Rudolfo Anaya, the author of "Bless Me, Ultima," whom Tony Hillerman calls the "godfather and guru of Chicano literature," makes Albuquerque, N.M., sound like the birthplace of life and the cradle of civilization. Other regional writers may feel the same about their own blessed plots, but few manage to express that feeling with Mr. Anaya's passion and lyricism.   "His parents had given him a history, a sense of the traditions of the valley . . . but somewhere along the way, he began to get separated," we learn of Sonny Baca, a private detective whose investigation into the grisly ritual slaying of his cousin leads him back to the cultural heritage of the antepasados, his ancestors. Sonny's hunt for the murderer sends him up and down the Rio Grande Valley, into the ideologically armed camps of environmentalists, New Age cultists and real estate developers, who all invoke the Zia sign -- "the powerful, positive image of the sun, symbol of the state flag, god of life" -- for their designs on the land. But the real journey is the spiritual one that takes Sonny through his racial and regional history and into the soul of his people.

snippet: In this first novel, “Matrix” meets Paul Auster meets a conceptual shark.
lead_paragraph: Amnesia plots are a gift to first-time writers; what better way to face down your fear of the empty white page than conjuring a hero whose life is also a complete blank? In Steven Hall’s first novel, “The Raw Shark Texts,” a man wakes one morning to find himself with no idea of who or where he is; outside his window lurks a brave new world, unpopulated save for a few random souls whose job it is to deliver dollops of plot exposition before whisking themselves away again. Thus is the first requirement of the Amnesiac genre fulfilled — the one that dictates that a man who is piecing together his life receive only the scantiest help in doing so. It would never do to have some kind soul simply tell him what the hell is going on.

snippet: SUPER MARIO: ''I wished like hell I'd written it better,'' Mario Puzo famously said about ''The Godfather,'' his third novel. ''I wrote below my gifts in that book.'' Readers didn't mind. The book stuck on the Times hardcover fiction list for 67 w...
lead_paragraph: SUPER MARIO: "I wished like hell I'd written it better," Mario Puzo famously said about "The Godfather," his third novel. "I wrote below my gifts in that book." Readers didn't mind. The book stuck on the Times hardcover fiction list for 67 weeks, making its final appearance on July 5, 1970. (That week, it was gunned down by a murderers' row of novels that included Erich Segal's "Love Story" at No. 1, John Fowles's "French Lieutenant's Woman" at No. 2 and James Dickey's "Deliverance" at No. 3.) The Corleone family is back on the list this week in Mark Winegardner's book "The Godfather Returns," which makes its debut at No. 7. Winegardner, 43, is a literary novelist who teaches at Florida State University. Like a lot of readers of a certain age, this one included, he first picked up Puzo's "Godfather" when he was 11 or 12 because he'd heard it had dirty parts. In a Newsday interview, Winegardner recalled admitting this fact to a friend, the writer Lorrie Moore: "Without missing a beat, she said, 'Page 27!' Sure enough, Page 27 -- the scene with Sonny Corleone and Lucy Mancini doing it standing up." Winegardner's book has received generally positive reviews, including the one in this issue, written by Sarah Vowell. Some readers may give Winegardner bonus points for being true to his school. In "The Godfather Returns," he has Sonny Corleone's daughter enroll at F.S.U.
abstract: SUPER MARIO: ''I wished like hell I'd written it better,'' Mario Puzo famously said about ''The Godfather,'' his third novel. ''I wrote below my gifts in that book.'' Readers didn't mind. The book stuck on the Times hardcover fiction list for 67 weeks, making its final appearance on July 5, 1970. (That week, it was gunned down by a murderers' row of novels that included Erich Segal's ''Love Story'' at No. 1, John Fowles's ''French Lieutenant's Woman'' at No. 2 and James Dickey's ''Deliverance'' at No. 3.) The Corleone family is back on the list this week in Mark Winegardner's book ''The Godfather Returns,'' which makes its debut at No. 7. Winegardner, 43, is a literary novelist who teaches at Florida State University. Like a lot of readers of a certain age, this one included, he first picked up Puzo's ''Godfather'' when he was 11 or 12 because he'd heard it had dirty parts. In a Newsday interview, Winegardner recalled admitting this fact to a friend, the writer Lorrie Moore: ''Without missing a beat, she said, 'Page 27!' Sure enough, Page 27 -- the scene with Sonny Corleone and Lucy Mancini doing it standing up.'' Winegardner's book has received generally positive reviews, including the one in this issue, written by Sarah Vowell. Some readers may give Winegardner bonus points for being true to his school. In ''The Godfather Returns,'' he has Sonny Corleone's daughter enroll at F.S.U.    GETTING THE WRINKLES OUT: ''The Perricone Promise'' -- no, it's not a new Robert Ludlum novel -- is No. 2 on this week's hardcover advice, how-to and miscellaneous list. Its author, Nicholas Perricone, M.D, is this country's newest anti-aging guru. No botox or plastic surgery here. Perricone's book explains how you can eliminate wrinkles and gain ''breathtaking radiance and glow'' through diet, nutritional supplements and ''neuropeptide-based creams.'' (Among the 10 ''superfoods'' he recommends are food co-op staples like sprouts, lentils and yogurt, perhaps explaining why hippie chicks always seemed to age so well.) Perricone has become a lifestyle brand: he sells his own products on his Web site and at his flagship store on Madison Avenue. Among Perricone's most ardent fans is Oprah Winfrey, who had him on her show last month. Oprah found plenty to like about Perricone's ideas -- especially his directive to put carbohydrates back into your diet. ''You need carbs,'' Perricone said. To which Oprah replied, speaking for a pasta-starved nation: ''Otherwise, you start speaking in tongues. . . . You get crazy. You become evil. Your breath stinks and everything else.'' What Oprah says, goes: ''Dr. Atkins' New Diet Revolution'' slides to No. 24 this week on the extended paperback list.   Dwight Garner

keywords: [{'name': 'persons', 'value': 'Trager, James', 'rank': 1, 'major': 'N'}, {'name': 'subject', 'value': 'BOOK REVIEWS', 'rank': 2, 'major': 'N'}, {'name': 'creative_works', 'value': 'PARK AVENUE: STREET OF DREAMS (BOOK)', 'rank': 3, 'major': 'N'}]
snippet: Unknown
lead_paragraph: PARK AVENUE: Street of Dreams. By James Trager. (Atheneum, $24.95.) It is to James Trager's credit that his detailed account of New York's plushest street breathes more life into the thoroughfare than is visible to the naked eye. There are several Park Avenues in addition to the rich residential one. There is the poor residential Park Avenue, the one of the barrio, up where the railroad tracks emerge from underground. There is the glassy Park Avenue of pretentious office buildings in the north 40's and the 50's. And there is an older, still more or less quiet Park Avenue south of Grand Central Terminal - which is, of course, the stunning centerpiece of the entire street. Farther downtown there is Park Avenue South, which is less lordly, and finally there are the half-dozen blocks of Fourth Avenue, which was Park's original name before it moved into more affluent circles. Like so many New York streets, Park Avenue represents change and various generations of architecture. Why, asks Mr. Trager, does Fifth Avenue have so many more big, ugly, modern apartment houses than Park Avenue has? He explains that Park Avenue, which had its beginnings as a railroad street, received its apartment houses during the early decades of the century, when building standards were high. When the Fifth Avenue mansions gave way to new builders after World War II, their replacements conformed to new architecture. Mr. Trager, the author of ''West of Fifth: The Rise and Fall of Manhattan's West Side,'' has studded his book with anecdotes about the great financiers, writers and society figures who have lived on Park Avenue. He appends a house-by-house chronological list of current Park Avenue buildings. There is no bus line on poshest Park Avenue and its relatively unpeopled sidewalks are far from chummy, but Mr. Trager takes the reader on an illuminating trip worthy of the carriage trade.
abstract: LEAD:    PARK AVENUE: Street of Dreams. By James Trager. (Atheneum, $24.95.) It is to James Trager's credit that his detailed account of New York's plushest street breathes more life into the thoroughfare than is visible to the naked eye. There are several Park Avenues in addition to the rich residential one.

snippet: "Cannibal Baby, Hoop Snake, the Rolling Head -- the inventive beasts of the world's folklore put Hollywood's movie monsters to shame. The Gruesome Guide to World Monsters (Candlewick, $18.99, ages 6 and up), by Judy Sierra, is presented as a kind ...
lead_paragraph: "Cannibal Baby, Hoop Snake, the Rolling Head -- the inventive beasts of the world's folklore put Hollywood's movie monsters to shame. The Gruesome Guide to World Monsters (Candlewick, $18.99, ages 6 and up), by Judy Sierra, is presented as a kind of global travel guide to recognizing and avoiding local legends. Peppered with Henrik Drescher's exuberantly creepy mixed-media illustrations, the book takes a geographic joy ride through the international imagination, finding folk monsters like the Ovda of Finland, which tickles its victims, and the Adaro of the Solomon Islands, which likes to throw poisonous flying fish at people for no reason. More familiar characters are found in Fantasy Encyclopedia (Kingfisher, $24.95, ages 9 to 14), by Judy Allen, with a foreword by Jonathan Stroud, which takes a more comprehensive approach to cataloging creatures from ancient mythology to modern fiction. Lavish illustrations by John Howe, Nicki Palin and Patricia Ludlow complement photographs of cultural artifacts and document a few nonimaginary subjects, including the Romanian tyrant Vlad the Impaler, who sounds just as unnerving as the boggarts, trolls and basilisks roaming through the book.

snippet: In the 1950s and ’60s, the prominence of gay artists evoked a homophobic panic.
lead_paragraph: Last September in Washington, Larry Craig’s risible self-defense was still quaintly competing with his colleagues’ apparent consensus that if any mere misdemeanor could get you kicked out of the United States Senate, it would be the one he had committed in a Minneapolis airport men’s room. Going largely unobserved amid the din was a small ceremony a mile or so away, at which the Smithsonian Institution’s National Museum of American History unveiled the glass-encased display of two picket signs that had been carried by homosexual-rights protestors outside the White House in 1965, four years before the Stonewall riot. That these signs are now considered national treasures, worthy of exhibition a few feet from the hat that Lincoln wore to Ford’s Theater, may tell us more about the long run of historical progress than the Craig mess says about enduring denial and hypocrisy.

snippet: Hunter Thompson was always much more, and sometimes a bit less, than the sum of his ribald public persona. “Gonzo” by Jann Wenner and Corey Seymour is a wonderfully entertaining chronicle of Hunter’s wild ride, but it is also a detailed, painful a...
lead_paragraph: On July 2, 1974, I started work as deputy Washington bureau chief for Rolling Stone magazine. My unlikely boss was Richard Goodwin, the former Kennedy speechwriter, who invited me to join him in temporary residence at Ethel Kennedy’s home in McLean, Va. (the owner was in Hyannis for the summer). On July 3, Hunter Thompson joined us. Much of what ensued that holiday weekend is lost in the mists of history and a fog of controlled substances. There were extensive conversations about the viability of renting a truck, filling it with rats and dumping them on the White House lawn. There was also an effort to remove all the Andy Williams songs from the Kennedy jukebox and replace them with Otis Redding. But mostly I remember having a marathon conversation with Hunter about books and writers, settling finally on Joseph Conrad’s exhortation in “Lord Jim”: “In the destructive element immerse!”

abstract: Hunter Thompson was always much more, and sometimes a bit less, than the sum of his ribald public persona. “Gonzo” by Jann Wenner and Corey Seymour is a wonderfully entertaining chronicle of Hunter’s wild ride, but it is also a detailed, painful account of his self-destructive immersions; and the anguish of a life that veered from inspired performance art to ruinous solipsism.

snippet: THE LOST PAINTING, by Jonathan Harr. (Random House, $13.95.) One of the Book Review's 10 best books of 2005, this is a captivating account of the rediscovery, in 1990, of one of the Italian artist Caravaggio's most sought-after paintings, ''The Ta...
lead_paragraph: THE LOST PAINTING, by Jonathan Harr. (Random House, $13.95.) One of the Book Review's 10 best books of 2005, this is a captivating account of the rediscovery, in 1990, of one of the Italian artist Caravaggio's most sought-after paintings, "The Taking of Christ." Harr, author of the best-selling environmental exposé "A Civil Action," follows a precocious graduate student and a beguiling cast of scholars, art restorers and aging nobles, each of whom contributes a piece of the puzzle. Our reviewer, Bruce Handy, called "The Lost Painting" a "rich and wonderful book": "Fortunately, the hunt for the canvas is a bit of a MacGuffin; the deeper mystery is the nature of capital-A art itself."
abstract: THE LOST PAINTING, by Jonathan Harr. (Random House, $13.95.) One of the Book Review's 10 best books of 2005, this is a captivating account of the rediscovery, in 1990, of one of the Italian artist Caravaggio's most sought-after paintings, ''The Taking of Christ.'' Harr, author of the best-selling environmental exposé ''A Civil Action,'' follows a precocious graduate student and a beguiling cast of scholars, art restorers and aging nobles, each of whom contributes a piece of the puzzle. Our reviewer, Bruce Handy, called ''The Lost Painting'' a ''rich and wonderful book'': ''Fortunately, the hunt for the canvas is a bit of a MacGuffin; the deeper mystery is the nature of capital-A art itself.''

snippet: Michael Pollan recommends books on gardening for summer reading; drawing (M)
lead_paragraph: Reading along in THE INVITING GARDEN: Gardening for the Senses, Mind, and Spirit (Holt, $40), I suddenly came upon this provocative sentence: ''Gardening is not a hobby, and only nongardeners would describe it as such.'' For a writer as genial as Allen Lacy, this qualifies as a shot across the wheelbarrow. ''There is nothing wrong with having hobbies,'' he goes on, ''but most hobbies are intellectually limited and make no reference to the larger world. By contrast, being wholeheartedly involved with gardens is involvement with life itself in the deepest sense.'' Indeed. For could it ever be said about, say, bridge that the way you play a hand has implications for the environment, American cuisine, biological diversity, drug policy and national identity, not to mention the nature of time and the meaning of place? ''A garden, whether we know it or not,'' Lacy writes, ''connects us to the world in many strange and wonderful ways.''
abstract: Michael Pollan recommends books on gardening for summer reading; drawing (M)

byline: {'original': 'By Scott Veale', 'person': [{'firstname': 'Scott', 'middlename': None, 'lastname': 'Veale', 'qualifier': None, 'title': None, 'role': 'reported', 'organization': '', 'rank': 1}], 'organization': None}
snippet: Unknown
lead_paragraph: THE BEAST GOD FORGOT TO INVENT, by Jim Harrison. (Grove, $13.) The loutish (but tenderhearted) tough guys who stumble through much of the author's earlier fiction turn up again in these three novellas, but this time they're older, more ruminative, more aware of their mortality and more prone to believe that only the right woman can rescue them from the bad choices they've made. ''The quality of Harrison's food and sex writing (his two major preoccupations) hasn't diminished a bit,'' Dwight Garner wrote in these pages last year. ''What wins you over in the end is the big, wet, sloppy kiss Harrison continues to plant on the face of life itself.''
abstract: THE BEAST GOD FORGOT TO INVENT, by Jim Harrison. (Grove, $13.) The loutish (but tenderhearted) tough guys who stumble through much of the author's earlier fiction turn up again in these three novellas, but this time they're older, more ruminative, more aware of their mortality and more prone to believe that only the right woman can rescue them from the bad choices they've made. ''The quality of Harrison's food and sex writing (his two major preoccupations) hasn't diminished a bit,'' Dwight Garner wrote in these pages last year. ''What wins you over in the end is the big, wet, sloppy kiss Harrison continues to plant on the face of life itself.''    HISTORY OF THE PRESENT: Essays, Sketches, and Dispatches From Europe in the 1990s, by Timothy Garton Ash. (Vintage, $15.) In kaleidoscopic fashion, one of the keenest observers of Europe's recent transformation takes stock of a convulsive decade, from the fall of the Berlin Wall to the Balkan quagmire. Last year our reviewer, Roger Cohen, said Garton Ash's ''strongest pieces combine a quick eye, a gift for concision and an ability to discern the deep currents of history in the restless waters of the present.''    BIRDS OF PASSAGE, by Robert Solé. (Harvill, $13.) This exotically flavored novel follows four generations of a Greek Catholic French-speaking Syrian clan living in Cairo, whose patriarch builds his wealth by manufacturing the tarboosh, or fez. ''Solé deftly weaves the family's history into a tapestry of a colorful and complicated era in Egypt,'' Peter Khoury said here in 2000.    UPSIDE DOWN: A Primer for the Looking-Glass World, by Eduardo Galeano. (Picador USA, $14.) A Uruguayan journalist explores the uneasy and unequal relations between North America and the have-nots of South America, finding much to blame in the policies of the United States but also in South America's blind mimicry of all things American. ''Galeano's pages are full of empathy, candor, unsettling connections and . . . affront at the suffering of his country,'' Isabel Fonseca wrote here last year.    ROMANTICISM AND ITS DISCONTENTS, by Anita Brookner. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $16.) The novelist and art historian examines the forces that animated the French Romantics, casting the work of Delacroix, Ingres, Zola and others as a revolt against the logical, the formal and the rational. In our review last year, Christopher Hitchens called this ''a compact and skillfully written book.''    SADDAM'S BOMBMAKER: The Daring Escape of the Man Who Built Iraq's Secret Weapon, by Khidhir Hamza with Jeff Stein. (Touchstone/Simon & Schuster, $14.) A main figure in Iraq's clandestine nuclear weapons program tells of his privileged life as part of Saddam Hussein's inner circle, his struggle to find safety in the West after his defection in 1994 and Hussein's implacable efforts to build weapons of mass destruction. The result is a ''gripping and unsettling memoir,'' Barbara Crossette said here in 2000.    THE LILY THEATER, by Lulu Wang. (Anchor, $14.) This sprawling novel is a fictionalized account of the author's own childhood during the Cultural Revolution in China. Her young heroine's parents -- a doctor and a professor -- were banished to a remote re-education camp along with a group of leading scholars, who fought to give their daughter an honest education under the eyes of the camp's informers. ''Wang is an original, a writer of real talent,'' John Burnham Schwartz wrote in the Book Review last year, and even if her tale's conclusion is unconvincing, '' 'The Lily Theater' evokes its world with abundant and cleareyed sympathy.''    GHOST LIGHT: A Memoir, by Frank Rich. (Random House, $13.95.) A former chief theater critic for The New York Times recounts his childhood obsession with the theater, a fantasy world that provided him fleeting refuge from his parents' divorce and remarriages. His ''engaging memoir'' describes ''how and why . . . he embraced the world of the stage so passionately, and what pleasures and disappointments playgoing offered in return,'' James Shapiro said in these pages in 2000.    WILD LIFE, by Molly Gloss. (Mariner/Houghton Mifflin, $13.) Set in the Pacific Northwest in the early 1900's, this novel unfolds as the journal of a freethinking widow who encounters some hairy members of the sasquatch clan after she gets lost in the woods while searching for a missing girl. ''Gloss's unconventional heroine . . . reminds us that opportunity exists inside the self as well as outside it,'' Abby Frucht wrote here last year.   Scott Veale

snippet: Unknown
lead_paragraph: AMBROSE BIERCE Alone in Bad Company. By Roy Morris Jr. 306 pp. New York: Crown Publishers. $30. THE journalist and short-story writer Ambrose Bierce was a master of pithy cynicism. His acrid sayings, collected in "The Devil's Dictionary," have a blackly humorous sting that can make even jaded moderns wince. Witness some of his definitions: "BIRTH, n. The first and direst of all disasters"; "RELIGION, n. A daughter of Hope and Fear, explaining to Ignorance the nature of the Unknowable"; "BRIDE, n. A woman with a fine prospect of happiness behind her"; "POSITIVE, adj. Mistaken at the top of one's voice"; "LAWYER, n. One skilled in circumvention of the law"; "SELF-ESTEEM, n. An erroneous appraisement."

snippet: Ian Rankin’s latest novel opens as protesters and celebrities converge on Edinburgh for the G-8 summit conference.
lead_paragraph: Anyone who turns to genre fiction for escapist reading is well advised to stay clear of Ian Rankin’s hard-boiled procedurals featuring Inspector John Rebus of the Edinburgh police force. Like George Pelecanos, the American crime novelist he most resembles, Rankin is a flinty realist with little use for the romantic heroics that allow series detectives to operate above the fray of real life lived in real time. Events that shape the course of history in Scotland are just as likely to determine the plots of his novels. But while that factual fidelity lends authenticity to his books, it also accounts for their unwieldy structure and overburdened narratives.

keywords: [{'name': 'persons', 'value': 'Torme, Mel', 'rank': 1, 'major': 'N'}, {'name': 'subject', 'value': 'BOOK REVIEWS', 'rank': 2, 'major': 'N'}, {'name': 'creative_works', 'value': 'MY SINGING TEACHERS (BOOK)', 'rank': 3, 'major': 'N'}]
snippet: Unknown
lead_paragraph: Whatever Mel Torme has to say about singing is worth reading, and in MY SINGING TEACHERS (Oxford University, $19.95), his reflections on a lifetime of listening and learning, he has a lot to say. The book is less a thoroughgoing analysis of musical technique than an anecdotal medley of the observations of a master. Vocalists who influenced him include the usual pantheon of gods (Bessie, Billie, Frank, Bing, Nat, Ella, Louis) and grandes dames (Ethel Waters, Mabel Mercer, Connee Boswell, Helen Forrest), as well as a few artists not known primarily for their singing: Johnny Mercer, Woody Herman, Fred Astaire. A gifted arranger and composer as well as a pre-eminent performer of American popular music, Mr. Torme displays the extent of his musicianship as he discusses the songwriters, instrumentalists, arrangers, bandleaders, vocal groups, Broadway and film vocalists and scat singers who are among his "role models almost too numerous to mention." I was fascinated to read that he numbers among his "heroes and heroines" the offstage Hollywood singers who were the "voices of the stars" in the film musicals of the 1940's, 50's and 60's: Anita Ellis, Carole Richards, Martha Mears, Marni Nixon, Buddy Clark and others. (We learn that Robert McFerrin, father of the pop star Bobby McFerrin, was the singing voice of Sidney Poitier in the 1959 film "Porgy and Bess.") Mr. Torme, whose previous books include portraits of Buddy Rich ("Traps, the Drum Wonder") and Judy Garland ("The Other Side of the Rainbow"), remains a musician first and a writer second; no one reading "My Singing Teachers" will advise him to give up his night job. But those who have admired the modesty, generosity and taste he has displayed as a singer will find many of those same qualities in this book. PATRICIA T. O'CONNER

headline: {'main': 'And Bear In Mind', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'And Bear In Mind', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}
byline: {'original': None, 'person': [], 'organization': None}
snippet: Unknown
lead_paragraph: (Editors' choices of other recent books of particular interest)
abstract: (Editors' choices of other recent books of particular interest)    JAMESLAND, by Michelle Huneven. (Knopf, $24.) Alice Black, who cannot forget her descent from William James (people keep bringing him up), has trouble being pragmatic about the paranormal in the Los Angeles of this novel, where unlikely things (a deer in the house) seem to trump less exotic ones (like mental illness and fear of mental illness).    THEY MARCHED INTO SUNLIGHT: War and Peace, Vietnam and America, October 1967, by David Maraniss. (Simon & Schuster, $29.95.) A big narrative by a reporter who juxtaposes a ghastly little battle in Vietnam with an antiwar and anti-Dow demonstration at the University of Wisconsin, Madison, on the same two days; it captures moral conviction and moral ambiguity everywhere, without stereotyping or condescension.    GIVING UP THE GHOST: A Memoir, by Hilary Mantel. (John Macrae/Holt, $23.) A dark tale of extravagant consequences and loathed transformations by a distinguished novelist and critic whose life was permanently compromised by misdiagnosis and foolish medication in her youth, and her mother was awful as well. Mantel is still furious, and well able to say why.    THE MEANING OF EVERYTHING: The Story of the Oxford English Dictionary, by Simon Winchester. (Oxford University, $25.) The real story is mostly the story of James Murray, a schoolteacher who knew everything (as so many Victorians did) and who edited the great dictionary heroically from 1879 to 1915 (others completed its 15,490 pages in 1928).    AMERICAN WOMAN, by Susan Choi. (HarperCollins, $24.95.) A fictional account of the intersection of the radical activist Wendy Yoshimura with the fugitive Patty Hearst, who appeared to have adopted the values and perspectives of the revolutionaries who kidnapped her in 1974. The revolutionary life, it turns out, is mainly squalor and dulled anxiety; time outwears everything, and rapidly too.    THE GREAT FIRE, by Shirley Hazzard. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $24.) In Hazzard's first novel in more than 20 years, set in the still smoldering aftermath of World War II, a British major of 32 falls in love with an impossibly precocious 17-year-old; the numerous vicissitudes that follow are supported by the weight and scope of the book's observation of a world and a time in chaos.    L'AFFAIRE, by Diane Johnson. (Dutton, $24.95.) Johnson's third witty and graceful novel about Americans in France is a comedy of manners that concerns a self-made woman, a dot-com millionaire from Palo Alto who goes to France seeking a life-changing love affair. Most of it happens at a ski resort in the Alps, where cultural misunderstandings prevail by day, love affairs by night.    CITY ROOM, by Arthur Gelb. (Marian Wood/ Putnam, $29.95.) A memoir of life at The New York Times by one who spent nearly 50 years there, rising from copy boy to managing editor; he has the power to evoke whole generations of change in the news business, reaching back to the glorious postwar years of manual typewriters, chain smokers and all-nighters.

byline: {'original': 'By Scott Veale', 'person': [{'firstname': 'Scott', 'middlename': None, 'lastname': 'Veale', 'qualifier': None, 'title': None, 'role': 'reported', 'organization': '', 'rank': 1}], 'organization': None}
snippet: Unknown
lead_paragraph: The Whore's Child: And Other Stories, by Richard Russo. (Vintage Contemporaries, $12.95.) In his first collection of short fiction, the author of ''Empire Falls'' bypasses the working-class settings and protagonists of his novels in favor of professors, writers and artists caught up in the drift of late middle age, worried about physical decline and deeply ambivalent about marriage. Last year our reviewer, Rand Richards Cooper, found these stories darker than Russo's friendlier, expansive novels, saying they ''insistently fish for failure beneath the surface of outwardly successful lives.''
abstract: The Whore's Child: And Other Stories, by Richard Russo. (Vintage Contemporaries, $12.95.) In his first collection of short fiction, the author of ''Empire Falls'' bypasses the working-class settings and protagonists of his novels in favor of professors, writers and artists caught up in the drift of late middle age, worried about physical decline and deeply ambivalent about marriage. Last year our reviewer, Rand Richards Cooper, found these stories darker than Russo's friendlier, expansive novels, saying they ''insistently fish for failure beneath the surface of outwardly successful lives.''    Beyond the Last Village: A Journey of Discovery in Asia's Forbidden Wilderness, by Alan Rabinowitz. (Island/Shearwater, $16.) A tenacious wildlife biologist tells of several expeditions he made to a remote Himalayan rain forest in Myanmar, and -- equally important -- his humanizing encounters with the mountain dwellers and others he met along the way. Blending science with soul-searching, his narrative ''often reads like a dispatch not just from a distant place but from a distant time,'' Adam Goodheart said here last year.    La Tour Dreams of the Wolf Girl, by David Huddle. (Mariner/Houghton Mifflin, $13.) This subtle novel shifts between two narratives: the first concerns an art history professor in modern-day Vermont whose cold marriage is dissolving, the second, her fantasy of a relationship between the 17th-century French painter Georges de La Tour and a peasant girl who becomes his model and muse. ''A study of the relation between art and life, the novel has an honesty and psychological depth that are at times painfully real and quietly moving,'' Jane Mendelsohn wrote here in 2002.    A Life in Pieces: The Making and Unmaking of Binjamin Wilkomirski, by Blake Eskin. (Norton, $14.95.) Published in 1997, Wilkomirski's childhood memoir, ''Fragments,'' was hailed as a masterpiece of Holocaust writing. A year later both he and his book were exposed as frauds, but even afterward there were museum curators, psychologists and others who not only stood by him but charged his discreditors with attacking the memories of all survivors. Less concerned with the Holocaust than with the fantasy life of a disturbed young man, this is a ''sad, outrageous, sometimes tragic, sometimes hilarious, always riveting tale,'' Jonathan Lear wrote in the Book Review in 2002.    Across Open Ground, by Heather Parkinson. (Bloomsbury, $14.95.) Set on the same fringes of premodern America as Cormac McCarthy's work, this first novel revolves around a love affair between a 17-year-old sheepherder and a beautiful trapper in the Idaho high country, and the profound impact of World War I on their relationship. In her ''immensely impressive debut,'' Parkinson ''writes with great authority not only about sheep and fish and horses but about the emotional lives of a variety of humans,'' Will Blythe wrote here in 2002.    The Count and the Confession: A True Mystery, by John Taylor. (Vintage, $14.) There are many puzzles running through this account of the 1992 death of Roger de la Burde on his Virginia estate: was the victim really a Polish aristocrat, or was he a social-climbing poseur, swindler or worse? Was his genteel mistress really guilty? Did the lead investigator cross the line to obtain a confession? ''The book has all the elements of a compelling murder mystery -- money, social position, passion and intrigue,'' James B. Stewart said in these pages last year. The result is ''an important study in the legal principle of reasonable doubt, not to mention good reading.''    Strangers: A Family Romance, by Emma Tennant. (New Directions, $14.95.) In her memoir of her wealthy, troubled forebears, Tennant, a British novelist, sifts through a century's worth of diaries, anecdotes and recollections to locate the source of the hostility lurking behind her family's carefully managed facade of unity and devotion. In 1999 our reviewer, Emily Eakin, admired Tennant's ''subtle irony and her impeccable ear'' and found this ''a lyrical meditation on the obscure psychodynamics of family life.''    Bear Me Safely Over, by Sheri Joseph. (Grove, $13.) Oddballs abound in this first novel, an old-fashioned family drama set in rural Georgia and freshened by the complicated factors of stepfamily, gay liberation and rock 'n' roll. ''Many writers are busy exploring similar territory, but Joseph claims her own corner with quiet empathy,'' Ann Powers wrote in these pages in 2002.   Scott Veale

keywords: [{'name': 'subject', 'value': 'Books and Literature', 'rank': 1, 'major': 'N'}, {'name': 'persons', 'value': 'Russo, Richard (1949- )', 'rank': 2, 'major': 'N'}]
snippet: In his latest novel, Richard Russo returns to familiar Northeastern territory.
lead_paragraph: Someone — it’s been attributed to everyone from Dostoyevsky to John Gardner — once said there are only two possible stories: a man goes on a journey, or a stranger comes to town. To these Richard Russo has added a third: schlub stays put. In a time known in trendier circles for literary exile, Russo is the unofficial poet laureate of uneasy stasis, of fixing yourself to the place where you were born. Out the window goes the dynamism of American self-invention; in comes something almost more mysterious: a reckoning with an apparently seamless life continuity. If I didn’t invent this self, where exactly did it come from? And yet more queasily: This place that nurtured me — did it also stunt me, inhibit me, even, literally, poison me?

keywords: [{'name': 'persons', 'value': 'Heyerdahl, Thor', 'rank': 1, 'major': 'N'}, {'name': 'subject', 'value': 'BOOK REVIEWS', 'rank': 2, 'major': 'N'}, {'name': 'creative_works', 'value': 'EASTER ISLAND (BOOK)', 'rank': 3, 'major': 'N'}]
snippet: Unknown
lead_paragraph: EASTER ISLAND: The Mystery Solved. By Thor Heyerdahl. (Random House, $24.95.) The explorer Thor Heyerdahl argues in ''Easter Island,'' as he has in such books as ''Kon-Tiki,'' that ancient peoples were more developed and mobile than modern thinking gives them credit for. Easter Island, off South America in the Pacific Ocean, has long been a subject of scientific speculation for its large stone statues, its cultural history, its language and even its plant life, all of which are distinct from those of its island neighbors. On his first visit to the island in 1955, Mr. Heyerdahl was struck by the similarity of Easter Island's sculptures to those of pre-Incan Peru. Scientists found numerous plants on Easter Island that exist nowhere else in Polynesia but do grow in South America - more evidence to bolster the legend that an early king arrived from a land to the east, a legend that had been summarily rejected by scientists. Mr. Heyerdahl, however, finds the legend both compelling and plausible. In fact, the mobility of ancient peoples has penetrated the public consciousness so thoroughly that his extensive arguments now seem almost redundant. The account of Mr. Heyerdahl's 1986 return to Easter Island is fascinating, as his team finds further links to South American civilizations and even to the ancient Hittites. Most intriguing is that scientists finally show how enormous 20-ton stone statues were moved from quarries to their resting places all over the island. The islanders had always said that their statues ''walked'' - were transported by humans - and, of course, the scientists had always rejected that answer. It is this triumph of ancient civilization and the humbling of science that should most appeal to the general reader.
abstract: LEAD:    EASTER ISLAND: The Mystery Solved. By Thor Heyerdahl. (Random House, $24.95.) The explorer Thor Heyerdahl argues in ''Easter Island,'' as he has in such books as ''Kon-Tiki,'' that ancient peoples were more developed and mobile than modern thinking gives them credit for. Easter Island, off South America in the Pacific Ocean, has long been a subject of scientific speculation for its large stone statues, its cultural history, its language and even its plant life, all of which are distinct from those of its island neighbors.

keywords: [{'name': 'persons', 'value': 'Guimard, Hector', 'rank': 1, 'major': 'N'}, {'name': 'subject', 'value': 'Reviews', 'rank': 2, 'major': 'N'}, {'name': 'subject', 'value': 'Books and Literature', 'rank': 3, 'major': 'N'}, {'name': 'creative_works', 'value': 'HECTOR GUIMARD: ARCHITECT, DESIGNER 1867-1942 (BOOK)', 'rank': 4, 'major': 'N'}]
snippet: Steven Heller reviews book Hector Guimard: Architect, Designer 1867-1942 by Hector Guimard; drawing (S)
lead_paragraph: Two sights define Paris: the Eiffel Tower and the entrances for the Métro, some of which have disappeared into museums and collections over the past few decades. Between 1900 and 1904 Hector Guimard produced the subway's marquees and railings, stunning gems of art nouveau, the sinuously curvilinear design style inspired by nature that became the dominant international architectural, furniture, and graphic movement from the mid-1890's until just before World War I. Guimard was the movement's most inventive proponent, probably the most prolific in any medium, and decidedly the most eccentric, given the excessive floriated madness that characterizes even his most simplified creations. Although some of the exquisitely decorative work in wood, metal, ceramic, and stone has been destroyed, enough has been preserved to illustrate the beautifully produced HECTOR GUIMARD: Architect, Designer 1867/1942 (Delano Greenidge Editions, $85). Through color photographs of buildings and details, as well as painstakingly researched original drawings, sketches, blueprints and other historical documentation related to the design of everything from intricate banisters and window frames to innovative cemetery memorials to casts of building numbers, Guimard's style is not just resurrected from the past but made to appear almost new. Steven Heller
abstract: Steven Heller reviews book Hector Guimard: Architect, Designer 1867-1942 by Hector Guimard; drawing (S)

keywords: [{'name': 'persons', 'value': 'MADSEN, AXEL', 'rank': 1, 'major': 'N'}, {'name': 'subject', 'value': 'BOOK REVIEWS', 'rank': 2, 'major': 'N'}, {'name': 'creative_works', 'value': 'CHANEL: A WOMAN OF HER OWN (BOOK)', 'rank': 3, 'major': 'N'}]
snippet: Unknown
lead_paragraph: CHANEL: A Woman of Her Own. By Axel Madsen. (Holt, $19.95.) ''Women no longer exist,'' said a Frenchman in 1920. ''All that's left are the boys created by Chanel.'' They are still coming down the runways and the fashionable boulevards looking that Coco way. Perhaps Gabrielle (Coco) Chanel (1883-1971) did not actually create the concept of chic. But she at least redefined it in a way that has had lasting meaning. What was so special about this woman? She was well known to be a fabricator of more than boucle wool suits and little black dresses, having reinvented her past, quite romantically, in interviews she gave after achieving fame and fortune. Given the pretensions that then and forever adhere to people who wear the most fashionable clothes, it could be disconcerting to know that an illegitimate daughter of a traveling salesman created the style of the times. Her history has always been rather sketchy. Hence, one presumes, the need for another Chanel biography. Casting Chanel as the personification of postwar feminism in Europe, Axel Madsen, the author of biographies of Yves Saint Laurent and John Huston, has gone back over Chanel's childhood, poring over provincial church records and such to trace her life in a kind of plodding chronological order. For all the rigor of this approach and its abundance of fascinating and extraneous detail, it frequently remains hard to imagine how she came to be who she was and to wield such an enduring power. ''Chanel: A Woman of Her Own'' takes the reader behind the coromandel veneers of Chanel's life, and what is found there turns out to be less than startling. When one examines the facts of her life - the orphaned childhood, the series of tempestuous, ill-fated romantic liaisons, the dalliance with a Nazi occupier in Vichy France, the rumors of lesbianism and drug use - they would seem to make for highly dramatic biography. Somehow, they do not.
abstract: LEAD:    CHANEL: A Woman of Her Own. By Axel Madsen. (Holt, $19.95.) ''Women no longer exist,'' said a Frenchman in 1920. ''All that's left are the boys created by Chanel.'' They are still coming down the runways and the fashionable boulevards looking that Coco way. Perhaps Gabrielle (Coco) Chanel (1883-1971) did not actually create the concept of chic.

LEAD: 

THE ASCENT OF PRAGMATISM: The Burger Court in Action. By Bernard Schwartz. (Addison-Wesley, $24.95.) Few governmental institutions are more secretive than the United States Supreme Court. Yet Bernard Schwartz, the Edwin D. Webb Professor of Law at New York University, has written a series of books (such as ''Super Chief'' and ''Beyond Bakke'') based on the conference notes, draft opinions and memoranda among the Justices that show how the Court arrives at its decisions.

snippet: Animal books by Anita Lobel, Ann Hodgman and John Grogan.
lead_paragraph: “Animals are such agreeable friends — they ask no questions, they pass no criticisms,” George Eliot wrote 150 years ago in “Scenes of Clerical Life.” Although some may argue that certain cats are never shy about offering persnickety commentary, three recent children’s books would be in enthusiastic agreement with Eliot, painting loving portraits of pet companions, from big dogs to hedgehogs.
abstract: Animal books by Anita Lobel, Ann Hodgman and John Grogan.

headline: {'main': "Rockin' With Nietzsche", 'kicker': 'IN SHORT: NONFICTION', 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': "IN SHORT: NONFICTION; Rockin' With Nietzsche", 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}
byline: {'original': 'By Michael E. Ross', 'person': [{'firstname': 'Michael', 'middlename': 'E.', 'lastname': 'Ross', 'qualifier': None, 'title': None, 'role': 'reported', 'organization': '', 'rank': 1}], 'organization': None}
keywords: [{'name': 'persons', 'value': 'Jones, Dylan', 'rank': 1, 'major': 'N'}, {'name': 'persons', 'value': 'Morrison, Jim', 'rank': 2, 'major': 'N'}, {'name': 'subject', 'value': 'BOOK REVIEWS', 'rank': 3, 'major': 'N'}, {'name': 'creative_works', 'value': 'JIM MORRISON: DARK STAR (BOOK)', 'rank': 4, 'major': 'N'}]
snippet: Unknown
lead_paragraph: In an era when Vietnam consumed the national attention, Jim Morrison may well have been rock's point man in the cultural free-fire zone of the 60's. As lead singer and chief lyricist of the Doors, Morrison's dark lyric vision, dramatic stage presence and leonine visage electrified the rock world. When he died -- at the age of 27, probably of a heroin overdose, in July 1971 -- many refused to believe he was gone. If ever a rock star was capable of resurrection, it was Jim Morrison. The Doors' records continue to sell well, in many instances better than they sold when Morrison was alive. His presence returns anew in Oliver Stone's film "The Doors" and in books chronicling his life. In JIM MORRISON: Dark Star (Viking Studio, $29.95), the journalist Dylan Jones charts the star's rise and fall and offers some fresh insights into his motivations and early influences. To his credit, Mr. Jones explores Morrison's embrace of Nietzsche's thought, calling "The Birth of Tragedy" the key to understanding Morrison and the Doors. But there's often a sense that the book has been rushed into print, and it offers us little beyond the boilerplate tragedy. "Dark Star" flickers occasionally, but it will probably take its place with other books on other stars whose grip on the popular imagination extended beyond their lives -- another well-intentioned example of cashing in on a dead legend.
abstract: In an era when Vietnam consumed the national attention, Jim Morrison may well have been rock's point man in the cultural free-fire zone of the 60's. As lead singer and chief lyricist of the Doors, Morrison's dark lyric vision, dramatic stage presence and leonine visage electrified the rock world. When he died -- at the age of 27, probably of a heroin overdose, in July 1971 -- many refused to believe he was gone. If ever a rock star was capable of resurrection, it was Jim Morrison. The Doors' records continue to sell well, in many instances better than they sold when Morrison was alive. His presence returns anew in Oliver Stone's film "The Doors" and in books chronicling his life. In JIM MORRISON: Dark Star (Viking Studio, $29.95), the journalist Dylan Jones charts the star's rise and fall and offers some fresh insights into his motivations and early influences. To his credit, Mr. Jones explores Morrison's embrace of Nietzsche's thought, calling "The Birth of Tragedy" the key to understanding Morrison and the Doors. But there's often a sense that the book has been rushed into print, and it offers us little beyond the boilerplate tragedy. "Dark Star" flickers occasionally, but it will probably take its place with other books on other stars whose grip on the popular imagination extended beyond their lives -- another well-intentioned example of cashing in on a dead legend.

keywords: [{'name': 'persons', 'value': 'Bailyn, Bernard', 'rank': 1, 'major': 'N'}, {'name': 'subject', 'value': 'BOOK REVIEWS', 'rank': 2, 'major': 'N'}, {'name': 'creative_works', 'value': 'FACES OF REVOLUTION (BOOK)', 'rank': 3, 'major': 'N'}]
snippet: Unknown
lead_paragraph: The sketches and essays are diverse. Mr. Bailyn's approaches to the three Thomases of the American Revolutionary epoch - Jefferson, Hutchinson and Paine - are as different from one another as the subjects were, but they are held together by a common theme: the influence of ideas on the politics of the period. More specifically, each is directed toward expanding, correcting, elaborating and illustrating the thesis Mr. Bailyn first advanced in his extremely influential 1967 book, ''The Ideological Origins of the American Revolution.''
abstract: LEAD:    FACES OF REVOLUTION    Personalities and Themes in the    Struggle for American Independence.    By Bernard Bailyn.    Illustrated. 296 pp. New York:    Alfred A. Knopf. $29.95.

keywords: [{'name': 'organizations', 'value': 'Roman Catholic Church', 'rank': 1, 'major': 'N'}, {'name': 'subject', 'value': 'Murders and Attempted Murders', 'rank': 2, 'major': 'N'}, {'name': 'glocations', 'value': 'Guatemala', 'rank': 3, 'major': 'N'}, {'name': 'subject', 'value': 'Priests', 'rank': 4, 'major': 'N'}, {'name': 'subject', 'value': 'Freedom and Human Rights', 'rank': 5, 'major': 'N'}, {'name': 'subject', 'value': 'Books and Literature', 'rank': 6, 'major': 'N'}, {'name': 'persons', 'value': 'Goldman, Francisco', 'rank': 7, 'major': 'N'}, {'name': 'subject', 'value': 'Religion and Churches', 'rank': 8, 'major': 'N'}]
snippet: The novelist Francisco Goldman investigates the real-life killing of a Roman Catholic bishop.
lead_paragraph: As a novelist, Francisco Goldman has mined Guatemalan misery and magic, most notably in his semiautobiographical “Long Night of White Chickens,” in which the protagonist investigates the murder of a young woman who was like a sister to him. In “The Art of Political Murder,” his first book of nonfiction, Goldman returns to Guatemala to try to solve a real killing, that of Bishop Juan Gerardi Conedera, a Roman Catholic human rights advocate. Becoming by turns a little bit Columbo, Jason Bourne and Seymour Hersh, Goldman gives us the anatomy of a crime while opening a window to a misunderstood neighboring country that is flirting with anarchy. More, he offers an overdue indictment of brutal war criminals who were not just behind the one killing, but also contributed to a generation of atrocities.

snippet: “The Holy or the Broken” tells the story of “Hallelujah,” Leonard Cohen’s 1984 song whose popularity seems only to solidify.
lead_paragraph: Leonard Cohen spent years struggling with his song “Hallelujah.” He recalls being in a New York hotel room in his underwear, “banging my head on the floor and saying, ‘I can’t finish this song.’ ” He wrote perhaps as many as 80 verses before paring the song down and recording it on the 1984 album “Various Positions.” Then his label, CBS Records, refused to release “Various Positions,” not realizing that “Hallelujah” would become one of the most haunting, mutable and oft-performed songs in American musical history.

snippet: How justice was finally served in the wake of a 1919 Arkansas race massacre.
lead_paragraph: My grandfather lived in West Helena, Ark., in 1919, in Phillips County, the place of the race massacre chronicled in “On the Laps of Gods.” A box of his papers that I recently uncovered shows evidence of that Jim Crow era in action  a receipt for his poll taxes from 1917, identifying him as white and stamped with the name of the sheriff, Frank Kitchens. Robert Whitaker’s book quotes a letter in which Kitchens is described as wanting a “free hand to hunt Mr. Nigger in his lair.”

snippet: A romp through new art and design books.
lead_paragraph: War is hell! Yet in James Aulich’s WAR POSTERS: Weapons of Mass Communication (Thames & Hudson, $40), a lush catalog for a current exhibition at the Imperial War Museum in London, many of the posters produced in favor of armed conflict and in opposition to it during the 20th and early 21st centuries are so exquisitely conceived and rendered that they can be appreciated as art, not mere propaganda.

keywords: [{'name': 'subject', 'value': 'Books and Literature', 'rank': 1, 'major': 'N'}, {'name': 'persons', 'value': 'Eco, Umberto', 'rank': 2, 'major': 'N'}, {'name': 'subject', 'value': 'Beauty', 'rank': 3, 'major': 'N'}]
snippet: Umberto Eco’s “On Ugliness” asks whether repulsiveness, too, is in the eye of the beholder.
lead_paragraph: In “History of Beauty,” Umberto Eco explored the ways in which notions of attractiveness shift from culture to culture and era to era. With ON UGLINESS (Rizzoli, $45), a collection of images and written excerpts from ancient times to the present, all woven together with a provocative commentary and translated by Alastair McEwen, he asks: Is repulsiveness, too, in the eye of the beholder? And what do we learn about that beholder when we delve into his aversions? Selecting stark visual images of gore, deformity, moral turpitude and malice, and quotations from sources ranging from Plato to radical feminists, Eco unfurls a taxonomy of ugliness. As gross-out contests go, it’s both absorbing and highbrow.

keywords: [{'name': 'persons', 'value': 'Wyszogrod, Morris', 'rank': 1, 'major': 'N'}, {'name': 'subject', 'value': 'JEWS', 'rank': 2, 'major': 'N'}, {'name': 'subject', 'value': 'Reviews', 'rank': 3, 'major': 'N'}, {'name': 'subject', 'value': 'Books and Literature', 'rank': 4, 'major': 'N'}, {'name': 'subject', 'value': 'Biographical Information', 'rank': 5, 'major': 'N'}, {'name': 'subject', 'value': 'Concentration Camps', 'rank': 6, 'major': 'N'}, {'name': 'subject', 'value': 'Art', 'rank': 7, 'major': 'N'}, {'name': 'subject', 'value': 'Nazi Policies Toward Jews and Minorities', 'rank': 8, 'major': 'N'}, {'name': 'creative_works', 'value': 'BRUSH WITH DEATH, A: AN ARTIST IN THE DEATH CAMPS (BOOK)', 'rank': 9, 'major': 'N'}]
snippet: Susan Shapiro reviews book A Brush With Death: An Artist in the Death Camps, memoir by Morris Wyszogrod; drawing (S)
lead_paragraph: In 1936, when Morris Wyszogrod turned 16, his parents pawned belongings to send him to Warsaw's Marshal Josef Pilsudski School of Graphics, an exclusive art school which accepted only a few Jewish students. Their sacrifice saved his life. During World War II, Wyszogrod told a young German officer he was an artist. He was given pen, ink and paper to write nameplates of soldiers, then asked to paint the officer's portrait in charcoal. He was rewarded with a special identification card that read ''The Jew shown in this photograph . . . is permitted to walk unescorted between the airfield and the Jewish district.'' The Kunstmahler, as he became known, painted more portraits of officers and their girlfriends and made a sign that said ''Fr Juden und Hunde Zutritt Verboten!'' (''Entry forbidden to Jews and dogs''), while secretly producing fake ID's for members of the Jewish resistance. Wyszogrod's talent was also his salvation at the Budzyn, Plaszow and Theresienstadt concentration camps, where he redecorated SS living quarters, produced pornographic drawings and painted coffins for German soldiers. A Brush With Death: An Artist in the Death Camps (State University of New York, cloth, $44.50; paper, $14.95) is a heartbreaking, succinctly told memoir, as well as a fascinating parable of the way society treats artists. Wyszogrod includes drawings he made in the camps, photographs and loving descriptions of his father, a professional musician from Lublin who fixed instruments, and his Warsaw-born mother, a theatrical costume designer. After the liberation of Theresienstadt in 1945, he learned they had perished in the camps, along with his three siblings. He was reunited with his Uncle Mendel in New York in 1947. In 1952 he married Helen Rosenberg, who survived the war in Poland. They have two children and six grandchildren. His daughter Diane, who married the son of Auschwitz survivors, edited her father's poignant story. Susan Shapiro
abstract: Susan Shapiro reviews book A Brush With Death: An Artist in the Death Camps, memoir by Morris Wyszogrod; drawing (S)

headline: {'main': 'The Man Who Dreamed of Faeryland', 'kicker': 'IN SHORT: NONFICTION', 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'IN SHORT: NONFICTION; The Man Who Dreamed of Faeryland', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}
