keywords: [{'name': 'persons', 'value': 'Yeats, William Butler', 'rank': 1, 'major': 'N'}, {'name': 'subject', 'value': 'BOOK REVIEWS', 'rank': 2, 'major': 'N'}, {'name': 'creative_works', 'value': 'W B YEATS: IMAGES OF IRELAND (BOOK)', 'rank': 3, 'major': 'N'}]
snippet: Unknown
lead_paragraph: How fine it would be if one were able to wander the Irish countryside accompanied by an erudite friend capable of spouting precisely appropriate lines by William Butler Yeats at the proper moments. In Sligo, in the shadows of Ben Bulben, or in Galway, at Coole Park, the words of the man who dreamed of Faeryland still echo. W. B. YEATS: Images of Ireland (Macmillan, $35) captures well the Ireland that Yeats knew and loved and wrote about, "where all outward things were the image of an inward life." Alain Le Garsmeur's reserved yet knowing photographs, in both color and black and white, are untainted by any nostalgic glow. They are accompanied by the scholar Bernard McCabe's useful and informative chronology and introductory essay, and paired with exceedingly well-chosen extracts from Yeats's poetry, memoirs, essays and plays. The photographs illuminate the text, while the text adds depth and meaning to the pictures. This elegant volume makes accessible the subtle passions and simplicities of the mental and physical Irish landscapes.
abstract: How fine it would be if one were able to wander the Irish countryside accompanied by an erudite friend capable of spouting precisely appropriate lines by William Butler Yeats at the proper moments. In Sligo, in the shadows of Ben Bulben, or in Galway, at Coole Park, the words of the man who dreamed of Faeryland still echo. W. B. YEATS: Images of Ireland (Macmillan, $35) captures well the Ireland that Yeats knew and loved and wrote about, "where all outward things were the image of an inward life." Alain Le Garsmeur's reserved yet knowing photographs, in both color and black and white, are untainted by any nostalgic glow. They are accompanied by the scholar Bernard McCabe's useful and informative chronology and introductory essay, and paired with exceedingly well-chosen extracts from Yeats's poetry, memoirs, essays and plays. The photographs illuminate the text, while the text adds depth and meaning to the pictures. This elegant volume makes accessible the subtle passions and simplicities of the mental and physical Irish landscapes.

snippet: Julia Reed essay shares her experiences and thoughts on flying; discusses four books related to flight and air travel--The Paris Review Book: For Planes, Trains, Elevators, and Waiting Rooms by Richard Powers; Air Fare: Stories, Poems and Essays o...
lead_paragraph: I have done some of my best writing on planes -- scribbled usually, on the backs of boarding passes, on the airsick bags from the seat pockets in front of me, on blank checks hurriedly ripped from my checkbook. Whole paragraphs come unbidden; solutions to problems long knotted in my brain slip free. Not long ago I turned down an assignment from this newspaper because I couldn't think how to make it work, and then, somewhere en route from Atlanta to New York, the answer came -- too late but in complete sentences, 30,000 feet above the ground.
abstract: Julia Reed essay shares her experiences and thoughts on flying; discusses four books related to flight and air travel--The Paris Review Book: For Planes, Trains, Elevators, and Waiting Rooms by Richard Powers; Air Fare: Stories, Poems and Essays on Flight edited by Nickole Brown and Judith Taylor; Window Seat: Reading the Landscape from the Air by Gregory Dicum; and Ask the Pilot by Patrick Smith

snippet: FRANKENOMICS: Five new books surface on this week's hardcover nonfiction list, further scattering the familiar titles -- ''Blink,'' ''1776,'' ''Freakonomics'' and ''The World Is Flat'' -- that have dominated the list's top third for months. The ne...
lead_paragraph: FRANKENOMICS: Five new books surface on this week's hardcover nonfiction list, further scattering the familiar titles -- "Blink," "1776," "Freakonomics" and "The World Is Flat" -- that have dominated the list's top third for months. The new title at No. 1 is "The Truth (With Jokes)," by Al Franken, a gloomier, more astringent book than his "Lies (and the Lying Liars Who Tell Them)," which came out in 2003. Franken's new one has dark circles under its eyes. "The Truth (With Jokes)" went to press before Katrina and the indictment of Lewis Libby, so it already feels mildly dated; and regular readers of political blogs, which have multiplied exponentially since Franken's last book, may feel a lot of the material here (on John Kerry and his "Swift Boat" attackers, Abu Ghraib, Fox News) has already been hashed to death. But Franken is more wicked than your average blogger. In his new book he recalls how Paul Wolfowitz, then the deputy secretary of defense, told Congress in April 2004 that "approximately 500" Americans had been killed in Iraq up to that point, when the actual number was 722. "The next Saturday," Franken writes, "I happened to run into Wolfowitz at the White House Correspondents Dinner. 'You want to hear the joke I've been using about your not knowing how many of our troops had died in Iraq?' I asked. The small group that had gathered around us made it impossible for him to say no. 'O.K. Here it is. Paul Wolfowitz was off by a third when he was asked how many Americans have died in Iraq. The good news, however, is that he won the office pool.' "
abstract: FRANKENOMICS: Five new books surface on this week's hardcover nonfiction list, further scattering the familiar titles -- ''Blink,'' ''1776,'' ''Freakonomics'' and ''The World Is Flat'' -- that have dominated the list's top third for months. The new title at No. 1 is ''The Truth (With Jokes),'' by Al Franken, a gloomier, more astringent book than his ''Lies (and the Lying Liars Who Tell Them),'' which came out in 2003. Franken's new one has dark circles under its eyes. ''The Truth (With Jokes)'' went to press before Katrina and the indictment of Lewis Libby, so it already feels mildly dated; and regular readers of political blogs, which have multiplied exponentially since Franken's last book, may feel a lot of the material here (on John Kerry and his ''Swift Boat'' attackers, Abu Ghraib, Fox News) has already been hashed to death. But Franken is more wicked than your average blogger. In his new book he recalls how Paul Wolfowitz, then the deputy secretary of defense, told Congress in April 2004 that ''approximately 500'' Americans had been killed in Iraq up to that point, when the actual number was 722. ''The next Saturday,'' Franken writes, ''I happened to run into Wolfowitz at the White House Correspondents Dinner. 'You want to hear the joke I've been using about your not knowing how many of our troops had died in Iraq?' I asked. The small group that had gathered around us made it impossible for him to say no. 'O.K. Here it is. Paul Wolfowitz was off by a third when he was asked how many Americans have died in Iraq. The good news, however, is that he won the office pool.' ''

lead_paragraph: JOHN MAYNARD KEYNES Volume One: Hopes Betrayed, 1883-1920 By Robert Skidelsky. Penguin, $15.95. This biography examines the ethical philosophy as well as the intellectual brilliance of one of the world's greatest economists, giving full attention to his homosexuality and the guilt he felt over his British Government role during World War I. Selected as one of the best books of 1986 by the editors of the Book Review, it is a "brilliant achievement," Robert L. Heilbroner said here.

snippet: Marilyn Stasio reviews following books: The Stone Monkey by Jeffery Deaver; In the Bleak Midwinter by Julia Spencer-Fleming; Widow's Walk by Robert B Parker; A Murder of Promise by Robert Andrew; and Catch as Cat Can by Rita Mae Brown; drawing (M)
lead_paragraph: ''Subtlety'' is a word you won't find in Jeffery Deaver's dictionary. The hero of his white-knuckle thriller THE STONE MONKEY (Simon & Schuster, $25), a quadriplegic forensics genius named Lincoln Rhyme who directs elaborate criminal investigations from his $3,000 customized bed, is the ''last hope'' of government agencies clamoring for his aid in capturing the master criminal who sank a ship of illegal Chinese immigrants off the coast of Long Island. Rhyme's quarry, a sinister shapeshifter known as the Ghost, is ''probably the most dangerous human smuggler in the world,'' and two desperate families will die if this fiend is not caught in the next 48 hours. Ticktock-ticktock-tick. . . .
abstract: Marilyn Stasio reviews following books: The Stone Monkey by Jeffery Deaver; In the Bleak Midwinter by Julia Spencer-Fleming; Widow's Walk by Robert B Parker; A Murder of Promise by Robert Andrew; and Catch as Cat Can by Rita Mae Brown; drawing (M)

snippet: China and the European Union have joined the United States as global players, says a young foreign-policy scholar.
lead_paragraph: After the collapse of Communism, the “new world order” quickly disintegrated into the new world disorder, as pent-up nationalism erupted, most dramatically in the Balkans. The nationalistic volcano subsided, replaced by fears about the “clash of civilizations,” which meant the West against the rest, and primarily Islam. After 9/11, the “ism” of concern became “terrorism,” and our book shelves groan under the weight of policy prescriptions from public officials, academics, journalists and even former spies.

snippet: Unknown
lead_paragraph: THE CUNNING MAN By Robertson Davies. Penguin, $12.95. The narrator is a physician, but no ordinary one: interested in religion and psychology as much as he is in medicine, Dr. Jonathan Hullah is prompted to look back on his own life when he is confronted by the sudden, bizarre death of a priest. "This is a wise, humane and consistently entertaining novel," Isabel Colegate said here last year.

lead_paragraph: It's no use trying to read Ruth Rendell's mind. You can follow her logic, analyze her insights and puzzle out her plots. But she'll always astonish you, as she does in HARM DONE (Crown, $24), with the emotional depth of her psychological mysteries.

snippet: In “A Wild Surge of Guilty Passion” Ron Hansen delves into the real-life case of a wife who coaxed her lover into killing her husband for insurance money.
lead_paragraph: Before it became one of the most familiar premises for hard-boiled fiction and film noir, the tale of the wife who coaxed her lover into getting rid of her annoying husband and cashing in on his life insurance was an actual news event. As he writes in an essay called “Whence Novels Come” (posted on the Web site of Santa Clara University, where he teaches) Ron Hansen found this out only accidentally. But he has made it the basis for “A Wild Surge of Guilty Passion,” a novel that separates the mawkish tabloid murder case from its later, tougher incarnations.

snippet: LEAD: It has been almost 20 years since Bobby Fischer beat Boris Spassky, and 83 years since a world championship chess match has been contested on American soil (Lasker-Marshall, 1907). With the first half of the latest Kasparov-Karpov title matc...
lead_paragraph: LEAD: It has been almost 20 years since Bobby Fischer beat Boris Spassky, and 83 years since a world championship chess match has been contested on American soil (Lasker-Marshall, 1907). With the first half of the latest Kasparov-Karpov title match now taking place in New York (the venue for the second half is Lyons, France), chess is enjoying another day in the American sun - a perfect occasion for welcoming a modern history of this ancient game.

keywords: [{'name': 'persons', 'value': 'Clarke, Arthur C', 'rank': 1, 'major': 'N'}, {'name': 'subject', 'value': 'BOOK REVIEWS', 'rank': 2, 'major': 'N'}, {'name': 'creative_works', 'value': 'ASTOUNDINGS DAYS (BOOK)', 'rank': 3, 'major': 'N'}]
snippet: Unknown
lead_paragraph: ASTOUNDING DAYS: A Science Fictional Autobiography. By Arthur C. Clarke. (Spectra/Bantam, Paper, $8.95.) Science fiction is sometimes closer to and often farther ahead of the truth than hard, cold reality. In 1990, it is difficult to remember just how new and mind-boggling were some of the concepts in Arthur C. Clarke's 1968 novel ''2001: A Space Odyssey.'' Mr. Clarke was in on the early, golden-age days of science fiction, from 1930 through 1971, the period covered in his curious ''science fictional autobiography,'' ''Astounding Days.'' Each of the book's three sections is dedicated to a science fiction magazine editor (and friend) who influenced Mr. Clarke's writing and thinking. Mr. Clarke gives a chatty, anecdotal account of science fiction, his career and his famous friends through the years. Parenthetical reminiscences and asides are included with references to and quotes from the author's works. Science fiction in the early days, he writes, was neither science nor fantasy, but a world of action, adventure, romance - a realm of the imagination. If the pulp magazine covers featured lurid monsters and damsels in distress, much of the old science fiction writing presaged today's hard science. Many of the creative, speculative writings of the 1930's and 40's are little dated, even now; even the fourth dimension, Mr. Clarke writes, suddenly became quite respectable after Einstein announced his theory of relativity. In this world of curiosity and wonder, even the creators of imaginary worlds don't know in advance what the endings in real life will be. Even Arthur C. Clarke will have to wait to find out what really happens in 2001.

lead_paragraph: BECOMING THE BUTLERS. By Pamela Brandt. (Bantam, $19.95)
abstract:
BECOMING THE BUTLERS. By Pamela Brandt. (Bantam, $19.95)

 Pamela Brandt's first novel begins originally and unpredictably. In a snappy, wisecracking voice, Rachel Harris, the 15-year-old heroine and narrator, tells of her mother's reckless flight to Spain with the superintendent of the family's apartment building on Manhattan's Upper West Side. Rachel and James, her devastated and drunken father, follow the runaways to Madrid, fail to bring them back, and return together to make what they can of their sadly incomplete domestic life. Rachel's father invites the super's helpless, Spanish-speaking wife and many noisy children to move into the Harris apartment; he seems to hope that, by adopting the super's family, he might somehow be transformed into the super. Rachel, obsessed with the two perfect children of a family named Butler, classmates at the private school they all attend, tries to become one of them. For Rachel is just as misguided as her father, believing that all her problems will be solved if she can be as rich, blond, poised and perfectly groomed as the Butlers. Needless to say, both James and Rachel learn the emptiness of strategies. "So I never did become a Butler," Rachel tells us at the novel's close, "and James couldn't change himself into a Spanish painter and woo my mother back. We never became what we hoped to be, but instead became better versions of ourselves." This insight is, unfortunatley, typical of Rachel; it is hardly new or surprising, and it is delivered in a voice of remarkable flatness. The smart and sassy girl we met at the beginnning of "Becoming the Butlers" soon becomes a very ordinary adolescent whose faith in the banal is expressed in bland and boring teen-age talk. The unpredictable and mad flight to Spain that begins the novel promises something new -- but the tame passages that follow it, and the sane compromise that ends it, fail to deliver on that promise.

snippet: Adam Goodheart roundup of travel books for summer reading; drawing (M)
lead_paragraph: IT'S been almost 20 years since Paul Fussell, in a curmudgeonly book called ''Abroad,'' declared that travel writing was a genre on its last legs, ready to go the way of courtship novels and pastoral eclogues. It had to, for the world had shrunk and the adventure of travel itself (picture Lord Byron setting sail for the Greek islands, draped in tragic glory) had been replaced everywhere by its degraded facsimile, tourism (picture herds of cruise ship passengers setting sail for those same islands, draped in Hard Rock Cafe T-shirts).

keywords: [{'name': 'persons', 'value': 'AAKHUS, PATRICIA', 'rank': 1, 'major': 'N'}, {'name': 'subject', 'value': 'BOOK REVIEWS', 'rank': 2, 'major': 'N'}, {'name': 'creative_works', 'value': "VOYAGE OF MAEL DUIN'S CURRAGH, THE (BOOK)", 'rank': 3, 'major': 'N'}]
snippet: Unknown
lead_paragraph: THE VOYAGE OF MAEL DUIN'S CURRAGH. By Patricia Aakhus. (Story Line Press, Paper, $12.95.) While the story elements central to Greek mythology have remained relatively stable, the oral tradition of Irish storytelling has frequently produced legends that have subtly shifted over time. Such is the case with the tale of Mael Duin, an ancient story of a questing son who sets out in a skin-covered boat called a curragh with a crew of 16 men in order to avenge his father's death. What he finds, as he travels in strange seas, is one bizarre and surrealistic island after another. In a series of dreamlike passages, the men encounter an impassable bridge of glass, giant insects, rivers of fire, strange sacrifices and rituals, and such sights as a small island inhabited by two flocks of sheep, one white and one black, with a brass fence dividing them. The first written fragments of this legend, which the writer and literary critic Frank O'Connor called ''autonomous and primary in the way of Greek and Hebrew literature,'' occur in medieval Irish Christian manuscripts. The monks who recorded the story in ''The Yellow Book of Lecan'' gave it a religious spin, incorporating God's will into the narrative. This shift, notes Patricia Aakhus in a useful introduction to her version of the quest, ''robs the story of dramatic tension.'' More recently, Victorian Celtic revivalists with another agenda cleansed the text of its pagan - and earthy - elements. Now, in this version by an American teacher, writer and actress, pagan elements are properly restored and superfluous additions have been stripped away. What remains is a scholarly yet exciting and vivid rendition of the voyage of Mael Duin, one that has never before been accessible to those without fluent Old Irish. It rings true, and that's what becomes a legend most.
abstract: LEAD:    THE VOYAGE OF MAEL DUIN'S CURRAGH. By Patricia Aakhus. (Story Line Press, Paper, $12.95.) While the story elements central to Greek mythology have remained relatively stable, the oral tradition of Irish storytelling has frequently produced legends that have subtly shifted over time. Such is the case with the tale of Mael Duin, an ancient story of a questing son who sets out in a skin-covered boat called a curragh with a crew of 16 men in order to avenge his father's death.

lead_paragraph: (Editors' choices of other recent books of particular interest)
abstract: (Editors' choices of other recent books of particular interest)    JAY'S JOURNAL OF ANOMALIES, by Ricky Jay. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $40.) The contents of the 16 issues of Jay's handsome and handsomely researched historical quarterly of the same title about magicians and unusual performers, like the armless and legless bowler Matthew Buchinger and the multiple crucifixion victim Chami Khan.    THE PICKUP, by Nadine Gordimer. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $24.) A chance meeting between a rich, white, South African woman and an immigrant from a Muslim country turns into a love affair that suggests two cultures in quest of each other and the uses of mutual incomprehension for mutual attraction.    READING CHEKHOV: A Critical Journey, by Janet Malcolm. (Random House, $23.95.) A gifted journalist's elegant excursion through and around Chekhov, finding ''wild and strange'' objects in his stories where others have often sighted only delicacy, modesty and candid, well-behaved shades of gray.    THE WAR AGAINST CLICHÉ: Essays and Reviews, 1971-2000, by Martin Amis. (Talk Miramax/Hyperion, $35.) Strong opinions and easily ignited aggression by an energetic stylist who mounts a powerful defense of Philip Larkin and declares ''The Adventures of Augie March'' his second-favorite novel ever.    WHAT EVOLUTION IS, by Ernst Mayr. (Basic Books, $26.) A wise and illuminating examination, by an illustrious evolutionary biologist, that sorts out the complexities of evolution -- as the author calls it, ''perhaps the greatest intellectual revolution experienced by mankind'' -- with insight and authority.    POEMS SEVEN: New and Complete Poetry, by Alan Dugan. (Seven Stories, $35.) A big volume by a major poet (it won a National Book Award this year) whose life work is adult matter, full of conviction and void of easy poses; its great theme is human pettiness exposed yet dignified by mortality.    CHRIST: A Crisis in the Life of God, by Jack Miles. (Knopf, $26.95.) The author of ''God: A Biography'' (1995) continues his examination of God strictly as a literary character -- a complex, contradictory one who learns about himself from his interactions with humans; in becoming one himself, God accepts and expiates his guilt for his errors since the Creation.    BAD ELEMENTS: Chinese Rebels From Los Angeles to Beijing, by Ian Buruma. (Random House, $27.95.) Conversations with Chinese dissidents around the world, beginning in the West and concluding in parts of China; they show a widespread desire for democracy that is not necessarily adapted to prevail.    THE BIRDS OF HEAVEN: Travels With Cranes, by Peter Matthiessen. (North Point, $27.50.) A veteran celebrant of nature's provision and a travel writer who defies every element searches out the world's 15 (11 endangered) species of cranes, observing with great passion and scrupulous attention to detail; splendidly illustrated by Robert Bateman.

snippet: Amity Shlaes argues that Roosevelt and his big government programs did nothing to end the Depression.
lead_paragraph: In the 1930s, the Schechter brothers ran a chicken business in Brooklyn. The name Schechter is derived from the Yiddish word for “butcher,” and this is what the brothers did: they slaughtered chickens and sold them to shops. The brothers seemed to be typical immigrants, at once struggling and succeeding.

keywords: [{'name': 'glocations', 'value': 'China', 'rank': 1, 'major': 'N'}, {'name': 'subject', 'value': 'Books and Literature', 'rank': 2, 'major': 'N'}, {'name': 'persons', 'value': 'Bergreen, Laurence', 'rank': 3, 'major': 'N'}, {'name': 'persons', 'value': 'Polo, Marco', 'rank': 4, 'major': 'N'}]
snippet: A biography of Marco Polo reanimates the exploits of a champion traveler.
lead_paragraph: Here’s a lesson in the graceful acceptance of defeat. In 1298, the Genoese navy bested the Venetian fleet at the Battle of Curzola. Unable to live with the disgrace, one Venetian commander, Andrea Dandolo, killed himself by beating his head against his ship’s mast. Another Venetian leader, Marco Polo, surrendered calmly, was taken prisoner and spent a few years writing his memoirs in comfortable captivity. Dandolo’s fame died on the deck; Polo’s will outlive our grandchildren. Few famous names have as much vagueness attached to their exploits, though. Marco Polo opened Asia to European trade, so we’re told, but we generally don’t know much else. Laurence Bergreen remedies that by bolstering Polo’s reputation and arguing for his historical importance in a book as enthralling as a rollicking travel journal. Bergreen, who has written biographies of Louis Armstrong, James Agee and Irving Berlin, turned his attention to ancient explorers with “Over the Edge of the World,” which tracked Ferdinand Magellan’s circumnavigation of the globe. I was a fan of that book, but “Marco Polo” far outshines it, and not surprisingly. Marco Polo, unlike Magellan, left his biographers a masterpiece of a memoir to work with.

byline: {'original': 'By Scott Veale', 'person': [{'firstname': 'Scott', 'middlename': None, 'lastname': 'Veale', 'qualifier': None, 'title': None, 'role': 'reported', 'organization': '', 'rank': 1}], 'organization': None}
snippet: Unknown
lead_paragraph: Anything Your Little Heart Desires:
abstract: Anything Your Little Heart Desires:   An American Family Story   By Patricia Bosworth.   Touchstone/Simon & Schuster, $15.    The daughter of Bartley C. Crum, the famous corporate lawyer of the 1940's and 50's and champion of leftist causes, tracks the dazzling arc of her father's life, including his undoing by his personal and political furies. Last year our reviewer, Richard Lingeman, called this a ''multilayered act of discovery and reconciliation . . . in which redemption comes from the truth of the telling.''    Underworld   By Don DeLillo. Scribner, $16.    This sprawling wake for the cold war explores how people rearranged their lives around the moral void of Mutual Assured Destruction, with its attending terror and absurdity. Selected by the editors of the Book Review as one of the best books of 1997, the novel spans half a century, from its opening in 1951 at one of baseball's legendary games to its epilogue in central Asia. The characters -- both fictional and cultural heroes like Frank Sinatra and Lenny Bruce -- are psychological fallout victims. '' 'Underworld' surges with magisterial confidence,'' Martin Amis said here last year. ''It isn't every day, or even every decade, that one sees the ascension of a great writer.''    Resurrection: The Struggle for a New Russia   By David Remnick. Vintage, $15.    The author argues that the Russian people have had their fill of Boris N. Yeltsin and the oligarchs who gained power after his re-election in 1996. ''As a gifted journalist, with an eye for the broad themes as well as the telling details of a story, he provides us with an amplitude of particulars'' about the miseries that have occurred during Yeltsin's reign of deception and criminality, Abraham Brumberg wrote here last year. The thesis of Petersburg, Crucible of Cultural Revolution, by Katerina Clark (Harvard University, $18.95), is that the city's idealistic artists and intellectuals during the tumultuous years between 1913 and 1931 created an atmosphere that made the Great Terror of the late 1930's possible. This revisionist account is ''a major contribution to the cultural history of this seminal period,'' Harlow Robinson said in the Book Review in 1995.    The Blessing   By Nancy Mitford. Carroll & Graf, $10.95.    This spirited riff on French-British relations on the highest social plane pits a beautiful English wife and her charming French nobleman husband against a diabolical villain: their young son. The result is a ''cunningly constructed, artfully written . . . farce of the most civilized kind,'' Elizabeth Janeway wrote here in 1951.    Imagining Robert. My Brother, Madness,   and Survival: A Memoir   By Jay Neugeboren. Owl/Holt, $14.95.    A novelist describes his younger brother's 30-year battle with mental illness, and his own struggle to navigate the nightmarish system of mistreatment and inattentive care that dooms many victims of schizophrenia and manic-depressive disorder. This is a ''powerful story,'' Frederick Busch said in these pages in 1997. In Out of the Shadows: Confronting America's Mental Illness Crisis, by E. Fuller Torrey (Wiley, $16.95), a psychiatrist reports that millions of Americans are suffering from severe mental illness without treatment. ''The crisis he delineates should stir any halfway sensitive human being to anger,'' Daniel J. Kevles wrote here last year.    The Underground Man   By Mick Jackson. Penguin, $12.95.    This first novel focuses on one of Victorian England's most famous eccentrics, the real-life fifth Duke of Portland, who built an elaborate network of tunnels beneath his lands to allow him hidden access to all parts of his realm. ''Jackson has produced a marvelous study of human foibles,'' Erik Burns said here in 1997.    Bear and His DaughTer: Stories   By Robert Stone. Mariner/Houghton Mifflin, $12.    The novelist's first collection of short fiction is populated by men who feel most alive when they are angry. In evoking a kind of grinding male arrest, ''Stone turns the scraps and figments of style that we call characters into real people,'' James Wood wrote here last year.    Never Eat Your Heart Out   By Judith Moore. North Point, $13.    A California writer and editor expresses her life story through the food she has prepared, peppering her lively account with bite-sized essays on everything from the history of the cranberry to the sex life of turkeys. Last year our reviewer, Susan Cheever, called this a ''tart, satisfying'' memoir.    The Teachings of Don B.: Satires, Parodies, Fables,  Illustrated Stories, and Plays of Donald Barthelme   Edited by Kim Herzinger. Vintage International, $15.    Whether a parody of Bret Easton Ellis or a shaggy dog story about a 4,000-pound Gouda cheese, the 63 pieces collected here bristle with the author's delight in surprising the reader with his genre-jumping acrobatics. The result is ''a small education in laughter, melancholy and the English language,'' James Marcus wrote here in 1992. A Dog's Head, by Jean Dutourd, translated by Robin Chancellor (University of Chicago, $12), is a slender Barthelmesque fantasy about a middle-class Frenchman born with the tete of a spaniel. This satirical novel is ''sad-eyed, witty and often very funny,'' C. J. Rolo wrote here in 1953.   Scott Veale

lead_paragraph: Additional titles of interest:
abstract: Additional titles of interest:    JOHNNY APPLESEED. By Reeve Lindbergh. Illustrated by Kathy Jakobsen. Joy Street/Little, Brown. $14.95. (Ages 4 to 9) The primitive-style illustrations, with details of quilt motifs in the borders, carry a narrative poem about John Chapman along briskly. The endpapers show a map, decorated with blooming apple trees, in which the states he walked through -- from Massachusetts to Indiana -- are outlined in fruit.   THE RANDOM HOUSE BOOK OF SPORTS STORIES. Selected by L. M. Schulman. Illustrated by Thomas B. Allen. Random House. $15.95. (Ages 8 and up) Is there a young athlete in your house who complains about nothing to read? A collection of sporting stories that includes the work of Roger Angell, Ring Lardner, Jack London, William Saroyan and William Faulkner is a guaranteed winner. It is a wonderful collection for reading aloud with older children, couch potatoes or team captains.   A NEW TREASURY OF POETRY. Selected by Neil Philip. Illustrated by John Lawrence. Stewart, Tabori & Chang. $25. (All ages) This heavy, handsome new selection of generally familiar British and American poetry is illustrated with unusually sophisticated wood engravings. It is a presentation volume, best left unshelved, to read aloud.

snippet: Unknown
lead_paragraph: ROADS: Driving America's Great Highways, by Larry McMurtry. (Touchstone/Simon & Schuster, $13.) This prolific author (23 novels and counting) cracks open a door on his own life as he crisscrosses the country, ruminating on anything that comes to his eye or mind. The mix includes odd facts, tributes to literary and historical figures and a quizzical look at the books in Hemingway's house in Key West. ''He has a reporter's eye, an affectionate ear for everyday speech and . . . a Dickensian storyteller's facility,'' Timothy Foote wrote here last year. Touchstone has also reissued Walter Benjamin at the Dairy Queen: Reflections at Sixty and Beyond ($12), a collection of personal essays in which McMurtry recalls his Texas childhood and laments what he sees as his failure to ''subvert'' some grand fallacies about the West. In 1999 our reviewer, Thomas Mallon, called this ''part memoir, part commonplace book, part tour de force.''
abstract: ROADS: Driving America's Great Highways, by Larry McMurtry. (Touchstone/Simon & Schuster, $13.) This prolific author (23 novels and counting) cracks open a door on his own life as he crisscrosses the country, ruminating on anything that comes to his eye or mind. The mix includes odd facts, tributes to literary and historical figures and a quizzical look at the books in Hemingway's house in Key West. ''He has a reporter's eye, an affectionate ear for everyday speech and . . . a Dickensian storyteller's facility,'' Timothy Foote wrote here last year. Touchstone has also reissued Walter Benjamin at the Dairy Queen: Reflections at Sixty and Beyond ($12), a collection of personal essays in which McMurtry recalls his Texas childhood and laments what he sees as his failure to ''subvert'' some grand fallacies about the West. In 1999 our reviewer, Thomas Mallon, called this ''part memoir, part commonplace book, part tour de force.''    A PLACE ON EARTH: (Revision), by Wendell Berry. (Counterpoint, $14.) First published in 1967 and reissued in 1983 in this compressed version, this novel by a renowned poet tells the interwoven stories of a dozen or so people in a rural Kentucky town at the close of World War II. The final result, which displays ''the tenderness one would like to imagine God has as he watches a human community act and interact,'' is ''a masterpiece,'' Noel Perrin wrote here.    MILLIONAIRE: The Philanderer, Gambler, and Duelist Who Invented Modern Finance, by Janet Gleeson. (Touchstone/Simon & Schuster, $13.) John Law was a Scotsman who introduced 18th-century France both to paper currency and to irrational exuberance on a grand scale, through a speculative venture to colonize the Mississippi River basin. Guess what? The bubble burst. The author's ''eye for sensual detail allows her to recreate vividly the opulent world of French Regency society,'' Diana B. Henriques wrote here in 2000.    THE QUESTION OF BRUNO, by Aleksandar Hemon. (Vintage International, $12.) In seven stories and a novella, the author evokes his homeland, Bosnia, and the Yugoslavia that dominated his youth back when the region was a hopeful place, as well as his émigré life in the United States. Hemon's appetite is ''insatiable and wild,'' Richard Eder said here last year, whether he writes about the assassination of Archduke Franz Ferdinand or a semifictional history of his own family. ''Several of the shorter pieces are so good as to make the reader feel certain of having discovered'' a writer ''who seems not simply gifted but necessary.''    I, FELLINI, by Charlotte Chandler. (Cooper Square, $19.95.) The Federico Fellini who dominates this biography is a conversational performance artist: talkative, beguiling and canny in recounting his life and passions. ''Fellini's storytelling races with the kind of high spirits familiar from his films,'' W. S. Di Piero wrote here in 1995.    ARSLAN, by M. J. Engh. (Orb/Tom Doherty, $14.95.) In this 1976 science fiction tale, a young Asian general conquers the world without firing a shot and sets up headquarters in a small Illinois town, where he begins his reign by publicly raping a girl and boy. Against all odds, the author makes the monstrous Arslan sympathetic and his conquest plausible, Gerald Jonas wrote in the Book Review: ''Engh's performance is as perversely flawless as Arslan's.''    QUITTING THE NAIROBI TRIO, by Jim Knipfel. (Berkley, $13.) The author recounts his six-month confinement in a Minneapolis psychiatric ward after repeated suicide attempts, and his long climb back to relative mental health, depicting the uselessness of psychiatrists and the virtues of self-help. The result ''is a zany lark of a read'' by ''a gifted stylist with a truly original take on things,'' Daphne Merkin wrote here in 2000. Of Two Minds: An Anthropologist Looks at American Psychiatry, by T. M. Luhrmann (Vintage, $14), is a study of how aspiring doctors learn psychiatry and of how mental illness has come to be seen as more a matter of biological dysfunction (best treated by drugs) than the product of psychosocial factors (best treated by psychotherapy). Last year our reviewer, Stephen S. Hall, admired the author's ''cleareyed intellectual analysis'' and ''shrewd, witty observations.''    REAP, by Eric Rickstad. (Penguin, $13.) Set in Vermont's rugged Northeast Kingdom, this first novel tells of a lonely boy who takes up with a crew of dope farmers and scammers, with dangerous repercussions. Though the violence is persuasive, Jennifer Schuessler said here last year, ''most remarkable is the evocation of the territory, the gothic tangle of native forest and exotic cash crop that mirrors the claustrophobic inner landscapes.''   Scott Veale

keywords: [{'name': 'persons', 'value': 'Stern, Howard Howard Stern', 'rank': 1, 'major': 'N'}, {'name': 'subject', 'value': 'Reviews', 'rank': 2, 'major': 'N'}, {'name': 'subject', 'value': 'Books and Literature', 'rank': 3, 'major': 'N'}, {'name': 'creative_works', 'value': 'MISS AMERICA (BOOK)', 'rank': 4, 'major': 'N'}]
snippet: Unknown
lead_paragraph: Many people already know everything there is to know about the contents of Howard Stern's MISS AMERICA (Regan Books, $27.50), the cover of which shows Mr. Stern in drag on the front and in a tuxedo hobnobbing with O. J. Simpson on the back. Inside, the jacket tells us, you'll find details of Mr. Stern's secret meeting with Michael Jackson and his pact with Adolf Hitler, as well as 40 pictures of naked breasts, so there is little point in discussing the literary merits here. But what readers may take for granted is the book's design, a complex melange of typographic hierarchies. It is a remarkable display of deconstructive, post-structural, post-modern experimentation -- or to put it simply for the layman, words explode across the page. The text and binding were designed by Chip Kidd and Nina Gaskin; the jacket and the inserted color section were designed by Jack Heller (no relation) and Ralph Cirella. Each of the 482 pages is a distinct design experience. But this kind of expressive typography is not new. In 1918 Guillaume Apollinaire published an antiwar poem, "Il Pleut," with lines of type falling down the page simulating a rainstorm; in 1914 F. T. Marinetti wrote and designed the Futurist book "Zang Tumb Tuuuum," using discordant typefaces designed to visually approximate the sounds that he described in words; and in 1967 Quentin Fiore gave a visual voice to Marshall McLuhan's "Medium Is the Massage" through a rebuslike integration of word and image complemented by shifts in typographic size and weight. In 1970 Mr. Fiore brought the same kinetic type and page design to Jerry Rubin's book "Do It!," to which "Miss America" owes a distinct debt. Unfortunately, "Miss America" really doesn't go as far as some of these books. While the design shouts and screams, by the standards of other 20th-century books it is actually pretty timid. STEVEN HELLER

J. Simpson on the  back. Inside, the jacket tells us, you'll find details of Mr. Stern's secret meeting with Michael Jackson and his pact with Adolf Hitler, as well as 40 pictures of naked breasts, so there is little point in discussing the literary merits here. But what readers may take for granted is the book's design, a complex melange of typographic hierarchies. It is a remarkable display of deconstructive, post-structural, post-modern experimentation -- or to put it simply for the layman, words explode across the page. The text and binding were  designed by Chip Kidd and Nina Gaskin; the jacket and the inserted color section were designed by Jack Heller (no relation) and Ralph Cirella. Each of the 482 pages is a distinct design experience. But this kind of expressive typography is not new. In 1918 Guillaume Apollinaire published an antiwar poem, "Il Pleut," with lines of type falling down the page simulating a rainstorm; in 1914 F. T. Marinetti wrote and designed the Futurist book "Zang Tumb Tuuuum," using discordant typefaces designed to visually approximate the sounds that he described in words; and in 1967 Quentin Fiore gave a visual voice to Marshall McLuhan's "Medium Is the Massage" through a rebuslike integration of word and image complemented by shifts in typographic size and weight. In 1970 Mr. Fiore brought the same kinetic type and page design to Jerry Rubin's book "Do It!," to which "Miss America" owes a distinct debt. Unfortunately, "Miss America" really  doesn't go as far as some of these books. While the design shouts and screams, by the standards of other 20th-century books it is actually pretty timid. keywords: [{'name': 'persons', 'value': 'Huxley, Aldous', 'rank': 1, 'major': 'N'}, {'name': 'subject', 'value': 'Books and Literature', 'rank': 2, 'major': 'N'}, {'name': 'subject', 'value': 'Writing and Writers', 'rank': 3, 'major': 'N'}]
snippet: A book of letters, many previously unpublished, reinforces the impression that Aldous Huxley was attracted to eccentric ideas.
lead_paragraph: Aldous Huxley began his literary career on the edge of Bloomsbury and ended it in Beverly Hills, the prophet of a dystopian future and advocate of LSD. Huxley was so preoccupied by the dangers threatening civilization that he could not rouse himself to defend it. The reader of this engrossing collection of letters, many previously unpublished, is dismayed to find him refusing to sign a declaration against Hitler — never mind fight — a few weeks after the outbreak of war, because “I do not feel that politics ... are my affair,” except “such politics as are dictated by the need to ‘make the world safe for mystical experience.’ ” Support from Bloomsbury old boys was not lacking: “Have you yet read [Bertrand] Russell’s new book, ‘Which Way to Peace’?” he asked a correspondent in 1936, as the Nazis prepared to trample over Europe. “It is a most admirably lucid argument leading by remorseless logic to the complete pacifist position.”

lead_paragraph: Stories about cowardice can be as gripping as those about courage. One tells us about who we’d like to be; the other tells us about who we fear we are.

snippet: Unknown
lead_paragraph: SPEAK NOW AGAINST THE DAY: The Generation Before the Civil Rights Movement in the South By John Egerton. Chapel Hill Books/University of North Carolina, $18.95.
abstract: SPEAK NOW AGAINST THE DAY: The Generation Before the Civil Rights Movement in the South By John Egerton. Chapel Hill Books/University of North Carolina, $18.95.    The author demonstrates how deeply entrenched Southern racism was in the years between 1932 and 1954, and pays tribute to the men and women who spoke out against bigotry when it was unpopular and often dangerous to do so. "His book is a stunning achievement: a sprawling, engrossing, deeply moving account," Charles B. Dew said here earlier this year.  BLOOD TIE By Mary Lee Settle. Mary Lee Settle Collection/University of South Carolina, $12.95.    Winner of a National Book Award for fiction, this novel takes place in Ceramos, on the coast of Turkey, where a number of American and European expatriates have gathered. Ranging from an ardent young archeologist to posturing tourists, these travelers are hoping for change, which comes in ways unforeseen and destructive. In 1977 The New York Times's reviewer, Anatole Broyard, said of the author, "Even for an experienced novelist . . . she has done a remarkable job of capturing the culture that is, in a sense, the most important character in her book." The same publisher is also restoring to print a number of Ms. Settle's other novels, all with new introductions by the author. CELEBRATION ($12.95) again evokes the problems of Turkey, where the heroine, Teresa Cerrutti, has done anthropological work. Recovering from cancer and the loss of her husband, she flees to London, where she falls in love with another troubled scholar. The "novel opens with intriguing power," William Boyd said in these pages in 1986. THE LOVE EATERS/THE KISS OF KIN ($14.95) unites Ms. Settle's first and second novels in one volume. "The Love Eaters," the story of a small-town theater troupe and two newcomers who change the thespians' lives, shows "a vigorous dramatic sense," Edmund Fuller said in The New York Times in 1955. "The Kiss of Kin" deals with the members of a Southern family gathered for the reading of a will. Each hoping for a bequest, they find that the deceased had her own vision of their future. In 1956 The Times's reviewer, Charlotte Capers, said, "The author . . . draws her portraits with skill." THE CLAM SHELL ($12.95), first published in 1971, focuses on a teen-age girl whose date attempts to rape her. Ms. Settle later revealed that the novel was autobiographical.  TRANSFORMING WOMEN'S WORK: New England Lives in the Industrial Revolution By Thomas Dublin. Cornell University, $15.95.    Female wage earners were a rarity in the United States until the 19th century, when mills and factories began to lure young women. This study shows that their independence was hard won and perhaps undermined by family obligations. "The data provide the single most detailed description of women and work a century ago," John Mack Faragher said here last year.  PRESUMPTION: An Entertainment. A Sequel to "Pride and Prejudice" By Julia Barrett. University of Chicago, $11.95.    Jane Austen's characters live again, although perhaps not as decorously. While Darcy's younger sister, Georgiana, tries to decide between two suitors, Elizabeth's aunt is arrested for shoplifting. The machinations of the plot "are energetically and often quite delightfully handled," Robert Grudin wrote in the Book Review in 1993.  THIRTEEN: The Apollo Flight That Failed By Henry S. F. Cooper Jr. Johns Hopkins University, $13.    This account of the doomed lunar mission, now back in print, may attract new readers who were entranced by the film "Apollo 13" last summer. Writing not long after the incident itself, Mr. Cooper explained the technology in laymen's terms while re-creating the drama of the astronauts' narrow escape. "You won't put the book down," Joseph McElroy said in these pages in 1973.  SUMMER LIGHT By Roxana Robinson. Hardscrabble/University Press of New England, $12.95.     Laura, a photographer who is estranged from her husband, allows him to spend a weekend at the vacation home she is sharing in Maine. With her are not only the couple's small son, but also Laura's lover and her sister's family. "All of Ms. Robinson's characters are artfully delineated," Michele Wolf wrote here in 1988.  THE RECKONING: The Murder of Christopher Marlowe By Charles Nicholl. University of Chicago, $14.95.    Was Shakespeare's young rival really killed by a lone swordsman, or was there an Elizabethan conspiracy afoot that would have intrigued Oliver Stone? The author concludes the latter. Last year our reviewer, A. L. Rowse, was not convinced, but noted that "Mr. Nicholl has done a great deal of praiseworthy research into everybody and everything."  THE VACANT CHAIR: The Northern Soldier Leaves Home By Reid Mitchell. Oxford University, $12.95.    The author draws on the letters and diaries written by Union soldiers during the Civil War to demonstrate how family bonds and community ties shaped their attitudes. "The variety of experience and expression among the individuals he quotes is truly fascinating," David Haward Bain said here in 1994.  REAL CHOICES/NEW VOICES: The Case for Proportional Representation Elections in the United States By Douglas J. Amy. Columbia University, $16.50.    The author argues that democracy would be better served if legislative representatives were elected according to the proportion of votes their parties received in each district. This is "a revelatory book that people serious about politics or social policy could wisely set aside the time to read," Ronnie Dugger wrote in the Book Review in 1993. LAUREL GRAEBER

lead_paragraph: A quick glance at C. D. Wright’s résumé confirms her position as a major American poet  a dozen critically praised books; the requisite laundry list of awards, grants and prizes; a day job teaching literature at Brown University  but in her case, predictable bullet points like these may be somewhat misleading, since C. D. Wright is now, and has been for decades, a uniquely unpredictable poet.

snippet: Marilyn Stasio reviews books Sold Down the River by Barbara Hambly, Running Blind by Lee Child, Deadly Decisions by Kathy Reichs, First Fruits by Penelope Evans and Ellipsis by Stephen Greenleaf; drawing (M)
lead_paragraph: Four years after the 1831 slave revolt led by Nat Turner in Virginia, black Americans were still being worked like livestock and their white owners were even more fearful of insurrection. In a masterly piece of historical storytelling, Barbara Hambly calls up the horrors of slavery in SOLD DOWN THE RIVER (Bantam, $23.95), the fourth and most unsettling chapter in her remarkable series featuring Benjamin January, a freed slave whose Paris education earns him a living in New Orleans and whose refined sense of justice puts him in peril wherever he goes.
abstract: Marilyn Stasio reviews books Sold Down the River by Barbara Hambly, Running Blind by Lee Child, Deadly Decisions by Kathy Reichs, First Fruits by Penelope Evans and Ellipsis by Stephen Greenleaf; drawing (M)

snippet: In Natsuo Kirino’s novel, a juvenile killer on the run in Tokyo murders without conscience -- and only in retrospect attempts to invent a philosophy to explain his crime.
lead_paragraph: “Sprinkle in some Dostoyevsky or Nietzsche or whatever. ... Then sort of wrap it up like ‘Evangelion,’” the popular animated television series that pits paramilitary teenagers against enemy angels bent on destroying humankind. Worm, the cipher at the center of Natsuo Kirino’s disquieting and suspenseful novel “Real World” and a juvenile killer on the run, is directing Terauchi, one of the four girls who become his accessories, to write a manifesto to fit the crime he has committed. He’d like it to be “something creative” rather than “introspective,” a “cool” and “incomprehensible” poem or story. Otherwise, his readers might conclude he isn’t the disaffected nihilist he imagines himself to be. “It doesn’t have to be long,” Worm tells Terauchi, but it does have to be “better than what that killer Sakakibara wrote.”

keywords: [{'name': 'persons', 'value': 'Fisher, Barbara', 'rank': 1, 'major': 'N'}, {'name': 'persons', 'value': 'Hobbie, Douglas', 'rank': 2, 'major': 'N'}, {'name': 'subject', 'value': 'Books and Literature', 'rank': 3, 'major': 'N'}, {'name': 'subject', 'value': 'Reviews', 'rank': 4, 'major': 'N'}, {'name': 'creative_works', 'value': 'This Time Last Year (Book)', 'rank': 5, 'major': 'N'}]
snippet: Barbara Fisher reviews book This Time Last Year by Douglas Hobbie; drawing (S)1
lead_paragraph: Sudden death and early loss haunt the characters in Douglas Hobbie's sorrow-filled third novel, THIS TIME LAST YEAR (John Macrae/Holt, $23). Henry Ash, grieving for the loss of his daughter (a young woman who died from a lingering disease with slow and savage self-awareness), is spending the summer alone in Vermont. Henry's summer project is a study of Melville, Whitman and Dickinson entitled ''Loners.'' In his spare time, he reads James's novel of renunciation, ''The Ambassadors.'' His second wife, Elizabeth, while traveling in England, struggles to reconcile herself to the prospect of sharing Henry's grim new reality. In Vermont, Henry lives in a house once inhabited in body and now in spirit by Fitz, a man who was afraid to live his own life fully and who was felled before he could realize his best intentions. Also vacationing in Vermont is Helen, a book editor from New York who has recovered physically, but perhaps not emotionally, from breast cancer surgery. The lives not lived by the characters in this novel, like the lives not lived by the American eccentrics whose work Henry reads, call out for redress. While most of the narrative is told in Henry's constrained prose, some of it is reported in Fitz's confessional journal, in Elizabeth's detached postcards and in Helen's urgent telephone calls. Sadness, loneliness and loss have many voices. Yet all the voices in this carefully controlled and beautifully balanced novel fairly shout one message -- carpe diem. Barbara Fisher
abstract: Barbara Fisher reviews book This Time Last Year by Douglas Hobbie; drawing (S)1

snippet: Unknown
lead_paragraph: Dreamland
abstract: Dreamland  By Kevin Baker. HarperTorch, $6.99.    Set in lower Manhattan and Coney Island circa 1910, this wild novel is a stew of real-life and fictional gangsters, Tammany pols, labor reformers and carnival performers, all deployed in a sprawling plot that begins with the ill-advised rescue of a midget by a gangster named Kid Twist. '' 'Dreamland' is historical fiction at its most entertaining,'' Thomas Mallon said here in 1999.    Annals of the Former World  By John McPhee. Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $18.    This Pulitzer Prize-winning opus about North America's rockscape pulls together the author's four previous books on geological history (focusing on the continent's dramatic eastern and western extremes) and a new essay on the Midwest. The result is an orderly march through deep time, exposing a lode of science and digressions. In 1998 our reviewer, David Quammen, found McPhee an overly cautious tour guide, but said, ''There are gemlike sentences, richly rhythmic paragraphs, nicely burnished synecdoches, metaphors as pungent as wasabi and, behind those felicities, vast amounts of painstaking research.''    Who's Irish? Stories  By Gish Jen. Vintage Contemporaries, $12.    The helter-skelter of the American immigrant experience is the subject of these tales, most of which revolve around cross-cultural skirmishes between an older generation of Chinese and their more assimilated children. ''Jen's gift is for comedy that resonates, and sadnesses that arise with perfect timing from absurdities,'' Jean Thompson wrote here in 1999.    An Actor and His Time  By John Gielgud with John Miller and John Powell.  Applause, $16.95.    In his modest memoir, the British actor, who died last month at 96, reveals his passion for the theatrical life while offering breezy portraits of T. S. Eliot, Edith Evans, Marlon Brando and others in his varied and eccentric supporting cast. ''He recounts his past with the same urbanity and sensitivity that have characterized his art,'' Frank Rich wrote here in 1980.    Breath and Shadows  By Ella Leffland. Ballantine, $14.    At the core of this melancholic novel about three generations of a well-to-do Danish clan is the question of what we lose in a lifetime, and what we leave behind to prove we existed. The result is ''an exquisite and moving family saga,'' Brooks Hansen wrote here last year.    The Lustre of Our Country:  The American Experience of Religious Freedom  By John T. Noonan Jr. University of California, $17.95.    A federal judge chronicles America's pursuit of religious freedom and the difficulties of reconciling faith and politics. In 1998 our reviewer, Richard Wightman Fox, called this a ''very enlightening tour through a complex legal and religious history.''    Truth Comes in Blows: A Memoir  By Ted Solotaroff. Norton, $13.95.    An editor and critic recalls his difficult childhood in prewar New Jersey and his struggle to understand his brutish father, the emperor of a plate-glass business and a malignant force in the lives of his family. ''For all its pain and sadness, 'Truth Comes in Blows' is as touching as gratitude and forgiveness, as exhilarating as truth,'' David Margolick wrote here in 1998. Fathers, Sons, and Brothers: The Men in My Family, by Bret Lott (Washington Square/Pocket Books, $12.95), is a collection of autobiographical essays exploring the complex emotions of being a son, sibling and father. ''Lott observes and beautifully renders those small moments that can change a life,'' Andrea Cooper said here in 1997. ''He captures the rough-and-tumble of men growing up.''    Imani All Mine  By Connie Porter. Mariner/Houghton Mifflin, $12.    Tasha is an unwed teenage mother in a Buffalo ghetto where her promise is frustrated by daunting obstacles, including her neglectful parents and teachers and her own poor self-image. Last year our reviewer, Andrea Higbie, called this a ''beautifully realized novel.'' The same publisher has reissued Porter's first novel, All-Bright COURT ($12), which traces two decades of life in a community of black steelworkers who migrated to upstate New York from the rural South in the 1960's. ''Porter conveys the truth of her characters' lives,'' Anne Whitehouse said here in 1991.    Fleur de Leigh's Life of Crime  By Diane Leslie. Scribner, $12.    The 10-year-old heroine of this first novel, failing to gain the attention of her glamorous show-biz parents in 1950's Hollywood, turns for love to a procession of oddball nannies. The result is ''a delicious and disturbing'' coming-of-age story, Nina Sonenberg said here in 1999.    Writing New York: A Literary Anthology  Edited by Phillip Lopate.  Washington Square/Pocket Books, $22.95.    This hymn to New York City marshals more than 100 voices spanning two centuries, from Washington Irving to Tom Wolfe, Edgar Allan Poe to Dawn Powell. Lopate's ''excellent anthology'' includes ''writers who love crowds and writers who hang out alone and brood,'' Garrison Keillor wrote here in 1998.   Scott Veale

lead_paragraph: THE HERE AND NOW By Robert Cohen. 351 pp. New York: Scribner. $22. TOWARD the end of Robert Cohen's second novel, "The Here and Now," the narrator's best friend, Warren Pinsky, comes back to New York from Texas and remarks that he misses Jews. "Oh sure," he tells Sam Karnish, "we've got them in the Sun Belt, but down there it's like . . . well, you've seen it. Even the rabbis wear sweat suits."

snippet: PRETTY BIRDS. By Scott Simon. (Random House, $24.95.) Simon, the host of ''Weekend Edition'' on National Public Radio, draws on his background as a war correspondent in this searing first novel, which traces the experiences of a young sniper durin...
lead_paragraph: PRETTY BIRDS. By Scott Simon. (Random House, $24.95.) Simon, the host of "Weekend Edition" on National Public Radio, draws on his background as a war correspondent in this searing first novel, which traces the experiences of a young sniper during the siege of Sarajevo. Before the war, Irena Zaric is a typical cosmopolitan teenager: a star basketball player, obsessed with Sting, Lady Di and Johnny Depp, she sneaks an occasional joint and carries on a furtive, casual affair with her coach. Then the Serbs advance, intent on purging Bosnia of its Muslim population, and Irena flees across the river with her family. Simon is unsparing in his catalog of war's cruelties -- as the siege drags on, the Bosnians are reduced to burning furniture for fuel and eating the worms in their macaroni -- but his real achievement is in realizing that even as she trades a basketball for a rifle, Irena remains 17 years old, the kind of girl who packs purple nail polish and a teddy bear for her descent into hell. The result is a portrait of resilience, punctuated by mortar blasts and Clash songs, and a tragicomic study of the moral ambivalence war forces on its victims. "I'm kind of a pacifist," Irena tells the man who recruits her as a sniper. His reply: "So am I. When the world permits."
abstract: PRETTY BIRDS. By Scott Simon. (Random House, $24.95.) Simon, the host of ''Weekend Edition'' on National Public Radio, draws on his background as a war correspondent in this searing first novel, which traces the experiences of a young sniper during the siege of Sarajevo. Before the war, Irena Zaric is a typical cosmopolitan teenager: a star basketball player, obsessed with Sting, Lady Di and Johnny Depp, she sneaks an occasional joint and carries on a furtive, casual affair with her coach. Then the Serbs advance, intent on purging Bosnia of its Muslim population, and Irena flees across the river with her family. Simon is unsparing in his catalog of war's cruelties -- as the siege drags on, the Bosnians are reduced to burning furniture for fuel and eating the worms in their macaroni -- but his real achievement is in realizing that even as she trades a basketball for a rifle, Irena remains 17 years old, the kind of girl who packs purple nail polish and a teddy bear for her descent into hell. The result is a portrait of resilience, punctuated by mortar blasts and Clash songs, and a tragicomic study of the moral ambivalence war forces on its victims. ''I'm kind of a pacifist,'' Irena tells the man who recruits her as a sniper. His reply: ''So am I. When the world permits.''    THE BOWL IS ALREADY BROKEN. By Mary Kay Zuravleff. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $25.) Disaster strikes early in Zuravleff's genial comic novel, when a priceless Chinese bowl shatters on the steps of the Museum of Asian Art in Washington. Left to pick up the pieces is Promise Whittaker, the museum's acting director, but Promise has other things to worry about: she's unexpectedly pregnant, an employee is dipping into the museum's funds, and her predecessor has been kidnapped by terrorists in an Asian desert. Worse still, her bosses want to convert the building into a food court for the National Mall. The museum here is a barely disguised version of the Smithsonian's Freer and Sackler Galleries, where Zuravleff once worked, and she knows her material -- sometimes too well. But readers who can look past the pedantic lessons on Buddhism and art history will find a tart, affectionate satire of the museum world's bickering and scheming. ''People assumed that behind these walls, beautiful decisions were arrived at in an intelligent, courteous manner,'' Zuravleff writes. ''Let the record show it might as well be mud-wrestling.''

snippet: (Editors' choices of other recent books of particular interest)    THE GOOD NANNY, by Benjamin Cheever. (Bloomsbury, $23.95.) This impeccably detailed satire about the lit biz in New York involves a high-end Westchester couple (he a book editor, s...
lead_paragraph: (Editors' choices of other recent books of particular interest)
abstract: (Editors' choices of other recent books of particular interest)    THE GOOD NANNY, by Benjamin Cheever. (Bloomsbury, $23.95.) This impeccably detailed satire about the lit biz in New York involves a high-end Westchester couple (he a book editor, she a movie critic), their children and Louise Washington, an omnicompetent 37-year-old black nanny whose superiority rattles everyone. It ends in tears, also blood.    YOU REMIND ME OF ME, by Dan Chaon. (Ballantine, $24.95.) Back and forth over three decades, the two principal characters of Chaon's first novel -- half brothers, we soon perceive -- suffer the extraordinary fates that Chaon devises for otherwise ordinary people, whose families are attenuated and dispersed but never lose the unseen links that attach them, consciously or not, to one another.    POLITICS: Observations & Arguments, 1966-2004, by Hendrik Hertzberg. (Penguin Press, $29.95.) A collection of almost 40 years of articles by an incisive, durable observer whose chief watchtowers have been The New Yorker, The New Republic and Newsweek, and who is best when his product is color commentary in the Mencken-Kempton-Liebling-Buckley tradition.    MY NINE LIVES: Chapters of a Possible Past, by Ruth Prawer Jhabvala. (Shoemaker & Hoard, $25.) This novel -- actually a collection of stories -- follows much of the author's recent fiction in its bleak detachment; the actions belong to a world of displaced people, dropouts and eccentrics who have seen India's post-independence idealism die.    RED GROOMS, by Arthur C. Danto, Timothy Hyman and Marco Livingstone. (Rizzoli, $65.) A lavish celebration of the art of Red Grooms, creator of ''Ruckus Manhattan'' and much, much more, with hundreds of pictures, a couple of lively essays on the art and a penetrating interview by the British artist Timothy Hyman.    SIRIO: The Story of My Life and Le Cirque, by Sirio Maccioni and Peter Elliot. (Wiley, $29.95.) The career autobiography of the inventive gastronome who did much to insert Italian cooking into the world of haute cuisine in New York; he and his collaborator, Peter Elliot, have produced a kind of oral history more integrated than the usual as-told-to approach.    THE TYRANT'S NOVEL, by Thomas Keneally. (Nan A. Talese/Doubleday, $25.) The fearless Keneally, who in ''Confederates'' and ''Schindler's List'' ventured to comprehend in novels whole societies not his own, ventures more: in a country very like Iraq, ruled by a ''Great Uncle of the People'' mighty like Saddam Hussein, a fiction writer is ordered to produce, in one month, a novel to be published under the tyrant's own name. Bizarre consequences follow, as how could they not?    CALIBAN'S SHORE: The Wreck of the Grosvenor and the Strange Fate of Her Survivors, by Stephen Taylor. (Norton, $24.95.) A gripping real-life disaster story concerning the passengers and crew of a Britain-bound ship, wrecked on a nasty piece of Africa's southeast coast in 1782. Nobody, not even the captain, really knew what best to do next; of the 140 on board, 106 perished, more or less miserably.

snippet: TRAVEL, the cliché runs, is broadening. But is that really the most accurate description? Some of the new season's books would suggest a more universal truism: travel is never easy.    The Spanish grow olives, ''but the taste is so bitter, I am su...
lead_paragraph: TRAVEL, the cliché runs, is broadening. But is that really the most accurate description? Some of the new season's books would suggest a more universal truism: travel is never easy.
abstract: TRAVEL, the cliché runs, is broadening. But is that really the most accurate description? Some of the new season's books would suggest a more universal truism: travel is never easy.    The Spanish grow olives, ''but the taste is so bitter, I am sure you would not like it.'' In China, ''it is a common thing to stumble over the bodies of dead babies in the streets.'' The Irish, ''if affronted, are filled with rage.'' These withering pronouncements come from a Victorian writer named Mrs. Favell Lee Mortimer, perhaps the most uncharitable person ever to have emerged from the country that also brought us Simon Cowell and Jack the Ripper. In THE CLUMSIEST PEOPLE IN EUROPE: Or, Mrs. Mortimer's Bad-Tempered Guide to the Victorian World (Bloomsbury, $19.95), the present-day writer and editor Todd Pruzan collects entries from three volumes of Mrs. Mortimer's wonderfully odious, travel-based misanthropy. Pruzan also provides some telling biographical details about Mortimer -- most notably that she left England only twice. Moreover, despite being a successful children's author whose Bible primer aimed at 4-year-olds sold a million copies, Mortimer led a life of utter misery. Her first great romantic attachment (to Henry Manning, who became Cardinal Manning) was unrequited; she later married a violent, cruel man from whom she often hid. To the modern eye, Mortimer's work -- by turns unsettling and hilarious -- is nothing short of a revolution in guidebook writing: here, at last, is irritable-bowel-syndrome-as-travelogue.

snippet: ONE afternoon in early October as my dog, Lizbeth, and I were returning to our bedroll, I saw a number of police cars parked on the quiet street to the east of our sleeping place. I passed the path to our place among the limbs of a fallen oak as c...
lead_paragraph: ONE afternoon in early October as my dog, Lizbeth, and I were returning to our bedroll, I saw a number of police cars parked on the quiet street to the east of our sleeping place. I passed the path to our place among the limbs of a fallen oak as casually as I could, considering that Lizbeth was straining on her leash, trying to make a beeline for our bedroll. When we were some distance past the path, I sat down on the grass and played with Lizbeth while I observed the police.
abstract:
ONE afternoon in early October as my dog, Lizbeth, and I were returning to our bedroll, I saw a number of police cars parked on the quiet street to the east of our sleeping place. I passed the path to our place among the limbs of a fallen oak as casually as I could, considering that Lizbeth was straining on her leash, trying to make a beeline for our bedroll. When we were some distance past the path, I sat down on the grass and played with Lizbeth while I observed the police. 

This was the 10th month since Lizbeth and I had become homeless and nearly two years since I had left my job as an attendant at a mental institution in Austin, Tex. In that time the police had dislodged us from several camps and had assisted in seizing Lizbeth when she was accused of biting a blind student. I knew the police would surely do us no good if they discovered we were sleeping on public park land.

snippet: Unknown
lead_paragraph: THE BOOK OF SECRETS By M. G. Vassanji. 337 pp. New York: Picador USA. $24. THE "book of our secrets" is the name the village elders use for the journal they see a young British administrator writing in so earnestly every evening. The book, they say, is full of captured spirits. The elders are Muslims, with their roots in India, and the village is in British East Africa, near the border of German territory. The time is the beginning of World War I. Before the war is over, the diary will be stolen and Alfred Corbin, the young administrator in his first foreign post, will be transferred away.

snippet: THE ICARUS PARADOX: How Exceptional Companies Bring About Their Own Downfall.  By Danny Miller. (Harper Business, $19.95.) The business manager's bible of the 1980's, "In Search of Excellence," pinpointed ways for companies to become more successf...
lead_paragraph: THE ICARUS PARADOX: How Exceptional Companies Bring About Their Own Downfall. By Danny Miller. (Harper Business, $19.95.) The business manager's bible of the 1980's, "In Search of Excellence," pinpointed ways for companies to become more successful, but it did not explain exactly why some very successful companies fail. In "The Icarus Paradox," Danny Miller, a Canadian professor of business administration, tackles the reasons for failure and develops the thesis that the very traits that make some highfliers so successful can later lead to their undoing. His message: Beware the "perils of excellence." Mr. Miller identifies four common "trajectories" that lead to corporate declines. "Craftsmen" like Digital Equipment's Ken Olsen focus so hard on their products that they become "tinkerers" and lose sight of their markets. "Builders" like I.T.T.'s Harold Geneen become so obsessed with expansion that they become out-of-control "imperialists." Inventor "pioneers" such as Polaroid's Edwin Land become "escapists" who lose sight of all business reality and develop impractical, exorbitant products. And "salesmen" -- brilliant marketers like those at Proctor & Gamble -- become "drifters" who start to believe they can sell anything, even the most mediocre products. Mr. Miller details the strategies of these companies and others, such as General Motors, I.B.M., A.& P. and Walt Disney, and then analyzes their declines (and, in some cases, their comebacks). He suggests ways to avoid similar troubles and even provides a detailed self-assessment questionnaire for readers. Unfortunately, the book reads like an academic thesis, because all of Mr. Miller's research is based on readings from various business publications, not his own legwork or interviews. But for executives concerned about maintaining the vitality and viability of their businesses, this book will provide some valuable insight into how to stay focused on the essential.

snippet: Gerald Jonas reviews books Finity and Apostrophes and Apocalypses, both by John Barnes; reviews book A Deepness in the Sky by Vernor Vinge (M)0
lead_paragraph: The hero of John Barnes's 1995 novel ''Kaleidoscope Century'' was a coldhearted hit man with one redeeming quality: he was marginally less nasty than a sadistic comrade in arms who took pleasure in ''serbing'' his female victims before dispatching them. Since Barnes has an undeniable knack for getting under the skin of his characters, it was perhaps inevitable that some readers had trouble distinguishing the author from his disturbing creations. My grudgingly positive review of ''Kaleidoscope Century'' ended with the hope that there would be no sequels. I am happy to report that FINITY (Tor/Tom Doherty, $22.95) is an altogether different kind of book.
abstract: Gerald Jonas reviews books Finity and Apostrophes and Apocalypses, both by John Barnes; reviews book A Deepness in the Sky by Vernor Vinge (M)0

keywords: [{'name': 'persons', 'value': 'Bunker, Edward', 'rank': 1, 'major': 'N'}, {'name': 'subject', 'value': 'Reviews', 'rank': 2, 'major': 'N'}, {'name': 'subject', 'value': 'Books and Literature', 'rank': 3, 'major': 'N'}, {'name': 'creative_works', 'value': 'ANIMAL FACTORY, THE (BOOK)', 'rank': 4, 'major': 'N'}]
snippet: Sia Michel reviews book The Animal Factory by Edward Bunker; drawing (S)
lead_paragraph: Edward Bunker's gritty prison novel, THE ANIMAL FACTORY (St. Martin's Minotaur, paper, $11.95), originally published in 1977, rings with an unsurprising authenticity. The author was in and out of the California penal system for 18 years and spent time in San Quentin, where he was first incarcerated as a baby-faced 17-year-old. Now the former bank robber and forger has become a cult icon of sorts, championed by filmmakers like Quentin Tarantino, who cast him in ''Reservoir Dogs,'' and Steve Buscemi, who adapted this book for a recent movie. Bunker's criminal past is embroidered into this melodrama about a handsome young middle-class cocaine dealer, Ronald Decker, who is sent to San Quentin for 10 years to life. Immediately beset by menacing suitors, Ron finds protection through a vaguely homoerotic father-son relationship with Earl Copen, a hard-timer who knows as much about Celine and Dostoyevsky as he does about scams and shivs. Both men are caught in prison's classic double bind: to get parole they have to play by the rules, but to stay alive they ''must follow the codes of the underworld.'' Of course, after a dehumanizing year of witnessing race wars, casual murder and sexual slavery, Ron is an animal who violently determines his chances, and Earl's, with the inevitability of Greek tragedy -- It had never been a matter of real choice,'' Earl says. Bunker, who is also the author of a memoir titled ''Education of a Felon,'' writes in plain, sometimes clumsy prose, yet his oddly honorable bad guys have a rich emotional complexity. His digressions on penal reform are impassioned, if redundant. What armchair gangsters will most enjoy are the details about prison culture -- from the price of a life in cigarettes to how inmates communicate through the toilet ''telephone'' system. Sia Michel
abstract: Sia Michel reviews book The Animal Factory by Edward Bunker; drawing (S)

headline: {'main': 'Books in Brief: FICTION & POETRY;Rumpole Returns', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Books in Brief: FICTION & POETRY;Rumpole Returns', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}
byline: {'original': 'By Brooke Allen', 'person': [{'firstname': 'Brooke', 'middlename': None, 'lastname': 'Allen', 'qualifier': None, 'title': None, 'role': 'reported', 'organization': '', 'rank': 1}], 'organization': None}
keywords: [{'name': 'persons', 'value': 'MORTIMER, JOHN JOHN CLIFFORD MORTIMER', 'rank': 1, 'major': 'N'}, {'name': 'subject', 'value': 'Reviews', 'rank': 2, 'major': 'N'}, {'name': 'subject', 'value': 'Books and Literature', 'rank': 3, 'major': 'N'}, {'name': 'creative_works', 'value': 'RUMPOLE AND THE ANGEL OF DEATH (BOOK)', 'rank': 4, 'major': 'N'}]
snippet: Unknown
lead_paragraph: First-rate comic writing is often more difficult to produce than the serious stuff, and real pros are few and far between. One of these is John Mortimer, an Englishman best known in this country for his mystery stories starring the comic and gallant barrister Horace Rumpole. Mr. Mortimer knows his territory, and his comments on the vagaries of the English legal system and the small value it places on common sense and moral standards are as sharp as ever in RUMPOLE AND THE ANGEL OF DEATH (Viking, $22.95), the 10th volume of stories in the series. In Rumpole, Mr. Mortimer has created a wonderfully durable and attractive character, henpecked as a husband but masterful with a jury, an honest man whose only cause is "preventing the conviction of the innocent." Rumpole's true home is the courtroom, but we are also made privy to life in the gloomy flat in Froxbury Mansions where he exists in pitiful thralldom to his wife, Hilda, otherwise known as She Who Must Be Obeyed. This moniker notwithstanding, the forbidding Hilda has occasional moments of decency, and Rumpole fans will be amused to find one story narrated by Hilda herself, in which she reveals surprisingly romantic yearnings as she contemplates an affair with a smarmy colleague of her husband's. In his happy ability to play a seemingly infinite number of diverting variations on the same theme, in the fluidity and panache of his prose, his combination of high intelligence and low foolery, John Mortimer is worthy of comparison to P. G. Wodehouse. "Rumpole and the Angel of Death," like all of the preceding Rumpole volumes, makes for ideally civilized light reading. Brooke Allen
abstract: First-rate comic writing is often more difficult to produce than the serious  stuff, and real pros are few and far between. One of these is John Mortimer, an  Englishman best known in this country for his mystery stories starring the comic and gallant barrister Horace Rumpole. Mr. Mortimer knows his territory, and his  comments on the vagaries of the English legal system and the small value it places on common sense and moral standards are as sharp as ever in RUMPOLE AND THE ANGEL OF DEATH (Viking, $22.95), the 10th volume of stories in the series. In Rumpole, Mr. Mortimer has created a wonderfully durable and attractive character, henpecked as a husband but masterful with a jury, an honest man whose only cause is "preventing the conviction of the innocent." Rumpole's true home is the courtroom, but we are also made privy to life in the gloomy flat in Froxbury Mansions where he exists in pitiful thralldom to his wife, Hilda, otherwise known as She Who Must Be Obeyed. This moniker notwithstanding, the forbidding Hilda has occasional moments of decency, and Rumpole fans will be amused to find one story narrated by Hilda herself, in which she reveals surprisingly romantic yearnings as she contemplates an affair with a smarmy colleague of her husband's. In his happy ability to play a seemingly infinite number of diverting variations on the same theme, in the fluidity and panache of his prose, his combination of high intelligence and low foolery, John Mortimer is worthy of comparison to P. G. Wodehouse. "Rumpole and the Angel of Death," like all of the preceding Rumpole volumes, makes for ideally civilized light reading.   Brooke Allen
