snippet: Henry Holt & Company, in its series "Scientific American Focus," has the rather interesting goal of taking areas of science that are likely to be in the  news or are generating controversy and making them clear to the average newspaper reader. The...
lead_paragraph: Henry Holt & Company, in its series "Scientific American Focus," has the rather interesting goal of taking areas of science that are likely to be in the news or are generating controversy and making them clear to the average newspaper reader. The first three volumes, all written by science journalists and each costing $22.50, are written in simple, straightforward language and are embellished with numerous photographs and diagrams. MEDICATION OF THE MIND, by Scott Veggeberg, grapples with one of the many deep and difficult problems uncovered by our new understanding that life depends, at bottom, on chemistry. Specialized molecules in the brain, called receptors, seem to govern our moods and general feelings, and drugs like Prozac, which affect molecular chemistry, are the first fruits of this new understanding. But as more and more illnesses are dealt with by manipulating the brain's chemistry, traditional mental health practitioners find themselves fighting a rear-guard action. COSMIC COLLISIONS, by Dana Desonie, takes on the bombardment of the earth by pieces of debris from interplanetary space. Starting with the Big Bang and the formation of the solar system, the book describes the historical process by which humans came to realize that large stones occasionally fall from the sky. My only problem was a sense that Ms. Desonie was trying too hard to make the subject relevant, perhaps underestimating its inherent interest and her own ability to spin a good story. THE LANGUAGE OF ANIMALS, by Stephen Hart, is full of interesting tidbits about the communication inherent in the feather displays of peacocks, the mechanisms for sound production in dolphins, and modern experiments on the language capabilities of chimpanzees. What is missing is a single coherent theme, or at least some direction as to which topics are sidelights and which bear on deep scientific questions. If these books are any indication of what is to come, I look forward to the next volumes with great anticipation. James Trefil

abstract: (Editors' choices of other recent books of particular interest)    THE MISSIONARY AND THE LIBERTINE: Love and War in East and West, by Ian Buruma. (Random House, $25.95.) snippet: Books about a restless little girl, an evening stroll and the city workers who start their jobs at bedtime.
lead_paragraph: I was never an easy sleeper. On restless childhood nights, I played a game: first I imagined a bird’s-eye view of the bed where I lay awake, then let the lens pull back to reveal the rooftop of my family’s house, then our town from above, then the silhouette of New Jersey, then America, and finally the whole world.

snippet: A prosecutor claims to have closed the (colossal) book on that day in November.
lead_paragraph: I have no idea what book wears the crown of longest nonfiction title ever published. Whoever holds the record, it is about to be challenged by Vincent Bugliosi, whose new work, “Reclaiming History,” a cellular-level re-examination of the assassination of President John F. Kennedy, clocks in at 1,612 pages. That’s not a typo. One thousand six hundred and twelve pages. Plus notes. On a CD-ROM. Bugliosi, best known as the prosecutor of Charles Manson and a co-author of the best seller “Helter Skelter” three decades ago, writes that his new offering, if chopped into books of 120,000 words each, would fill 13 full volumes. Note to editor: You owe me big time.

snippet: In Cathleen Schine’s fable of urban loneliness, dogs play the fairy godmothers.
lead_paragraph: One of the tenderest, least self-interested love scenes to have graced a page in a decade or so pops up a little more than halfway through Cathleen Schine’s latest novel, “The New Yorkers,” when Everett, a gruff, divorced 50-year-old chemist who has been conducting a lazy affair with a 26-year-old named Polly (she lives in his building), is bowled over by a wave of bliss. As Everett sits in his apartment, reading the paper and sipping a martini, a pair of warm eyes unexpectedly meets his, and his world turns from blasé to rosé. “Everett experienced an unfamiliar sensation,” Schine writes. “He was suddenly, intensely aware of the room around him, of the soft order of his furnishings and his life, of the soft order outside where day was giving way to night, of the TV sounds and the cold wet of the martini glass, of the smudgy feel of newsprint on his fingers, but mostly he was aware of joy — the wild, clattering joy of being alive. ‘Howdy,’ he whispered.”

byline: {'original': 'By Laurel Graeber', 'person': [{'firstname': 'Laurel', 'middlename': None, 'lastname': 'Graeber', 'qualifier': None, 'title': None, 'role': 'reported', 'organization': '', 'rank': 1}], 'organization': None}
snippet: Unknown
lead_paragraph: NIAGARA: A History of the Falls
abstract: NIAGARA: A History of the Falls   By Pierre Berton. Penguin, $14.95.    A Canadian historian describes the effect this natural wonder has had on human affairs. In addition to attracting daredevils, honeymooners and suicides, Niagara Falls has fostered science, industry and conservation. Berton's book is ''surprising, rich and engrossing,'' Thurston Clarke said here last year.    GUIDED TOURS OF HELL: Novellas  By Francine Prose. Owl/Holt, $12.    Both of these stories unfold in Europe, in places that are overwhelmingly associated with death. In the title novella, a minor playwright participating in a Kafka conference in Prague finds himself on a tour of a Nazi concentration camp. In the second novella, ''Three Pigs in Five Days,'' a woman and her lover, who produce a travel newsletter, visit a string of Paris cemeteries and prisons. Each encounter pushes the main characters to a confrontation with self-image and cherished illusions that probably would not have happened at home. In 1997 our reviewer, David Lodge, called the novellas ''irresistibly readable.'' The same publisher has also restored to print Prose's earlier novel BIGFOOT DREAMS ($12), the tale of a tabloid writer whose specious article about a fountain of youth turns out to have elements of truth. ''Once one starts a novel by Prose, it is almost impossible not to pay attention,'' Susan Allen Toth wrote in these pages in 1986. ''Her first lines are finely caught, not to be released until her final narrative fling.''    COLOR-BLIND:   Seeing Beyond Race in a Race-Obsessed World   By Ellis Cose. Harper Perennial, $13.    The author writes of issues ranging from affirmative action to multiracialism. Acknowledging the arguments of both sides of these debates, he encourages policies that will promote a just society rather than mere equality. He ''has written a book this country desperately needs,'' Alan Wolfe said in the Book Review last year. RACE RULES: Navigating the Color Line, by Michael Eric Dyson (Vintage, $12), explores divisions within the black community as well as the conflicts between blacks and whites. Dyson ''has mapped out some valuable coordinates for the course the nation continues to steer,'' Allen D. Boyer wrote here in 1996.    LOVE INVENTS US  By Amy Bloom. Vintage Contemporaries, $12.    Elizabeth Taube is rich in material things but poor in love. This novel follows her from girlhood to single motherhood, as she constructs a self from the impressions the men in her life have formed of her. Last year our reviewer, Sarah Ferguson, said Bloom ''writes lyrically and describes complicated emotional states with great sensitivity and tenderness.''    THE CASE FOR MARS:  The Plan to Settle the Red Planet and Why We Must  By Robert Zubrin with Richard Wagner.  Touchstone/Simon & Schuster, $13.    The author, a former aeronautical engineer, sees our neighboring planet as ripe for exploration. Rebutting NASA's estimate of a $450 billion cost for a manned mission, Zubrin proposes a $20 billion plan that would use existing technology and Mars's own resources. This is ''one of the most provocative and hopeful documents I have read about the space program in 20 years,'' Dennis Overbye wrote in these pages in 1996.    AFTER  By Melvin Jules Bukiet. Picador USA, $14.  This novel follows the exploits of three Holocaust survivors who use wit, deceit and manipulation to profit from the black market in postwar Europe. A final reckoning comes, however, when they decide to steal a massive hunk of gold made from dental fillings taken from the mouths of Nazi victims. In 1996 one critic described the book as ''funny and heartbreaking and thought-provoking at once.'' Bukiet's collection WHILE THE MESSIAH TARRIES: Stories (Syracuse University, $16.95) has also been reissued. These nine tales deal with Jewish life, ultimately questioning the seeming indifference of God to human suffering. In 1995 a reviewer wrote that they ''leave you shaken or wonder-struck.''    IRA GERSHWIN: The Art of the Lyricist  By Philip Furia. Oxford University, $14.95.    According to Ira Gershwin, ''a good lyric should be rhymed conversation.'' This book shows how well his work fit his philosophy and the music it accompanied. It is ''a clear, focused, highly readable study,'' James Gavin said in the Book Review in 1996.    NAKED CAME THE MANATEE  Fawcett Columbine, $11.95.    The work of 13 Florida writers, each of whom contributed a chapter, this novel spoofs the mystery genre with a tale that includes a 102-year-old environmentalist, former President Jimmy Carter and cryonically preserved human heads. The authors, among them Elmore Leonard, Carl Hiaasen, Dave Barry and Edna Buchanan, have concocted ''a deliciously twisted paean to South Florida,'' Philip Gambone wrote here last year.    THE LIFE AND DEATH OF ANDY WARHOL  By Victor Bockris. Da Capo, $17.95.    The author shows how this pop iconoclast succeeded through his talents for art and for manipulation. Now restored to print, this biography is ''the one to read for knowledge of Warhol the man,'' our reviewer, Peter Schjeldahl, said in 1989.   Laurel Graeber

snippet: The children of Muhammad bin Laden, from the desert to the jet set to the cave.
lead_paragraph: Is Osama bin Laden a rebel against the Saudi Arabian ruling class or a model member of it? That question lurks behind “The Bin Ladens,” by the Pulitzer Prize-winning New Yorker writer Steve Coll. The world’s most famous terrorist owes his fortune and his standing to a family business that Coll calls “the kingdom’s Halliburton.” Like Halliburton, the Saudi Binladin Group specializes in gigantic infrastructure projects. Government connections are the key to the family’s wealth. So you would assume they would react with unmixed horror to a radical son, like the duchess in the Noël Coward song:

lead_paragraph: Miko Hayashi and her colleagues have worked hard to organize the Asian-American Digi-Fest, a little film festival in Berkeley, Calif., and now it’s time to screen the prizewinner, “Fortune Cookie Rookie.” The movie is just another piece of high-minded, low-budget hokum, but the Asian-American audience smiles and applauds at the fade-out — except for Miko’s boyfriend, Ben Tanaka, a grumpy, 30-year-old Japanese-American, who’s having none of it. After refusing to go to the after-party, he starts spewing his usual venom.

keywords: [{'name': 'persons', 'value': 'Howard, Clark', 'rank': 1, 'major': 'N'}, {'name': 'subject', 'value': 'BOOK REVIEWS', 'rank': 2, 'major': 'N'}, {'name': 'creative_works', 'value': 'HARD CITY (BOOK)', 'rank': 3, 'major': 'N'}]
snippet: Unknown
lead_paragraph: HARD CITY. By Clark Howard. (Dutton, $21.95.) Clark Howard's autobiographical novel is set in the slums of Chicago's West Side in the 1950's. Its hero, Richie, is a 12-year-old who escapes from a succession of malignant foster homes, as well as his heroin-ridden mother, to strike out on his own. While polishing his talents as a petty thief, he manages to eke out an existence by working in a bowling alley, where he secretly holes up at night. When his mother dies, Richie is sent to a sadistic correctional institution for juveniles, then later is released to his maternal grandmother, who lives in a small town in Tennessee, where he is ostracized not only for being the son of a convict but also because he's a Yankee. Two factors sustain Richie: the hope of finding his father, who disappeared after his release from prison, and a passion for books. Although there are no surprises in Mr. Howard's 19th novel, it sustains a sense of tension, moving smoothly between flashbacks of the events of Richie's early years and the traumatic experiences of his adolescence, then on to his return to Chicago and his emergence as a young man in control of his life.
abstract: LEAD:    HARD CITY. By Clark Howard. (Dutton, $21.95.) Clark Howard's autobiographical novel is set in the slums of Chicago's West Side in the 1950's. snippet: Marilyn Stasio reviews following books: The Return of the Dancing Master by Henning Mankell; Dirty South by Ace Atkins; The Girl With The Long Back by Bill James; and Shadow Men by Jonathon King: drawing (M)
lead_paragraph: Henning Mankell's dark, despairing police procedurals reflect the authentic noir sensibility -- which has less to do with rain-slicked alleys and high-heeled women than with the fatalistic conviction that something evil is waiting just beyond the door. As it often does in Mankell's mysteries featuring his Swedish police inspector Kurt Wallander, violence strikes with quick and shocking ferocity in THE RETURN OF THE DANCING MASTER (New Press, $24.95). But this time it falls to a younger, if no less troubled, detective named Stefan Lindman to determine who tortured and killed an aged recluse in his hideaway in the dense forests of northern Sweden, leaving no clues but a pattern of tango steps outlined by the victim's bloodied feet.
abstract: Marilyn Stasio reviews following books: The Return of the Dancing Master by Henning Mankell; Dirty South by Ace Atkins; The Girl With The Long Back by Bill James; and Shadow Men by Jonathon King: drawing (M)

headline: {'main': 'Idi Amin and Worse', 'kicker': 'BOOKS IN BRIEF: FICTION', 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'BOOKS IN BRIEF: FICTION; Idi Amin and Worse', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

keywords: [{'name': 'persons', 'value': 'Isegawa, Moses', 'rank': 1, 'major': 'N'}, {'name': 'subject', 'value': 'Reviews', 'rank': 2, 'major': 'N'}, {'name': 'subject', 'value': 'Books and Literature', 'rank': 3, 'major': 'N'}, {'name': 'creative_works', 'value': 'SNAKEPIT (BOOK)', 'rank': 4, 'major': 'N'}]
snippet: Brock Baker reviews book Snakepit by Moses Isegawa; drawing; photo (S)
lead_paragraph: Like Moses Isegawa's first novel, ''Abyssinian Chronicles,'' SNAKEPIT (Knopf, $24) is a depiction of Uganda in the 1970's, during Idi Amin's brutal and chaotic rule. The interlocking stories of three characters, each of whom takes advantage of the state of lawlessness, make up the narrative. There's Bat Katanga, fresh from graduate school in Britain; his boss, General Bazooka, who is, like the illiterate Amin, from the less developed north; and the British-born mercenary Robert Ashes, a latecomer to Amin's wild ride, who as the president's confidant becomes one of General Bazooka's rivals. Isegawa's hurtling style and tone of outraged helplessness convey the vertiginous atmosphere of the Ugandan free-for-all. Some readers may regret that he sometimes adds his own exaggerations to the already nearly incredible historical record. For instance: Amin did voluntarily appear as the subject of a documentary that captured much of his insanity; he did not, as in the novel, star in two biographical films in which he played Il Duce. And in the most ghastly scene in the book, when one of Ashes' henchmen (known as the Pounder) kills the wife of a British businessman, the mode of execution -- it is carried out with a ''meter-long pestle'' -- is the stuff of pulp horror stories. Despite this, ''Snakepit'' remains a considerable achievement, an insider's viscerally imagined dramatization of the monumental and horrific follies of that particular time and place. Brock Baker
abstract: Brock Baker reviews book Snakepit by Moses Isegawa; drawing; photo (S)

snippet: Wilson is the most popular author in British libraries — exceeding you-know-who.
lead_paragraph: With all the ambitious novels for young adults and fat fantasy trilogies, it’s easy to forget the abiding category of children’s domestic fiction  stories for 9-to-12-year-olds about school, friends and family. Beverly Cleary provided the postwar model with her books about Beezus, Ramona and Henry Huggins; Judy Blume and Norma Klein brought a little edge to the genre in the 1970s; and Ann M. Martin sold millions of books with the Baby-Sitters Club series in the 1980s.
abstract: Wilson is the most popular author in British libraries — exceeding you-know-who.

snippet: Group of books on cooking reviewed by Richard Flaste; drawing (M)
lead_paragraph: During one of the worst restaurant meals I've had in years, all I could do was fume about how deceptively pretty the presentation was. There were the usual bright squiggles of sauce (every chef in America, no matter how incompetent, knows how to use a squeeze bottle) surrounding bits of desiccated food erected like a sculpture so that patrons in the know could gush, ''Ooh, good height.'' Just pretentious and pointless.
abstract: Group of books on cooking reviewed by Richard Flaste; drawing (M)

snippet: After her longtime partner’s murder, a woman goes into business as a fortune-teller.
lead_paragraph: Maryse Condé’s latest novel, her 12th, is a highly, sometimes unbearably realistic psychological portrait of one woman’s grief after the unsolved murder of her partner of 20 years. “The Story of the Cannibal Woman” opens three months after the crime, and Rosélie Thibaudin, a 50-year-old painter, still finds it hard to get out of bed. She can’t sleep, or eat or paint, and is mired in a state of semi-wakeful numbness — that “hour of lead,” when “the feet, mechanical, go round,” that Emily Dickinson wrote follows “great pain.”

headline: {'main': 'And Bear In Mind', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'And Bear In Mind', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}
byline: {'original': None, 'person': [], 'organization': None}
snippet: Unknown
lead_paragraph: (Editors' choices of other recent books of particular interest)
abstract: (Editors' choices of other recent books of particular interest)    THE ROMANTIC, by Barbara Gowdy. (Metropolitan/Holt, $24.) Obsession knows no greater exponent than Louise, narrator and protagonist of this adroit novel that refuses to honor the claims of adulthood. Abandoned by her mother at 9, Louise soon falls madly in love with another family's mother, then with that mother's adopted son, and remains consciously faithful to her doomed love ever after.    THE QUALITY OF LIFE REPORT, by Meghan Daum. (Viking, $24.95.) A fine comic first novel in which misguided fantasy betrays a young New York television journalist, first by sending her to the Midwest, where folks are simple and good, then by orders from New York to do a lifestyle series on the simple, good folk.    THE WIFE, by Meg Wolitzer. (Scribner, $23.) A light-footed, streamlined novel that rushes in to shed new heat on old themes like gender, writing and identity; Joan Castleman gives up her writing career to service that of her husband, Joe, a jerk of many flavors.    DARK LOVER: The Life and Death of Rudolph Valentino, by Emily W. Leider. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $35.) An accomplished study of the movie star and his era, and of how he altered forever the electric charges of both men and women in 1921 with the release of ''The Sheik.''    RAISING AMERICA: Experts, Parents, and a Century of Advice About Children, by Ann Hulbert. (Knopf, $27.50.) To what, exactly, has the vast body of expert opinion about child rearing amounted? Hulbert's prodigious collection of material represents it mainly as teeter-tottering between discipline and permissiveness, sometimes inside the same expert at different stages.    PERSEPOLIS, by Marjane Satrapi. (Pantheon, $17.95.) A dramatic, witty, insouciant autobiography in bold, densely rendered comic-book form by a woman born to the leftish secular bourgeoisie of 1960's Iran; she was 10 when the shah fell and his tyranny was replaced by the ayatollah version. The book ends when she is 14 and her parents put her on a plane for some safer place (she now lives in France).    GULAG: A History, by Anne Applebaum. (Doubleday, $35.) Applebaum, a columnist for The Washington Post, is one of those who think Hitler and Stalin merit the same opprobrium. Using archival material Solzhenitsyn never saw, she supports his analysis of Stalin: Lenin written larger.    GETTING MOTHER'S BODY, by Suzan-Lori Parks. (Random House, $23.95.) This first novel by the Pulitzer-winning African-American playwright takes a cheerful tack across deep Faulknerian waters, relating the fortunes of the survivors of a woman who was buried (as people think) in some very expensive jewelry.    THE DUST OF EMPIRE: The Race for Mastery in the Asian Heartland, by Karl E. Meyer. (Century Foundation/PublicAffairs, $26.) A veteran journalist and scholar revisits the playing fields of the ''great game,'' where Russia and Britain met and blocked each other in a tussle for influence that isn't over yet.

snippet: Henry Louis Gates Jr essay on Harriet Beecher Stowe novel Uncle Tom's Cabin; notes 1949 scathing critique of novel by James Baldwin that finds character of Tom to be menace to view of black race; holds that while Baldwin attacks novel for its over...
lead_paragraph: I first read "Uncle Tom's Cabin" in an eighth-grade class in 1964, when it was probably just going out of fashion as required reading for American school children -- and the phrase "Uncle Tom" was about to come into widespread use as the ultimate instrument of black-on-black derogation.
abstract: Henry Louis Gates Jr essay on Harriet Beecher Stowe novel Uncle Tom's Cabin; notes 1949 scathing critique of novel by James Baldwin that finds character of Tom to be menace to view of black race; holds that while Baldwin attacks novel for its over-sentimentality, he fails to make connection that literary melodrama has power to change minds of readers and has influenced his own novels; photo (M)

lead_paragraph: MY FELLOW AMERICANS: A Family Album. Written and illustrated by Alice Provensen. Browndeer/Harcourt Brace. $19.95. (All ages) In the spirit of "The Buck Stops Here," her remarkable compendium of portraits and information about American Presidents, this distinguished artist has made an album of faces and facts about hundreds of interesting Americans who lived then and now. A great browsing book for adults as well as children.

headline: {'main': 'And Bear In Mind', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'And Bear In Mind', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}
byline: {'original': None, 'person': [], 'organization': None}
snippet: Unknown
lead_paragraph: (Editors' choices of other recent books of particular interest)
abstract: (Editors' choices of other recent books of particular interest)    THE FEAST OF THE GOAT, by Mario Vargas Llosa. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $25.) A bloody end is never in doubt in this novel starring Gen. Rafael Trujillo, dictator of the Dominican Republic for 30 years; the suspense comes from wondering which of Vargas Llosa's nightmare characters will be the one to succeed him.    THE COMPLETE WORKS OF ISAAC BABEL, edited by Nathalie Babel. (Norton, $39.95.) The total product of the marvelous writer who tried to create a synthesis of the Russian, the Jewish, the literary and the revolutionary, a mix that bestowed life on his fiction but could not save him from death on Stalin's orders in 1940.    UNCLE TUNGSTEN: Memories of a Chemical Boyhood, by Oliver Sacks. (Knopf, $25.) A fresh, joyous, wistful, generous, tough-minded memoir about discovering, with the aid of a brilliant extended family, what the human mind is up to in its discernment of pattern and organization in what first looks like the arbitrary jungle of nature; in other words, science.    WHY DID I EVER, by Mary Robison. (Counterpoint, $23.) In Robison's first novel for a decade, Monica Breton (known as Money) has three ex-husbands she can't quite remember and two children she loves immensely but can't figure out how to help; she defends herself, painfully, with wit and irony, Ritalin and lots of rules for living.    AUSTERLITZ, by W. G. Sebald. (Random House, $25.95.) A middle-aged Welsh architectural historian discovers that he is really the son of Holocaust victims from Czechoslovakia in this rich, gloomy novel by a writer who has specialized in characters crippled by the past.    TRIESTE AND THE MEANING OF NOWHERE, by Jan Morris. (Simon & Schuster, $23.) An account both personal and historical of the heterogeneous corner of Italy that attracted James Joyce, Italo Svevo and Morris herself, partly because of the pleasurable melancholy she calls ''the Trieste effect.''    NO SAINTS OR ANGELS, by Ivan Klima. (Grove, $24.) The personal and the political are inseparable in Klima's newest novel, in which a Prague dentist, daughter of a zealous bureaucrat of the former regime, determines that the hate mail she has been receiving originates with a half brother previously unknown to her.    THE ROYAL PHYSICIAN'S VISIT, by Per Olov Enquist. (Overlook, $26.95.) A fast-paced historical novel ringing with the clash of ideas, set in the Danish court in the 1770's, when the young King Christian VII was dominated by his German physician, a fan of the French Enlightenment who tried to transform Denmark into a land of liberty, equality and fraternity; by a veteran Swedish novelist and playwright.    HATESHIP, FRIENDSHIP, COURTSHIP, LOVESHIP, MARRIAGE: Stories, by Alice Munro. (Knopf, $24.) Things may be very bad for the people in Munro's stories, but they do not always get worse. Instead, the stories may see what can be said in favor of life in dire circumstances, not by comforting or defiant formulations but by attending for whatever may come up in the way of a favorable sign.

snippet: Writing is what the Waugh men do, says Alexander — son of Auberon, grandson of Evelyn and author of a new family memoir.
lead_paragraph: If students of George Bernard Shaw can be called Shavians, a friend of Evelyn Waugh’s named John Sutro argued, then those interested in all things Waugh might be called Wavians. I now realize that, without knowing it, I have been a Wavian for many years. And I opened this book eagerly, anticipating a trove of revelation about the author’s father, Auberon, and grandfather Evelyn. Instead, I was engrossed for almost half the book by an extraordinary depiction of the true paterfamilias, Arthur Waugh, whose position in London publishing helped launch his two sons — the elder brother, Alec, and the younger, Evelyn — on their careers as authors. Here is a sample of the old boy’s prose. He is writing to his favorite, Alec, who has been having a spot of sexual trouble at school:

snippet: Jeffrey Sachs explores economic solutions to the problems of overpopulation.
lead_paragraph: The timing for Jeffrey D. Sachs’s new book on how to avert global economic catastrophe couldn’t be better, with food riots in Haiti, oil topping $120 a barrel and a gnawing sense that there’s just less of everything  rice, fossil fuels, credit  to go around. Of course, we’ve been here before. In the 19th century, Thomas Malthus teased out the implications of humans reproducing more rapidly than the supply of food could grow. In 1972, the Club of Rome published, to much hoopla, a book entitled “Limits to Growth.” The thesis: There are too many people and too few natural resources to go around. In 1978, Mr. Smith, my sixth-grade science teacher, proclaimed that there was sufficient petroleum to last 25 to 30 years. Well, as Yogi Berra once may have said, “It’s hard to make predictions, especially about the future.”

snippet: Dave Itzkoff Across the Universe column notes John Scalzi book The Android's Dream; drawing (M)
lead_paragraph: When an emerging science-fiction writer's work earns him comparisons to Robert A. Heinlein, should he take them as a compliment? Don't misunderstand me: I have no reason to doubt that the old master's classic novels "Stranger in a Strange Land" and "The Cat Who Walks Through Walls" are still as good as I remember them (and if they aren't, please don't tell me). But Heinlein's military sci-fi, particularly the book that practically invented the genre, "Starship Troopers," has not aged well, to put it mildly.

keywords: [{'name': 'persons', 'value': 'Kurzweil, Raymond', 'rank': 1, 'major': 'N'}, {'name': 'subject', 'value': 'BOOK REVIEWS', 'rank': 2, 'major': 'N'}, {'name': 'creative_works', 'value': 'AGE OF INTELLIGENT MACHINES, THE (BOOK)', 'rank': 3, 'major': 'N'}]
snippet: Unknown
lead_paragraph: In ''The Age of Intelligent Machines,'' Mr. Kurzweil valiantly attempts to provide an overview of artificial intelligence - the field devoted to the theory, design and construction of computing machines that think, or at least appear to. He discusses its philosophical, mathematical, psychological and technical roots; the outstanding problems in contemporary research on artificial intelligence; the history and current state of the industry; the impact of artificial intelligence on the arts, and the future of the discipline. The volume is an innovative blend of monograph and anthology, for it includes not only Mr. Kurzweil's own writing but a number of essays by philosophers and researchers in artificial intelligence. This structure would have been more successful, however, if the author had included views divergent from his own alongside those that buttress his position.
abstract: LEAD:    THE AGE OF INTELLIGENT MACHINES    By Raymond Kurzweil.    Illustrated. 565 pp. Cambridge, Mass.:    MIT Press. $29.95; $39.95 after Dec. 31.

keywords: [{'name': 'persons', 'value': 'GODWIN, MALCOLM', 'rank': 1, 'major': 'N'}, {'name': 'subject', 'value': 'BOOK REVIEWS', 'rank': 2, 'major': 'N'}, {'name': 'creative_works', 'value': 'ANGELS: AN ENDANGERED SPECIES (BOOK)', 'rank': 3, 'major': 'N'}]
snippet: Unknown
lead_paragraph: ANGELS: An Endangered Species. By Malcolm Godwin. (Simon & Schuster, $19.95.) Angels are all around us -- in movies ("Angels With Dirty Faces"), sports (California Angels), even law enforcement (Guardian Angels). Angels figure in our most rarefied worship and in everyday figures of speech. They appear in many guises, from ancient bringers of glad tidings to modern comic-book heroes who appear in the nick of time to rescue good and defeat evil. Artists have been known to spend lifetimes creating substantial representations of these insubstantial beings. But are angels merely figments of our collective imaginations, inspired by legend and fostered by religion? That is a question not easily answered without serious study of the delightful "Angels: An Endangered Species." Malcolm Godwin begins by discussing such cloud-shaking matters as just how seraphim are distinct from cherubim, who are in turn quite separate from archangels. Understanding this heavenly hierarchy creates an important foundation for our knowledge of the more advanced material concerning these winged messengers. But winged messengers from whom, what or where? The author, a British artist and lecturer, presents cases in which encounter and speculation in some way transform those who have been witness to angelic presences. If angels are real, could they appear in other forms -- as unidentified flying objects, for instance? And if real, how do they fly? Are those dainty, feathered shoulder appendages aerodynamically adequate? Just what did Ezekiel see in that fiery chariot, up in the air? Could the legends of the lost continent of Mu be based on fact? Obviously, the questions surrounding these issues require further study by angelic scholars. Tongue parked firmly in cheek, Mr. Godwin takes us through the intricacies of modern angelology and a good deal of our own history, using text, charts, drawings and glorious illustrations. As to whether angels are real or not, endangered or not, Mr. Godwin leaves that up to his readers to discover in this heavenly book.

keywords: [{'name': 'subject', 'value': 'Books and Literature', 'rank': 1, 'major': 'N'}, {'name': 'persons', 'value': 'Weidensaul, Scott', 'rank': 2, 'major': 'N'}, {'name': 'subject', 'value': 'Birds', 'rank': 3, 'major': 'N'}]
snippet: Some Americans used shotguns, while others made do with opera glasses.
lead_paragraph: As recently as a generation ago, one of the stock figures in the repertoire of cartoonists and comedy writers was the Bird Watcher — usually the male of the species, bony-kneed in short pants, draped with gear and all atwitter. But the female was not altogether neglected, as Scott Weidensaul reminds us in “Of a Feather,” his delightful history of American birding. He cites Jane Hathaway, a character in “The Beverly Hillbillies,” “the tall, mannish spinster ... who’d pop up with a pith helmet and a pair of binoculars, so starchy, so prim, so nerdy, though no one used that word in those days.”

keywords: [{'name': 'persons', 'value': 'ROBINSON, ROBBY', 'rank': 1, 'major': 'N'}, {'name': 'persons', 'value': 'LIE, ARNE BRUN', 'rank': 2, 'major': 'N'}, {'name': 'subject', 'value': 'BOOK REVIEWS', 'rank': 3, 'major': 'N'}, {'name': 'creative_works', 'value': 'NIGHT AND FOG (BOOK)', 'rank': 4, 'major': 'N'}]
snippet: Unknown
lead_paragraph: NIGHT AND FOG. By Arne Brun Lie with Robby Robinson. (Norton, $18.95.) Half of ''Night and Fog'' is the story of the Norwegian Arne Brun Lie's year as a political prisoner of the occupying Nazi Government. The other half is the story of how Mr. Lie got up the nerve to talk about that year. The two halves run alongside each other the length of the book and somehow never quite cohere. That can be a bit jarring, but it is not really a problem, because Mr. Lie, an inexperienced writer who worries about ''the clumsy feel of a pen in my hands,'' with the help of Robby Robinson, an English teacher in Massachusetts, writes engagingly and well. Mr. Lie was a schoolboy who had just begun training with the Norwegian Resistance and had not yet shot a gun when the Nazis ''disappeared'' him and put him in a special ''night and fog'' camp for enemies of the state. (''Night and fog'' was the Nazi designation for their program for political prisoners; they stamped its initials on uniforms, broke its victims down with ''cat-and-mouse torment instead of instant death'' and called them ''the already dead.'') Forty years later, Mr. Lie skippered a 37-foot cutter from Boston to Oslo and, during long watches, talked out his repressed memories. The moral of the story is that he survived through dreams: Arne Brun Lie the camp prisoner dreamed of meat pudding, sailboats, fjords and even elephants, while Arne Brun Lie the survivor dreamed guiltily about surviving and was finally tortured by dreams into speech. The tragedy of it, for a world where ''disappearing'' and abusing political prisoners is still commonplace, is that it took Mr. Lie so long to talk - and, by talking, to heal.
abstract: LEAD:    NIGHT AND FOG. By Arne Brun Lie with Robby Robinson. (Norton, $18.95.) Half of ''Night and Fog'' is the story of the Norwegian Arne Brun Lie's year as a political prisoner of the occupying Nazi Government. The other half is the story of how Mr. Lie got up the nerve to talk about that year. The two halves run alongside each other the length of the book and somehow never quite cohere.

lead_paragraph: MIDWAY through Nicholson Baker's best-selling novel, "Vox," Jim on the telephone sex line offers Abby on the sex line an imaginary pair of self-arousal options: an X-rated videotape or "some book of Victorian pornography." abstract: MIDWAY through Nicholson Baker's best-selling novel, "Vox," Jim on the telephone sex line offers Abby on the sex line an imaginary pair of self-arousal options: an X-rated videotape or "some book of Victorian pornography." Abby responds at once: "The Victorian pornography, no question."   Amazed at first, Jim proceeds to muse on his recent brainstorm that "in general people would prefer written porn. . . . I guess insofar as verbal pornography records thoughts rather than exclusively images, or at least surrounds all images with thoughts, or something, it can be the hottest medium of all. Telepathy on a budget."

snippet: In an Enron-meets-“Deliverance” twist, a group of business executives is tormented by gun-toting brutes.
lead_paragraph: Joseph Finder is perhaps the lead player in the corporate thriller genre, a thriving subset of the traditional suspense novel in which executives are both villains and victims. The stakes tend to be smaller here: there’s no threat to the free world, no killer virus decimating American cities, no madmen plotting serial mayhem. What there is in “Power Play” is an off-site business conference gone horribly wrong — and we’re not talking about a run on bran muffins or a lack of participation in the “trust fall” exercise.
abstract: In an Enron-meets-“Deliverance” twist, a group of business executives is tormented by gun-toting brutes.

snippet: ''A New York friendship,'' Kurt Vonnegut once wrote, ''is a friendship with a person you have met at least once. If you have met a person only once, and you are a New Yorker, you are entitled to say, whenever that person's name comes up in convers...
lead_paragraph: "A New York friendship," Kurt Vonnegut once wrote, "is a friendship with a person you have met at least once. If you have met a person only once, and you are a New Yorker, you are entitled to say, whenever that person's name comes up in conversation, 'Yes -- so-and-so is a friend of mine.' "

If you have met a person only once, and you are a New Yorker, you are entitled to say, whenever that person's name comes up in conversation, 'Yes -- so-and-so is a friend of mine.' ''

snippet: This novel’s hero loses everything to a betting habit.
lead_paragraph: “There are only two kinds of gamblers: the lucky and the broke,” says the compulsive wagerer at the center of Preston L. Allen’s casino noir “All or Nothing.” Known simply as P (protagonist? Preston?), he’s been one or the other his entire adult life. A Miami school bus driver with a large family and an even larger jones, he squanders his paychecks and scrounges loose change from school bus seats, then loses it all at South Florida Indian casinos, mostly to slot machines, the crack cocaine of gambling. P is not above wishing for his young son’s life-threatening allergic reactions, believing the child utters winning numbers while slipping toward a coma. He plays, he loses and, with the Sisyphean regularity of the certifiably insane, he returns to play again. Above all, he lies  to his wife, his bosses, his children, himself.
abstract: This novel’s hero loses everything to a betting habit.

lead_paragraph: NEW YORK's BRAVEST. By Mary Pope Osborne. Illustrated by Steve Johnson and Lou Fancher. Knopf. $15.95. (Ages 4 to 8) The legend that built up around Mose Humphreys, a New York City firefighter of the 1840's, is that of a noble urban giant, perhaps a cousin of Paul Bunyan. abstract: NEW YORK's BRAVEST. By Mary Pope Osborne. Illustrated by Steve Johnson and Lou Fancher. Knopf. $15.95. (Ages 4 to 8) The legend that built up around Mose Humphreys, a New York City firefighter of the 1840's, is that of a noble urban giant, perhaps a cousin of Paul Bunyan. This telling enlarges on his valor and the bravery of firefighters.    LIKE A WINDY DAY. Written and illustrated by Frank Asch and Devin Ash. Harcourt. $15. (Ages 3 to 7) A little girl imagines the wind in many guises and shares adventures with it. In the illustrations, the busy wind that zooms down hillsides and races through streets, scatters seeds, flies kites, waves flags, steals hats and sails boats resembles a little girl.

snippet: Mary Roach’s book “Packing for Mars” delights in the fringe material associated with astronauts’ life in space.
lead_paragraph: In conducting research into the physiology of astronauts in space, Mary Roach found out that one man on a Space Shuttle flight wore a sound monitor on his belly for the duration of his voyage. It is Ms. Roach’s style to be less interested in the belly-noise findings than in the freaky-deaky part of the story. “Don’t feel bad for him,” she writes in “Packing for Mars” about that awkwardly wired astronaut. “Feel bad for the Air Force security guy assigned to listen to two weeks of bowel sounds to be sure no conversations including classified information had been inadvertently recorded.”

keywords: [{'name': 'persons', 'value': 'Goodman, Hal', 'rank': 1, 'major': 'N'}, {'name': 'persons', 'value': 'Teachout, Terry', 'rank': 2, 'major': 'N'}, {'name': 'subject', 'value': 'BOOK REVIEWS', 'rank': 3, 'major': 'N'}, {'name': 'creative_works', 'value': 'BEYOND THE BOOM (BOOK)', 'rank': 4, 'major': 'N'}]
snippet: BEYOND THE BOOM: New Voices on American Life, Culture, and Politics.  Edited by Terry Teachout. (Poseidon, $18.95.) "What we think," writes Terry Teachout in his foreword to this collection of essays by and about baby boomers, "is as diverse as wh...
lead_paragraph: BEYOND THE BOOM: New Voices on American Life, Culture, and Politics. Edited by Terry Teachout. (Poseidon, $18.95.) "What we think," writes Terry Teachout in his foreword to this collection of essays by and about baby boomers, "is as diverse as who we are." Wrong. These essays are a lot more diverse than their authors, and thank goodness, for it would be tough to find a less diverse bunch than the 15 contributors to "Beyond the Boom." Mr. Teachout, an editorial writer at The New York Daily News, says that he and his 14 conservative middle-class East Coast colleagues (nine of whom either work for or contribute to Commentary, National Review, The American Spectator or The Wall Street Journal) "represent the vast majority of baby boomers" -- an astonishingly arrogant leap from the undeniable fact that most baby boomers, like most members of pretty much every group, voted for Ronald Reagan. The essays themselves do vary, in both subject and quality, and the good ones are terrific, notably Maggie Gallagher's funny and touching analysis of what she calls "house lust," Roger Kimball's funeral dirge for the craft of criticism and David Brooks's hilarious description of a Washington black-tie dinner. ("The whole point of being a moderate is that it doubles the field of possible dinner guests.") Also worthy of note, though only for its shock value, is Lisa Schiffren's regretful reflection that the baby-boom generation has not been through a war. "In years to come," writes Ms. Schiffren, a special assistant at the Defense Department, "nations like Afghanistan will have plenty of eager young men, refined and proven in the forge of war, fit to shoulder responsibility for leading their societies. What about us?" Mr. Teachout's contribution is an explanation of why he has said farewell to politics, a statement that would be more convincing in a different context. Yes, this is a diverse collection, and indeed the premise of "Beyond the Boom" is that the cliches and preconceptions that lump baby boomers into a homogeneous mass aren't true. No doubt they aren't, but these essays and these authors don't prove it. All they prove is that conservative middle-class East Coast journalists in their 30's -- some, anyway -- can write entertainingly on a variety of subjects.
abstract: BEYOND THE BOOM: New Voices on American Life, Culture, and Politics.  Edited by Terry Teachout. (Poseidon, $18.95.) "What we think," writes Terry Teachout in his foreword to this collection of essays by and about baby boomers, "is as diverse as who we are." Wrong. These essays are a lot more diverse than their authors, and thank goodness, for it would be tough to find a less diverse bunch than the 15 contributors to "Beyond the Boom." Mr. Teachout, an editorial writer at The New York Daily News, says that he and his 14 conservative middle-class East Coast colleagues (nine of whom either work for or contribute to Commentary, National Review, The American Spectator or The Wall Street Journal) "represent the vast majority of baby boomers" -- an astonishingly arrogant leap from the undeniable fact that most baby boomers, like most members of pretty much every group, voted for Ronald Reagan. The essays themselves do vary, in both subject and quality, and the good ones are terrific, notably Maggie Gallagher's funny and touching analysis of what she calls "house lust," Roger Kimball's funeral dirge for the craft of criticism and David Brooks's hilarious description of a Washington black-tie dinner. ("The whole point of being a moderate is that it doubles the field of possible dinner guests.") Also worthy of note, though only for its shock value, is Lisa Schiffren's regretful reflection that the baby-boom generation has not been through a war. "In years to come," writes Ms. Schiffren, a special assistant at the Defense Department, "nations like Afghanistan will have plenty of eager young men, refined and proven in the forge of war, fit to shoulder responsibility for leading their societies. What about us?" Mr. Teachout's contribution is an explanation of why he has said farewell to politics, a statement that would be more convincing in a different context. Yes, this is a diverse collection, and indeed the premise of "Beyond the Boom" is that the cliches and preconceptions that lump baby boomers into a homogeneous mass aren't true. No doubt they aren't, but these essays and these authors don't prove it. All they prove is that conservative middle-class East Coast journalists in their 30's -- some, anyway -- can write entertainingly on a variety of subjects.

snippet: Laura Miller The Last Word column discusses the literary pleasures of the case study; cites works of Oliver Sack and Sigmund Freud; drawing (M)
lead_paragraph: What literary form offers the illicit allure of the sideshow wrapped in the edifying aura of the lecture hall? The suspense of a murder mystery without the taint of violence? The voyeuristic appeal of the memoir freed from the nattering self-regard of the memoirist? Only the case study, that unsung genre inhabiting the borderland between art and science.

byline: {'original': 'By Scott Veale', 'person': [{'firstname': 'Scott', 'middlename': None, 'lastname': 'Veale', 'qualifier': None, 'title': None, 'role': 'reported', 'organization': '', 'rank': 1}], 'organization': None}
snippet: Unknown
lead_paragraph: Part coming-of-age story and part paean to life on the links, Turk Pipkin's charming first novel, FAST GREENS (Dial, $19.95), is narrated by Billy Hemphill, who wistfully recalls his childhood living with his grandmother in West Texas in the 1960's. "Golf is a noble game," he says early on, "a combination of uncertain skill and specific laws, untainted by ethical dilemmas or moral quandaries." It's the players who are tainted, of course, as Billy discovers at age 13 when he agrees to be a caddy in a bizarre grudge match between two grizzled old oilmen, Roscoe Fowler and William March, and their partners, Carl (Beast) Larsen, "the biggest, meanest, ugliest golfer that ever came out of Texas," and Sandy Bates, a fine player with a reputation for choking in head-to-head matchups with the Beast. In the course of nine holes on a torrid summer morning, with money, land, pride and a woman's affections at stake, the members of this foursome resort to a wild assortment of scams, cons and psych jobs to square a bitter dispute that goes back 27 years. It hardly matters that the plot is a bit predictable and the writing overly sentimental in places; the narrative is endowed with a vivid sense of time and place, the characters are wonderfully drawn and the dialogue is sharp and colorful. And at the heart of "Fast Greens" is the game itself, whose lore and wisdom are lovingly imparted. Amid all the talk of "mulligans," "worm burners" and "duck hooks" lies an unmistakable -- and infectious -- passion for a pastime that is "more religion than sport, a religion with a very tiny and unforgiving goal: perfection." Scott Veale

snippet: Lee Siegel essay on revisiting author Paul Zweig, who died in 1984; holds that at time when writers often write with calculated eccentricity rather than out of fateful obsession, and compose memoirs that seem devoid of self-understanding, his raw,...
lead_paragraph: RILKE once said that fame is the sum of misunderstandings that accrue around a name. Though the poet, critic and memoirist Paul Zweig was admired in literary circles during his lifetime, he slipped through fame's embrace. That may have been his misfortune, but you can read the books of this "fierce little man" -- as his friend, the poet Robert Bly, called Zweig at a tribute held last month at Poets House in Manhattan -- unclouded by commentary and judgment, fresh, as if they had just appeared. And Zweig, who died of lymphatic cancer in 1984 at the age of 49, is well worth revisiting. At a time when writers often write with calculated eccentricity rather than out of a fateful obsession, and compose memoirs that seem devoid of self-understanding, his raw, original studies of culture and his masterly autobiographies provide a rich diet for famished readers. Zweig may have spent much of his life in the academy, but he wished to throw himself into the world and test his ideas against experience, and then measure himself against the results. He wanted a destiny, not a career.
abstract: Lee Siegel essay on revisiting author Paul Zweig, who died in 1984; holds that at time when writers often write with calculated eccentricity rather than out of fateful obsession, and compose memoirs that seem devoid of self-understanding, his raw, original studies of culture and masterly autobiographies provide rich diet for famished readers; notes books Eternity of Woods, Three Journeys, Departures, The Heresy of Self-Love: A Study of Subversive Individualism and The Adventurer: The Fate of Adventure in the Western World; asserts that Zweig was not just one of pioneers of contemporary memoir, but one of its ideal practitioners; photo (M)

snippet: In his first collection of essays, the fiction writer George Saunders weighs in on world affairs, border politics and great books.
lead_paragraph: The short-story writer George Saunders apparently has a Thing for Capital Letters. His first collection of nonfiction is Chock Full of Them — phrases like “Men Who Fish” and “Big Naïve Philosophical Realizations” and “American Male Opinionated Chatterbox” and “Appallingly Porous Border Syndrome,” to name but a few. These locutions resonate with Wiseguy Knowingness and serve as the literary equivalent of People Making Quote Marks With Their Fingers.

lead_paragraph: SOMEBODY'S BABY, by Claire Harrison. (Signet, $3.95.) The Beemes, a family of 60's liberals, find it disturbing enough that their 15-year-old daughter is pregnant, but they really hit the roof when she refuses to get an abortion. Last year our reviewer, Ellen Feldman, said this novel is ''as topical as today's headlines. It is the drama of Roe v. Wade played out on a family stage.''

byline: {'original': 'By Scott Veale', 'person': [{'firstname': 'Scott', 'middlename': None, 'lastname': 'Veale', 'qualifier': None, 'title': None, 'role': 'reported', 'organization': '', 'rank': 1}], 'organization': None}
snippet: Unknown
lead_paragraph: VERTIGO, by W. G. Sebald. (New Directions, $13.95.) A rich stew of history, fiction, reporting, fantasy, travel notes, autobiography, photographs and illustrations, this German-born author's first novel is a spiraling inquiry into the workings of memory, as the narrator reflects on episodes in European history and how they relate to his own origins and inner life. The result is an ''extraordinary, unclassifiable book'' by ''a thrilling, original writer,'' W. S. Di Piero wrote in these pages last year. ''He makes narration a state of investigative bliss.''
abstract: VERTIGO, by W. G. Sebald. (New Directions, $13.95.) A rich stew of history, fiction, reporting, fantasy, travel notes, autobiography, photographs and illustrations, this German-born author's first novel is a spiraling inquiry into the workings of memory, as the narrator reflects on episodes in European history and how they relate to his own origins and inner life. The result is an ''extraordinary, unclassifiable book'' by ''a thrilling, original writer,'' W. S. Di Piero wrote in these pages last year. ''He makes narration a state of investigative bliss.''    GOD'S NAME IN VAIN: The Wrongs and Rights of Religion in Politics, by Stephen L. Carter. (Basic Books, $15.) A Yale law professor and evangelical Episcopalian argues that a religious voice should be welcome in American politics, but warns that religion can lose its integrity and moral bearings when it strays too far into civic affairs. Last year our reviewer, Brent Staples, found this a provocative, if flawed, book. For one thing, he wrote, ''Carter's contention . . . that the state should cede more power to religion will strike many people as a recipe for warfare in the streets.''    PROPERTIES OF LIGHT, by Rebecca Goldstein. (Mariner/Houghton Mifflin, $13.) In a Gothic novel that explores the darker side of the quest for scientific truth, two physicists who share a noble dream of reconciling the principles of quantum mechanics and relativity become locked instead in a collaboration that leads to hatred, treachery and violence. Last year in these pages, Sylvia Brownrigg admired the book's ''cool grace'' and its ''luminous, incendiary imagery.''    AN OBEDIENT FATHER, by Akhil Sharma. (Harvest/Harcourt, $13.) Ram Karan, the main narrator of this ambitious first novel by a young New York investment banker, is a corrupt functionary in the Delhi school system, a vile, guilt-ridden schemer who somehow elicits more pity than disgust despite his voracious appetites. ''At its best'' the tale ''displays some of the most psychologically acute writing to have come out of modern India,'' Akash Kapur wrote in the Book Review in 2000. ''Sharma's evenhanded treatment of men like Karan . . . is wise and compassionate.''    HOME ICE: Reflections on Backyard Rinks and Frozen Ponds, by Jack Falla. (McGregor, $14.95.) In a paean to small-time hockey and its enthusiasts, a sportswriter tells of his lifelong infatuation with the sport and how his homemade rink at his New England home became a gathering ground for family and friends. The result is ''literary hot chocolate that will warm your heart,'' Robert Lipsyte wrote in The Times last year.    HILDA AND PEARL, by Alice Mattison. (Perennial/HarperCollins, $13.) An 11-year-old girl coming of age in Brooklyn during the McCarthy era uncovers the long-held secrets of her mother and aunt, whose passionate bond endures in the face of tragic events that include a painful betrayal and a baby's death. Mattison renders her characters' working-class lives ''in spare, graceful detail,'' Joyce Reiser Kornblatt said here in 1995. ''Forgiving and wise, 'Hilda and Pearl' is a memorable novel about love's resilience.''    EASTWARD TO TARTARY: Travels in the Balkans, the Middle East, and the Caucasus, by Robert D. Kaplan. (Vintage Departures, $14.) A prolific travel writer and political journalist shuttles readers across an immense region stretching from Bulgaria to Baku and beyond, recounting his own journeys and examining with hard-nosed realism the ''new Silk Roads'' winding through newly opened lands. ''Erudite and intrepid,'' with a wealth ''of elite contacts all over the world, he is a deft guide,'' Laura Secor wrote in these pages last year. The same publisher has reissued Soldiers of God: With Islamic Warriors in Afghanistan and Pakistan ($14), Kaplan's 1990 account of living among the mujahedeen fighting the Soviets in the 1980's and of the rise of the Taliban. The book, which has been updated with a new introduction and final chapter, is ''affecting and informative,'' one critic said.    JAYBER CROW, by Wendell Berry. (Counterpoint, $15.) Set in a fading Kentucky town, this rough-hewn novel by a renowned poet tells of a young man who abandons his plans to become a minister and becomes the village barber instead. By the end of his elegiac life story, ''this melancholy barber has won both our attention and our hearts,'' Gail Gilliland said here in 2000.   Scott Veale

lead_paragraph: It's a serious pleasure to have Joseph Wambaugh back in Los Angeles and writing another blisteringly funny police procedural about the L.A.P.D. While it may have taken him a couple of decades to get his mojo back, after some half-baked books set elsewhere in Southern California, HOLLYWOOD STATION (Little, Brown, $24.99) has all the authority, outrage, compassion and humor of the great early novels (like "The New Centurions" and "The Choirboys") this onetime cop wrote in the 1970s.
abstract: Marilyn Stasio reviews books Hollywood Station by Joseph Wambaugh, Redemption by Frederick Turner, A Whole New Life by Betsy Thornton and Why We Die by M Herron; photo (M)

snippet: Ted Sorensen, John Kennedy’s speechwriter and close aide, battled blindness to write a memoir.
lead_paragraph: In 1956, Douglas McKay left the Eisenhower cabinet to go back to Oregon and run against Wayne Morse for the Senate. At the Portland airport, he read a ghostwritten arrival statement, took off his glasses and said, to snickers, “Now I’d like to add a few words of my own.”

snippet: Judy Collins’s memoir addresses her early life, career, romantic relationships, alcoholism and eating disorder, as well as the fraught life of her son, Clark.
lead_paragraph: Albert Grossman, who had put together Peter, Paul and Mary as a folk-singing trio, once suggested to Judy Collins that she become part of a trio too. She would sing with two other women, Judy Henske and Jo Mapes. “We can call you the Brown-Eyed Girls,” he said.

keywords: [{'name': 'persons', 'value': 'Due, Tananarive', 'rank': 1, 'major': 'N'}, {'name': 'subject', 'value': 'Reviews', 'rank': 2, 'major': 'N'}, {'name': 'subject', 'value': 'Books and Literature', 'rank': 3, 'major': 'N'}, {'name': 'creative_works', 'value': 'BLACK ROSE, THE (BOOK)', 'rank': 4, 'major': 'N'}]
snippet: Charles Wilson reviews novel The Black Rose by Tananarive Due; drawing (S)
lead_paragraph: Tananarive Due's graceful historical novel, THE BLACK ROSE (Ballantine, $25.95), traces the life of Madame C. J. Walker (1867-1919), nee Sarah Breedlove, a penniless girl from Delta, La., who became America's first black female millionaire. This book is based on research and an outline left behind by Alex Haley, who planned to write a novel about Walker; Due, a former columnist for The Miami Herald and the author of two previous novels, has taken the material and made it her own. Walker was orphaned at 6, married at 14 and was widowed a few years later; she was a washerwoman and cook until, in her late 30's, she married a Denver businessman named Charles Walker in 1906. By her death at the age of 51 she was, after starting her own hair care company, extraordinarily wealthy. Sarah's business began with experiments to treat her own hair loss and itchy scalp; thanks to word-of-mouth advertising, the company flourished and eventually employed some 20,000 ''Walker agents'' throughout the country. No retiring mogul, Walker financed a mission school in Africa, stumped for the N.A.A.C.P., sued a movie theater for charging blacks higher ticket prices than whites and built an Italian Renaissance-style palace in upstate New York as her home and as her ''monument to Negro achievement.'' Due's book resists becoming a facile Horatio Alger story: We follow the estrangement between Sarah and her daughter, and watch as Sarah courts the man who would become her second husband, despite our suspicion that he might be a poor companion. ''Maybe when you've lost as much as me, you don't take happy for granted,'' Sarah says. ''You scrape and hoard every piece of happy that comes your way.'' Charles Wilson
abstract: Charles Wilson reviews novel The Black Rose by Tananarive Due; drawing (S)

snippet: IN THE SHADOWS OF HISTORY: Fifty Years Behind the Scenes of Cold War Diplomacy. By Chester L. Cooper. (Prometheus, $28.) The unmasking of W. Mark Felt as Deep Throat is a reminder of the power of a No. 2: he wasn't the boss, but he was twice as da...
lead_paragraph: IN THE SHADOWS OF HISTORY: Fifty Years Behind the Scenes of Cold War Diplomacy. By Chester L. Cooper. (Prometheus, $28.) The unmasking of W. Mark Felt as Deep Throat is a reminder of the power of a No. 2: he wasn't the boss, but he was twice as dangerous. Cooper's political memoir opens with the claim that in his long career as a senior officer in the C.I.A. and various other federal agencies -- "as deputy or special assistant to, of or for somebody or something" -- he has had a wisdom far beyond that of his high-powered but short-term bosses. A promising hypothesis, but what Cooper's experience shows -- from minor O.S.S. operations in China during World War II through Korea, the Cuban missile crisis, Vietnam and other conflicts -- is that bureaucratic work, even all the way (or almost all the way) to the top, is always dull and usually inconsequential. During the Suez crisis of 1956, as the British-French-Israeli plan to recover the canal from Egypt builds to a dangerous standoff, our hero wrings his hands for a while and then plays Monopoly with his family; in 1966 he rubber-stamps an empty promise from President Lyndon Johnson to withdraw troops from Vietnam within six months. Cooper describes every diplomatic tea party and handshake in fetishistic detail, but his role is never clear, nor are any of those vital lessons from history. Sometimes a fly on the wall is just a fly.
abstract: IN THE SHADOWS OF HISTORY: Fifty Years Behind the Scenes of Cold War Diplomacy. By Chester L. Cooper. (Prometheus, $28.) The unmasking of W. Mark Felt as Deep Throat is a reminder of the power of a No. 2: he wasn't the boss, but he was twice as dangerous. Cooper's political memoir opens with the claim that in his long career as a senior officer in the C.I.A. and various other federal agencies -- ''as deputy or special assistant to, of or for somebody or something'' -- he has had a wisdom far beyond that of his high-powered but short-term bosses. A promising hypothesis, but what Cooper's experience shows -- from minor O.S.S. operations in China during World War II through Korea, the Cuban missile crisis, Vietnam and other conflicts -- is that bureaucratic work, even all the way (or almost all the way) to the top, is always dull and usually inconsequential. During the Suez crisis of 1956, as the British-French-Israeli plan to recover the canal from Egypt builds to a dangerous standoff, our hero wrings his hands for a while and then plays Monopoly with his family; in 1966 he rubber-stamps an empty promise from President Lyndon Johnson to withdraw troops from Vietnam within six months. Cooper describes every diplomatic tea party and handshake in fetishistic detail, but his role is never clear, nor are any of those vital lessons from history. Sometimes a fly on the wall is just a fly.       THE LAST VOYAGE OF COLUMBUS: Being the Epic Tale of the Great Captain's Fourth Expedition, Including Accounts of Swordfight, Mutiny, Shipwreck, Gold, War, Hurricane, and Discovery. By Martin Dugard. (Little, Brown, $24.95.) Vast new lands, strange new peoples, Edenic flora and fauna aside, Columbus's four voyages to the new world were commercial enterprises, with a nervous Spanish court expecting a return on its investment. In a rich, fluent account, Dugard offers both a gripping naval adventure and a revealing history of the competitive mercantile politics of the turn of the 16th century, and portrays Columbus as a star-crossed striver eager to legitimize his quest. Reined in by hard-nosed administrators and for a time imprisoned for failing to maintain order in the critical outpost of Santo Domingo, the Admiral of the Ocean Sea made a final, desperate attempt in 1502 to find that elusive passage to India. Perhaps he knew it was doomed when, while searching for gold in the lush Panamanian jungle, a scout was told by angry inhabitants that ''these people were going to burn our ships and kill us all,'' a threat they nearly carried out. The leaking fleet escaped, only to be marooned in Jamaica for a year. But Columbus's ingenuity never failed him. In an archetypal high-seas scam, when the local tribe in Jamaica began to cut off the castaways' food supply, he consulted an astronomy text and told the Indians ''God would send them a clear token from heaven of the punishment they were about to receive'' if they didn't cough up the daily victuals; right on schedule a lunar eclipse came, the Indians cried for mercy, and that was that. Dugard's detailed reconstructions, while sometimes far-fetched (how could he know that Columbus's prison shackles were ''clattering lightly'' as he wrote an apology to Ferdinand and Isabella?), rely on ships' logs, journals, letters and other contemporary accounts, letting the participants describe these extraordinary adventures themselves.

snippet: In Ethan Canin’s novel, a boy from humble roots becomes entangled with a powerful New York family — and its secrets — in the early 1970s.
lead_paragraph: Novelists often bristle when asked to account for what provoked a book to be written. If the reply is a churlish “for me to know and you to find out,” who can blame him or her? Being asked to justify a preoccupation is like being grilled about the attractions of a hobby or a sweetheart.

headline: {'main': "What Was on Lewis Carroll's Mind?", 'kicker': 'THE CLOSE READER', 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': "THE CLOSE READER; What Was on Lewis Carroll's Mind?", 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}
byline: {'original': 'By Judith Shulevitz', 'person': [{'firstname': 'Judith', 'middlename': None, 'lastname': 'Shulevitz', 'qualifier': None, 'title': None, 'role': 'reported', 'organization': '', 'rank': 1}], 'organization': None}
keywords: [{'name': 'persons', 'value': 'Leach, Karoline', 'rank': 1, 'major': 'N'}, {'name': 'persons', 'value': 'Dodgson, Charles Lutwidge', 'rank': 2, 'major': 'N'}, {'name': 'subject', 'value': 'Books and Literature', 'rank': 3, 'major': 'N'}, {'name': 'creative_works', 'value': 'IN THE SHADOW OF THE DREAMCHILD (BOOK)', 'rank': 4, 'major': 'N'}]
snippet: Judith Shulevitz The Close Reader column on continuing debate over Lewis Carroll's apparent obsession with little girls; discusses book by Karoline Leach titled In the Shadow of the Dreamchild; drawing (M)
lead_paragraph: ART begets certainties that biography can't confirm. We know, for instance, that Charles Lutwidge Dodgson, whose nom de plume was Lewis Carroll, loved little girls a little too much. Only a man with a dangerous affinity with female children could have produced the defiantly sane Alice, debunker of Wonderland; the beautiful and troubling photographs of her real-life counterpart, Alice Liddell; and all those other portraits of startlingly unbashful prepubescent maidens. The historical record, riddled with gaps made when Dodgson's family excised passages from his diary or mislaid volumes altogether, doesn't prove Dodgson's -- let's not call it pedophilia, let's call it obsession -- but doesn't disprove it either, and so into the evidentiary void generations of biographers and novelists and filmmakers have poured their beliefs about his secret sexual predilections, which have been repeated so often they have attained the status of fact.
abstract: Judith Shulevitz The Close Reader column on continuing debate over Lewis Carroll's apparent obsession with little girls; discusses book by Karoline Leach titled In the Shadow of the Dreamchild; drawing (M)

snippet: Unknown
lead_paragraph: BORROWED FINERY: A Memoir, by Paula Fox. (Owl/Holt, $12.) According to this fragmentary account of her childhood, the author has repeatedly fictionalized her real life in both her children's books and her adult fiction. And it's not a very pretty story: her parents were cruelly feckless, and after her mother decreed she had to go, Fox was passed among relatives and friends in locales as varied as Long Island, Hollywood and Cuba. Her imagistic memoir, chosen by the editors of the Book Review as one of the best books of 2001, displays her ''intelligence and her exceptional eye,'' Thomas Mallon wrote here. ''Sharp observations and pieces of humor stick out from all the confusion and dread.'' Fox's recently reissued novel THE GOD OF NIGHTMARES (Norton, $13.95) follows the fortunes of a young woman who abandons her sheltered life on a rural horse farm to search for her aunt in the liberating, bohemian world of New Orleans in 1941. In 1990 our reviewer, Jill McCorkle, admired the tale's ''wonderfully rich'' prose.
abstract: BORROWED FINERY: A Memoir, by Paula Fox. (Owl/Holt, $12.) According to this fragmentary account of her childhood, the author has repeatedly fictionalized her real life in both her children's books and her adult fiction. And it's not a very pretty story: her parents were cruelly feckless, and after her mother decreed she had to go, Fox was passed among relatives and friends in locales as varied as Long Island, Hollywood and Cuba. Her imagistic memoir, chosen by the editors of the Book Review as one of the best books of 2001, displays her ''intelligence and her exceptional eye,'' Thomas Mallon wrote here. ''Sharp observations and pieces of humor stick out from all the confusion and dread.'' Fox's recently reissued novel THE GOD OF NIGHTMARES (Norton, $13.95) follows the fortunes of a young woman who abandons her sheltered life on a rural horse farm to search for her aunt in the liberating, bohemian world of New Orleans in 1941. In 1990 our reviewer, Jill McCorkle, admired the tale's ''wonderfully rich'' prose.    WAR IN A TIME OF PEACE: Bush, Clinton, and the Generals, by David Halberstam. (Touchstone/Simon & Schuster, $16.) Examining the foreign policy challenges facing President Bill Clinton and the first President Bush, the author finds that the United States, whose power structure was filled with decision makers personally touched by the Vietnam War, was reluctant to commit itself in Bosnia, Somalia, Haiti and elsewhere. Last year in these pages, Jane Perlez called this ''a sprawling tapestry of exquisite bottom-up reporting and powerful vignettes.''    THE GRAND COMPLICATION, by Allen Kurzweil. (Theia/Hyperion, $16.) Alexander Short, a New York librarian obsessed with rules and order, is enlisted by an eccentric bibliophile and collector (who happens to have a crush on him) to help track down a missing watch belonging to an 18th-century inventor. The result is a ''satisfying, multilevel tale'' of love and mystery, D. T. Max wrote in the Book Review in 2001. ''Kurzweil has a gentle touch, and Alexander is a delightful observer.''    WHERE DEAD VOICES GATHER, by Nick Tosches. (Back Bay/ Little, Brown, $14.95.) The author's sketchy portrait of the 1920's blackface minstrel Emmett Miller (1900-62), whom he calls ''one of the strangest and most stunning of stylists ever to record,'' is also ''a book of asides on creativity, originality and individuality,'' Jeff Waggoner said here last year. ''His quest for the facts about Miller may have come up short, but he has turned his failure into a memorable rumination, full of roguish passion and sardonic humor, on forgotten men like Miller.''    RECENT HISTORY, by Anthony Giardina. (Random House, $13.95.) This novel's hero is 12 years old in 1962, when his father abandons his close-knit Italian family to move in with another man, an act that casts a long shadow over his son's sexual coming of age. Giardina ''manages to handle an enormous amount of emotional material with a light touch,'' Jessica Olin wrote in these pages last year.    THE HUNTERS: Two Novellas, by Claire Messud. (Harvest/Harcourt, $13.) In ''A Simple Tale,'' an aging Ukrainian woman who has led an unrelentingly bleak life of exile and endurance (she and her husband moved to Canada after surviving German work camps) comes to wonder at what point she can abandon the past. The second novella, ''The Hunters,'' tells of an American tenant in a dingy London apartment building who allows his imagination to run wild when he suspects his downstairs neighbor may be a mass murderer. Last year our reviewer, Miranda Seymour, preferred the first tale, calling it ''a marvelously subtle and poignant work'' of ''near miraculous perfection.''    FOUR WINGS AND A PRAYER: Caught in the Mystery of the Monarch Butterfly, by Sue Halpern. (Vintage, $12.) Traveling up to 200 miles a day, monarchs as far as Canada and the Pacific Coast fly to the same Mexican forest each fall -- and it isn't memory that guides them. ''Halpern delivers wonderful images'' as she ''tells the story of the amazing butterflies . . . and the equally interesting story of the entomologists and amateur enthusiasts who migrate with them,'' Carol Peace Robins wrote here in 2001.    JUNO & JULIET, by Julian Gough. (Anchor, $13.) This first novel chronicles the adventures -- mainly romantic -- of a pair of beautiful identical twins coping with their first year at the University of Galway. ''With all its adolescent ironies,'' the story ''still manages to be intelligent, lighthearted and thoroughly entertaining,'' William Ferguson said here last year.   SCOTT VEALE

keywords: [{'name': 'subject', 'value': 'Books and Literature', 'rank': 1, 'major': 'N'}, {'name': 'subject', 'value': 'Organized Crime', 'rank': 2, 'major': 'N'}, {'name': 'glocations', 'value': 'Italy', 'rank': 3, 'major': 'N'}]
snippet: A journalist explores the rampant organized crime in Italy’s Campania region.
lead_paragraph: To the average tourist, or even the devoted Italophile, the Italy of Roberto Saviano’s “Gomorrah” is an utterly unrecognizable place. There is no Renaissance art, no leisurely lunches or bustling piazzas, no world-class design, no achingly beautiful landscapes. Instead, we find an alien land of doped-up child soldiers, gun-toting clan women, illegal Chinese immigrants, sweatshops, drug smuggling, garbage and cement.

keywords: [{'name': 'subject', 'value': 'Books and Literature', 'rank': 1, 'major': 'N'}, {'name': 'persons', 'value': 'Spencer, Scott', 'rank': 2, 'major': 'N'}, {'name': 'subject', 'value': 'Prostitution', 'rank': 3, 'major': 'N'}]
snippet: In Scott Spencer’s new novel, a cuckolded writer embarks on a therapeutic assignment: a sex-tour exposé.
lead_paragraph: Scott Spencer has, through his career, established an instantly recognizable voice: blunt, earthy and intellectual, if not always wise. When employed well, this voice has great appeal. In orbit around the novels themselves are a few reliable moons. Spencer’s central characters are typically misruled by obsession  with women, usually younger; with their parents, often still living; and with money, rarely their own. It is not a Scott Spencer novel if the main character does not, at some point, fear for his sanity.

keywords: [{'name': 'persons', 'value': 'Bradbury, Ray', 'rank': 1, 'major': 'N'}, {'name': 'persons', 'value': 'Woods, Stuart', 'rank': 2, 'major': 'N'}, {'name': 'persons', 'value': 'Roberts, Nora', 'rank': 3, 'major': 'N'}, {'name': 'persons', 'value': 'Kamp, David', 'rank': 4, 'major': 'N'}, {'name': 'subject', 'value': 'Books and Literature', 'rank': 5, 'major': 'N'}]
snippet: FIXES ARE IN: The thriller writer Stuart Woods -- his novel ''Short Straw'' is No. 8 on the fiction list -- doesn't want to hear from readers about factual mistakes in his books. ''Save time for yourself and me, and DO NOT write to me about errors...
lead_paragraph: FIXES ARE IN: The thriller writer Stuart Woods -- his novel "Short Straw" is No. 8 on the fiction list -- doesn't want to hear from readers about factual mistakes in his books. "Save time for yourself and me, and DO NOT write to me about errors and corrections," he says on his Web site. "The book is going to remain pretty much as it's first published, errors and all." That's a curious position to take, even for a novelist, and one that bucks a trend. Many writers are scurrying, while their books are still in hardcover editions, to fess up to errors early and often. Take David Kamp, the author of "The United States of Arugula." On the "corrections" page of his Web site, Kamp admits misplacing a popular 70's-era Manhattan restaurant in his book. Then he makes the fix and thanks the reader who pointed it out: Amy Fine Collins, a fellow Vanity Fair writer. Just because writers are more open about their screw-ups doesn't mean they're happy about them, however. Kamp writes: "O.K., now, readers: Order Collins's 'The God of Driving,' and find some mistakes in her book."

''Save time for yourself and me, and DO NOT write to me about errors and corrections,'' he says on his Web site. ''The book is going to remain pretty much as it's first published, errors and all.'' That's a curious position to take, even for a novelist, and one that bucks a trend. Many writers are scurrying, while their books are still in hardcover editions, to fess up to errors early and often. Take David Kamp, the author of ''The United States of Arugula.'' On the ''corrections'' page of his Web site, Kamp admits misplacing a popular 70's-era Manhattan restaurant in his book. Then he makes the fix and thanks the reader who pointed it out: Amy Fine Collins, a fellow Vanity Fair writer. Just because writers are more open about their screw-ups doesn't mean they're happy about them, however. Kamp writes: ''O.K., now, readers: Order Collins's 'The God of Driving,' and find some mistakes in her book.''
