headline: {'main': 'And Bear In Mind', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'And Bear In Mind', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}
byline: {'original': None, 'person': [], 'organization': None}
snippet: Unknown
lead_paragraph: (Editors' choices of other recent books of particular interest)
abstract: (Editors' choices of other recent books of particular interest)    THE TAPIR'S MORNING BATH: Mysteries of the Tropical Rain Forest and the Scientists Who Are Trying to Solve Them, by Elizabeth Royte. (Houghton Mifflin, $25.) A year's exacting work at the Smithsonian's research center in Panama, rendered by a smart writer who has no fear of complex situations.    THE BEAUTY OF THE HUSBAND: A Fictional Essay in 29 Tangos, by Anne Carson. (Knopf, $22.) Poems are they, these objects? Whatever, they are bold and abbreviated, they fear no free association and no kind of knowledge or desire and are overtly concerned with the ways intellectual discernment can clash with erotic taste.    SAILING ALONE AROUND THE ROOM: New and Selected Poems, by Billy Collins. (Random House, $21.95.) Clean, suburban, antiseptic, humorous poems by the new poet laureate of the United States. Death, longing and regret figure in his work, but only at the margins; the heart remains funny.    MARY SHELLEY, by Miranda Seymour. (Grove, $35.) The author (at 19!) of ''Frankenstein'' lived at the center of English Romanticism and knew all its characters; Seymour's new biography sketches the scientific background of ''Frankenstein'' and delineates the Shelley-Byron circle, including the sexual who-whom that rotated around its two dominant rich kids.    THE WORLD BELOW, by Sue Miller. (Knopf, $25.) The grasp of this ambitious novel stretches to seven generations; the narrator, an up-to-date twice-divorced mother, hears in her grandmother's journals the voice of a simpler time, and recognizes the weight and power of the pastoral impulse, valuable however much it is recognized as a simplification.    VENICE: LION CITY. The Religion of Empire, by Garry Wills. (Simon & Schuster, $35.) A cultural historian's guide to the Most Serene Republic through the arts, beliefs and ideologies that sustained it in its days as a medium-great power, able to withstand the Turks in the Mediterranean and rule much of Italy.    THE PRACTICAL HEART: Four Novellas, by Allan Gurganus. (Knopf, $25.) Well, some of them are more like memoirs than novellas. The title story, about a woman who got herself painted by Sargent, is an elusive Jamesian affair; there's also a coming-out story, a ditsy ramble from a preservationist journal and ''Saint Monster,'' about a boy who unwillingly destroys his father.    BORROWED FINERY: A Memoir, by Paula Fox. (Holt, $23.) A fascinating, fragmentary account by a novelist who has repeatedly put her life in her fiction; in reality, Fox's existence was somehow a calamitous insult to her mother, who got rid of her as fast as possible.    THE SAVAGE GIRL, by Alex Shakar. (HarperCollins, $26.) A wild first novel about a young woman who has moved to Middle City and taken a job with a trend-spotting visionary who sees a perfect product in diet water.

keywords: [{'name': 'persons', 'value': "D'Amato, Alfonse M", 'rank': 1, 'major': 'N'}, {'name': 'subject', 'value': 'Books and Literature', 'rank': 2, 'major': 'N'}, {'name': 'creative_works', 'value': 'POWER, PASTA AND POLITICS (BOOK)', 'rank': 3, 'major': 'N'}]
snippet: Unknown
lead_paragraph: POWER, PASTA AND POLITICS The World According to Senator Al D'Amato. By Alfonse M. D'Amato. Hyperion, $24.95.
abstract: POWER, PASTA AND POLITICS  The World According to  Senator Al D'Amato. By Alfonse M. D'Amato. Hyperion, $24.95.     "I paid a price for pursuing Whitewater," Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato writes in "Power, Pasta and Politics." He elaborates: He was insulted by Phil Donahue, sneered at and subjected to "any number of energetic outbursts" by television commentators, and depicted as "an arrogant lout" in "Doonesbury." Hardly the stuff of "Profiles in Courage." Mr. D'Amato's political biography begins by revealing a lot about what drives him and, perhaps, about his surprising defense of individual rights in allowing homosexuals in the military -- an issue, he warns in a savvy final chapter, that threatens to split the Republican Party. As a youngster, he writes, he was embarrassed by his first name, terrorized by a bully (a label he also applies to Saddam Hussein and Mario Cuomo) and dumped into a special reading class because of his bad eyesight. The book lapses into Mr. D'Amato's distinct voice when he recounts his search for a place to lunch with President Ronald Reagan in Little Italy ("I'd like to make a reservation for 12, no smoking, and oh, by the way, do you have organized-crime connections?"), a memorable exchange with Elizabeth Holtzman ("Well, they finally got your brother," she said, to which the Senator replied, "Liz, you are as ugly on the inside as you are on the outside"), and the day he and Rudolph W. Giuliani, then the United States Attorney for Manhattan, donned ridiculous undercover disguises to expose drug dealing (perhaps, he writes with what may be unintended irony, "the high point of our alliance"). Mr. D'Amato is less revealing when describing patronage abuses in his Nassau County home base or the lingering ethics accusations of which he and his brother, Armand Jr., were largely cleared. He acknowledges that the Senate Ethics Committee did admonish him, but doesn't quote its conclusion that he "conducted the business of his office in an improper and inappropriate manner." Without accepting blame, he writes, "I personally lament the fact that politics has come to be held in such low regard." If you like Mr. D'Amato's brazenness, you'll like his book. SAM ROBERTS

snippet: In David Lodge's 1984 novel, ''Small World,'' a literature professor fond of computer programming presents a novelist with a fantastic discovery: by entering all the novelist's books into a computer, the professor can determine the novelist's favo...
lead_paragraph: In David Lodge's 1984 novel, "Small World," a literature professor fond of computer programming presents a novelist with a fantastic discovery: by entering all the novelist's books into a computer, the professor can determine the novelist's favorite word. The computer knows to ignore the mortar of sentences -- articles, prepositions, pronouns -- to get to "the real nitty-gritty," Lodge writes, "words like love or dark or heart or God." But the computer's conclusion causes the novelist to shrink from ever writing again. His favorite word, it finds, is "greasy."
abstract: In David Lodge's 1984 novel, ''Small World,'' a literature professor fond of computer programming presents a novelist with a fantastic discovery: by entering all the novelist's books into a computer, the professor can determine the novelist's favorite word. The computer knows to ignore the mortar of sentences -- articles, prepositions, pronouns -- to get to ''the real nitty-gritty,'' Lodge writes, ''words like love or dark or heart or God.'' But the computer's conclusion causes the novelist to shrink from ever writing again. His favorite word, it finds, is ''greasy.''    Two decades later, Amazon.com, improving on its popular ''search inside the book'' function, in April introduced a concordance program, whereby a click of the mouse reveals a book's most frequently occurring words, ''excluding common words.'' Further clicks reveal their contexts. And so we learn that the nitty-gritty words appearing most frequently in the King James Bible include ''God,'' ''Lord,'' ''shall'' and ''unto.'' The word that appears most frequently in T. S. Eliot's ''Collected Poems'' is ''time'' -- ''There will be time, there will be time'' -- while the word that turns up most frequently in ''Extraordinary Golf,'' by Fred Shoemaker and Pete Shoemaker, is, illuminatively, ''golf.''

snippet: Unknown
lead_paragraph: What if the chimney St. Nicholas came down had not been that of Clement Clarke Moore in the 1820's but that of Walter Winchell in the 1930's? Or Ernest Hemingway in the 50's, or Shirley MacLaine at some point in reincarnational space-time, or, closer to our own era, Jackie Collins, Jay McInerney or Clive Cussler? Imagine! Better, let Bruce McCall imagine it, as he does here. Instead of reciting Moore's "Visit From St. Nicholas" while roasting chestnuts on an open fire, we'd have to force children to memorize stuff like the following frightening accounts of the night before Christmas, somewhere, somewhen.

snippet: The battle of Leyte Gulf, the last great naval confrontation of World War II, is the focus of Evan Thomas’s new book.
lead_paragraph: A peculiar characteristic of warfare after 1945 was that while navies became steadily more powerful and more expensive, naval battles — that is, combat between fleets of ships at sea — became almost extinct. Thus it is easy to understand the fascination of the Battle of Leyte Gulf, the last great naval confrontation of the 20th century, fought from Oct. 23 to 26, 1944, between the American and Japanese Navies in the waters off the Philippines. The scale of the battle was immense, involving four separate engagements extending over hundreds of miles, between fleets that included 35 large and small aircraft carriers, 21 battleships, 34 cruisers and hundreds of destroyers, along with submarines and motor torpedo boats and more than 1,700 aircraft.

snippet: Unknown
lead_paragraph: Only readers familiar with Neal Stephenson's previous novel, the turbocharged "Snowcrash," will appreciate the relative restraint of THE DIAMOND AGE (Spectra/Bantam, $22.95). "Snowcrash" drew its manic energy from the cyber punkish conceit that anything is possible in virtual reality; in "The Diamond Age" the wonders of cyberspace pale before the even more dazzling powers of nanotechnology.
abstract: Only readers familiar with Neal Stephenson's previous novel, the turbocharged "Snowcrash," will appreciate the relative restraint of THE DIAMOND AGE (Spectra/Bantam, $22.95). "Snowcrash" drew its manic energy from the cyber punkish conceit that anything is possible in virtual reality; in "The Diamond Age" the wonders of cyberspace pale before the even more dazzling powers of nanotechnology.   Nanotechnology, which is still only a gleam in the eye of science, rearranges molecules the way a riverboat gambler shuffles a deck of cards. With sufficient energy and an ample supply of raw material, nanotechnology can convert any kind of matter into any other kind. Instead of letting this potent tool run away with his narrative, Mr. Stephenson wisely focuses on the social implications of a new materialism that is beyond the dreams of any previous Gilded Age.

keywords: [{'name': 'persons', 'value': 'Lacambre, Genevieve', 'rank': 1, 'major': 'N'}, {'name': 'persons', 'value': 'Moreau, Gustave', 'rank': 2, 'major': 'N'}, {'name': 'subject', 'value': 'Reviews', 'rank': 3, 'major': 'N'}, {'name': 'subject', 'value': 'Books and Literature', 'rank': 4, 'major': 'N'}, {'name': 'creative_works', 'value': 'GUSTAVE MOREAU: BETWEEN EPIC AND DREAM ((BOOK)', 'rank': 5, 'major': 'N'}]
snippet: Suzanne MacNeille reviews book Gustave Moreau: Between Epic and Dream by Genevieve Lacambre; drawing (S)
lead_paragraph: The French painter Gustave Moreau (1826-98) was a visionary who resisted getting swept up in the late-19th-century tides of naturalism and Impressionism and pursued instead his own version of an epic past. Through his eclectic use of exotic imagery, he imbued his mythical and biblical scenes with an Oriental mysticism, creating what Genevieve Lacambre, the director of the Musee Gustave Moreau in Paris, in GUSTAVE MOREAU: Between Epic and Dream (Art Institute of Chicago/Princeton University, $60), calls ''a realm of evocation, imagination and dreams.'' But to many of his contemporaries, Moreau's vision was perplexing. ''Are we in poor Judea or in the home of the opulent rajah of Mysore?'' one mystified critic asked after viewing one of Moreau's most celebrated paintings, ''Salome,'' at the Paris Salon of 1876. In the 20th century Moreau has become even more of an enigma. Largely ignored by an Impressionism-obsessed public, and often pigeonholed by critics as a transitional artist whose work paved the way for Surrealism, Moreau's best-known legacy may be that he taught Henri Matisse and Georges Rouault. ''Gustave Moreau: Between Epic and Dream,'' with more than 200 color reproductions, essays by several Moreau scholars, and Lacambre's historical and critical text about the artist's major works, examines Moreau's amazingly varied influences, which include da Vinci's ''Adoration of the Magi,'' Algerian dance costumes, Mogul miniatures, medieval tapestries and the seven labors of Hercules. The many excerpts from Moreau's own writings give the reader the clearest idea of what he aspired to: ''the flashes of illumination that one doesn't know how to situate, that have something divine in their seeming insignificance.'' Suzanne MacNeille
abstract: Suzanne MacNeille reviews book Gustave Moreau: Between Epic and Dream by Genevieve Lacambre; drawing (S)

snippet: David Leavitt explores class in a historical novel about the English mathematician G. H. Hardy and a poor clerk working in a colonial office in Madras.
lead_paragraph: In the most common type of historical novel, invented characters inhabit a real place at a particular point in time. They may fight in the Civil War, or watch the Kennedy assassination on a black-and-white TV, but they live in an essentially separate space, and the author may decide which real events (if any) should touch their lives. The second type, rarer in so-called literary fiction, is a novel about people who really existed, recreated by an author who plays with the facts, and especially the intriguing lacunae, of their lives. “The Indian Clerk,” David Leavitt’s richly imagined seventh novel, is such a book, and for several reasons Leavitt is brave to attempt it.

snippet: A hefty new volume collects Charles Bukowski’s hard-found music of the streets.
lead_paragraph: Poetry shouldn’t tell us what we already know, though of course it can revive what we think we know. A durable poet, the rarest of all birds, has a unique point of view and the gift of language to express it. The unique point of view can often come from a mental or physical deformity. Deep within us, but also on the surface, is the wounded ugly boy who has never caught an acceptable angle of himself in the mirror. A poet can have a deep sense of himself as a Quasimodo in a world without bells, or as the fine poet Czeslaw Milosz wrote:

keywords: [{'name': 'persons', 'value': 'Gammell, Stephen', 'rank': 1, 'major': 'N'}, {'name': 'subject', 'value': 'Reviews', 'rank': 2, 'major': 'N'}, {'name': 'subject', 'value': 'Books and Literature', 'rank': 3, 'major': 'N'}, {'name': 'creative_works', 'value': 'RIDE (BOOK)', 'rank': 4, 'major': 'N'}]
snippet: Scott Veale reviews book Ride by Stephen Gammell; drawing (S)
lead_paragraph: Every parent has been there: the low rumble rising from the back seat, growing in pitch and urgency as the miles tick off and patience wears thin. It's the ''Are we there yet?'' syndrome, and it's the subject of RIDE (Silver Whistle/Harcourt, $16; ages 5 to 9), a quirky, gently subversive look at life in the rearview mirror, written and illustrated by Stephen Gammell. He sets his story in the long-ago of his childhood, even though he begs us to believe: ''What you see in this book never happened in our back seat. Oh no. I just made this up. Really.''
abstract: Scott Veale reviews book Ride by Stephen Gammell; drawing (S)

snippet: A professed grouch travels to pleasurable destinations and analyzes their formulas for happiness.
lead_paragraph: Pity the writer who attempts a treatise on happiness without resorting to shopworn philosophic quotations and the predictable shout-out to Tolstoy. Surely Eric Weiner deserves points for devising a new way to address the perennial question of what makes people happy and why.

keywords: [{'name': 'persons', 'value': 'Hart, Josephine', 'rank': 1, 'major': 'N'}, {'name': 'subject', 'value': 'Reviews', 'rank': 2, 'major': 'N'}, {'name': 'subject', 'value': 'Books and Literature', 'rank': 3, 'major': 'N'}, {'name': 'creative_works', 'value': 'OBLIVION (BOOK)', 'rank': 4, 'major': 'N'}]
snippet: Unknown
lead_paragraph: OBLIVION By Josephine Hart. Viking, $19.95.
abstract: OBLIVION  By Josephine Hart. Viking, $19.95.     Laura is dead. Her husband, Andrew, just can't stop thinking about her -- even as he's diligently trysting with Sarah, a lusty young thing who would make an admirable replacement wife. Andrew's mother-in-law, a retired civil servant named Jane, is also thinking about Laura and holding impromptu solo seances in Laura's old room, sometimes in the nude. Then she starts following Sarah, finding herself "moved to sudden tears" when she watches her daughter's rival buying tampons in a drugstore. Readers of Josephine Hart's previous novels, "Damage" and "Sin," may be forgiven for expecting these preliminary maneuvers to be whipped into yet another kinkily dysfunctional family set-to. But here the drama is presented in a thuddingly literal fashion as Andrew, who interviews celebrities on television, takes himself off to grill Catherine, a cranky old playwright, then sits through a reading of her latest work, ominously entitled "The Book." Andrew seems to find it all fascinating and therapeutic. Readers -- who must endure an 80-page script in which the grimly larky voices of a crowd of dear and not so dear departed try to "get across the fact that they existed" -- will soon be squirming in their seats. When it's all over, Jane has stopped being sinister and Andrew has resigned himself to remaining "a little sad" forever. The rest of us are left pondering the remarks of the "Maitre Death" of Catherine's play: "Remember, the people with the most interesting stories aren't necessarily the ones who talk." ALIDA BECKER

snippet: Unknown
lead_paragraph: WONDERS OF THE AFRICAN WORLD, by Henry Louis Gates Jr. Photographs by Lynn Davis. (Knopf, $24.95.) The Harvard professor and noted essayist draws on 30 years of experience visiting and studying Africa in this lively introduction to the continent's history and archaeology, which highlights the achievements of African societies from Timbuktu to Zanzibar. Originally a ''companion'' to a PBS series, the book is somewhat limited in scope, but ''Gates writes with concentration and clarity,'' William Langewiesche wrote in the Book Review in 1999.
abstract: WONDERS OF THE AFRICAN WORLD, by Henry Louis Gates Jr. Photographs by Lynn Davis. (Knopf, $24.95.) The Harvard professor and noted essayist draws on 30 years of experience visiting and studying Africa in this lively introduction to the continent's history and archaeology, which highlights the achievements of African societies from Timbuktu to Zanzibar. Originally a ''companion'' to a PBS series, the book is somewhat limited in scope, but ''Gates writes with concentration and clarity,'' William Langewiesche wrote in the Book Review in 1999.    MR. SPACEMAN, by Robert Olen Butler. (Grove, $12.) This novel's hero is Desi, a many-fingered, zoot-suit-wearing extraterrestrial who learns to speak a demented English by watching television and who beams up American earthlings to his spaceship to pick their brains. His mission is to reveal himself to the world on the eve of the millennium. ''Desi is the most likable, engaging and human of aliens,'' Geoff Nicholson said in these pages last year.    EDWARD ALBEE. A Singular Journey: A Biography, by Mel Gussow. (Applause, $16.95.) The Pulitzer Prize-winning playwright is portrayed by a cultural critic for The New York Times as tenaciously self-assured despite his ragged record on Broadway, and remarkably candid about his many ups and downs. In 1999 our reviewer, Lawrence DeVine, called this ''a riveting biography.''    MOTHER NATURE: Maternal Instincts and How They Shape the Human Species, by Sarah Blaffer Hrdy. (Ballantine, $18.95.) A biologist and anthropologist (as well as a parent) questions some long-held assumptions about maternity, presenting encyclopedic evidence from history, literature and evolutionary science to support her theory that motherhood is neither instinctive nor automatic. ''This is not just a book for mothers but one that will stimulate and challenge anyone interested in the relationship between parents and children,'' Anne Magurran said here last year.    A STRANGER IN THE EARTH, by Marcel Theroux. (Harvest/Harcourt, $13.) Horace Littlefair is an amiably tweedy orphan who stumbles into London to take a job at an eccentric newspaper that at first glance resembles something cooked up by Evelyn Waugh. But this novel is less a satire than a kindhearted coming-of-age story that revels in its characters' predicaments and the messiness of life. It ''delights because it's never quite what you expect it to be,'' David Willis McCullough said here in 1999.    WHERE THE RAINBOW ENDS, by Jameson Currier. (Overlook, $14.95.) This first novel revolves around a group of gay friends and lovers as they mature from their exuberant, sexually liberated early days in 1970's Manhattan to more cautious, often painful, lives in the 1990's. ''Currier is adept at drawing a fine line between the erotic and the tragic,'' Erik Burns wrote here in 1999.    MOTH SMOKE, by Mohsin Hamid. (Picador USA, $13.) Set in modern-day Pakistan, this Gatsbyesque first novel traces the downward spiral of a young man who is resentful and mocking of the sybaritic jet set while desperate to join its ranks. The result is a ''brisk, absorbing'' tale that ''probes the vulgarity and violence that lurk beneath a surface of affluence and ease,'' Jhumpa Lahiri said in the Book Review last year. ''Hamid steers us from start to finish with assurance and care.''    HOMEMADE ESTHETICS: Observations on Art and Taste, by Clement Greenberg. (Oxford University, $15.95.) In a series of seminars at Bennington College in 1971, the influential art critic Clement Greenberg (1909-94) argues that taste matters above all in making aesthetic judgments. His book ''is studded with bright aper-->us, sharp critique and copious evidence of refreshingly honest taste formation,'' David Cohen wrote in these pages in 1999.    NOBROW: The Culture of Marketing -- the Marketing of Culture, by John Seabrook. (Vintage, $12.) Part memoir of a cultural consumer, part group portrait of today's ''culture capitalists'' in the entertainment industry, this book argues that a ''hierarchy of hotness'' has replaced traditional notions of quality. ''Seabrook is at his best in dryly sending up the artificiality and arbitrariness of life in the culture ministries,'' Alexander Star wrote here in 2000.    FORTUNE'S ROCKS, by Anita Shreve. (Back Bay/Little, Brown, $13.95.) This unabashedly florid novel turns on the carnal education of a young girl who falls for a married doctor in a New Hampshire coastal town. The result ''is a slickly made confection for readers who want to laugh and cry at the noble struggle of the human heart,'' Albert Mobilio said here in 1999.   Scott Veale

abstract: Additional titles of interest:   MAXI, THE STAR. By Debra and Sal Barracca. Illustrated by Alan Ayers. Dial. $13.99. (Ages 5 to 9) A producer wants to test Maxi the taxi dog for a pet food commercial, so he and his driver, Jim, set out from New York to California. Hollywood is fun, the test is a success, but Jim and Maxi are glad to be back in Manhattan at the end. The intensely colored illustrations of city scenes and the wide-open spaces are richly amusing.

keywords: [{'name': 'subject', 'value': 'Books and Literature', 'rank': 1, 'major': 'N'}, {'name': 'subject', 'value': 'Biographical Information', 'rank': 2, 'major': 'N'}, {'name': 'persons', 'value': 'Lerman, Leo', 'rank': 3, 'major': 'N'}]
snippet: A magnificent arrangement of the unpublished memoirs and correspondence of Leo Lerman, a dazzling man who knew absolutely everyone.
lead_paragraph: Leo Lerman once turned down an invitation from the king and queen of Spain so he could dine with the Condé Nast publishing magnate Donald Newhouse. Another time, he flatly rejected a “Narcissus naked” Yul Brynner, who was begging him to sleep with him and pathetically murmuring, “Why won’t you? Why won’t you?” The first, and probably only, woman Lerman ever saw naked was his great friend Marlene Dietrich, at a time when she was having what he described in a diary entry as an “intense affair with Yul.” According to Lerman’s lifelong love and partner, the artist Gray Foy, Dietrich had asked Lerman into her bath to demonstrate “the female anatomy.” Apparently, Lerman took in the view with respectful attention, if not passion. But he was not always so above-it-all. Meeting a young writer at a New York gathering in the mid-1940s, he complied with good humor when the man jumped on his back in a stairwell and demanded a piggyback ride. That man turned out to be Truman Capote. If you are not one of the sun-seeking stems craning out of the thicket of magazine-world Manhattan, this may raise an echoing question for you: Who is Leo Lerman?

byline: {'original': 'By Scott Veale', 'person': [{'firstname': 'Scott', 'middlename': None, 'lastname': 'Veale', 'qualifier': None, 'title': None, 'role': 'reported', 'organization': '', 'rank': 1}], 'organization': None}
snippet: Unknown
lead_paragraph: THE SHAPE OF THINGS TO COME, by Maud Casey. (Perennial/HarperCollins, $12.95.) This first novel's heroine, bounced from her job in San Francisco, returns to her desolate Midwestern hometown, where she tries to keep her angst at bay while working as a ''mystery shopper,'' assuming new identities to spy on faceless mall and town-house developments. ''Casey is a stand-up philosopher posing the most vexing questions about human existence while satirizing the materialistic ways we find to hold our despair at a distance,'' Valerie Sayers wrote here last year.
abstract: THE SHAPE OF THINGS TO COME, by Maud Casey. (Perennial/HarperCollins, $12.95.) This first novel's heroine, bounced from her job in San Francisco, returns to her desolate Midwestern hometown, where she tries to keep her angst at bay while working as a ''mystery shopper,'' assuming new identities to spy on faceless mall and town-house developments. ''Casey is a stand-up philosopher posing the most vexing questions about human existence while satirizing the materialistic ways we find to hold our despair at a distance,'' Valerie Sayers wrote here last year.    NO PEACE, NO HONOR: Nixon, Kissinger, and Betrayal in Vietnam, by Larry Berman. (Touchstone/Simon & Schuster, $14.) Drawing on newly available archival materials, the author builds a strong case that Richard Nixon encouraged the South Vietnamese to refuse to negotiate with North Vietnam and then betrayed them by allowing Henry Kissinger to make secret deals with the North. Last year our reviewer, Jack F. Matlock Jr., praised Berman's ''carefully researched analysis and measured, though damning, conclusions.'' Touchstone has also reissued Vietnam: The Necessary War: A Reinterpretation of America's Most Disastrous Military Conflict, by Michael Lind ($14), a bold polemic that attacks cold war revisionism and puts the domino theory back on center stage. In 1999 in these pages, Sam Tanenhaus called this an ''intriguing and original book.''    BOSIE: A Biography of Lord Alfred Douglas, by Douglas Murray. (Talk Miramax/Hyperion, $14.) This portrait of the beautiful young man whose achievements as a sonneteer were overshadowed by his betrayal of his lover, Oscar Wilde, was published when the author was 20 years old. It pulls no punches in recounting Douglas's flaws and his bizarre journey to the brink of madness. The result is ''a shrewd, generous and wise biography,'' Miranda Seymour wrote here in 2000. ''Its stories and its cast of characters make it irresistible -- although not because of their charm.''    YELLOW: Stories, by Don Lee. (Norton, $13.95.) Questions of identity are central in these tales by a third-generation Korean-American. Most of them are set in a fictional California town and revolve around well-mannered, baffled men and a rowdy bunch of self-assured women. Lee ''proves himself a worthy practitioner of realistic fiction in the vein of writers like Richard Yates and Andre Dubus,'' Will Blythe wrote in the Book Review in 2001.    THE STRENGTH OF POETRY: Oxford Lectures, by James Fenton. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $15.) In a collection of lectures delivered as professor of poetry at Oxford, the author pays tribute to the quirks and confusions of 20th-century poets as varied as Wilfred Owen, Sylvia Plath, W. H. Auden and Seamus Heaney. The result is ''a series of passionately intelligent conversations between critic and poet,'' Edward Mendelson said here last year.    FURY, by Salman Rushdie. (Modern Library, $12.95.) In his first novel to be set squarely in New York City, Rushdie tells the tale of Malik Solanka, a former Cambridge professor from Bombay whose skill as a deviser of television puppets enables him to indulge in elaborate replays of the creator-creation question and to rail against the poisonous excesses of his adopted culture. Last year in these pages, Richard Eder found the book overly convoluted and not among Rushdie's strongest works, but said, ''Malik's pronouncements on New York and America are sometimes ingenious and acute.''    THE DEVIL'S CANDY: The Anatomy of a Hollywood Fiasco, by Julie Salamon. (Da Capo, $18.) The author, a television critic for The Times, wrote this 1991 insider's account of a big-budget Hollywood disaster while at The Wall Street Journal. Granted unfettered access to the set of Brian De Palma's adaptation of Tom Wolfe's novel ''The Bonfire of the Vanities,'' she witnessed the making and unmaking of a colossal dud from every angle. The book, reissued with a new afterword, is notable for Salamon's ''insightful, objective reporting,'' Steven Bach wrote here in 1991.    THE STEPFORD WIVES, by Ira Levin. (Perennial/HarperCollins, $11.95.) Believe it or not, it's been 30 years since Levin uncorked his creepy thriller about a sunny suburban community populated by eerily domesticated housewives and their blissed-out husbands. ''There is a broad current of humor beneath the horrific surface of this little ambush of Women's Lib, life and the pursuit of happiness,'' Martin Levin said here in 1972.   Scott Veale

snippet: Introduction by Book Review editors to Mike Meyer article on China's publishing industry (S)
lead_paragraph: This week, we feature a wild tour of the publishing scene in China, "The World's Biggest Book Market." Our guide is Mike Meyer, a Minnesota native who has lived in China ever since the Peace Corps sent him there to teach English in a rural village in Sichuan Province 10 years ago. Meyer, who studied with Adam Hochschild and Maxine Hong Kingston at Berkeley, where he got a master's degree in education, now lives in Beijing and is writing a book about the destruction of the ancient neighborhood where he lives.
abstract: Introduction by Book Review editors to Mike Meyer article on China's publishing industry (S)

lead_paragraph: AFRICAN LAUGHTER: Four Visits to Zimbabwe By Doris Lessing. Harper Perennial, $13. The author revisited her homeland at intervals between 1982 and 1992. As she describes the burdens crippling Zimbabwe, her book becomes an elegy for the hope that accompanied independence. Last year our reviewer, Vincent Crapanzano, called it a "brilliant report."

snippet: Benjamin Cheever, a long-distance runner himself, looks into the history of the sport.
lead_paragraph: Some sports lend themselves readily to literary effort. Baseball, fly-fishing and mountain climbing, for example, have produced bowing shelves of writing that turns the activities themselves, and their highly structured conflicts, into grand, glistening metaphors for life, sex, survival, achievement — all the biggies that occupy the human race.
abstract: Benjamin Cheever, a long-distance runner himself, looks into the history of the sport.

keywords: [{'name': 'persons', 'value': 'Gifford, Barry', 'rank': 1, 'major': 'N'}, {'name': 'subject', 'value': 'BOOK REVIEWS', 'rank': 2, 'major': 'N'}, {'name': 'creative_works', 'value': 'WILD AT HEART (BOOK)', 'rank': 3, 'major': 'N'}]
snippet: Unknown
lead_paragraph: WILD AT HEART: The Story of Sailor and Lula. By Barry Gifford. (Grove Weidenfeld, $15.95.) Barry Gifford's fourth novel (which David Lynch, the director of ''Blue Velvet,'' is bringing to the screen) is made up mostly of conversations in cars, Southern variety. In ''Wild at Heart,'' Sailor Ripley, fresh from two years in a North Carolina prison farm, breaks parole and hits the road for dream-bright California. Along for the ride is his girlfriend, Lula Pace Fortune. On their tail is a private investigator, Johnnie Farragut, who's trying to win the affections of Lula's disapproving mother, Marietta. Sailor is thoughtful but spacey, a sweet boy who nonetheless suffers an amoral lack of judgment. Lula, barely out of her teens, is the one to reckon with - dreamy, poetic, persevering, meditative, perspicacious, heartsore and practical to boot. Her past is disturbing, too. When the others are on stage, Barry Gifford's brief gab-driven novel offers a tangy low-life farce, spiced by eccentricities but never quite achieving full novelistic pungency. The lovelorn tracker Farragut, a bit of a writer himself, seems likable, but he's a desultory detective at best. The man never figures out enough of what's going on to deserve genuine sympathy. And Bobby Peru, the bad boy who comes to threaten Sailor and Lula's flight, has some awfully familiar elements: bigotry, misogyny, bloodlust left over from Vietnam, even steel-toed boots. Whenever Lula is at the center of events, however, the drawling sideways talk can hurt like fine fiction should hurt; she delivers surprises at once artful and humane. Not for nothing does Mr. Gifford give her the novel's title line: ''The world is really wild at heart and weird on top.''
abstract: LEAD:    WILD AT HEART: The Story of Sailor and Lula. By Barry Gifford. (Grove Weidenfeld, $15.95.) Barry Gifford's fourth novel (which David Lynch, the director of ''Blue Velvet,'' is bringing to the screen) is made up mostly of conversations in cars, Southern variety. In ''Wild at Heart,'' Sailor Ripley, fresh from two years in a North Carolina prison farm, breaks parole and hits the road for dream-bright California.

snippet: Unknown
lead_paragraph: A HOLE IN THE EARTH, by Robert Bausch. (Harvest/Harcourt, $14.) At 39, Henry Porter has already struck out at marriage, parenthood and the real estate business. He's willfully suspended in late-stage adolescence, a condition sorely tested by the humiliations that mount when his teenage daughter shows up unexpectedly after six years and his girlfriend tells him she's pregnant. Last year our reviewer, Will Blythe, called this ''a splendid novel'' with ''characters so fresh yet familiar that they might be helping themselves to what's in your refrigerator even as you read about them.''
abstract: A HOLE IN THE EARTH, by Robert Bausch. (Harvest/Harcourt, $14.) At 39, Henry Porter has already struck out at marriage, parenthood and the real estate business. He's willfully suspended in late-stage adolescence, a condition sorely tested by the humiliations that mount when his teenage daughter shows up unexpectedly after six years and his girlfriend tells him she's pregnant. Last year our reviewer, Will Blythe, called this ''a splendid novel'' with ''characters so fresh yet familiar that they might be helping themselves to what's in your refrigerator even as you read about them.''    BASIL STREET BLUES, by Michael Holroyd. (Norton, $13.95.) The acclaimed biographer of George Bernard Shaw turns to autobiography, revealing how his literary life was shaped by his desire to flee from his relatives, a once grand family with a large cast of wildly dysfunctional eccentrics. The result is ''a wonderful offbeat memoir,'' Ben Macintyre said here in 2000. ''It evokes a postwar English world of genteel decay, tea in good china and repressed emotion.''    THE SOOTERKIN, by Tom Gilling. (Penguin, $13.) Born into a hellish 19th-century penal colony in Tasmania, Arthur Dyer looks, barks and plays like a seal -- in fact, the weasel-sized ''human monstrosity'' is an oddly appealing protagonist whose fortunes are shaped by those who care for him (his mother, mainly) and those out to exploit his entertainment value. Along the way, there are reflections on weird science, weird religion and human nature. Last year in these pages, Alida Becker called this a ''jubilantly irreverent first novel.''    PASSIONATE NOMAD: The Life of Freya Stark, by Jane Fletcher Geniesse. (Modern Library, $14.95.) Traveler, explorer, writer, social lioness, Dame Freya Stark (1893-1993) was a complex, driven Englishwoman who transformed herself from a shy expatriate into a legendary Arabist, whose private life was awash with vulnerability and self-delusion. This portrait ''is subtle and generous,'' Colin Thubron wrote here in 1999. ''For all Stark's unresolved contradictions . . . her distinction as a latter-day woman of letters survives.'' The same publisher has reissued two of Stark's travel books, including The Southern Gates of Arabia: A Journey in the Hadhramaut ($13.95), a chronicle of Stark's voyage with Bedouins and donkeys along the ancient frankincense trade routes into the remote reaches of southern Arabia. ''The result is an extraordinarily rich and interesting'' account by a ''completely democratic human being,'' Katherine Woods wrote in the Book Review in 1936. The Valleys of the Assassins: And Other Persian Travels ($13.95) tells of -- among other things -- her encounters with the nomadic peoples of Luristan, the rugged region between Iraq and what is now Iran. ''She writes with spirit, humor and authority,'' C. G. Poore said here in 1934.    LIKE NORMAL PEOPLE, by Karen E. Bender. (Mariner/Houghton Mifflin, $13.) Set against the extravagant hopes of parents for their offspring, this first novel asks what happens when a child turns out to be less than normal. Despite a few rough patches, there are moments of ''marvelous writing,'' Suzanne Berne wrote here last year.    LEFT BACK: A Century of Battles Over School Reform, by Diane Ravitch. (Touchstone/Simon & Schuster, $17.) In tracing the effects of ''progressive'' theorists on the public education system over the last century, the author argues that the watering down of curriculums in service to non-elites has actually held back those groups it was intended to help. ''Since 1900, we have gone from educating a tiny elite group to providing true universal education to most Americans through high school,'' Sara Mosle wrote here last year. ''Ravitch's contribution . . . is to help us realize how far we still have to go.''    OUR GANG: (Starring Tricky and His Friends), by Philip Roth. (Vintage International, $12.) Written when Richard Nixon was in full flower, this political satire conjures a commander in chief who does battle with the Boy Scouts and runs against Satan in the afterlife for the presidency of Hell. The result is a ''far-fetched, unfair, tasteless, disturbing, logical, coarse and very funny'' romp, Dwight Macdonald said here in 1971. ''In short, a masterpiece.''    LA DONNA DETROIT, by Jon A. Jackson. (Grove, $11.) The latest mystery featuring Sgt. Fang Mulheisen showcases a mob boss who sets out to modernize his operation by downsizing his work force and cleaning up his act. He's ''one of those deep-thinking . . . master criminals who keep edging this series onto bolder levels of ironic wit,'' Marilyn Stasio wrote here in 2000.   Scott Veale

snippet: Eric Weisbard essay on new understandings of history of American music, focusing on musician Robert Johnson and birth and evolution of blues; discusses books Escaping the Delta: Robert Johnson and the Invention of the Blues by Elijah Wald and Lost...
lead_paragraph: The image of the bluesman Robert Johnson standing at a crossroads in the Mississippi Delta, selling his soul to play guitar as though he had invented the instrument, has long epitomized the romance of American music. In some accounts, this is the magic moment that gave rock its roots, as the blues traveled north to Chicago, went electric, then reached England, where the Rolling Stones would cover Johnson's "Love in Vain."
abstract: Eric Weisbard essay on new understandings of history of American music, focusing on musician Robert Johnson and birth and evolution of blues; discusses books Escaping the Delta: Robert Johnson and the Invention of the Blues by Elijah Wald and Lost Sounds: Blacks and the Birth of the Recording Industry, 1890-1919 by Tim Brooks; also notes influence of Cuban music as discussed in book Cuba and Its Music: From the First Drums to the Mambo by Ned Sublette; drawing (M)

byline: {'original': 'By Philip Gambone', 'person': [{'firstname': 'Philip', 'middlename': None, 'lastname': 'Gambone', 'qualifier': None, 'title': None, 'role': 'reported', 'organization': '', 'rank': 1}], 'organization': None}
keywords: [{'name': 'persons', 'value': 'Barry, Dave', 'rank': 1, 'major': 'N'}, {'name': 'subject', 'value': 'Reviews', 'rank': 2, 'major': 'N'}, {'name': 'subject', 'value': 'Books and Literature', 'rank': 3, 'major': 'N'}, {'name': 'creative_works', 'value': 'NAKED CAME THE MANATEE (BOOK)', 'rank': 4, 'major': 'N'}]
snippet: Philip Gambone reviews book Naked Came the Manatee by Dave Barry; drawing (M)
lead_paragraph: Dave Barry kicks off NAKED CAME THE MANATEE (Putnam, $22.95) by introducing a 102-year-old Coconut Grove environmentalist named Marion McAlister Williams and a lovable, pea-brained manatee called Booger. Into the murky world of these two endangered species drops a metal canister whose contents could unleash ''the big one,'' the announcement Cuban Miami has been waiting for. So begins this wacky romp of a novel, originally serialized in The Miami Herald's Tropic magazine, with each of a baker's dozen of chapters contributed by one of South Florida's finest writers. Before they're done, the thermodynamic 13 (whose ranks include Elmore Leonard, Carl Hiaasen and Edna Buchanan) will have dropped into this imbroglio more than 20 delectable denizens of Dade County and a couple of cryonically preserved heads that look like Fidel Castro's. Aside from the speedboat ride of a plot -- ''a three-beer story,'' as one character puts it -- there's the pleasure of listening to these masters play with the language and conventions of the mystery genre, manipulating cliches (yes, there's a moon over Miami) and dopey lines, picking up threads previous chapter writers have left behind while deftly upping the ante. ''Naked Came the Manatee'' is a deliciously twisted paean to South Florida, to its color, corruption, cacophony and Cubano culture. Philip Gambone
abstract: Philip Gambone reviews book Naked Came the Manatee by Dave Barry; drawing (M)

snippet: Marilyn Stasio reviews following books: In the Moon of Red Ponies by James Lee Burke; Ten Big Ones by Janet Evanovich; Shakedown Beach by Eric Dezenhall; and I Dreamed I Married Perry Mason by Susan Kandel; photo (M)
lead_paragraph: Like wolves, authors generally head for the high ground when they feel the urge to howl. IN THE MOON OF RED PONIES (Simon & Schuster, $24.95) finds James Lee Burke on leave from the Louisiana bayous, where he sets his Dave Robicheaux novels, and on the edge of the Bitterroot Mountains in Montana, rhapsodically lamenting ''the last of an unspoiled America'' and howling about things that sadden and enrage him.
abstract: Marilyn Stasio reviews following books: In the Moon of Red Ponies by James Lee Burke; Ten Big Ones by Janet Evanovich; Shakedown Beach by Eric Dezenhall; and I Dreamed I Married Perry Mason by Susan Kandel; photo (M)

lead_paragraph: Ed McBain's new Matthew Hope mystery, THREE BLIND MICE (Arcade/Little, Brown, $18.95), takes its ironic nursery rhyme title from the grisly ritual slaying of three Vietnamese kitchen helpers who lived in a Florida coastal town called Calusa. Not long before their deaths, the men had been acquitted of gang-raping the wife of a rich local farmer; so, when hard evidence turns up to implicate the husband of the rape victim, the new assistant state attorney (whose courtroom style is described as ''flamboyant, seductive, aggressive, unrelenting, and unforgiving'') naturally thinks she's got a lock on the case. Indeed, it looks like another no-win situation for Hope, the patron saint defense attorney for such hopeless causes.

snippet: Unknown
lead_paragraph: TO THE HERMITAGE, by Malcolm Bradbury. (Overlook, $16.95.) This posthumous novel by Bradbury (1932-2000) employs two voyages -- that of an unnamed English novelist (the author's stand-in) on an academic junket to St. Petersburg, and that of the Enlightenment writer Denis Diderot to Russia in the 18th century -- to advance a wacky theory called postmortemism: that great writers are never really dead and buried, in either the physical or literary sense. ''It's a wonderful conceit,'' James Shapiro said in the Book Review in 2001. ''Bradbury breaks new ground'' in the tale, including ''a surprising final turn toward the elegiac.''
abstract: TO THE HERMITAGE, by Malcolm Bradbury. (Overlook, $16.95.) This posthumous novel by Bradbury (1932-2000) employs two voyages -- that of an unnamed English novelist (the author's stand-in) on an academic junket to St. Petersburg, and that of the Enlightenment writer Denis Diderot to Russia in the 18th century -- to advance a wacky theory called postmortemism: that great writers are never really dead and buried, in either the physical or literary sense. ''It's a wonderful conceit,'' James Shapiro said in the Book Review in 2001. ''Bradbury breaks new ground'' in the tale, including ''a surprising final turn toward the elegiac.''    THE LAST EMPIRE: Essays 1992-2000, by Gore Vidal. (Vintage International, $16.) In 48 wide-ranging essays on literary, cultural and political topics, from the Bill of Rights to Frank Sinatra to the novelists Dawn Powell and Sinclair Lewis, Vidal displays ''a carefree touch and a humorous air,'' according to our reviewer, Paul Berman, who last year found the collection uneven but at its best ''lively, instructive, lucid and amusing.''    CARRY ME ACROSS THE WATER, by Ethan Canin. (Random House, $12.95.) This novel's 78-year-old protagonist, a former Pittsburgh brewery owner, has led a vital, eventful life, and as death approaches he finds himself vulnerable to sudden eruptions of memory, which arrive unbidden but not always unwelcome. Last year in these pages, Gary Krist admired the ''complex, almost musical interplay of reminiscence and current experience.''    FRANTZ FANON: A Biography, by David Macey. (Picador USA, $20.) The Martinique-born Fanon, a psychiatrist before becoming a spokesman for the Algerian uprising against French colonial rule, is portrayed as a fiery, reckless figure whose belief in the therapeutic value of violence -- given full throat in ''The Wretched of the Earth'' -- hasn't aged well, though much of what he wrote seems prescient today. ''Macey has written a prodigiously researched, absorbing book about the mind and passion of a 20th-century revolutionary,'' Adam Shatz said here last year.    CHANCE IN THE HOUSE OF FATE: A Natural History of Heredity, by Jennifer Ackerman. Mariner/Houghton Mifflin, $14.) Blending science writing with personal experience, a journalist explores the genetic links between humans and the rest of the world, and examines the history of research into heredity. ''Tying together the famous and the forgotten, the microscopic and the vast,'' the result is ''a sprawling but fascinating book,'' Christine Kenneally wrote here in 2001. Invisible Frontiers: The Race to Synthesize a Human Gene, by Stephen S. Hall (Oxford University, $15.95), is a 1987 account of the scramble by three teams of molecular biologists in the 1970's not only to clone the human insulin gene but to manufacture genetically engineered insulin for the marketplace. Our reviewer, Daniel J. Kevles, called this ''an important and pioneering book, dealing with events of high scientific and economic consequence.''    THE BOOK OF HAPPINESS, by Nina Berberova. (New Directions, $12.95.) Set in the years before and after the Russian Revolution, this passionately candid yet unsentimental novel about a woman's three defining love affairs is notable for its striking absence of irony as it allows people to speak ingenuously about the things that matter to them, including happiness. ''Like Turgenev and Chekhov . . . Berberova (who died in 1993) is uncannily shrewd about romance, about its bright promise, without making her characters' real satisfactions seem trite,'' Adam Phillips wrote here in 1999.    A FORTUNE-TELLER TOLD ME: Earthbound Travels in the Far East, by Tiziano Terzani. (Three Rivers, $14.) An Italian journalist recounts his ground-level trek through Thailand, Malaysia, Myanmar and other nations, where he was determined to consult every fortuneteller who crossed his path. ''He's a first-rate raconteur, and once he gets moving -- by train, car or on foot -- he proves excellent company,'' Michael Upchurch wrote here in 2001.    THE HOLE, by Guy Burt. (Ballantine, $12.) What happens when five British teenagers allow themselves to be locked in a school cellar for three days as a prank, or, as the plan's mastermind puts it, ''an experiment in real life''? Think ''Lord of the Flies'' meets ''The Blair Witch Project.'' Last year our reviewer, King Kaufman, called this a ''chilling'' little novel ''about that most elemental of human fears, being buried alive.''   Scott Veale

snippet: Unknown
lead_paragraph: ECONOMIES OF THE HEART. By Christopher Zenowich. (Harper & Row, $17.95.) The 10 stories collected in ''Economies of the Heart'' document a poor boy's introduction to the brutish world of manual labor, a world he chooses to enter so he'll make enough money to escape to college. Christopher Zenowich's protagonist is Bob Bodewicz, a younger version of the hero of Mr. Zenowich's recent novel, ''The Cost of Living.'' In the first two stories, which tell of abortive attempts to make money by raising chinchillas and reopening an old nickel mine, Bob learns that schemes will not suffice. The subsequent stories recount Bob's real jobs, first cleaning up a rat-infested factory and then toiling on his cousin's farm. The most inspired story is ''Field Work,'' in which Bob's near-Sisyphean task is to clear a seven-acre field whose stones have risen to the surface, as they do every few years. But while Mr. Zenowich is adept at evoking the spirit as well as the mechanics of hard physical labor, his portrayal of people is less than convincing. Even Bob, who is depicted almost exclusively at work, remains thinly drawn. The problem is partially a function of the book's form: the discrete stories inhibit the development of character, which might not be the case in a novel. The stories do not always add new dimensions, and at times the author repeats himself unnecessarily. The stories - selected snapshots of Bob's life - consider only the worst labors he must endure, such as picking out the stones and spreading manure in the fields. A bountiful harvest, however, is never reaped.
abstract: LEAD:    ECONOMIES OF THE HEART. By Christopher Zenowich. (Harper & Row, $17.95.) The 10 stories collected in ''Economies of the Heart'' document a poor boy's introduction to the brutish world of manual labor, a world he chooses to enter so he'll make enough money to escape to college. Christopher Zenowich's protagonist is Bob Bodewicz, a younger version of the hero of Mr.

snippet: Reginald Hill shows how the 2005 London suicide bombings have upended the civilized police-procedural genre.
lead_paragraph: Whether Detective Superintendent Andy Dalziel survives DEATH COMES FOR THE FAT MAN (HarperCollins, $24.95) is almost beside the point. Reginald Hill’s crude and canny policeman (“the Marcus Aurelius of mid-Yorkshire” to those who love him) is nothing less than a force of nature in these idiosyncratic procedurals, and the act of terrorism that has his life hanging by a thread may pose an even graver threat to the natural order of his kind of genre novel.

lead_paragraph: LEAD:
abstract:
LEAD: 

THE LONG HAUL: An Autobiography. By Myles Horton with Judith Kohl and Herbert Kohl. (Doubleday, $21.95.) Two Myles Hortons run through ''The Long Haul.'' The first is the poor boy from Tennessee who grew up in a shingled cabin at the beginning of the century. This Myles Horton came from an Appalachia of sickly millworkers and hungry farmers.

keywords: [{'name': 'subject', 'value': 'Books and Literature', 'rank': 1, 'major': 'N'}, {'name': 'persons', 'value': 'Faber, Michel', 'rank': 2, 'major': 'N'}, {'name': 'persons', 'value': 'Rhodes, Dan', 'rank': 3, 'major': 'N'}]
snippet: Two Scottish writers imagine their way into some awkward situations.
lead_paragraph: The mark of greatness in golf is the ability to play long ball and sink a chip shot. Apply the same measures to writing, and you begin to get a sense of Michel Faber’s talents. In his novel “The Crimson Petal and the White” (2002), Faber, who was born in the Netherlands and now lives in Scotland, delivered an 800-plus-page panorama worthy of Trollope or Dickens. Following a collection of novellas, he is back with “Vanilla Bright Like Eminem,” a set of 16 stylish, harrowing stories that get off to running starts and have concise, cut-to-the-chase precision. Does Faber write poetry too? If so, I want to read it.

snippet: GREENWAYS FOR AMERICA.  By Charles E. Little. (Johns Hopkins University, $22.95.) Our system of land use may have lost much of its legitimacy and the planning profession may have few new ideas to offer, but Charles E. Little sees greenways as a gr...
lead_paragraph: GREENWAYS FOR AMERICA. By Charles E. Little. (Johns Hopkins University, $22.95.) Our system of land use may have lost much of its legitimacy and the planning profession may have few new ideas to offer, but Charles E. Little sees greenways as a grass-roots source of positive change. Greenways are protected natural areas; most are used for recreation such as hiking or biking, although some are designed primarily to protect environmental resources. Central to the greenway concept is the idea of linkage: creating connections among recreational resources, natural resources and communities. Mr. Little, whose previous books include "Challenge of the Land" and "Green Fields Forever," sees such networks as providing the framework for regional planning. "Greenways for America" makes clear that greenways have provided recreation, environmental enhancement, economic stimulus and civic pride in widely varied situations. Mr. Little concludes that to make a greenway is to make a community. The projects that the author visited are located across the country, from the San Juan Islands in Washington to the Hudson River Valley, and are "as rich and diverse as human ingenuity and topographic opportunity could make them." Mr. Little is an enthusiastic journalist with both an eye and an ear for local history and politics. With a few colorful strokes he brings to life the unconventional people he met along the way. His text ranges from the history of the greenway concept to an examination of the types of greenways he identified. During his greenway reconnaissance, Mr. Little found the tenacity and ingenuity that we want to believe continue to define the American character. And he provides many practical ideas for people who would follow suit.

snippet: Carolyn Brown offers an insider’s view of the modernist pioneers John Cage and Merce Cunningham.
lead_paragraph: Carolyn Brown’s rich account of 20 years of dancing with Merce Cunningham and John Cage, “Chance and Circumstance,” provides an insider’s portrait of two pioneering modernists who ventured into uncharted territory in the realm of dance and music. Brown vividly evokes the thrills and struggles inherent to true liberation, and describes the courage requisite to artistic inventiveness. She is a rare memoirist who focuses on her mentors’ physical and spiritual leaps rather than on herself; her guileless revelations illuminate what went right and wrong in Cunningham and Cage’s personal dealings, as well as in their fight for survival.

snippet: Robert Houston reviews book Duane's Depressed by Larry McMurtry (M)
lead_paragraph: DUANE'S DEPRESSEDBy Larry McMurtry.431 pp. New York:Simon & Schuster. $26. READERS of Larry McMurtry's ''Last Picture Show'' (1966) and ''Texasville'' (1987), the first two novels in the trilogy that ''Duane's Depressed'' completes, will find themselves in familiar territory here. McMurtry has come back home -- and brought us along -- to Thalia, Tex., for one last look around. Several of the old bunch are still in town: Sonny Crawford, for example, and Ruth Popper and Bobby Lee, though they are considerably the worse for wear. But it's Duane Moore, still married to Karla, who is the book's focus.
abstract: Robert Houston reviews book Duane's Depressed by Larry McMurtry (M)

snippet: Marilyn Stasio reviews mystery novels No Badge, No Gun by Harold Adams, The Charles Dickens Murders by Edith Skom, Drinker of Blood by Lynda S Robinson, The Disposable Man by Archer Mayor and Crime of Silence by Patricia Carlon (S)
lead_paragraph: Harold Adams is not a flashy writer; but in his quiet way, he applies his spare, unruffled style to the creation of a modest kingdom of the imagination where the landscape has a comforting familiarity, where values seem certain and where characters come and go with the confident step of people who know they belong here. In NO BADGE, NO GUN (Walker, $22.95), as in earlier books in this offbeat series, the stranger in this land is Carl Wilcox, an itinerant sign painter and sometime sleuth who wanders across South Dakota during the Great Depression, settling in a town just long enough to get the lay of the land, spruce up the drugstore or dance hall and maybe solve a murder.
abstract: Marilyn Stasio reviews mystery novels No Badge, No Gun by Harold Adams, The Charles Dickens Murders by Edith Skom, Drinker of Blood by Lynda S Robinson, The Disposable Man by Archer Mayor and Crime of Silence by Patricia Carlon (S)

snippet: Tom DeLay offers personal attacks on Democrats for their attacks on him.
lead_paragraph: Over more than 20 roller-coaster years in Congress, Tom DeLay reached the pinnacle of success and the depths of embarrassment and failure. He moved steadily up the Republican leadership ladder to become the most adept party whip in modern times, nearly lost his post in 1997 after an abortive coup against the speaker of the House, Newt Gingrich, stayed in place through ethical improprieties, single-handedly engineered the impeachment of President Bill Clinton by the House when his colleagues favored a bipartisan censure and managed adroitly to move up to majority leader — under his protégé Dennis Hastert — after the 2002 elections. He was unquestionably the most powerful member of the House from 1999 until 2005, when a series of new ethical missteps, combined with an indictment against him for election law violations in Texas, forced him out of the leadership and precipitated his resignation from Congress in 2006.

keywords: [{'name': 'persons', 'value': 'MOREHOUSE, WARD 3D', 'rank': 1, 'major': 'N'}, {'name': 'subject', 'value': 'BOOK REVIEWS', 'rank': 2, 'major': 'N'}, {'name': 'creative_works', 'value': "WALDORF-ASTORIA, THE: AMERICA'S GILDED DREAM (BOOK)", 'rank': 3, 'major': 'N'}]
snippet: Unknown
lead_paragraph: The grand cities of the world have their grand hotels, the bed-and-breakfasts for the mighty and the moneyed. Ward Morehouse 3d explores one of New York City's grandest in THE WALDORF-ASTORIA: America's Gilded Dream (Evans, $22.95). Mr. Morehouse, a former reporter for The Christian Science Monitor, is more of a guide than a historian, embellishing his meanderings about the Waldorf with entertaining anecdotes and portraits of those who have been the lifeblood of its fame, such as Elsa Maxwell and Cole Porter. The Waldorf is 60 years old this year, and the author reminds us that it opened during the Great Depression, the descendant of the original Waldorf-Astoria that occupied the site, until 1929, where the Empire State Building now stands. It is a hotel big enough to handle Golda Meir and Yasir Arafat at the same time, without embarrassment to anyone, and vast enough to need computers to sort out the task of housekeeping, with a staff of nearly 400 for the 1,850 rooms to be cleaned. Mr. Morehouse writes of pleasures and scandals, of the hard facts of running a hotel and of its romance. This is not the last word on the Waldorf-Astoria, and the publisher is to be chided for neglecting to provide readers an index. Even so, the hotel comes off well in the hands of its appreciative Boswell and one will find "The Waldorf-Astoria" to be a pleasant buffet.

keywords: [{'name': 'persons', 'value': 'Maso, Carole', 'rank': 1, 'major': 'N'}, {'name': 'subject', 'value': 'BOOK REVIEWS', 'rank': 2, 'major': 'N'}, {'name': 'creative_works', 'value': 'ART LOVER, THE (BOOK)', 'rank': 3, 'major': 'N'}]
snippet: Unknown
lead_paragraph: THE ART LOVER. By Carole Maso. (North Point, $18.95.) Dedicated to a friend of the author's who died of AIDS, Carole Maso's second novel reads like an anguished meditation on the insufficiency of art as a refuge from life. Fragmented and hesitant, as if unsure of its powers, ''The Art Lover'' eventually centers on a character named Caroline, herself a writer, whose novel-in-progress turns out to have peopled the opening pages of the book we are reading. Like Carole Maso, Caroline has a friend who dies of AIDS. Her recently deceased father, Max, an eminent critic, taught her that art is all that matters; instinct tells her to agree, yet she worries that her mother's suicide may have been encouraged in some way by Max's esthetic distancing. Faced with the awful reality of her friend Steven's terminal illness, Caroline begins to feel that retreating into art may in fact be nothing but an exquisite form of betrayal. (Toward the end of the book, as if repenting her own fictive nature, Caroline actually dissolves for a time and is replaced by Carole Maso herself.) The novel's locus of pain, on many levels, is Greenwich Village; the restoring oasis is an artists' colony in Cummington, Mass., where shattered characters measure emotional losses against the recurring patterns of art, religion and nature. The narration moves brokenly from speaker to speaker, sketching thoughts, dreams, memories. Newspaper clippings on various topics - star maps, artists' lives - are patched in throughout, often as ironic counterpoint. When the story draws to an end, characters from different imaginative levels seem to be melting into one another. Yet none of this is jarring. On the contrary, though it takes the incoherence of grief as a compositional principle, ''The Art Lover'' in its realization is fully coherent, moving and elegiac, a genuine consolation.
abstract: LEAD:    THE ART LOVER. By Carole Maso. (North Point, $18.95.) Dedicated to a friend of the author's who died of AIDS, Carole Maso's second novel reads like an anguished meditation on the insufficiency of art as a refuge from life. Fragmented and hesitant, as if unsure of its powers, ''The Art Lover'' eventually centers on a character named Caroline, herself a writer, whose novel-in-progress turns out to have peopled the opening pages of the book we are reading.

keywords: [{'name': 'persons', 'value': 'Youman, Marly', 'rank': 1, 'major': 'N'}, {'name': 'subject', 'value': 'Reviews', 'rank': 2, 'major': 'N'}, {'name': 'subject', 'value': 'Books and Literature', 'rank': 3, 'major': 'N'}, {'name': 'creative_works', 'value': 'CATHERWOOD (BOOK)', 'rank': 4, 'major': 'N'}]
snippet: Unknown
lead_paragraph: Once a barefoot beggar child, the heroine of the poet Marly Youmans's second novel, CATHERWOOD (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $20), is brought to live with a noble family in the years after the English Civil War. Something between an indentured servant and an adopted daughter, Catherwood is eventually married off to Gabriel Lyte, who takes her across the Atlantic to a world "fresh and curious" that appears to be "just league after league of woods and swamp and wild river." Feeling herself "the newest of all created things," the young woman confronts her new home, outside Albany, with a keen eye for the "lovely-fierce" sensuousness of nature. Then one day she and her infant daughter become lost in the wilderness, and for months they wander about, trying to find their way. Through her harrowing ordeal, Catherwood learns to divest herself of sentiment and fear, including the fear of "man judgment," until she comes to understand that there are "many roads through wilderness, many paths to the city." In describing this process, Ms. Youmans's language is trenchant, graceful and, in places, sumptuously archaic, filled with a richness that provides more than just period color. Her prodigious powers of description render with acuity both small moments and large: the sea crossing, childbirth, snowfall, the slitting of a fawn's throat, the "rammish" stench of a trapper. Ms. Youmans has written a subtle, intelligent novel about one of the most enduring issues in the American experiment: how to embrace "the world and God" as "better" than men dream. Philip Gambone

In describing this process, Ms. Youmans's language is trenchant, graceful and, in places, sumptuously archaic, filled with a richness that provides more than just period color. Her prodigious powers of description render with acuity both small moments and large: the sea crossing, childbirth, snowfall, the slitting of a fawn's throat, the "rammish" stench of a trapper. snippet: Margo Jefferson On Writers and Writing column on historical fiction and the making of myths; discusses two books: Elegy for Kosovo by Ismail Kadare and Cassandra: A Novel and Four Essays by Christa Wolf; drawing (M)
lead_paragraph: Some historical novelists build on facts recorded in accessible languages; others build their narrative from ancient and obscure sources: ruins, remains, cave paintings, hieroglyphics, oral histories and song cycles. But all history is the interplay of fact and myth. Numbers and official documents lie. People choose what they want to believe about themselves. In war, collective memory is shaped by rulers, armies and civilians. The official version can decide what wars people will fight or choose not to fight for centuries.
abstract: Margo Jefferson On Writers and Writing column on historical fiction and the making of myths; discusses two books: Elegy for Kosovo by Ismail Kadare and Cassandra: A Novel and Four Essays by Christa Wolf; drawing (M)

keywords: [{'name': 'persons', 'value': 'Hochman, Gloria', 'rank': 1, 'major': 'N'}, {'name': 'persons', 'value': 'CASSELL, ERIC J (DR)', 'rank': 2, 'major': 'N'}, {'name': 'subject', 'value': 'BOOK REVIEWS', 'rank': 3, 'major': 'N'}, {'name': 'creative_works', 'value': 'NATURE OF SUFFERING, THE (BOOK)', 'rank': 4, 'major': 'N'}]
snippet: Eric J. Cassell maintains that physicians depend too heavily on recipes for diagnosing and treating disease and that they ignore what he calls the "art of medicine" -- understanding patients, how they live, what they think and how they should be t...
lead_paragraph: Eric J. Cassell maintains that physicians depend too heavily on recipes for diagnosing and treating disease and that they ignore what he calls the "art of medicine" -- understanding patients, how they live, what they think and how they should be treated. In THE NATURE OF SUFFERING: And the Goals of Medicine (Oxford University, $24.95) Dr. Cassell, a professor of public health at Cornell University Medical College and the author of "The Healer's Art," insists that physicians need to recognize that disease and suffering are not the same thing. Two women treated for breast cancer, for example, may suffer quite differently. One may resume life with gusto and optimism; the other may become seriously depressed, tortured by an altered image of herself, worried about the way her husband feels about her and fearful of early death. Dr. Cassell says the way a doctor treats these two distinct women involves more than technical competence and medical knowledge. The physician must provide empathetic support and be sensitive to their unspoken needs. This, he writes, is what "distinguishes the practice of medicine -- clinical medicine -- from medical science." Dr. Cassell's book is not easy to read. It is dense and ponderous, and the fine lines he draws between disease and illness, bodies and persons, signs and symptoms are sometimes blurry. But the essence of his message is clear: If physicians want to restore their good name, if they want to create "the magical bond that permits a sick person to be healed by a stranger," they had better start focusing on people, not just diseases.

Cassell maintains that physicians depend too heavily on recipes for diagnosing and treating disease and that they ignore what he calls the "art of medicine" -- understanding patients, how they live, what they think and how they should be treated. Dr. Cassell says the way a doctor treats these two distinct women involves more than technical competence and medical knowledge. The physician must provide empathetic support and be sensitive to their unspoken needs. This, he writes, is what "distinguishes the practice of medicine -- clinical medicine -- from medical science." Dr. Cassell's book is not easy to read. It is dense and ponderous, and the fine lines he draws between disease and illness, bodies and persons, signs and symptoms are sometimes blurry. But the essence of his message is clear: If physicians want to restore their good name, if they want to create "the magical bond that permits a sick person to be healed by a stranger," they had better start focusing on people, not just diseases.

keywords: [{'name': 'persons', 'value': 'Hoffman, Abbie', 'rank': 1, 'major': 'N'}, {'name': 'persons', 'value': 'SIMON, DANIEL', 'rank': 2, 'major': 'N'}, {'name': 'subject', 'value': 'BOOK REVIEWS', 'rank': 3, 'major': 'N'}, {'name': 'creative_works', 'value': 'BEST OF ABBIE HOFFMAN, THE (BOOK)', 'rank': 4, 'major': 'N'}]
snippet: Unknown
lead_paragraph: THE BEST OF ABBIE HOFFMAN. Edited by Daniel Simon with Abbie Hoffman. (Four Walls Eight Windows, $21.95.) At the Chicago conspiracy trial 20 years ago, the judge gently scolded Tom Hayden: ''Fellows as smart as you could do awfully well under [the American] system.'' Those words would have been lost on Abbie Hoffman, who remained, in his actions and, as this book shows, in his writings, incorrigibly and imaginatively subversive to the end. The self-styled ''cultural revolutionary'' - who committed suicide last year at the age of 52 and has since become, as Norman Mailer says in his foreword, ''our own holy ghost of the Left'' - chose the selections here from ''Revolution for the Hell of It'' (1968), ''Woodstock Nation'' (1969) and ''Steal This Book'' (1971). To those Daniel Simon has added essays and speeches from the 1980's, when Hoffman, no longer on the run from a drug charge, was working as an environmentalist and still trying to stir up student activism. What set him apart was his wit, a virtue as rare in American politics as it is in American comedy. This is his account of the ''language barrier'' between a zonked Yippie and members of the House Un-American Activities Committee: ''They spoke of Marx and I thought they meant Groucho. My interpreter said, 'No, they mean Karl Marx.' They spoke of Lenin and I thought they meant John Lennon of the Beatles. My interpreter said, 'No, they mean the guy without a first name.' '' If you liked Abbie - and don't mind reading about be-ins, bad acid trips and ''the politics of ecstasy'' - you'll like this collection. But it isn't really ''The Best of Abbie Hoffman.'' We saw the best of Abbie Hoffman inside a Federal courthouse, and outside the walls of the Pentagon.
abstract: LEAD:    THE BEST OF ABBIE HOFFMAN. Edited by Daniel Simon with Abbie Hoffman. (Four Walls Eight Windows, $21.95.) At the Chicago conspiracy trial 20 years ago, the judge gently scolded Tom Hayden: ''Fellows as smart as you could do awfully well under [the American]  system.'' Those words would have been lost on Abbie Hoffman, who remained, in his actions and, as this book shows, in his writings, incorrigibly and imaginatively subversive to the end.

snippet: New visual books about presidential campaign curios, the peace symbol, the emblems of American military operations and flight attendants.
lead_paragraph: Presidential electioneering was a lot more fun  visually speaking  in the days before slick television commercials became dominant and professional branding strategists and focus groups removed the camp from campaigns. As recently as a few decades ago, getting recognized meant that candidates and their minions had to devise eye-catching curios that were also collectible. And as far back as 1832, when President Andrew Jackson was running for a second term, useful trinkets  including Jackson hairpins, razor sharpeners with the slogan “Old Rough and Ready” and metal frog doorstops engraved “I Croak for the Jackson Wagon”  were widely distributed. Other famous nicknames and catchphrases, like “Old Hickory,” “Free Soil and Free Speech” (for John Charles Frémont) and “The Great Rail Splitter,” were emblazoned on everything from handbills to lanterns. After advances in printing technology, candidates’ faces were reproduced on scarves and clip-on ties, fans and parasols. In contrast to today’s endless endurance test, earlier presidential spectacles lasted for much shorter periods and were, therefore, more memorable.

snippet: Unknown
lead_paragraph: IT'S all very well for the White House to put out the word that President Clinton dotes on Marcus Aurelius and Gabriel Garcia Marquez and that he reads books in German. It's something else again to catch our Chief Executive red-handed with something called "The Concrete Blonde."
abstract: IT'S all very well for the White House to put out the word that President Clinton dotes on Marcus Aurelius and Gabriel Garcia Marquez and that he reads books in German. It's something else again to catch our Chief Executive red-handed with something called "The Concrete Blonde."   Don't be surprised if you've not heard of "The Concrete Blonde," one of four novels that Mr. Clinton picked up (on blind credit, having been short of cash and bereft of plastic) on a recent binge at Mystery Books in Washington. This new police procedural by Michael Connelly won't be out until June; the advance copy was the store owners' gift to the President, who had expressed his satisfaction with the author's two previous novels, "The Black Ice" and "The Black Echo," which won an Edgar Award as best first mystery in 1993.

snippet: “Going Clear,” by Lawrence Wright, examines Scientology, its history and its appeal.
lead_paragraph: Lawrence Wright’s avowed purpose in writing “Going Clear” is to understand why Scientology, a religion known for its bizarre creation myth, mining of church members’ secrets and draconian punishment system, has appeal. “What do its adherents get out of it?” he asks. “How can seemingly rational people subscribe to beliefs that others find incomprehensible? Why do public personalities” — he’s talking to you, Tom Cruise — “associate themselves with a faith that is likely to create a kind of public relations martyrdom?”

keywords: [{'name': 'persons', 'value': 'Anastas, Benjamin', 'rank': 1, 'major': 'N'}, {'name': 'subject', 'value': 'Reviews', 'rank': 2, 'major': 'N'}, {'name': 'subject', 'value': 'Books and Literature', 'rank': 3, 'major': 'N'}, {'name': 'creative_works', 'value': "UNDERACHIEVER'S DIARY, AN (BOOK)", 'rank': 4, 'major': 'N'}]
snippet: James Polk reviews book An Underachiever's Diary by Benjamin Anastas; drawing (S)
lead_paragraph: William, the firstborn of twin boys, has determined to spend the rest of his life making sure he will never be first again. In the course of Benjamin Anastas's fine, funny debut novel, AN UNDERACHIEVER'S DIARY (Dial, $15.95), William provides exquisitely detailed explanations of his strategies for falling short -- even backing them up with a vague attempt at scholarship. In clinging to the depths, William is aided most of all by the fact that his twin brother, Clive, can do no wrong; his destiny is to travel smoothly from success to success, impressing parents, teachers, therapists and girlfriends (although there turns out to be a small cloud of doubt about the last) through his incredible ease of accomplishment and the wealth of his potential. With such a paragon of achievement available for ready comparison, William doesn't have to try very hard to disappoint. Instead, he drifts rather gracefully -- it must be admitted -- down the plane of life until he reaches the zenith of underachievement: ''Having disappointed every expectation that my parents held for me, I had finally been cast out of their constructive thoughts.'' Imbued with a kind of half-serious mockery, William's account of his misadventures sometimes recalls Frederick Exley's masterpiece of the genre, ''A Fan's Notes.'' Similarly, Benjamin Anastas makes his protagonist a successful failure, happy to be written off, perhaps, but understanding his world pretty well: ''Life has been an experiment in trial and error, without any guiding principles . . . like prayer without a God to listen.'' James Polk
abstract: James Polk reviews book An Underachiever's Diary by Benjamin Anastas; drawing (S)

lead_paragraph: John Gardner's trilogy featuring Herbie Kruger ("The Nostradamus Traitor," "The Garden of Weapons" and "The Quiet Dogs") is now a tetralogy. In MAESTRO (Otto Penzler, $23), Big Herbie, the shambling ace of British intelligence, is called back from retirement to interrogate Louis Passau, a great 90-year-old German-born American conductor.
abstract: John Gardner's trilogy featuring Herbie Kruger ("The Nostradamus Traitor," "The Garden of Weapons" and "The Quiet Dogs") is now a tetralogy. In MAESTRO (Otto Penzler, $23), Big Herbie, the shambling ace of British intelligence, is called back from retirement to interrogate Louis Passau, a great 90-year-old German-born American conductor.   It seems that an unauthorized biography of the conductor maintains that Passau, a Jew, not only worked for the Nazis but also channeled top-secret information to the K.G.B. after the war. And why should Kruger be given the job of sticking close to Passau and debriefing him? Because he too is German-born, with a comprehensive knowledge of classical music (especially Mahler), and because he is an ardent admirer of Passau's.
