snippet: Two new books tell the story of African-American baseball before Jackie Robinson signed with the Brooklyn Dodgers.
lead_paragraph: No more tragic or romantic institution emerged from the Jim Crow era of American life than the Negro League. African-Americans were banished from the majors in 1884, and a few seasons later from the minors as well, under a “gentleman’s agreement” between white owners and players. None would return until Jackie Robinson signed with the Brooklyn Dodgers some 60 years later.

keywords: [{'name': 'persons', 'value': 'Widmer, Ted', 'rank': 1, 'major': 'N'}, {'name': 'subject', 'value': 'Books and Literature', 'rank': 2, 'major': 'N'}, {'name': 'subject', 'value': 'United States International Relations', 'rank': 3, 'major': 'N'}, {'name': 'subject', 'value': 'United States Politics and Government', 'rank': 4, 'major': 'N'}, {'name': 'subject', 'value': 'History', 'rank': 5, 'major': 'N'}]
snippet: How the United States has inspired struggles against oppression.
lead_paragraph: What do Mohandas Gandhi, Ho Chi Minh and Chinese student protesters have in common? The answer, Ted Widmer says in “Ark of the Liberties,” an ambitious, if ultimately familiar, account of America’s enduring global reach, is that all looked to the United States for inspiration in their struggles against oppression. The pacifist Gandhi cited the impact of American ideals on the liberation movement in India. The Marxist Ho Chi Minh employed the words of the Declaration of Independence to demand the right of self-determination in Vietnam. And who can forget the stirring images from Tiananmen Square in 1989, when pro-democracy students marched behind a Styrofoam version of the Statue of Liberty before being brutally dispersed?

snippet: Unknown
lead_paragraph: SHIFTING LOYALTIES By Daniel Cano. Arte Publico, paper, $9.95.
abstract: SHIFTING LOYALTIES  By Daniel Cano. Arte Publico, paper, $9.95.     Initially, Daniel Cano's second novel seems to offer a fresh fictional perspective on the Vietnam War as it explores the disillusionment of several Mexican-American men who find their experiences totally at odds with their fathers' gung-ho stories of patriotism and machismo in action during World War II. Unfortunately, good ideas are sabotaged here by clunky prose and clumsy execution. Although the book opens with David Almas's letter to the parents of his dead comrade, Wayne Podleski, and closes with David visiting Wayne's grave, the narrative in between is rambling and unfocused. The cast of characters seems too large, and so does a time frame that jerks the reader from Southeast Asia to pre- and post-Vietnam America, as well as Spain in the 1970's and Mexico in the 1980's. The author's political insights, intelligent though they often are, lose credibility when crammed into the mouths of people who have previously shown no signs of being terribly introspective. "Shifting Loyalties" seems to be the product of intellectual conviction rather than deep emotional identification. WENDY SMITH

lead_paragraph: LEAD: THE JOURNEY FROM PRAGUE STREET. By Hana Demetz. (St. Martin's, $16.95.) This sequel to Hana Demetz's moving autobiographical novel, ''The House on Prague Street,'' begins just after World War II in Czechoslovakia, then moves with dazzling speed through rural Bavaria, Munich, New York City and Cambridge, Mass., finally ending in Bethlehem, Pa., in the present.

headline: {'main': 'BOOKS IN BRIEF: NONFICTION; Polio, and Good Riddance', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'BOOKS IN BRIEF: NONFICTION; Polio, and Good Riddance', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}
byline: {'original': 'By Stephanie Sun', 'person': [{'firstname': 'Stephanie', 'middlename': None, 'lastname': 'Sun', 'qualifier': None, 'title': None, 'role': 'reported', 'organization': '', 'rank': 1}], 'organization': None}
keywords: [{'name': 'persons', 'value': 'Sun, Stephanie', 'rank': 1, 'major': 'N'}, {'name': 'persons', 'value': 'Seavey, Nina Gilden', 'rank': 2, 'major': 'N'}, {'name': 'persons', 'value': 'Smith, Jane S', 'rank': 3, 'major': 'N'}, {'name': 'persons', 'value': 'Wagner, Paul', 'rank': 4, 'major': 'N'}, {'name': 'subject', 'value': 'Books and Literature', 'rank': 5, 'major': 'N'}, {'name': 'subject', 'value': 'Reviews', 'rank': 6, 'major': 'N'}, {'name': 'creative_works', 'value': 'Paralyzing Fear, A: The Triumph Over Polio in America (Book)', 'rank': 7, 'major': 'N'}]
snippet: Stephanie Sun reviews book A Paralyzing Fear: The Triumph Over Polio in America by Nina Gilden Seavey, Jane S Smith and Paul Wagner; photo (S)
lead_paragraph: The polio epidemic of the first half of the 20th century is largely forgotten. Even today, one out of five American children is behind on immunizations by the age of 2, Nina Gilden Seavey, Jane S. Smith and Paul Wagner write in their sweeping history of polio, A PARALYZING FEAR: The Triumph Over Polio in America (TV Books, $29.95). Drawing on the recollections of survivors, physicians and scientists, the authors alternate historical analysis with personal testimonies to re-create the disease cycle, from epidemic to cure. Punctuated by haunting photographs of hospital wards and medical laboratories, the result is a series of fascinating and sobering stories: how polio changed Franklin Delano Roosevelt and how he changed the country's attitude toward polio; how the March of Dimes mobilized average citizens to finance care for tens of thousands of patients; how movie stars and politicians got involved in the effort; and how scientists raced for control of the disease. The most gripping stories are those of the survivors; in their own words, they discuss growing up in metal leg braces and iron lungs, facing the disease day after day. While the authors celebrate America's triumph over polio, they do not sidestep the flaws in human nature that the epidemic brought out: neighbor blaming neighbor, hospitals refusing patients for fear of contagion, and treatment that was at best ''separate but sometimes equal'' for black patients in the South. Stephanie Sun
abstract: Stephanie Sun reviews book A Paralyzing Fear: The Triumph Over Polio in America by Nina Gilden Seavey, Jane S Smith and Paul Wagner; photo (S)

byline: {'original': 'By Rosmary Ranck', 'person': [{'firstname': 'Rosmary', 'middlename': None, 'lastname': 'Ranck', 'qualifier': None, 'title': None, 'role': 'reported', 'organization': '', 'rank': 1}], 'organization': None}
keywords: [{'name': 'persons', 'value': 'Ranck, Rosemary', 'rank': 1, 'major': 'N'}, {'name': 'persons', 'value': 'Morris, John G', 'rank': 2, 'major': 'N'}, {'name': 'subject', 'value': 'Books and Literature', 'rank': 3, 'major': 'N'}, {'name': 'subject', 'value': 'Reviews', 'rank': 4, 'major': 'N'}, {'name': 'creative_works', 'value': 'Get the Picture: A Personal History of Photojournalism (Book)', 'rank': 5, 'major': 'N'}]
snippet: Rosemary Ranck reviews book Get the Picture: A Personal History of Photojournalism by Johnn G Morris; drawing (S)
lead_paragraph: During his long and eventful career, John G. Morris operated at the heart of 20th-century photojournalism, working as a picture editor for Life, Magnum, The Washington Post, The New York Times and National Geographic. In the late 1940's, The Ladies' Home Journal, a less obvious member of that fraternity, gave him a base from which to hire photographers like Robert Capa, Martin Muncacsi and Lisette Model. In 1948 he ran a series, ''People Are People the World Over,'' photographed largely by Magnum photographers, which inspired Edward Steichen's renowned ''Family of Man'' exhibition. Morris begins his memoir, Get the Picture: A Personal History of Photojournalism (Random House, $30), not with his childhood but with his path to Life magazine. Before he ends his story in Paris, where he moved in 1983, he weaves several photographers, anecdotes, players, history and a credo or two into an engaging and informative tale. Not surprisingly, this veteran of photojournalism's glory days sees a decline in recent years, not in the committed, courageous and excellent photography still produced, but in editors and publishers who pander to focus groups and celebrity mania and do not provide outlets for photo reportage. Morris, an unapologetic humanist, believes in the persuasive power of images and discusses in some detail his efforts over the years to strengthen the role of photography in journalism. Despite his losses -- wives, friends, employment -- and the many frustrations of an often thankless and unheralded job, the 81-year-old Morris is an optimistic and amusing raconteur. Rosemary Ranck
abstract: Rosemary Ranck reviews book Get the Picture: A Personal History of Photojournalism by Johnn G Morris; drawing (S)

snippet: Gerald Jonas reviews following books: Appleseed by John Clute; The Watch by Dennis Denvers; and Warchild by Karin Lowachee (M)
lead_paragraph: John Clute's APPLESEED (Tor/Tom Doherty, $25.95) is virtually criticproof. It may also be readerproof. Clute is a co-author of both The Encyclopedia of Science Fiction and The Encyclopedia of Fantasy, two reference books that dominate their respective fields. There is virtually nothing about the literature of imagination that Clute doesn't know -- which may explain why this estimable novel is so hard to read.

snippet: How Pepsi helped open corporate doors to African-Americans.
lead_paragraph: History-making heroism, Stephanie Capparell means to demonstrate in this admiring account of the Pepsi-Cola Company’s pioneering — but largely unsung — “special-markets sales staff,” ought not to be measured solely by the fame it attracts. She’s right. Inconceivable without the giants of the ballpark and the ring, demonstrations and courtrooms, the movement for African-American civil rights depended even more on the mostly unknowable actions of millions, black and white, who created new ways of thinking and working and acting within and across racial lines.

lead_paragraph: The Laying on of Hands: Stories, by Alan Bennett. (Picador, $11.) The playwright, screenwriter and one-quarter of the 1960's British comedy group Beyond the Fringe offers up three polished satirical tales about lonely people coming together in unlikely combinations -- a department store clerk who discovers romance with her podiatrist, for example, or an oppressed schoolteacher who finds love in the hospital at his father's deathbed. ''Bennett's brilliant and luminous'' prose ''is like stained glass: if you stare at it, you see things you missed,'' Christopher Buckley wrote here last year. Picador has also reissued Writing Home ($20), a revised and updated edition of Bennett's 1995 collection of critical writings and diaries, including an account of the eccentric Miss Shepherd, a former nun who lived in a van in his yard in London for nearly 20 years. Our reviewer, Ben Brantley, found this ''a rare, rich volume, replete with insights that demand to be memorized and quoted.''
abstract: The Laying on of Hands: Stories, by Alan Bennett. (Picador, $11.) The playwright, screenwriter and one-quarter of the 1960's British comedy group Beyond the Fringe offers up three polished satirical tales about lonely people coming together in unlikely combinations -- a department store clerk who discovers romance with her podiatrist, for example, or an oppressed schoolteacher who finds love in the hospital at his father's deathbed. ''Bennett's brilliant and luminous'' prose ''is like stained glass: if you stare at it, you see things you missed,'' Christopher Buckley wrote here last year. Picador has also reissued Writing Home ($20), a revised and updated edition of Bennett's 1995 collection of critical writings and diaries, including an account of the eccentric Miss Shepherd, a former nun who lived in a van in his yard in London for nearly 20 years. Our reviewer, Ben Brantley, found this ''a rare, rich volume, replete with insights that demand to be memorized and quoted.''    Think of England, by Alice Elliott Dark. (Simon & Schuster, $13.) Set in the well-heeled, well-groomed suburbs of Philadelphia and in 1970's London in full glam mode, this novel traces the aftershocks of a family tragedy in the life of a sensitive, resolutely self-aware 9-year-old girl. Last year in these pages, Adam Goodheart described Dark's writing as ''understated'' and ''precise'' while ''managing to convey, with the slightest of hints, a sense not just of fecundity but of foreboding.''    The Brother: The Untold Story of the Rosenberg Case, by Sam Roberts. (Random House, $16.95.) Drawing on recently declassified material and 50 hours of interviews, an editor at The Times re-examines the notorious nuclear secrets case from the perspective of David Greenglass, a co-conspirator and government witness whose testimony helped send his sister, Ethel Rosenberg, and her husband to the electric chair in 1953. In 2001 our reviewer, David Oshinsky, found this an ''absorbing account of the Rosenberg atomic spy drama.'' Racing for the Bomb: General Leslie R. Groves, the Manhattan Project's Indispensable Man, by Robert S. Norris (Steerforth, $24.95), is a large-canvas portrait of the Army general whose ''organizational and managerial skills'' were vital to the success of the gargantuan military effort to build the first atom bomb. ''The result is an authoritative biography'' that is ''readable and eye-opening,'' Daniel J. Kevles said here last year.    Wavemaker II, by Mary-Beth Hughes. (Grove, $12.) This first novel about the complex nature of loyalty revolves around a young couple whose lives are disastrously affected by their proximity to the orbit of Roy Cohn, humanized here as sentimental yet sanctimonious, thuggishly blunt yet devoted to his friends. ''Hughes is a writer of dexterity and imagination, with a great feel for sensory images,'' Beverly Lowry wrote here in 2002.    Twelve, by Nick McDonell. (Grove, $12.) White Mike, the central character in this first novel about the dissolute doings of rich teenagers returning home to Manhattan's Upper East Side for the Christmas holidays, is a drug dealer who doesn't do drugs, but one whose line of work connects him to a bunch of young people whose separate stories converge at a single calamitous party. The young author ''maintains a teasing affection for the absurdities of adolescence,'' Jennifer Egan wrote here last year. He ''delivers a satirical, even playful portrait of a world that is perilous but essentially humane.''    American Scoundrel: The Life of the Notorious Civil War General Dan Sickles, by Thomas Keneally. (Anchor, $15.) According to this debunking biography, the dashing war hero and successful politician Gen. Daniel Sickles was actually an unscrupulous rogue, adulterer and murderer. (It turns out he was a lousy military commander as well.) Last year in the Book Review, Kevin Baker called this a ''spellbinding'' portrait with a ''nearly tragic sweep.''    Unless, by Carol Shields. (Fourth Estate, $13.95.) With its loving attention to the small domestic habits and serious hopes of its heroine, this novel, about a 40-something writer whose sense of happiness is shaken to its foundation when her daughter opts out of life to beg on the streets of Toronto, is ''classic Carol Shields,'' Catherine Lockerbie said here last year. ''Lives may have cracked asunder, but wry comedy leavens the tale,'' and the writing is ''pellucid and knowing, as naturally paced as breathing itself.''   Scott Veale

snippet: IN 1857, members of the Philological Society of London proposed the creation of a dictionary built upon quotations contributed by readers. The Book Review's project to make a literary map of Manhattan (see centerfold, next page) was wildly more mo...
lead_paragraph: IN 1857, members of the Philological Society of London proposed the creation of a dictionary built upon quotations contributed by readers. The Book Review's project to make a literary map of Manhattan (see centerfold, next page) was wildly more modest than the Oxford English Dictionary, but our reliance on reader submissions was as great, and our gratitude to participants as genuine. The response to our announcement on May 1 ("We'll Map Manhattan") was both enthusiastic and far flung. Submissions arrived from across the country and around the world (Paris, Tampico, Singapore), from general readers, university departments (English, of course, but also German and forestry), and from the third-grade classes of Ms. Chapnick in Ardsley, N.Y., and Mrs. Rosee and Mrs. Absgarten in Scarsdale.
abstract: IN 1857, members of the Philological Society of London proposed the creation of a dictionary built upon quotations contributed by readers. The Book Review's project to make a literary map of Manhattan (see centerfold, next page) was wildly more modest than the Oxford English Dictionary, but our reliance on reader submissions was as great, and our gratitude to participants as genuine. The response to our announcement on May 1 (''We'll Map Manhattan'') was both enthusiastic and far flung. Submissions arrived from across the country and around the world (Paris, Tampico, Singapore), from general readers, university departments (English, of course, but also German and forestry), and from the third-grade classes of Ms. Chapnick in Ardsley, N.Y., and Mrs. Rosee and Mrs. Absgarten in Scarsdale.     Celia Hartmann, a New Yorker, wrote in an e-mail message, ''I am obviously not the only one who walks around town with a world of fictional locations imprinted on top of the so-called real geography of the city.'' She suggested Jack Finney's novel ''Time and Again'' and E. L. Konigsburg's ''From the Mixed-Up Files of Mrs. Basil E. Frankweiler,'' as did enough other readers to make those books -- along with F. Scott Fitzgerald's ''Great Gatsby'' -- the three most frequently submitted. Also much cited were Caleb Carr and Lawrence Block. Some other books and authors we thought emblematic of New York went nearly unmentioned: only two readers proposed Jay McInerney's ''Bright Lights, Big City,'' about the number for Isaac Bashevis Singer's stories (for citations to these and more authors, see the expanded listings at nytimes.com/literarymap)

snippet: THE MOVIE GUY: The 2007 edition of Leonard Maltin's annual movie guide is in stores, and it's a double-wide production. A mass-market paperback, this book is thicker than a brick and stuffed with more than 17,000 entries, yet it sells at a price (...
lead_paragraph: THE MOVIE GUY: The 2007 edition of Leonard Maltin's annual movie guide is in stores, and it's a double-wide production. A mass-market paperback, this book is thicker than a brick and stuffed with more than 17,000 entries, yet it sells at a price ($8.99) that almost makes you feel you're shoplifting it. Maltin's books have essentially cornered the movie guide market. There are plenty of competing volumes -- from VideoHound, Halliwell's, Time Out and Zagat, among others -- but Maltin's have become the go-to choice for both film geeks and casual couch potatoes. Maltin, who is 55, managed to climb on top partly by being there early. He's been issuing these compendiums of thumbnail reviews since 1969, and annually since 1988. As a critic and historian, Maltin is discriminating but unfailingly polite, more open to the ways a film works than the ways it doesn't. (His lowest ranking, besides the citation "BOMB," is a charitable one and a half stars.) Maltin has also been, for many years, a regular on "Entertainment Tonight," and people sometimes mock his eager, chipmunkish demeanor. (In his book "The Film Snob's Dictionary," David Kamp notes Maltin's "adenoidal speaking voice" and "poindexterish appearance.") But he's earned critical respect and become a pop culture icon. In one episode of "The Simpsons," Marge asks, "Did you know there are over 600 critics on TV and Leonard Maltin is the best looking of them all?" (Lisa sensibly replies: "Ewwww!") This week, "Leonard Maltin's 2007 Movie Guide" (Signet) is at No. 13 on the extended version of the miscellaneous paperback list. These extended lists are available at nytimes.com/books.

keywords: [{'name': 'persons', 'value': 'HOOD, MARY', 'rank': 1, 'major': 'N'}, {'name': 'subject', 'value': 'Reviews', 'rank': 2, 'major': 'N'}, {'name': 'subject', 'value': 'Books and Literature', 'rank': 3, 'major': 'N'}, {'name': 'creative_works', 'value': 'FAMILIAR HEAT (BOOK)', 'rank': 4, 'major': 'N'}]
snippet: Unknown
lead_paragraph: FAMILIAR HEAT By Mary Hood. Knopf, $25.
abstract: FAMILIAR HEAT  By Mary Hood. Knopf, $25.     Not all of Florida's east coast is as glitzy and sordid as Miami. Pick your way through the prickly, oddly truncated prose in Mary Hood's novel and you're deep in a small coastal town where Cuban exiles are torn between the old life and the new one and a girl can fall in love and marry and lose everything before she turns 20. In outline, Faye Rios's story sounds like a soap opera: love at first sight; instant marriage; abduction and rape, and estrangement from her philandering husband, Vic. As if that weren't enough, a car wreck wipes Faye's slate completely clean, leaving her with amnesia. Part observer and part dogged survivor, Faye is a simple character at best, even before the wreck. It is the supporting characters who bring Faye's story to life: the wifty priest, the compulsive ex-mother-in-law intent on reviving the marriage. There's more: Vic's affair. Brother Tom's sacred, secret mission. Faye's doomed admirer. Fireworks. Oh yes, and a hurricane. In an odd way, reading "Familiar Heat" is like walking through marsh grass: the going can be tough, but once you've done it, you know you've really been somewhere. KIT REED

keywords: [{'name': 'persons', 'value': 'Webb, Alex', 'rank': 1, 'major': 'N'}, {'name': 'subject', 'value': 'Reviews', 'rank': 2, 'major': 'N'}, {'name': 'subject', 'value': 'Books and Literature', 'rank': 3, 'major': 'N'}, {'name': 'creative_works', 'value': 'AMAZON: FROM THE FLOODPLAINS TO THE CLOUDS (BOOK)', 'rank': 4, 'major': 'N'}]
snippet: Lance Gould reviews book Amazon: From the Floodplains to the Clouds by Alex Webb; photo (S)
lead_paragraph: You're on the Amazon. Suddenly you come upon five blindfolded, pot-bellied American businessmen, dressed in war paint and loincloths, their wrists loosely tied to trees, the river's muddy water lapping at their knees. You turn to your tour guide for some insight into this bizarre ritual. All he says is, ''North American salesmen celebrating the year's successes.'' Such are the frustrations of AMAZON: From the Floodplains to the Clouds (Monacelli, $60), a book of photographs of the world's most mysterious river. Alex Webb presents readers with a jumbled variety of images from the entire 4,000-mile length of the Amazon -- from its mouth on the Brazilian coast to its source in the mountains of Peru -- but his captions fail to provide any context for them. Though many of the photographs are arresting, too many others are incapable of communicating their message without adequate text. Worse, the layout is a disservice to Webb's work: each photograph has an overwhelming white border, diminishing the verisimilitude of the entire you-are-there experience. That said, there is much work of merit here, from the photograph of an overheated gentleman who escapes the sun in the shadows of a satellite dish in backwater Tapia, Brazil, to a shot of a Peruvian militia whose uniforms seem to consist of white headbands, hand-me-down soccer shirts, bare feet and primitive firearms. Webb's best images capture the fluidity not only of the river but of the life along its banks. Lance Gould

snippet: Learning to surf, adolescent friends get caught up in a very grown-up world.
lead_paragraph: What is it about surfing that inclines so steeply toward the mystical? To the Polynesians who first rode the waves on heavy wooden boards, surfing was a spiritual practice aimed at connecting with the gods of the sea while cementing the power of the nobility, who jealously protected their breaks against incursions by commoners and rivals. The Australian surf legend Nat Young, author of the imposing “Complete History of Surfing” (along with the more usefully prophylactic “Surf Rage”), reportedly once tried to register surfing as a religion. Even Frankie Avalon, board-shorted stalwart of Hollywood’s beach party movies, was given to the odd soggy pronouncement about sun, sand and the meaning of life.

BLUEPRINTS. By Sara Vogan. (Bantam, Cloth, $19.95; Paper, $8.95.) Responding to an urgent call, Emery Lannier, the narrator of Sara Vogan's disturbing third novel, flies off on what she thinks is an errand of mercy - caring for her rootless and unreliable (not to mention alcoholic) parents, Nina and Frank.

byline: {'original': None, 'person': [], 'organization': None}
snippet: (Editors' choices of other recent books of particular interest)    SWIMMING TO ANTARCTICA: Tales of a Long-Distance Swimmer, by Lynne Cox. (Knopf, $24.95.) An account of her own performances, culminating in a mile-long swim in the Antarctic, by a ...
lead_paragraph: (Editors' choices of other recent books of particular interest)
abstract: (Editors' choices of other recent books of particular interest)    SWIMMING TO ANTARCTICA: Tales of a Long-Distance Swimmer, by Lynne Cox. (Knopf, $24.95.) An account of her own performances, culminating in a mile-long swim in the Antarctic, by a woman whose remarkable physiology (plus plenty of training) allows her to survive (though painfully) in water that would kill an ordinary hero in minutes.    OUR FATHERS: The Secret Life of the Catholic Church in an Age of Scandal, by David France. (Broadway, $26.95.) France, who covered the pedophilia scandal for Newsweek, demands that both the priests and their victims be seen as people with faces, no two alike and no amorphous masses of perps and victims; this makes for a long book and sometimes an overwhelming one.    AFTER SUCH KNOWLEDGE: Memory, History, and the Legacy of the Holocaust, by Eva Hoffman. (PublicAffairs, $25.) Hoffman, born to Holocaust survivors in Poland in 1945, renders the catastrophe as it is revealed to members of a generation drastically affected by events they cannot themselves remember, filtered through the memories of their elders and their vastly diverse experiences since the end of World War II.    THE FOUNTAIN AT THE CENTER OF THE WORLD, by Robert Newman. (Soft Skull, paper, $14.95.) This frisky political novel by a British comedian concerns resistance to international capitalism's world empire and stars two brothers who have never met; one is a corporate shark who manipulates consciousness, the other an inept eco-terrorist.    SHOOTING THE SUN, by Max Byrd. (Bantam, $23.95.) Science fiction meets the Wild West in this ingenious novel about an expedition in 1840, organized by a beautiful young Francophile American astronomer, to photograph an eclipse of the sun, predicted by an early computing machine of the English savant Charles Babbage.    THE LIBERATED BRIDE, by A. B. Yehoshua. (Harcourt, $27.) A dark and comic novel that presents the two worlds of Israel's two nations, the Jews and the Arabs, and the travels in both of them by an Israeli professor whose magnificent obsession, for five years so far, is with finding out why his son's marriage to a rich young woman failed to endure.    LOVE AND HYDROGEN: New and Selected Stories, by Jim Shepard (Vintage Contemporaries, paper, $13), and PROJECT X, by Jim Shepard (Knopf, $20). A story collection and a novel by an author who applies a lapidary style to outlandish subjects like German fighter pilots flying deathtraps or a collector whose bubble gum cards become hallucinations. ''Project X'' considers the half-demented, perpetually embarrassed world of early adolescence in a sensitive examination of the Columbine phenomenon.    BANDBOX, by Thomas Mallon. (Pantheon, $24.95.) At the center of this novel, set in a Hecht-and-MacArthur universe of curmudgeonly editors, swell dames and shimmering watering holes, two glossy magazines wage a circulation war in the pre-Depression twilight.

snippet: Why have Democrats been losing? Because, Drew Westen says, they appeal to the rational part of the mind.
lead_paragraph: Between 2000 and 2006, a specter haunted the community of fundamentalist Democrats. Members of this community looked around and observed their moral and intellectual superiority. They observed that their policies were better for the middle classes. And yet the middle classes did not support Democrats. They tended to vote, in large numbers, for the morally and intellectually inferior party, the one, moreover, that catered to the interests of the rich.

keywords: [{'name': 'subject', 'value': 'Books and Literature', 'rank': 1, 'major': 'N'}, {'name': 'persons', 'value': 'Winerip, Michael', 'rank': 2, 'major': 'N'}, {'name': 'subject', 'value': 'Children and Youth', 'rank': 3, 'major': 'N'}]
snippet: Adam Canfield, the star reporter of his middle school newspaper, takes on some high school bullies.
lead_paragraph: Life is not like high school. Life is like junior high school. Even high school is like junior high school. That is the real proving ground, the passage from elementary to upper, bliss to hell, where identities are fixed and alliances hammered into place. If you’re a kind of Columbus of the near at hand, wanting to map the world, there is nothing better to be than a reporter at a junior high newspaper, just like Adam Canfield, the hero of Michael Winerip’s new novel. Adam is the star reporter of The Slash, a paper named for the punctuation mark that so aptly describes the school as a place of painful transition: Harris Elementary/Middle School. Of course, Adam, having the body of a middle schooler but the soul of a reporter, likes to think the paper is in fact named for the verb, because the pens of his fellow newshounds “were so mighty, they slashed like swords through thick, swampy lies until they reached the truth.”
abstract: Adam Canfield, the star reporter of his middle school newspaper, takes on some high school bullies.

snippet: Laura Miller The Last Word column on readers who feel compelled to finish a book once they've started it; sees no reason to stay with an 'irksome book when so many sublime ones are available'; drawing (M)
lead_paragraph: A READER recently wrote in to say she was ''amused -- vindicated in fact'' -- to discover in this column some disparaging comments about a certain historical novel she'd read. ''I knew,'' she continued, ''like a bad marriage, that I had made a mistake halfway through the first chapter. I was bored, irritated and actively offended,'' but ''brought up in New England on various strictures of the clean-your-plate school, I did skim it from start to finish with no change of heart.''

snippet: Book Review editors introduce Henry Alford essay (S)
lead_paragraph: "The most enjoyable kind of writing to do is the kind where you don't actually write anything." That's what the humor writer Henry Alford told us when we asked him how he came to put together the quotations from various acknowledgments pages that make up this week's back-page essay. "I compiled this," he said. "It's more like flower arranging than it is like writing."
abstract: Book Review editors introduce Henry Alford essay (S)

headline: {'main': 'Who Put the ‘Cold’ in Cold War?', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Who Put the ‘Cold’ in Cold War?', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}
byline: {'original': 'By James Traub', 'person': [{'firstname': 'James', 'middlename': None, 'lastname': 'Traub', 'qualifier': None, 'title': None, 'role': 'reported', 'organization': '', 'rank': 1}], 'organization': None}
keywords: [{'name': 'subject', 'value': 'United States International Relations', 'rank': 1, 'major': 'N'}, {'name': 'subject', 'value': 'United States Politics and Government', 'rank': 2, 'major': 'N'}, {'name': 'persons', 'value': 'Lukacs, John', 'rank': 3, 'major': 'N'}, {'name': 'subject', 'value': 'Books and Literature', 'rank': 4, 'major': 'N'}, {'name': 'subject', 'value': 'Biographical Information', 'rank': 5, 'major': 'N'}, {'name': 'subject', 'value': 'History', 'rank': 6, 'major': 'N'}, {'name': 'organizations', 'value': 'State Department', 'rank': 7, 'major': 'N'}]
snippet: George Kennan, a student of the Soviet Union and the human soul, was the architect of containment.
lead_paragraph: Back in the mid-1970s, Natan Sharansky and his fellow Soviet dissidents bitterly amused themselves by conducting mock trials of Henry Kissinger, the architect of the détente policy that left them feeling abandoned. Sharansky, as judge, would sentence Kissinger to exile in the Soviet Union without benefit of the Jackson amendment, which pressured the Soviets to permit Jews to emigrate. One can scarcely imagine the punishment he would have meted out to George Kennan (1904-2005), the diplomat-scholar who laid the foundations for the cold war policy Kissinger later executed, and who, we learn from John Lukacs’s elegant and elegiac biography, sharply opposed “the American insistence that the Soviet Union facilitate emigration of its citizens in accord with some American preferences.” Sharansky would not have been surprised to learn that Kennan also felt “fairly at home” in Berlin in the years before America’s entry into World War II, and “regretted” our involvement in the war (though he later wrote that the Holocaust was sufficient reason to fight Germany).

keywords: [{'name': 'persons', 'value': 'Kizer, Carolyn', 'rank': 1, 'major': 'N'}, {'name': 'subject', 'value': 'Reviews', 'rank': 2, 'major': 'N'}, {'name': 'subject', 'value': 'Books and Literature', 'rank': 3, 'major': 'N'}, {'name': 'creative_works', 'value': 'COOL, CALM & COLLECTED: POEMS 1960-2000 (BOOK)', 'rank': 4, 'major': 'N'}]
snippet: Melanie Rehak reviews book Cool, Calm & Collected: Poems 1960-2000 by Carolyn Kizer; drawing (S)
lead_paragraph: For more than 40 years, Carolyn Kizer has used poetry as an outlet for her humanistic, liberal ethos. She was a feminist practically before the term existed, and she has consistently spoken out against injustice both in her work and in her life. As a result, COOL, CALM & COLLECTED: Poems 1960-2000 (Copper Canyon, $30) provides an opportunity to look back not only at her career, but at the recent social and political history of America. She covers civil rights, women's rights and almost everything in between, but even when she's writing about more intimate matters, her underlying concern is freedom. One of the earliest poems in the book, ''The Worms,'' is about a child walking over the worm-strewn ground after a rainstorm, viscerally aware of ''Trying not to wound / anything alive; / Most especially / Not to maim the self / By any kind of death.'' It's an innocent desire that can't last, of course, a bitter truth Kizer gets to in her long poem from the 1960's, ''Pro Femina.'' ''I take as my theme 'The Independent Woman,' ''she writes. And then she adds, pointedly, ''Independent but maimed.'' Despite her constant railing against the machine, however, Kizer's poetry remains fundamentally optimistic, perhaps because she seems to love existence almost in spite of herself. ''Observe the world with desperate affection,'' she wrote in the 70's. This collection, which includes translations from a dizzying number of foreign poets, is ample proof that she's spent a lifetime taking her own good advice. Melanie Rehak
abstract: Melanie Rehak reviews book Cool, Calm & Collected: Poems 1960-2000 by Carolyn Kizer; drawing (S)

lead_paragraph: BURN MARKS, by Sara Paretsky. (Dell, $4.95.) After her crazy Aunt Elena is burned out of her fleabag hotel, the Chicago private eye Vic Warshawski is dragged into a case involving real estate developers and the Cook County political machine. "The 'whydunit' in Ms. Paretsky's books is often embedded in the fabric of problems that confront us all," Elaine Budd said here last year. "This extra dimension adds an immediacy to 'Burn Marks' that is not found in many private-eye novels."
abstract: BURN MARKS, by Sara Paretsky. (Dell, $4.95.) After her crazy Aunt Elena is burned out of her fleabag hotel, the Chicago private eye Vic Warshawski is dragged into a case involving real estate developers and the Cook County political machine. "The 'whydunit' in Ms. Paretsky's books is often embedded in the fabric of problems that confront us all," Elaine Budd said here last year. "This extra dimension adds an immediacy to 'Burn Marks' that is not found in many private-eye novels."   MY TRAITOR'S HEART: A South African Exile Returns to Face His Country, His Tribe, & His Conscience, by Rian Malan. (Vintage International, $10.95.) In 1977, the author, an Afrikaner from Johannesburg, left his job as a South African police reporter because he was sick of his country's paradoxes; but exile in America was empty, and seven years later he returned to a land that had become even more violent. In this book, he concentrates on crime rather than politics, telling "tales of ordinary murders, and though he writes without grace, egoistically, vulgarly, his stories are haunting the way bad dreams are," Vincent Crapanzano said in The Book Review last year. "They fascinate us, and only in retrospect do we realize their horror."

snippet: Unknown
lead_paragraph: PARALLEL TIME: Growing Up in Black and White By Brent Staples. Avon, $11. The author, an editorial writer for The New York Times, recalls his experiences as the eldest son of a black family in Chester, Pa., a town where obvious forms of segregation had vanished but more subtle divisions between the races were strong. His memoir explores those boundaries and the one between himself and his brother Blake, a drug dealer who died violently. "It is a complex portrait of a worldly education, written at times with affection, at times with a sting," Verlyn Klinkenborg wrote here last year. A BOOK OF COMMON PRAYER By Joan Didion. Vintage International, $12. Charlotte Douglas, a woman with no understanding of revolutions, seeks her 18-year-old daughter, who is trying to foment one. After participating in a bombing and a hijacking, the young woman is believed to be in Boca Grande, a fictional Central American country. Grace Strasser-Mendana, another American expatriate, tells their story. In 1977 our reviewer, Joyce Carol Oates, said that Joan Didion "has been an articulate witness to the most stubborn and intractable truths of our time, a memorable voice, partly eulogistic, partly despairing; always in control." Vintage has also brought another of Ms. Didion's novels back into print: DEMOCRACY ($12), in which the author herself is a character. She narrates the drama of the Victor family, whose life in 1975 involves both politics and murder. The author "is wonderful not only at hearing her characters but at naming them," Mary McCarthy said in the Book Review in 1984. LISTENING By Hannah Merker. Harper Perennial, $12. More than two decades ago, the author went skiing for the first time -- an event that marked the last time she would ever hear completely. Her book assesses the importance of sound and demonstrates how she adjusted to the silence imposed by a devastating accident. Writing in these pages last year, Lou Ann Walker said: "We feel her loss. . . . But we are receptive to the lessons of listening she is teaching us." Also reissued is TRAIN GO SORRY: Inside a Deaf World, (Vintage, $13). The author, Leah Hager Cohen, is the daughter of the superintendent of the Lexington School for the Deaf in Queens. A hearing child of hearing parents, she describes her life within a culture she could never really be part of. In 1994 our reviewer, Russ Rymer, said the book often reads "like a love story -- as intimate, tender and troubling a love story as any you're likely to find." THE WAY WE KNOW IN DREAMS: Stories By Gordon Weaver. University of Missouri, $14.95. Many of the men in this collection are disappointed middle-aged souls who feel powerless to change their fates -- as well they might, since two of the other characters are God and Satan. The result is "inspired, clever and unexpected fiction," Chris Bohjalian wrote here last year. The men in the stories in WANTING ONLY TO BE HEARD, by Jack Driscoll (University of Massachusetts, $12.95), are even more desperate. Frequently hunters and fishermen, often bereft of female company, they live close to nature -- and to violence. In 1993 Jonis Agee said in the Book Review that "Jack Driscoll's poetic language gives them a stature that makes their struggle meaningful, tragic and universal." MOTHERLESS DAUGHTERS: The Legacy of Loss By Hope Edelman. Delta, $12.95. The author, who was 17 when her mother died, draws on clinical research and the experiences of more than 200 other women to analyze the impact of such a loss. Daughters in mourning, she explains, often feel that their own lives are incomplete. This is "a moving and valuable treatment of a neglected subject," Nancy Caldwell Sorel said here last year. Maternal roles are also examined in THE MYTHS OF MOTHERHOOD: How Culture Reinvents the Good Mother, by Shari L. Thurer (Penguin, $12.95). Ranging from the Stone Age to today, this history reveals how society, not biology, has defined women's task as parents. In 1994 our reviewer, Rachel Billington, called it "positive, sensible and readable." ACTS OF LOVE By Emily Listfield. Penguin, $10.95. It's a familiar scenario: a gun goes off in a suburban living room, and a marital quarrel ends in death. The question this novel poses is whether Ted Waring deliberately or accidentally killed his estranged wife. The author's "chilling meditation . . . is a sobering reminder that some puzzles are better left unsolved," Sarah Ferguson said in the Book Review last year. THE PROTEAN SELF: Human Resilience in an Age of Fragmentation By Robert Jay Lifton. Basic Books, $13. If a foolish consistency is indeed the hobgoblin of little minds, the author has found quite a few large-minded people. Their response to the dislocation of today's world is to become eminently adaptable. In 1994 our reviewer, Richard A. Shweder, found this "a fascinating and appealing book because it is a near-perfect example of an intellectual stance that skeptics sometimes disparage." Human resilience is also evident in THE AGELESS SELF: Sources of Meaning in Late Life, by Sharon R. Kaufman (University of Wisconsin, $11.95). A study of 60 elderly men and women, it demonstrates that strength of spirit and mind often compensates for bodily weakness. It is "a book that no novelist or indeed any caring person with a fondness for human interiors could resist," Paul West said here in 1987. DROWN ALL THE DOGS By Thomas Adcock. Pocket Books, $5.50. Detective Neil Hockaday has to confront his own family's shadowy past when he returns to Ireland to find out about the father he never knew. Last year our reviewer, Marilyn Stasio, called this mystery's dialogue "lively and literate." LAUREL GRAEBER

lead_paragraph: L. FRANK BAUM: Creator of Oz, by Katharine M. Rogers. (Da Capo, $17.95.) In the first full-length biography of the sweet-natured creator of more than 70 children's books, the author (a scholar and lifelong Oz fan) portrays Baum (1856-1919) as an ironist whose 14 Oz books stress the homely American virtues of self-reliance and practicality, as well as tolerance, egalitarianism and a deep mistrust of leaders. Last year in the Book Review, Brooke Allen found this ''a strong and sympathetic portrait.''

In the first full-length biography of the sweet-natured creator of more than 70 children's books, the author (a scholar and lifelong Oz fan) portrays Baum (1856-1919) as an ironist whose 14 Oz books stress the homely American virtues of self-reliance and practicality, as well as tolerance, egalitarianism and a deep mistrust of leaders. Last year in the Book Review, Brooke Allen found this ''a strong and sympathetic portrait.''    EVA'S COUSIN, by Sibylle Knauss. (Ballantine, $13.95.) In this fact-based German novel, Eva is Eva Braun and her cousin is Gertrude Weisker, a bright young physics student summoned to Hitler's Bavarian mountain retreat in 1944 to amuse Eva while the Führer is away at work. By the time she flees, nine months later, she has been transformed by her encounters with love, life and death. The result is a ''strange, moving and disturbing book'' that ''feels like the truth,'' Alan Riding wrote here in 2002.    NINETY DEGREES NORTH: The Quest for the North Pole, by Fergus Fleming. (Grove, $15.) This follow-up to ''Barrow's Boys'' (2000), Fleming's account of the British Admiralty's search for the Northwest Passage from 1816 to 1845, tells of the race to reach the North Pole between the 1850's and 1926, an obsession that attracted many explorers and plenty of controversy. Fleming ''has great narrative gifts, and his brief character sketches draw readers in while pithy summaries of each expedition carry us on breathlessly from one ice hummock to the next,'' Jonathan Dore said here last year.    ZORA NEALE HURSTON: A Life in Letters. Edited by Carla Kaplan. (Anchor, $19.95.) The prolific Hurston -- she wrote novels, stories, folk tales, plays and essays -- may be most often associated with the Harlem Renaissance of the 1920's, but she was a highly inventive quick-change artist, this sampling of nearly 500 letters suggests. Though ''they tell us something of how she viewed the outside world and clarify some of her thinking about art and politics,'' Hurston ''emerges . . . more of an enigma than ever,'' Ann duCille wrote here earlier this year.    DISTURBANCE OF THE INNER EAR, by Joyce Hackett. (Carroll & Graf, $14.) This first novel's narrator, a brilliant but artistically blocked cellist, is stirred back to life when she encounters an exquisite 16th-century cello that, like her, has a history deeply linked to the Holocaust. The result is a ''singular and sometimes haunting'' tale, Jennifer Marie Reese wrote here last year.    FROM THE LAND OF GREEN GHOSTS: A Burmese Odyssey, by Pascal Khoo Thwe. (Perennial/HarperCollins, $13.95.) The author, now in his 30's and living in London, recounts his improbable escape from Myanmar, an intensely beautiful land virtually sealed off from the outside world since the 1960's by a repressive, corrupt military. Last year our reviewer, Barbara Crossette, called this a ''powerful portrait of a suffering nation'' by a ''writer of uncommon elegance and sensitivity.''    RUMPOLE RESTS HIS CASE, by John Mortimer. (Penguin, $13.) Horace Rumpole, the curmudgeonly London barrister and hero of 12 other collections of stories, is pushing 70 by now, but despite his gout, chain-smoking and penchant for bad wine, he finds time to defend a crew of lowlifes and lost causes. These tales (which culminate, inevitably, in a courtroom heart attack) ''won't disappoint die-hard fans,'' Patricia T. O'Conner wrote here last year. ''Horace is at his rumpled best, quoting Wordsworth, scratching under his yellowing horsehair wig'' and ''puffing at his cheroots.''    AMERICAN SUBLIME: Landscape Painting in the United States, 1820-1880, by Andrew Wilton and Tim Barringer. (Princeton University, $35.) According to the authors, mid-19th-century painters from Thomas Cole to Frederick Church ''celebrated the beauty of the wilderness at the moment of its historical transformation'' by settlement and industry. In 2002 our reviewer, Christopher Benfey, said, ''The spectacular paintings . . . retain their power to entice and overwhelm.''    BORN TWICE, by Giuseppe Pontiggia. (Vintage International, $13.) This utterly unsentimental Italian novel focuses on a father's struggle to cope with his son's severe disability and his ambivalent reaction to his child's limitations. The author's ''artful'' story ''lays bare the moral stakes in representing the disabled,'' Lawrence Venuti wrote here in 2002.   Scott Veale

lead_paragraph: A BURDEN OF EARTH And Other Stories.By Beth Bosworth.Hanging Loose Press,cloth, $20; paper, $12.
abstract:
A BURDEN OF EARTH 
And Other Stories.
By Beth Bosworth.
Hanging Loose Press,
cloth, $20; paper, $12. 

 Joseph Klingle is a man always poised in midflight. A distinguished physicist, he spends his life aloft in the hush of an airliner, passing to and from academic conventions, musing on the condensational properties of the water drops that blur his small window. Below him, his daughter Ruth studies his cometlike progress and waits for abrupt phone calls from the stratosphere, for the sound of his expensive silence singing down the wire. As she stands in her kitchen, she remembers the moment when the line of his flight path crossed her fixed point: the summer when he first molested her. The rage, sadness and love characteristic of incest survivors' stories lurk at the heart of Beth Bosworth's sometimes affecting collection of short fiction. But "A Burden of Earth" is all too clearly a beginner's book, the work of an apprentice entranced by style and its possibilities. Like Klingle aloft in his capsule, Ms. Bosworth neglects earthbound niceties -- well-rounded characters, a fast-moving story line -- to pursue a higher goal: the idiosyncratic new language that could "represent the universe." Annoyed by her self-conscious, arty style, readers may want to hang up early on, rather than linger in the static hush of her anomie.
ROSE KERNOCHAN

snippet: Once the Nazis lost, Leni Riefenstahl and her defenders tried to argue that artistic genius trumps politics.
lead_paragraph: A BRAZEN shout from long trumpets held high at the angle of a Hitler salute. Cut to medium close-up of young Aryan faces with puffed cheeks. Dolly back as two new biographies of Leni Riefenstahl appear virtually at once. Jürgen Trimborn’s book, well translated from the German by Edna McCown, has the better pictures. Steven Bach’s book, backed up by his deep personal experience as a high-echelon film executive handling dingbat directors, has the better text. Though neither book is precisely adulatory, put them together and they add up to an awful lot of attention. She might be dead, but she won’t lie down.

keywords: [{'name': 'persons', 'value': 'GELB, ALAN', 'rank': 1, 'major': 'N'}, {'name': 'subject', 'value': 'BOOK REVIEWS', 'rank': 2, 'major': 'N'}, {'name': 'creative_works', 'value': 'MOST LIKELY TO SUCCEED (BOOK)', 'rank': 3, 'major': 'N'}]
snippet: Unknown
lead_paragraph: MOST LIKELY TO SUCCEED: Multiple Murder and the Elusive Search for Justice in an American Town. By Alan Gelb. (Dutton, $19.95.) The frustrating thing about nonfiction is that sometimes reasonable questions - like, why would a successful high school senior murder his family? - simply do not have reasonable answers. The novelist Alan Gelb lives in East Chatham, N.Y., on the very street where four people were killed in December 1986. In ''Most Likely to Succeed,'' Mr. Gelb eloquently conveys the sense of a town both secure and small; for example, the town justice who presided over a preliminary hearing is also a real-estate agent who later tried to sell the dead family's home. Through it all, however, 17-year-old Wyley Gates, the accused murderer, remains a shadow. Despite being vice president of his high school class, the boy was emotionally alone. His parents were divorced, Mr. Gelb writes, and Wyley resented his father's blue-collar work ethic. Compulsive about computers, Wyley was required to mow the lawn and get his hands dirty at his dad's machine shop, without pay. He especially disliked Cheryl Brahm, his father's longtime companion. Wyley was not close to his older brother, and objected to sharing a room with his 3-year-old orphaned nephew. In retrospect Wyley Gates's mental difficulties are obvious; dozens of better adjusted classmates apparently knew of and ignored Wyley's violent plans, Mr. Gelb writes. Although Wyley confessed to police within hours of the crime, procedural errors by investigators cast doubt upon his statement, and a jury acquitted Wyley Gates of murder.
abstract: LEAD:    MOST LIKELY TO SUCCEED: Multiple Murder and the Elusive Search for Justice in an American Town. By Alan Gelb. (Dutton, $19.95.) The frustrating thing about nonfiction is that sometimes reasonable questions - like, why would a successful high school senior murder his family? - simply do not have reasonable answers.

lead_paragraph: LEAD:
abstract:
LEAD: 

PARLOR GAMES. By Mavis Cheek. (Simon & Schuster, $18.95.) It can be a lot of fun to watch the British make fun of themselves. Instructive, too, since their wicked irony has long offered clues about life among classes to which most of us have not been born. And so a reader can be forgiven for approaching Mavis Cheek's second novel, ''Parlor Games,'' with high expectations.

JOHN AND ANZIA: An American Romance. By Norma Rosen. (Dutton, $18.95.) For her fourth novel, Norma Rosen has chosen to imagine what went on in 1917 between John Dewey, the distinguished educator and philosopher, and Anzia Yezierska, a Jewish immigrant from Poland whose short stories ultimately earned her the sobriquet ''Sweatshop Cinderella.

snippet: In “Alan Lomax: The Man Who Recorded the World,” John Szwed, a biographer of Miles Davis and Sun Ra, covers the life of a tireless music folklorist and anthologist.
lead_paragraph: In 1961, as a young graduate student at an ethnomusicologists’ meeting, John Szwed caught the eye of the master: Alan Lomax, the man whose tremendous body of work allowed previously unheard folk recordings to become universally well known. Seemingly apropos of nothing, Lomax remarked “Pygmies are a baseline culture.” Then he went on his way.

lead_paragraph: LEAD:
abstract:
LEAD: 

ONION. By Kate Braestrup. (Viking, $17.95.) '' 'Annnnhhh!' he said, newly emerged, and still smeared with his mother's blood, and with vernix, the white paste that had kept him from getting pruny while in utero.'' That's the initial image in Kate Braestrup's first novel, a book-length disquisition on the subject of how a radical feminist theologian comes to find herself intellectually justified in changing diapers.

keywords: [{'name': 'subject', 'value': 'Books and Literature', 'rank': 1, 'major': 'N'}, {'name': 'persons', 'value': 'McGinniss, Joe', 'rank': 2, 'major': 'N'}, {'name': 'glocations', 'value': 'Las Vegas (Nev)', 'rank': 3, 'major': 'N'}]
snippet: The hero of this novel, a blocked painter, returns to his native Las Vegas and its temptations.
lead_paragraph: The Madonna-whore complex is seldom as well defined as in “The Delivery Man,” Joe McGinniss Jr.’s brisk, bleak debut novel. Caught in the middle is Chase, a 25-year-old who fled New York University and is festering in his native Las Vegas, a blocked painter turned heel-dragging high school teacher. His girlfriend, Julia, is on the corporate fast track (and in town briefly for a black M.B.A. conference), contemplating bearing his child; Michele, a relic from his past, is, to be brutal, a whore.

snippet: Peter H. Stone’s book is a one-stop shop for anyone wanting to know what the Jack Abramoff scandal is all about.
lead_paragraph: Like the spot on Lady Macbeth’s hand, the Jack Abramoff scandal can’t be washed away. Abramoff was sentenced to five years and 10 months on fraud charges, former Representative Bob Ney is scheduled to begin his two-year-plus prison term, former DeLay staff members Michael Scanlon, Tony Rudy and Ed Buckham await their sorry fates (as does Tom DeLay himself) and several other miscreants, including lawmakers, staffers and top administration officials, are praying that the continuing, aggressive investigation by prosecutors will pass them by.

snippet: This magnificent biography of Henry Morton Stanley is a superb adventure story as well as a feat of advocacy.
lead_paragraph: Poor Africa, the happy hunting ground of the mythomaniac, the rock star buffing up his or her image, the missionary with a faith to sell, the child buyer, the retailer of dirty drugs or toxic cigarettes, the editor in search of a scoop, the empire builder, the aid worker, the tycoon wishing to rid himself of his millions, the school builder with a bucket of patronage, the experimenting economist, the diamond merchant, the oil executive, the explorer, the slave trader, the eco-tourist, the adventure traveler, the bird watcher, the travel writer, the escapee, the colonial and his crapulosities, the banker, the busybody, the Mandela-sniffer, the political fantasist, the buccaneer and your cousin the Peace Corps Volunteer. Oh, and the atoner, of whom Thoreau observed in a skeptical essay: “Now, if anything ail a man so that he does not perform his functions ... if he has committed some heinous sin and partially repents, what does he do? He sets about reforming the world.” Thoreau, who had Africa specifically in mind, added, “Do you hear it, ye Wolofs?”

byline: {'original': 'By Scott Veale', 'person': [{'firstname': 'Scott', 'middlename': None, 'lastname': 'Veale', 'qualifier': None, 'title': None, 'role': 'reported', 'organization': '', 'rank': 1}], 'organization': None}
snippet: Unknown
lead_paragraph: COLLECTED POEMS, by James Merrill. Edited by J. D. McClatchy and Stephen Yenser. (Knopf, $27.50.) This gigantic volume reveals the poet's absorption of human experience in all its shapes and sizes, and his delight in reporting it from every conceivable point of view. In 2001 our reviewer, Daniel Mendelsohn, praised both the formal skill and emotional intensity of Merrill's work, saying ''his lyrics . . . have a lapidary smoothness and mosaic fit that recall not his beloved Greeks but, if anyone, the Roman lyricist Horace -- another poet who was haunted by the specter of time and death even as he puckishly pursued the pleasures of life.''
abstract: COLLECTED POEMS, by James Merrill. Edited by J. D. McClatchy and Stephen Yenser. (Knopf, $27.50.) This gigantic volume reveals the poet's absorption of human experience in all its shapes and sizes, and his delight in reporting it from every conceivable point of view. In 2001 our reviewer, Daniel Mendelsohn, praised both the formal skill and emotional intensity of Merrill's work, saying ''his lyrics . . . have a lapidary smoothness and mosaic fit that recall not his beloved Greeks but, if anyone, the Roman lyricist Horace -- another poet who was haunted by the specter of time and death even as he puckishly pursued the pleasures of life.''    THEM: Adventures With Extremists, by Jon Ronson. (Simon & Schuster, $13.) A British writer and documentary filmmaker adopts a chipper faux-naïf pose as he insinuates himself into the homes and graces of various groups of extremists, among them neo-Nazis, the Ku Klux Klan and the New World Order conspiracy theorists. The result is an ''entertaining, more often disturbing, book,'' Ron Rosenbaum wrote in the Book Review in 2002.    TISHOMINGO BLUES, by Elmore Leonard. (HarperTorch/HarperCollins, $7.99.) Among the moving parts in the author's latest whirligig are a high diver whose specialty is plunging into shallow tanks from an 80-foot platform; the kooky residents of Tunica, Miss.; a constellation of crooks, among them a bunch of redneck lowlifes known as the Dixie Mafia; and a re-enactment of a less-than-epic Civil War battle. The result is ''Leonard's best work since 'Get Shorty,' '' Joe Queenan said here last year.    TEPPER ISN'T GOING OUT, by Calvin Trillin. (Random House, $12.95.) Murray Tepper, this novel's peculiarly obsessive hero, haunts the streets of Manhattan in search of ideal parking spaces in which he can idle away his time reading the newspaper. He becomes something of a folk hero, dispensing sidewalk wisdom à la Chauncey Gardiner, until the city's authoritarian mayor (think Rudolph W. Giuliani) decides Tepper is an agent of disorder. The result is ''an entertaining read'' that is ''perfectly believable'' as fact or fiction, Clyde Haberman said in these pages last year.    WARRIOR POLITICS: Why Leadership Demands a Pagan Ethos, by Robert D. Kaplan. (Vintage, $12.) Drawing on the worldviews of historical figures as varied as Winston Churchill and Sun-Tzu, the author seeks to provide guidance for American statesmen, arguing for policies shaped more by hard-nosed realism (a pagan approach) than by idealism. ''Kaplan's purpose is to help the United States achieve its destiny by using the selected wisdom of the past as a guide,'' Donald Kagan wrote here in 2002.    MARY SHELLEY, by Miranda Seymour. (Grove, $20.) Shelley, who wrote ''Frankenstein'' at 19, seemed to know everyone worth knowing in the Romantic avant-garde of early-19th-century London, a free-spirited cast that included Percy Bysshe Shelley (with whom she eloped to France) and Lord Byron. In 2001 our reviewer, Claude Rawson, found this an ''affectionate and well-written biography.''    LIMBO, and Other Places I Have Lived: Short Stories, by Lily Tuck. (Perennial/HarperCollins, $12.95.) The author's first collection of short fiction focuses on American women in exotic locales who are searching for themselves even as they constantly measure their distance from husbands, families and lovers. ''As with all good stories about life, these are full of sex and death,'' Catherine Lockerbie said here last year. ''But humanity is sometimes visible, filtered through the Marguerite Duras settings, the David Lynch strangenesses and the pellucid intelligence.''    THE ILLUSTRATED ZULEIKA DOBSON: Or an Oxford Love Story, by Max Beerbohm. (Yale University, $14.95.) Beerbohm's only novel, originally published in 1911, is a satire on university life and aristocratic manners that revolves around a beautiful showgirl who sets all of Oxford aflutter. Reissued with 80 watercolor sketches reproduced from Beerbohm's own copy, this volume is ''perfectly delightful,'' Michiko Kakutani wrote in The Times in 1985.    BEGINNINGS: A Memoir, by Horton Foote. (Scribner, $14.) The follow-up to the playwright's 1999 memoir, ''Farewell,'' carries him from his childhood home in Texas to New York City in the 1930's and 40's, where he struggled to make it in acting before discovering his talent for writing. In 2001 our reviewer, N. Graham Nesmith, called this a ''charming and refreshingly wholesome'' account.   Scott Veale

snippet: For young people in 1255, life tends to be nasty, brutish and short.
lead_paragraph: Camelot, it’s not. Lowdy, for example, hates the fleas. The girl is not troubled by the lice “raising families in my hair” and doesn’t really mind having to scrape the maggots off the cheese. But she helps her father, a varlet, tend the lord’s dogs, and fleas are one of the occupational hazards. So she prays for relief:

snippet: Maureen McLane reviews book The Secret Names of Women by Lynne Barrett; drawing (M)
lead_paragraph: The idiosyncratic survivors and self-inventors who populate the eight stories in Lynne Barrett's new collection, THE SECRET NAMES OF WOMEN (Carnegie Mellon University, paper, $15.95), speak a sassy American demotic tinged by a loopy melancholia: ''I kicked Tommy Falcon out at the end of May '91. Tommy had never formally moved in, but was sleeping over most nights and accumulating stuff and just getting more and more comfortable, which was courtship as I knew it.'' All but one of these stories feature offbeat female protagonists facing some juncture or transition -- mourning a love affair's end, marrying an Estonian to get him a green card, facing an unplanned pregnancy. Barrett focuses on the pathos and dignity of the underdetermined life: the late-20th-century life shaped by improvisation, bad or good luck and the seemingly random impulses of the heart. When her characters rename themselves, they do so less to assert identity than to clean the slate, all the while making clear that the slate is already a well-worn, much-marked surface. A few stories work up striking conceits: in ''Hush Money,'' a ''gardener to the stars'' in Hollywood befriends a lonely recluse who was Marilyn Monroe's friend back when Monroe was Norma Jean and new to town. In ''Elvis Lives,'' Barrett chronicles the predicament of three addled Elvis impersonators under the thumb of a latter-day Colonel Parker. Although Barrett occasionally stretches her form to accommodate a more complex narrative structure, this collection has a certain sameness of tone and stance -- a wry, lucid optimism. Her truest allegiances and richest writing emerge in those stories with musician-heroines (''Meet the Impersonators!'' and ''The Former Star Carlson''): their slightly bruised openness to experience and their straightforward commitment to their art mirror Barrett's own. Maureen McLane
abstract: Maureen McLane reviews book The Secret Names of Women by Lynne Barrett; drawing (M)

snippet: The outlook for the American worker: increasingly hostile.
lead_paragraph: Eight years ago, Deborah Shank was seriously injured when a semitrailer rig struck the driver’s side of her minivan. Because Shank, then a shelf stocker at a Wal-Mart store in Cape Girardeau, Mo., had recently qualified for the company’s health plan, most of her immediate hospital expenses were covered. But because the accident left her in a wheelchair, with permanent brain damage, she continues to require full-time nursing care. To help pay for it, a court set up a $417,000 trust, using the proceeds of a lawsuit against the company whose driver caused the accident.

headline: {'main': 'And Bear In Mind', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'And Bear In Mind', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}
byline: {'original': None, 'person': [], 'organization': None}
snippet: Unknown
lead_paragraph: (Editors' choices of other recent books of particular interest)
abstract: (Editors' choices of other recent books of particular interest)    THE DIVE FROM CLAUSEN'S PIER, by Ann Packer. (Knopf, $24.) Many a young person has come to New York for a restart; the narrator of this beguiling first novel, which is much concerned with the particularities of place and conduct, does it after a nitwit move by her fiancé in Wisconsin renders him quadriplegic.    THE SEAL WIFE, by Kathryn Harrison. (Random House, $23.95.) In this thickly atmospheric novel, set in 1915 Alaska, Harrison characteristically combines love and suffering, vulnerability and dominance, in a sexual affair between a young weather scientist and an Aleutian woman who almost never speaks.    CHERRY: A Life of Apsley Cherry-Garrard, by Sara Wheeler. (Random House, $26.95.) An authoritative evocation of the English amateur explorer who was permanently bemused by his two years with Scott and his fatal Antarctic expedition, and wrote a classic book about them, ''The Worst Journey in the World.''    TONIGHT AT NOON: A Love Story, by Sue Graham Mingus. (Pantheon, $24.) A memoir (by a onetime Milwaukee debutante) of 11 years and numerous tumults with a very difficult man, the jazz composer, bandleader and double-bass virtuoso Charles Mingus, the last three as his wife until his death in 1979.    LIVING PROOF: A Medical Mutiny, by Michael Gearin-Tosh. (Scribner, $25.) After a vague but discouragingly mortal medical prognosis, the author, an Oxford don, took charge of his own multiple myeloma, a virulent bone-marrow cancer, working out a program of Chinese breathing exercises, acupuncture, enemas, vitamins and other alternative medicine stuff, and is still alive after eight years. Could be a fluke, but a hard one to argue with.    INTERESTING WOMEN: Stories, by Andrea Lee. (Random House, $22.95.) A lush collection of beautifully textured fiction, set mostly in Italy, where the author lives, and featuring American expatriate beauties, many of them black, in situations that are concerned with the many ways of being foreign -- even in your own home, country or marriage.    UNLESS, by Carol Shields. (Fourth Estate, $24.95.) ''The useful monotony of happiness'' is what's missing for Reta, a writer whose eldest daughter has taken to sitting and begging on a downtown street corner; Reta's response and the author's tone, measured and calm, are of greater interest than the withdrawal itself.    THE TRANSLATOR, by John Crowley. (Morrow, $24.95.) A college student's crush on a Soviet poet in the 1960's serves to support this novel's fictional world full of conspiracy theories and paranoia but sustained with far nobler stuff: poetry, the souls of nations, the transforming power of language.    THE BONDWOMAN'S NARRATIVE, by Hannah Crafts. (Warner, $24.95.) An autobiographical novel from the 1850's by ''a fugitive slave, recently escaped,'' this is apparently the first novel by a black woman, let alone by a female fugitive slave; its access to the reality of slavery is as unmediated as we are likely to get.

(Northwestern University, Cloth, $24.95; Paper, $9.95.) The Czechoslovak playwright, journalist, essayist and novelist Karel Capek (1890-1938) is perhaps best known for his science-fiction novel ''War With the Newts'' and his futuristic play ''R.U.R.,'' in which he coined the term ''robot.

snippet: In his "Survivors: A New Vision of Endangered Wildlife," the photographer James Balog banished the illusory prettiness of nature photography to expose the viewer directly to endangered species, to creatures temporarily freed from the diminished el...
lead_paragraph: In his "Survivors: A New Vision of Endangered Wildlife," the photographer James Balog banished the illusory prettiness of nature photography to expose the viewer directly to endangered species, to creatures temporarily freed from the diminished elements of natural habitat within which zoos or parks had imprisoned and, thus, romanticized them. Among studio lights, scrims and screens, his subjects were revealed in their incomparable, irreplaceable beauty. His new volume, ANIMA (Arts Alternative Press, 3200 Valmont Avenue, Suite 7, Boulder, Colo. 80301; $29.95), continues to disrupt the cavalier perception of nature by focusing on Homo sapiens. In 28 dramatic photographs, Mr. Balog portrays his figures as if they were fossils obscured by the darkness of history. His photographs are of individuals -- human and chimpanzee -- encountering one another with no context but light and space. His photographs capture the radiance of pure expression in Isabella Rossellini's face and in the chimp who cradles it. The accompanying text, similarly denuded of metaphor, is itself what the photographer calls a "psychological labyrinth," an accretion of typography and meditation on our animal nature and our unnatural dissociation from it. The resulting elegantly designed book is an unsettling record of an artist exposing us, with neither shame nor embarrassment, for the animals we are.MICHAEL J. ROSEN

In his "Survivors: A New Vision of Endangered Wildlife," the photographer James Balog banished the illusory prettiness of nature photography to expose the viewer directly to endangered species, to creatures temporarily freed from the diminished elements of natural habitat within which zoos or parks had imprisoned and, thus, romanticized them. Among studio lights, scrims and screens, his subjects were revealed in their incomparable, irreplaceable beauty. His new volume, ANIMA (Arts Alternative Press, 3200 Valmont Avenue, Suite 7, Boulder, Colo. 80301; $29.95), continues to disrupt the cavalier perception of nature by focusing on Homo sapiens. In 28 dramatic photographs, Mr. Balog portrays his figures as if they were fossils obscured by the darkness of history. His photographs are of individuals -- human and chimpanzee -- encountering one another with no context but light and space. His photographs capture the radiance of pure expression in Isabella Rossellini's face and in the chimp who cradles it. The accompanying text, similarly denuded of metaphor, is itself what the photographer calls a "psychological labyrinth," an accretion of typography and meditation on our animal nature and our unnatural dissociation from it. The resulting elegantly designed book is an unsettling record of an artist exposing us, with neither shame nor embarrassment, for the animals we are.
MICHAEL J. ROSEN

keywords: [{'name': 'persons', 'value': 'Dessaix, Robert', 'rank': 1, 'major': 'N'}, {'name': 'subject', 'value': 'Reviews', 'rank': 2, 'major': 'N'}, {'name': 'subject', 'value': 'Books and Literature', 'rank': 3, 'major': 'N'}, {'name': 'creative_works', 'value': 'NIGHT LETTERS (BOOK)', 'rank': 4, 'major': 'N'}]
snippet: Patrick Farrell reviews book Night Letters by Robert Dessaix; drawing (S)
lead_paragraph: A middle-aged Australian, told he has a terminal illness, indulges a long-held urge to set off alone on a meandering trip, guided only by whim, chance and a need to figure out how to live without a belief in his own future. He travels to Switzerland, northern Italy and finally a hotel in Venice, where each night he retraces his journey in letters to a friend, fretting that his observations on mortality and the search for meaning have ''all been said before in a thousand different ways.'' Perhaps, but rarely with the wit, economy or success of Robert Dessaix's novel NIGHT LETTERS (Wyatt/St. Martin's, $22.95). This pocket-size book, dense with allusions to literary travelers like Dante, Casanova and Sterne, drove the Hollywood-bound ''Horse Whisperer'' from atop the Australian best-seller list. That's a testament to the popularity of its author, a book commentator on television and radio, and to the wry, chatty, surprisingly cheerful voice in which he discourses on heaven and hell, seduction and sex. (The inevitable nod to ''Death in Venice'' is Professor Eschenbaum, a fellow hotel guest drawn to S & M.) Dessaix even provides sniping footnotes to puncture every epiphany that swells too grandly. But his central insight, if hardly original, is hard won and moving: that life may be lived best as a voyage, not to get somewhere or to accumulate experiences but to savor each moment. Patrick Farrell
abstract: Patrick Farrell reviews book Night Letters by Robert Dessaix; drawing (S)

lead_paragraph: A MOTHER'S PLACE:
abstract: A MOTHER'S PLACE:  Choosing Work and Family Without Guilt or Blame  By Susan Chira. Harper Perennial, $13.  Chira, the deputy foreign editor of The New York Times, argues that parenting and working are compatible and helpful to mothers and children, and that day care is not harmful. In 1998 our reviewer, Carol Tavris, said this ''splendid book . . . makes an eloquent, well-documented case that motherhood does not require martyrdom.''    RIVEN ROCK  By T. Coraghessan Boyle. Penguin, $13.95.  Stanley McCormick is a rich schizoid who spends 20 years holed up in his California mansion out of sight of women because he both loves and hates them too much. That includes his wife, a scientist, suffragist and lifelong virgin who remains loyal to her husband through all his years of madness. Surprisingly, both characters in this ambitious novel are based on actual early-20th-century figures. In 1998 in these pages, D. M. Thomas said that even though the prose strayed toward the purple, ''the book is filled with good writing and richly observed scenes; it has humanity and humor in abundance.''

snippet: ELEPHANT WALK: Dean Koontz has the No. 1 book on the hardcover fiction list again this week with ''The Husband.'' Farther down on the extended list (available online), at No. 23, you'll find Sara Gruen's third novel, a Depression-era circus tale c...
lead_paragraph: ELEPHANT WALK: Dean Koontz has the No. 1 book on the hardcover fiction list again this week with "The Husband." Farther down on the extended list (available online), at No. 23, you'll find Sara Gruen's third novel, a Depression-era circus tale called "Water for Elephants" (Algonquin). Gruen's book is not selling particularly well at chain stores, but it's an indie darling -- if this list reflected independent stores alone, "Water for Elephants" would be at No. 3. Independent booksellers have been cheering Gruen's novel for months, comparing it to surprise best sellers like "The Kite Runner" and "The Lovely Bones," and it was the No. 1 Book Sense Pick last month. (Book Sense is a list of recommended titles from independent booksellers.) Reviews, however, have been mixed. In The Cleveland Plain Dealer, Karen R. Long wrote that Gruen batters readers "with barely serviceable, primary-color prose, full of sobbing, shrieking, fighting, boozing and whoring that comes off at the clip of an exaggerated Saturday-morning cartoon." In the Book Review a few weeks ago, Elizabeth Judd voiced similar concerns, but she also praised Gruen's storytelling skills: "With a showman's expert timing, she saves a terrific revelation for the final pages, transforming a glimpse of Americana into an enchanting escapist fairy tale."

keywords: [{'name': 'persons', 'value': 'DALBY, LIZA CRIHFIELD', 'rank': 1, 'major': 'N'}, {'name': 'subject', 'value': 'BOOK REVIEWS', 'rank': 2, 'major': 'N'}, {'name': 'creative_works', 'value': 'KIMONO: FASHIONING CULTURE (BOOK)', 'rank': 3, 'major': 'N'}]
snippet: Unknown
lead_paragraph: At first glance, the closet of the Senior Grand Empress Tashi, one of the taste makers of 12th-century Japan, would hardly look like a mine field. But imagine yourself faced with its 500 robes, meant to be layered in a subtle array of fabrics, colors and designs, each appropriate to a particular season, occasion or mood -- and each, if improperly chosen, the social equivalent of wearing a sealskin coat to a Greenpeace rally. Small wonder, then, as Liza Crihfield Dalby points out in KIMONO: Fashioning Culture (Yale University, $30), that modern Japanese women, who may wear their national costume only a few times a year, can be turned into fashion victims by traditional dress that is "woven of meanings as much as it is of fiber." Ms. Dalby, an anthropologist whose 1983 book, "Geisha," described her year as an apprentice in a Kyoto geisha house, acquired her initial learning the hard way -- by attempting to master the skills of "professional kimono wearers." That sort of devotion may well be required to stick with some of the essays in her new book, which covers "such diverse topics as political hierarchy, the esthetics of color, the sociology of gender and the logic of formal systems" as it traces the history of an "elegantly anachronistic" garment that continues to maintain a firm grip on "the Japanese heart, mind and purse." Less diligent readers will be content with a parade of intriguing drawings, woodcuts and photographs, and a number of chapters -- particularly those on the shift from native costume to Western clothing ("The Kimono Discovers Itself") and the kimono in modern Japan ("Women Who Cross Their Legs") -- that demonstrate, in illuminating detail, Ms. Dalby's belief that while innocents may wear their hearts on their sleeves, we all reveal something of our personality there. ALIDA BECKER
