keywords: [{'name': 'subject', 'value': 'Reviews', 'rank': 1, 'major': 'N'}, {'name': 'subject', 'value': 'Books and Literature', 'rank': 2, 'major': 'N'}, {'name': 'creative_works', 'value': 'DANCE FOR A CITY: FIFTY YEARS OF THE NEW YORK CITY BALLET (BOOK)', 'rank': 3, 'major': 'N'}]
snippet: Terry Teachout reviews book Dance For a City: Fifty Years of the New York City Ballet; photo (M)
lead_paragraph: The New-York Historical Society's exhibition devoted to the New York City Ballet was a bedazzling parade of photographs, souvenirs, ephemera and breathtakingly rare film clips documenting the long and spectacular history of the most important dance company since Serge Diaghilev's Ballets Russes. DANCE FOR A CITY: Fifty Years of the New York City Ballet (Columbia University, $50), alas, is not a comprehensive catalogue but a companion volume containing six essays, transcripts of a group of vivid interviews with George Balanchine conducted by Nancy Reynolds in 1974 and 1975, a complete list of the stage works of Jerome Robbins and, last but not least, some of the black-and-white photos on display in the exhibition (as well as several others not seen there). The illustrations range from a 1952 magazine cover depicting Maria Tallchief's legs to three witty drawings from Edward Gorey's ''Lavender Leotard; Or, Going a Lot to the New York City Ballet.'' Some of the best images in the show are inexplicably omitted -- I especially missed Robbins's harrowing portrait of Tanaquil LeClercq, Balanchine's last wife and the company's greatest and most photogenic ballerina, made not long after polio forced her to retire from the stage in 1956 -- and certain of the essays that take their place, including Jonathan Weinberg's apologia for George Platt Lynes's soft-core porn dance photographs, seem beside the point. But others are first-rate, particularly Charles M. Joseph's ''Making of 'Agon,' '' while the pictures are so good that you may want to buy two copies of ''Dance for a City,'' one for reading and the other for clipping and framing. Terry Teachout
abstract: Terry Teachout reviews book Dance For a City: Fifty Years of the New York City Ballet; photo (M)

keywords: [{'name': 'subject', 'value': 'Books and Literature', 'rank': 1, 'major': 'N'}, {'name': 'persons', 'value': 'Wilcox, James', 'rank': 2, 'major': 'N'}]
snippet: In this novel, a dashing visitor shakes things up in a small Southern town.
lead_paragraph: Change has come to Tula Springs, La. Readers familiar with St. Jude Parish from James Wilcox’s first novel, “Modern Baptists” (1983), may have trouble recognizing the place today. There’s a Starbucks in the Piggly Wiggly. The Sonny Boy Bargain Store, rechristened Redds, is now part of the BurgerMat empire. Romance unfolds in chat rooms, and Viagra-touting spam finds at least one willing customer. The globalized marketplace has pressed its thumb on Tula Springs, uncorking a plethora of brands including Vera Wang, Armani, Dolce & Gabbana and Christian Louboutin. We’ve come a long way from the Ajax Feed and Seed and bourbon and Tabs at Juniors.
abstract: In this novel, a dashing visitor shakes things up in a small Southern town.

headline: {'main': 'Books in Brief: Nonfiction; Wilde Thing', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Books in Brief: Nonfiction; Wilde Thing', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

keywords: [{'name': 'persons', 'value': 'Wilde, Oscar', 'rank': 1, 'major': 'N'}, {'name': 'persons', 'value': 'Holland, Merlin', 'rank': 2, 'major': 'N'}, {'name': 'subject', 'value': 'Reviews', 'rank': 3, 'major': 'N'}, {'name': 'subject', 'value': 'Books and Literature', 'rank': 4, 'major': 'N'}, {'name': 'creative_works', 'value': 'WILDE ALBUM, THE (BOOK)', 'rank': 5, 'major': 'N'}]
snippet: Evelyn Toynton reviews book The Wilde Album by Merlin Holland; photos (S)
lead_paragraph: ''Somehow or other I'll be famous,'' Oscar Wilde told a friend when he was an undergraduate at Oxford, ''and if not famous, notorious.'' He became both -- first as the deliberately outrageous exponent of estheticism, caricatured in Punch and lampooned by Gilbert and Sullivan; later as the brilliantly witty playwright whose work mocked and subverted all the easy pieties of Victorian England. He became a social lion, the dazzling talker every London hostess clamored to have at her table. Then came scandal and ruin: in love with Lord Alfred Douglas, petulant, beautiful son of the Marquess of Queensberry, Wilde allowed himself to be talked into a lawsuit against the brutish Marquess that eventually landed him and not Queensberry in prison. In the 98 years since Wilde's death, his story has been recounted by everyone from the man who ruined him to the distinguished scholar Richard Ellmann. Now Merlin Holland, Wilde's grandson, has published THE WILDE ALBUM (Holt, $19.95), which brings together hundreds of images of Wilde and his circle, accompanied by a biographical text. Some of the photographs have never been published before; others are classics of Wildeiana, like the studio shots of a dreamy, languorous young Wilde, in a fur-lined coat, velvet jacket and knee breeches, taken during his triumphant lecture tour in the United States (where he famously told a customs officer that he had nothing to declare but his genius, and won over the miners of Leadville, Colo., by drinking with them). Holland has no dramatic revelations or bold new theories to offer, but his narrative serves to remind us all over again of what an extraordinary man his grandfather was -- and how much he influenced the art of the 20th century. Evelyn Toynton
abstract: Evelyn Toynton reviews book The Wilde Album by Merlin Holland; photos (S)

keywords: [{'name': 'subject', 'value': 'Poetry and Poets', 'rank': 1, 'major': 'N'}, {'name': 'subject', 'value': 'Weddings and Engagements', 'rank': 2, 'major': 'N'}, {'name': 'subject', 'value': 'Books and Literature', 'rank': 3, 'major': 'N'}]
snippet: David Orr essay on epithalamiums, commonly known as wedding poems; says that poetry has been connected to weddings in Western world for more than two and half millennium; notes that couples often have trouble finding such poems for ceremonies, esp...
lead_paragraph: Weddings, as everyone knows, are extraordinary -- which is to say, they're occasions to do things you wouldn't usually do, like wear a boutonniere, eat a five-pound lump of cake or pledge your eternal soul to a person from Delaware. But they're also one of the few events at which you're likely to hear (or possibly even read) a poem. According to a recent study by the Poetry Foundation, "Poetry is most often experienced at private ceremonies such as weddings . . . with 80 percent of nonusers and more than 90 percent of poetry users reporting that they've been exposed to poetry at one of these private occasions." Granted, this makes poetry sound like a combination of heroin and the Marburg virus (most nonusers were exposed at private ceremonies, were they?). But the foundation's report does make a point worth remembering: although poetry is often belittled as obscure and unpopular, it's an art form we turn to when we need to bear not only the weight of our own promises of eternal fidelity, but the scrutiny of all our relatives.
abstract: David Orr essay on epithalamiums, commonly known as wedding poems; says that poetry has been connected to weddings in Western world for more than two and half millennium; notes that couples often have trouble finding such poems for ceremonies, especially in modern poetry; asserts reason for this might be that modern poetry normally focuses on personal and internal and does not stress happiness in its subject matter; photo (M)

keywords: [{'name': 'persons', 'value': 'Lenya, Lotte', 'rank': 1, 'major': 'N'}, {'name': 'persons', 'value': 'Farneth, David', 'rank': 2, 'major': 'N'}, {'name': 'subject', 'value': 'Reviews', 'rank': 3, 'major': 'N'}, {'name': 'subject', 'value': 'Books and Literature', 'rank': 4, 'major': 'N'}, {'name': 'creative_works', 'value': 'LENYA, THE LEGEND: A PICTORIAL AUTOBIOGRAPHY (BOOK)', 'rank': 5, 'major': 'N'}]
snippet: David Kaufman reviews book Lenya, the Legend: A Pictorial Autobiography of Lotte Lenya, assembled by David Farneth; photo (S)
lead_paragraph: Though she had a voice as distinctive as Piaf's, Mabel Mercer's or Billie Holiday's, Lotte Lenya's husky vibrato -- like her face -- was not always pretty. However, it was consistently warm, honest and expressive, and her singing immortalized the music of her first husband, Kurt Weill. LENYA, THE LEGEND: A Pictorial Autobiography (Overlook, $45), a combination scrapbook and memoir, has been assembled by David Farneth to celebrate Lenya's 100th birthday. It is lavishly illustrated with photographs from her shows, program and album covers, caricatures and publicity shots; the text has been culled from letters, journals, interviews and Lenya's unfinished autobiography. As she discusses her life and times, Lenya proves to be a canny and humorous observer. Following Weill's death in 1950, she declared that the ''task of my life'' was to make his music better known in the United States, a task that she soon began to fulfill in a legendary long-running production of ''The Threepenny Opera.'' As evidenced here, Lenya became a ferocious guardian of Weill's legacy until her own death in 1981. In her own words, Lenya comes across as an extremely shrewd if loving person. Whether singing or writing, she had a strong and appealing voice, and it is easy to see why Tennessee Williams began each morning listening to her. David Kaufman

snippet: This first novel, a modern twist on “Hamlet,” revolves around a mute boy in a family of dog trainers.
lead_paragraph: Near the beginning of the fifth act of “Hamlet,” just a few lines after he fondles Yorick’s skull, the Prince of Denmark grows distraught at the sight of Ophelia’s burial and avows he’ll do anything to avenge the death of his love  including eat a crocodile. When his boasts are taken for psychosis, Hamlet threatens, “Let Hercules himself do what he may, / The cat will mew, and dog will have his day.” Here, David Wroblewski, in his ambitious first novel, uses the framework of Shakespeare’s tragedy to grant that patient dog its day.

snippet: Unknown
lead_paragraph: WHAT I LIVED FOR By Joyce Carol Oates. William Abrahams/Plume, $14.95. Jerome (Corky) Corcoran, an Irish-American businessman of modest means, has never felt at home in the world since the murder of his father when he was 11. In this novel he seeks the meaning behind another death, the suicide of a young black woman. The result is "an engrossing, moving study of desperate, lonely and lost souls," James Carroll said here last year.
abstract: WHAT I LIVED FOR By Joyce Carol Oates. William Abrahams/Plume, $14.95. keywords: [{'name': 'persons', 'value': 'Franklin, Tom', 'rank': 1, 'major': 'N'}, {'name': 'subject', 'value': 'Blacks', 'rank': 2, 'major': 'N'}, {'name': 'subject', 'value': 'Black People', 'rank': 3, 'major': 'N'}, {'name': 'subject', 'value': 'Books and Literature', 'rank': 4, 'major': 'N'}, {'name': 'creative_works', 'value': 'HELL AT THE BREECH (BOOK)', 'rank': 5, 'major': 'N'}]
snippet: Laura Miller article praises Hell at the Breech, Tom Franklin novel set in Alabama in 1890's, but says it seem inauthentic in matter of race; notes that 'N' word is spoken only by most reprehensible characters in novel, not its sheriff hero, who m...
lead_paragraph: I was happily reading ''Hell at the Breech,'' Tom Franklin's suspenseful new novel, based on actual events, about a bush war in Alabama in the 1890's, when something about it began to feel a bit off. There are people who find historical fiction unbearably affected, but not me -- not, at least, as long as the author avoids sinning outrageously against verisimilitude. ''Hell at the Breech,'' which is told from the points of view of a handful of characters in language meant to sound more or less like their own, sounds a few wrong notes, but none glaring enough to ruin this otherwise tough, smart, niftily plotted tale. It wasn't the presence of an objectionable word or expression that kept tripping me up. It was the absence of a word, or, to be more precise, the highly selective presence of a particular, very objectionable word, a word many Americans consider to be the worst in the English language.
abstract: Laura Miller article praises Hell at the Breech, Tom Franklin novel set in Alabama in 1890's, but says it seem inauthentic in matter of race; notes that 'N' word is spoken only by most reprehensible characters in novel, not its sheriff hero, who might be expected to share some of racial prejudices of his time; drawing (M)

snippet: Marilyn Stasio reviews books Stalker by Faye Kellerman, A Smile on the Face of the Tiger by Loren D Estelman, The Fifth Woman by Henning Mankell, Jane and the Stillroom Maid by Stephanie Barron and Crazybone by Bill Pronzini; drawing (M)
lead_paragraph: Peter Decker, the Los Angeles police lieutenant and family man who has always been the soul of calm, compassionate humanity in Faye Kellerman's crime novels, blows his stack in STALKER (Morrow, $25) when his daughter, a rookie on the force, privately takes on one of his investigations and nearly gets herself killed. A colleague's assessment of Cindy Decker -- She's young, she's female, she's smart, and she has a big mouth'' -- doesn't begin to describe the career problems of this imprudent rebel, who alienates half the cops in her department and foolishly keeps it a secret when some unknown enemy starts stalking her.
abstract: Marilyn Stasio reviews books Stalker by Faye Kellerman, A Smile on the Face of the Tiger by Loren D Estelman, The Fifth Woman by Henning Mankell, Jane and the Stillroom Maid by Stephanie Barron and Crazybone by Bill Pronzini; drawing (M)

lead_paragraph: Old women, giant waves, washtub boats and surfing dogs make up the wacky, whimsical universes of two delightfully different books. In Quentin Blake's MRS. ARMITAGE AND THE BIG WAVE (Harcourt Brace, $15; ages 4 to 8) the clamdigger-and-halter-top-clad beachgoer and her trusty canine sidekick, Breakspear, hop a banana yellow surfboard over a blue-green sea to wait out the big wave.

snippet: Is pride a sin at all? The Oxford English Dictionary strikes a primly English note: "A high or overweening opinion of one's own qualities, attainments or estate," or too clever by half, the ultimate put-down in those bright arid islands where igno...
lead_paragraph: Is pride a sin at all? The Oxford English Dictionary strikes a primly English note: "A high or overweening opinion of one's own qualities, attainments or estate," or too clever by half, the ultimate put-down in those bright arid islands where ignorance must be lightly worn.
abstract:
Is pride a sin at all? The Oxford English Dictionary strikes a primly English note: "A high or overweening opinion of one's own qualities, attainments or estate," or too clever by half, the ultimate put-down in those bright arid islands where ignorance must be lightly worn.

Apparently, the Romans and the Greeks had other, by no means pejorative, words for it. The quintessential Greek, Odysseus, reveled in being too clever by any number of halves. Of course, neither Greeks nor Romans had a word for sin, a Judeo-Christian concept that the Germans did have a word for, Sunde, which Old English took aboard. Obviously, in any time and place an overweening person is tiresome, but surely laughter is the best tonic for restoring him to our common weeniness. He hardly needs to be prayed for or punished as a sinner. Yet pride is listed as the first of the seven deadly sins, and only recently -- by accident, not design -- did I figure out why.

snippet: Marilyn Stasio reviews following books: The First Eagle by Tony Hillerman; The Ape Who Guards the Balance by Elizabeth Peters; The Dog Who Bit a Policeman by Stuart M Kaminsky; Blind Bloodhound Justice by Virginia Lanier; and Death Row by Jon Katz...
lead_paragraph: Tony Hillerman is a wonderful storyteller, which means that you believe every word he says. In THE FIRST EAGLE (HarperCollins, $25), which like his previous police procedurals is set on the Big Reservation, straddling the Arizona-New Mexico border, a Navajo woman by the name of Old Lady Notah claims to have sighted a ''skinwalker'' -- a witch. In such a place, on such authority, it's easy to believe in skinwalkers. But as Joe Leaphorn, now retired as a tribal policeman, says, ''Witches offer an easy explanation for unexplained illnesses.'' So it's just as logical to suspect, as do some biologists working for the Indian Health Service, that a new and extraordinarily virulent strain of bubonic plague is abroad.
abstract: Marilyn Stasio reviews following books: The First Eagle by Tony Hillerman; The Ape Who Guards the Balance by Elizabeth Peters; The Dog Who Bit a Policeman by Stuart M Kaminsky; Blind Bloodhound Justice by Virginia Lanier; and Death Row by Jon Katz (M)

keywords: [{'name': 'persons', 'value': 'Harrison, Martin', 'rank': 1, 'major': 'N'}, {'name': 'persons', 'value': 'Fonssagrives, Lisa', 'rank': 2, 'major': 'N'}, {'name': 'persons', 'value': 'Seidner, David', 'rank': 3, 'major': 'N'}, {'name': 'subject', 'value': 'Reviews', 'rank': 4, 'major': 'N'}, {'name': 'subject', 'value': 'Books and Literature', 'rank': 5, 'major': 'N'}, {'name': 'creative_works', 'value': 'LISA FONSSAGRIVES (BOOK)', 'rank': 6, 'major': 'N'}]
snippet: Rosemary Ranck reviews book Lisa Fonssagrives: Three Decades of Classic Fashion Photography by Martin Harrison and David Seidner; drawing (S)
lead_paragraph: Lisa Fonssagrives, a self-described ''good clothes hanger,'' was a leading figure during the 1940's and 50's in the business of being beautiful. A consummate professional, the willowy Swedish model projected a combination of lofty sophistication, impossible slimness and radiant physical well-being. She worked with the foremost fashion photographers of her time, and together they produced classics. In the early 1930's, Fonssagrives's first husband, a dancer turned photographer, sold photos of her gamboling on the French coast to European magazines. She entered fashion's big time in 1936 when Horst P. Horst was commissioned to do test shots of her for Paris Vogue. In LISA FONSSAGRIVES: Three Decades of Classic Fashion Photography (Vendome, $75), with an essay by the art historian Martin Harrison, the photographer David Seidner has assembled more than 100 images of her by 21 photographers. The pleasure of the collection, aside from its appeal to the fashion-afflicted, is the quality and variety of photographic vision. Some photographers, best represented by Horst, use Fonssagrives as a key element in formal compositions. Others, notably Louise Dahl-Wolfe and Frances McLaughlin-Gill, portray her as an active woman in less studied environments. Erwin Blumenfeld exploits her dancer's strength and agility by photographing her leaning out from the Eiffel Tower, her skirts billowing in the wind. The few disappointments -- images of vaporous fantasies of the model swathed in chiffon -- only enliven the whole by contrast. Her collaboration with Irving Penn, whom she married in 1950, transcends mere mastery of technique, graphic design and merchandising. In the soft northern light in which he photographed her wearing the Paris collections, both the woman and the clothes crackle with wit and sex appeal. Fonssagrives, who died in 1992 at the age of 80, was a direct descendant of the Gibson girl, but her own progeny are difficult to discern among the disordered and disturbed images in vogue today. Rosemary Ranck
abstract: Rosemary Ranck reviews book Lisa Fonssagrives: Three Decades of Classic Fashion Photography by Martin Harrison and David Seidner; drawing (S)

snippet: Darin Strauss’s third novel is about suspicion, prejudice and child abuse on Long Island.
lead_paragraph: In his first two novels, Darin Strauss made the strange familiar. Taking the perspective of a 19th-century Siamese twin in “Chang and Eng,” he brilliantly humanized a figure known to history as a traveling curiosity. And “The Real McCoy” turned the story of the famous boxer Kid McCoy into the tall yet intimate tale of a flimflammer who slugged and conned his way to notoriety at the turn of the 20th century. Although Strauss’s new novel, “More Than It Hurts You,” is set in present-day Long Island, where he grew up, this is no retreat into a safer territory and time. What he’s after is, in fact, very ambitious: to show what strangers we can be, even to those we think we know best.
abstract: Darin Strauss’s third novel is about suspicion, prejudice and child abuse on Long Island.

headline: {'main': 'Books in Brief: Fiction; Otherworldly Stories', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Books in Brief: Fiction; Otherworldly Stories', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}
byline: {'original': 'By Jenny McPhee', 'person': [{'firstname': 'Jenny', 'middlename': None, 'lastname': 'McPhee', 'qualifier': None, 'title': None, 'role': 'reported', 'organization': '', 'rank': 1}], 'organization': None}
keywords: [{'name': 'persons', 'value': 'McPhee, Jenny', 'rank': 1, 'major': 'N'}, {'name': 'persons', 'value': 'Fowler, Karen Joy', 'rank': 2, 'major': 'N'}, {'name': 'subject', 'value': 'Books and Literature', 'rank': 3, 'major': 'N'}, {'name': 'subject', 'value': 'Reviews', 'rank': 4, 'major': 'N'}, {'name': 'creative_works', 'value': 'Black Glass (Book)', 'rank': 5, 'major': 'N'}]
snippet: Jenny McPhee reviews Black Glass, new collection of stories by Karen Joy Fowler; drawing (S)
lead_paragraph: In ''The Brew,'' a powerful story from Karen Joy Fowler's new collection, BLACK GLASS (Marian Wood/Holt, $23), a woman stands in a hotel lobby staring at an aquarium. ''Sometimes,'' she tells herself, ''we can find a smaller world where we can live, inside the bigger world where we cannot.'' Other worlds, worlds within worlds, shifting realities -- all these inform Fowler's highly imaginative short fiction. In the title story, a zombie terrorizes the United States in the form of Carry Nation, and this gigantic hatchet-wielding Amazon becomes the obsession of Patrick Harris, an undercover Federal drug agent. A Christ story involving a 15-year-old boy unfolds in 17th-century Japan in ''Shimabara.'' ''The Elizabeth Complex'' assembles a composite life story from those of formidable figures like Lizzie Borden, Elizabeth Taylor and Elizabeth I. In ''Duplicity,'' two American women are taken captive by noseless aliens in the Brazilian rain forest. And in ''The View From Venus: A Case Study,'' Venusians analyze the romantic practices of college-age students in Berkeley in the late 1960's. More earthly but equally inventive narratives include ''Contention,'' which describes a housewife's loneliness; ''Go Back,'' in which a young girl discovers her father's infidelity; and ''Letters From Home,'' an affecting meditation on what became of the narrator's boyfriend in Vietnam. There is much that is fantastical about Fowler's fiction, but also much that is rooted in a solid emotional reality; in fine-edged and discerning prose, she manages to re-create both life's extraordinary and its ordinary magic. Jenny McPhee
abstract: Jenny McPhee reviews Black Glass, new collection of stories by Karen Joy Fowler; drawing (S)

snippet: Unknown
lead_paragraph: JAY'S JOURNAL OF ANOMALIES: Conjurers, Cheats, Hustlers, Hoaxsters, Pranksters, Jokesters, Impostors, Pretenders, Sideshow Showmen, Armless Calligraphers, Mechanical Marvels, Popular Entertainments, by Ricky Jay. (Quantuck Lane, $25.) As the title suggests, there's plenty of weird lore stuffed into this collection of all 16 issues of Jay's erudite and lovingly researched quarterly of the same name about magicians and unusual performers. Among the showmen are an armless and legless bowler and a performance artist who specialized in self-crucifixion. The versatile author ''has pulled off yet another impressive trick,'' Francis Heaney wrote here in 2001. ''He has simultaneously written a work of popular entertainment and a work of serious history.''
abstract: JAY'S JOURNAL OF ANOMALIES: Conjurers, Cheats, Hustlers, Hoaxsters, Pranksters, Jokesters, Impostors, Pretenders, Sideshow Showmen, Armless Calligraphers, Mechanical Marvels, Popular Entertainments, by Ricky Jay. (Quantuck Lane, $25.) As the title suggests, there's plenty of weird lore stuffed into this collection of all 16 issues of Jay's erudite and lovingly researched quarterly of the same name about magicians and unusual performers. Among the showmen are an armless and legless bowler and a performance artist who specialized in self-crucifixion. The versatile author ''has pulled off yet another impressive trick,'' Francis Heaney wrote here in 2001. ''He has simultaneously written a work of popular entertainment and a work of serious history.''    FAMILY MATTERS, by Rohinton Mistry. (Vintage International, $14.95.) In a decaying mid-1990's Bombay beset by gangsterism, destitution and corruption, a Parsi patriarch lies slowly dying, yet no one in his extended family seems willing or able to take care of him. This ''fine and disturbing novel,'' John Sutherland said here last year, asks the question of whether family really matters in the modern age, especially in an increasingly strife-torn India.    THE GAY TALESE READER: Portraits & Encounters. (Walker, $14.95.) This collection of journalistic essays and profiles includes the author's first article for Esquire, ''New York Is a City of Things Unnoticed'' (1960), as well as portraits of figures as varied as Frank Sinatra, Joe DiMaggio and George Plimpton. ''The stories here are shining examples of a time in publishing history when magazine writing was an art form and Talese its Michelangelo,'' one critic wrote recently.    THE DOUBLE BOND. Primo Levi: A Biography, by Carole Angier. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $20.) Large in scale and intricately layered, this life of the author, chemist and Auschwitz survivor Primo Levi (1919-87) manages to overcome a lack of access to family members and personal papers, relying instead on Angier's scrupulous research as well as her critical powers, deductions and intuitions. The result is a ''meticulous and visionary biography'' that captures ''the entwined complexities and contradictions of man and writer,'' Richard Eder said here last year.    LOOKOUT CARTRIDGE, by Joseph McElroy. (Overlook, $16.95.) The hero of this 1974 novel tries to find out who exposed the negative of a film he was making with a friend, and why, a search that leads him into a murder mystery with an expanding number of sinister puzzles. ''For its technical brilliance, its unremitting intelligence'' and its ''rich complexity,'' George Stade wrote in these pages, '' 'Lookout Cartridge' is the rarest kind of achievement.''    BIG GAME, SMALL WORLD: A Basketball Adventure, by Alexander Wolff. (Warner, $15.95.) It may seem like an all-American sport, but the author, a senior writer for Sports Illustrated, reveals how basketball has stirred passions in locales from Bhutan to Lithuania. In canvassing the globe for offbeat stories, Wolff displays ''terrific'' reporting skills and provides ''some memorable cultural insights,'' John Paul Newport wrote here in 2002.    CHILD OF MY HEART, by Alice McDermott. (Picador, $13.) The 15-year-old narrator of McDermott's fifth novel, set in East Hampton in the early 1960's, describes summer days spent baby-sitting for four dogs, three cats and a bunch of children. Yet her growing awareness of the risks and pleasures of the adult world seems to augur some historical change in women's lives. There is ''something Jamesian about McDermott's style: this novel's craftsmanship and its moral intelligence are as one,'' Michael Gorra said here last year.    NATASHA'S DANCE: A Cultural History of Russia, by Orlando Figes. (Picador, $20.) The sequel to the author's history of the Russian Revolution focuses on the debates that have absorbed the nation's intelligentsia since Peter the Great opened Russia to the West. Last year our reviewer, Serge Schmemann, said, ''Figes succeeds in describing the extraordinary scope and power of Russian culture.''    BREAKOUT, by Richard Stark. (Warner, $12.95.) Stark's ice-cold hero, the career criminal known as Parker, no sooner breaks out of jail than he breaks into another fortress and is trapped within, forcing yet another breakout and leading to even more mayhem. Stark ''applies his great wit and dexterous mental skills to a series of . . . ingenious exits and entrances,'' Marilyn Stasio said here last year.   Scott Veale

lead_paragraph: ONE UP, ONE DOWN. By Carol Snyder. Illustrated by Maxie Chambliss. Atheneum. $15. (Ages 4 to 8) For that first year or so after her twin brothers arrived, Katie never felt bigger at all, just tired. Either Ben was up or wet or hungry, or Adam was, and Katie helped her folks all the time. The lesson in this gentle, funny story is that her parents noticed, and they appreciate just what a fine daughter and sister Katie is.
abstract: ONE UP, ONE DOWN. By Carol Snyder. Illustrated by Maxie Chambliss. Atheneum. $15. (Ages 4 to 8) For that first year or so after her twin brothers arrived, Katie never felt bigger at all, just tired. Either Ben was up or wet or hungry, or Adam was, and Katie helped her folks all the time. The lesson in this gentle, funny story is that her parents noticed, and they appreciate just what a fine daughter and sister Katie is.     HEROES. BY Ken Mochizuki. Illustrated by Dom Lee. Lee & Low. $14.95. (Ages 5 to 9) In the 1960's Donnie Okada took a lot of razzing from the other boys in the neighborhood; they insisted that he had to be the enemy in their war games because he looked like the enemy, and they did not believe his father and uncle had served in the American military. Dad and Uncle Yosh give those boys a dignified and effective lesson.

snippet: Rae Armantrout’s stanzas are compact and as densely patterned as silicon chips.
lead_paragraph: What if you woke up one morning and lost faith in the power of words to describe your world? What if your own most heartfelt admissions sounded, to you, like cheap self-deceptions, illusions, slogans anyone could use? What if you were a poet of supreme concision — having learned much from Emily Dickinson — and you wanted to make vivid, bitter poems from that anxious and baffling predicament?

lead_paragraph: Why does the common reader pick up a scholarly book? We all have our scholar-fan passions: military history; this or that ancient civilization; Monk, Messaien or Monteverdi. Still, life is short and these books are often long. Why take a chance outside of your chosen limits?

headline: {'main': 'Books in Brief: Nonfiction; An Immensity of Greatness', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Books in Brief: Nonfiction; An Immensity of Greatness', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}
byline: {'original': 'By Charles Salzberg', 'person': [{'firstname': 'Charles', 'middlename': None, 'lastname': 'Salzberg', 'qualifier': None, 'title': None, 'role': 'reported', 'organization': '', 'rank': 1}], 'organization': None}
keywords: [{'name': 'subject', 'value': 'Reviews', 'rank': 1, 'major': 'N'}, {'name': 'subject', 'value': 'Books and Literature', 'rank': 2, 'major': 'N'}, {'name': 'creative_works', 'value': 'AMERICAN GREATS (BOOK)', 'rank': 3, 'major': 'N'}]
snippet: Charles Salzberg reviews book American Greats; photo (M)
lead_paragraph: America is great. It may even be the greatest. But just what is it that makes it so great? With the help of a bevy of writers, including David Halberstam, Christopher Buckley and John Updike, Robert A. Wilson, who has produced documentaries for public television, and Stanley Marcus, chairman emeritus of Neiman Marcus, have assembled dozens of short essays and a host of wonderful photographs, paintings and drawings -- more than 250 of them -- pinpointing exactly what it is that has and does make America great. The results are somewhat uneven. AMERICAN GREATS (Public Affairs, $50) is at its best when it uncovers somewhat obscure, unexpected treasures -- like Charles F. Kettering, who invented the self-starter, which changed the face of automobiles forever; the invention of ''the devil's hatband,'' otherwise known as barbed wire; Keeneland, in Lexington, Ky., where the best of the best racehorses are trained (the reader gets a useful betting tip: when unsure of what horse to put your money on, choose the one that's been trained in Keeneland); The Chicago Defender, a black newspaper, established by Robert Abbott, which aided and abetted the migration of blacks from the South to the North; and the Mohawk Indians who work the high beams on skyscrapers and bridges, staring acrophobia in the eye without blinking. Some choices are interesting simply because the subject matter is so absorbing: Thomas Edison, ''Huckleberry Finn,'' The New Yorker, the Iditarod, Coney Island and the Corvette. Others are so obvious that they elicit little more than a ho-hum, like ticker tape parades, black baseball and Thomas Paine. Of course, as the editors say, everyone will have a personal list of greats, which will simply open up welcome debates across this great nation. I wonder about the glaring omission of fast food from this list, in particular Ray Kroc and his brainchild, McDonald's. But restaurants are represented, in a charming essay by Ruth Reichl on the restaurant Chez Panisse. Charles Salzberg
abstract: Charles Salzberg reviews book American Greats; photo (M)

snippet: LITTLE BLACK BOOK OF STORIES, by A. S. Byatt. (Vintage International, $12.95.) These five haunting Gothic stories bear all the hallmarks of Byatt's style: they're carefully constructed, allusive meditations on art and its place in the world. The c...
lead_paragraph: LITTLE BLACK BOOK OF STORIES, by A. S. Byatt. (Vintage International, $12.95.) These five haunting Gothic stories bear all the hallmarks of Byatt's style: they're carefully constructed, allusive meditations on art and its place in the world. The collection's first entry, "The Thing in the Forest," reunites two women who shared a horrific vision as children during their wartime evacuation from London. Another story, drawing on Icelandic fables, describes a woman's literal transformation into stone. "Byatt's stories are provoking and alarming, richly yet tautly rendered," Claire Messud wrote in the Book Review.
abstract: LITTLE BLACK BOOK OF STORIES, by A. S. Byatt. (Vintage International, $12.95.) These five haunting Gothic stories bear all the hallmarks of Byatt's style: they're carefully constructed, allusive meditations on art and its place in the world. The collection's first entry, ''The Thing in the Forest,'' reunites two women who shared a horrific vision as children during their wartime evacuation from London. Another story, drawing on Icelandic fables, describes a woman's literal transformation into stone. ''Byatt's stories are provoking and alarming, richly yet tautly rendered,'' Claire Messud wrote in the Book Review.    AMERICAN MAFIA: A History of Its Rise to Power, by Thomas Reppetto. (John Macrae/Holt, $15.) This smart, reasoned study, by a former Chicago detective and the president of the Citizens Crime Commission of New York, traces the rise of Italian-American organized crime, from a few bad-guy immigrants in the late 19th century to the Kefauver Committee hearings in the early 1950's.

lead_paragraph: NEW AND COLLECTED POEMS: 1931-2001, by Czeslaw Milosz. (Ecco/HarperCollins, $19.95.) Throughout this collection of verse gathered from a 70-year career, Milosz argues with himself about the nature of his poetics. While he long celebrated the power of poetry to rescue mankind, his later work expresses misgivings about the ability of language to capture reality. Because he is now in his 90's, his ''focus gradually shifts from the world he has left and the world he anticipates leaving to the drama of the aging poet,'' Harvey Shapiro said here in 2001. Yet his poems remain ''capacious, hospitable and often rise to quietly ecstatic heights.''
abstract: NEW AND COLLECTED POEMS: 1931-2001, by Czeslaw Milosz. (Ecco/HarperCollins, $19.95.) Throughout this collection of verse gathered from a 70-year career, Milosz argues with himself about the nature of his poetics. While he long celebrated the power of poetry to rescue mankind, his later work expresses misgivings about the ability of language to capture reality. Because he is now in his 90's, his ''focus gradually shifts from the world he has left and the world he anticipates leaving to the drama of the aging poet,'' Harvey Shapiro said here in 2001. Yet his poems remain ''capacious, hospitable and often rise to quietly ecstatic heights.''    A THREAD ACROSS THE OCEAN: The Heroic Story of the Transatlantic Cable, by John Steele Gordon. (Perennial/HarperCollins, $12.95.) The laying of the first telegraph cables between Europe and North America in 1866 was a hugely ambitious undertaking marked by calamity, misfortune, failure and the amazing perseverance of men like Cyrus Field, who dreamed up the idea and overcame much -- including seasickness -- to fulfill his dream. The result is a ''delightful and unsettling book'' that ''reminds us, excruciatingly, agonizingly, unforgettably,'' how difficult a feat it was, Michael Parfit said here last year.    THE DREAM OF SCIPIO, by Iain Pears. (Riverhead, $14.) This novel braids together three stories, all set in Provence: the first concerns a cultivated aristocrat who wrestles with his faith in the twilight of the Roman Empire, the second a 14th-century poet who discovers a manuscript written by the aristocrat. The third tells of a scholar who during the Nazi occupation learns the secret of the poet's life and death. ''Pears builds a multilayered tale of moral choice, love, danger and loss,'' John Crowley said here last year.    THE EXTINCTION CLUB: A Tale of Deer, Lost Books, and a Rather Fine Canary Yellow Sweater, by Robert Twigger. (Perennial/HarperCollins, $12.95.) Skipping back and forth between esoteric, often personal asides (including the loss of his favorite sweater) and matters of gravity, the author recounts the strange story of the Milu, or Père David's deer, a rare species that became extinct in the wild in China during the Boxer Rebellion. Luckily, the deer survived in captivity under the protection of the eccentric 11th Duke of Bedford, who fed his pet owl at the breakfast table. Last year our reviewer, Robert Eisner, called this a ''deliriously clever chimera of a travel book.''    BENJAMIN FRANKLIN, by Edmund S. Morgan. (Yale University, $16.) An eminent historian portrays Franklin as a magnetic extrovert who channeled his sociability and extraordinary curiosity into a life of commitment to the Philadelphia community and the young nation. This ''engaging and readable'' book ''skillfully dissects the man's personality and mind, his social self and political beliefs, deftly exploring . . . how the two halves of his being lived together,'' Susan Dunn wrote in these pages in 2002.    GOING UP THE RIVER: Travels in a Prison Nation, by Joseph T. Hallinan. (Random House, $13.95.) The author, a reporter for The Wall Street Journal, spent four years visiting prisons and concludes that they have essentially become public works projects in which conditions are typically severe and which require a steady flow of inmates. ''By documenting the vested interest many Americans now have in building more prisons, he has made a valuable contribution to the debates over crime and punishment in America,'' Michael Massing wrote here in 2001.    A BRIEF HISTORY OF THE FLOOD: Stories, by Jean Harfenist. (Vintage Contemporaries, $12.) The young narrator of these interlinked stories, set mainly in a small Minnesota town, proves both spirited and practical as she provides snapshots of herself and her large, struggling family from 1959, when she is under the spell of her manic, self-dramatizing mother, to 1970, when she graduates from high school. Last year in The Times, Michiko Kakutani called this an ''auspicious and stirring'' debut.    THE PIRATE HUNTER: The True Story of Captain Kidd, by Richard Zacks. (Theia/Hyperion, $15.95.) According to this lively account, William Kidd, a k a Captain Kidd, was hardly the bloodthirsty buccaneer of legend but a mercenary who lived in New York and was hired by the British government and some wealthy merchants to hunt down pirates and reclaim their booty. The result is an ''entertaining, richly detailed and authoritatively narrated'' yarn, one critic said last year.   Scott Veale

keywords: [{'name': 'persons', 'value': 'Sanders, James', 'rank': 1, 'major': 'N'}, {'name': 'subject', 'value': 'Reviews', 'rank': 2, 'major': 'N'}, {'name': 'subject', 'value': 'Books and Literature', 'rank': 3, 'major': 'N'}, {'name': 'creative_works', 'value': 'CELLULOID SKYLINE: NEW YORK AND THE MOVIES (BOOK)', 'rank': 4, 'major': 'N'}]
snippet: Michael J Agovino reviews book Celluloid Skyline: New York and the Movies by James Sanders; photo (S)
lead_paragraph: In CELLULOID SKYLINE: New York and the Movies (Knopf, $45), James Sanders sets out to define a dualism particular to New York -- that between the real city and the mythic city, or movie city, and how the two ''reflected each other, changed each other, taught each other.'' Sanders, who wrote a documentary series about New York with Ric Burns, is an architect by trade and a sociologist by extension, and architecture is where his strength lies. Maybe a more apt subtitle of the book would have been ''New York: Its Buildings, Landscapes and Movies.'' From his opening chapters, he lavishly delineates the foregrounds and backgrounds (both on the screen and in the society) of hundreds of films set in New York. In fact, he seems intent on citing every movie that took place in New York -- he comes close, from 1903 (''At the Foot of the Flatiron'') to 1999 (''Ghost Dog: The Way of the Samurai'') -- and by doing so ends up discussing some unworthy films. But his exhaustive research is supported by a multifaceted understanding (and love) of the city. And when it appears the book could become another narrow look at New York-equals-Manhattan, he takes a wide-angle view of the other boroughs, lovingly evoking ''Marty,'' ''True Love,'' ''Queens Logic,'' ''Working Girl'' and ''I Like It Like That.'' The ample movie stills are refreshingly unpredictable and perfectly illustrate Sanders's fresh ways of thinking and seeing. Michael J. Agovino
abstract: Michael J Agovino reviews book Celluloid Skyline: New York and the Movies by James Sanders; photo (S)

snippet: An encounter with a former classmate shakes up Yasmina Reza’s protagonist.
lead_paragraph: Like many writers with grand ambitions, Yasmina Reza has often strained to be what she’s not. She is a born satirist, a gifted and wry observer of the absurdities and feints of social life (three old friends feud over an all-white painting in her hit play “Art”) and of the small self-deceptions that help us all survive. Yet in her slender dramas and fictions she has also set herself up as a mini-Proust, grasping at immense themes that elude her: the slipstream of time, the isolation of individuals and especially of artists.

keywords: [{'name': 'persons', 'value': 'Yakin, Erez', 'rank': 1, 'major': 'N'}, {'name': 'subject', 'value': 'Reviews', 'rank': 2, 'major': 'N'}, {'name': 'subject', 'value': 'Books and Literature', 'rank': 3, 'major': 'N'}, {'name': 'creative_works', 'value': 'SILENT CITY, THE (BOOK)', 'rank': 4, 'major': 'N'}]
snippet: Unknown
lead_paragraph: Between the world wars, wordless picture novels were produced by visionary artists like Lynd Ward and Frans Masereel, both of whom were masters of the art of turning iconic images into acerbic narratives about human folly. After a period of decline, wordless novels have recently enjoyed a small revival as an offshoot of so-called graphic novels, which are themselves offshoots of comic books. Since the wordless novel relies so strongly on visual shorthand, it is often a difficult genre in which to express complex ideas and emotions. THE SILENT CITY (Kitchen Sink Press, paper, $24.95), Erez Yakin's story of the plight of individuals in an industrial totalitarian state, is by no means graphically simplistic; in fact, as Yevgeny Yevtushenko writes in his introduction, "Erez Yakin screams with the silence of his drawings." It is indeed remarkable that such powerfully and exquisitely rendered pictures -- reminiscent of George Grosz and Otto Dix's post-World War I antiwar prints -- were made in 1988, when the artist was just 18 years old. But it is no surprise that each image is more effective individually than as an element of a complete story. Mr. Yakin finds it difficult to keep his theme of totalitarian oppression from being a shrill echo of George Orwell's "Nineteen Eighty-four," replete with the common visual clichs of fascist brutality. Nevertheless, "The Silent City" is remarkable for its horrific portrayals of unbridled, demonic power, as well as for the difficult, oppressive darkness of its pictures, which makes them at times barely reproducible. "The Silent City" may not have pushed the limits of the wordless novel beyond what was accomplished in the 1930's, but it proves that Erez Yakin is a virtuoso image maker, a gifted artist at the beginning of what might well be a brilliant career. Steven Heller

snippet: Unknown
lead_paragraph: TOURS OF THE BLACK CLOCK, by Steve Erickson. (Avon, $8.95.) After wiping out his family, a Pennsylvania boy named Banning Jainlight flees to Vienna, where he changes the course of history by writing pornographic fantasies for Hitler. In this novel, "everything is strange and, at the same time, recognizable," Kathy Acker said here last year. " 'Tours of the Black Clock' is, above all, a gorgeous argument against a culture of absolutes and for a way of life based on questioning."
abstract: TOURS OF THE BLACK CLOCK, by Steve Erickson. (Avon, $8.95.) After wiping out his family, a Pennsylvania boy named Banning Jainlight flees to Vienna, where he changes the course of history by writing pornographic fantasies for Hitler. In this novel, "everything is strange and, at the same time, recognizable," Kathy Acker said here last year. " 'Tours of the Black Clock' is, above all, a gorgeous argument against a culture of absolutes and for a way of life based on questioning."   HOW WAR CAME: The Immediate Origins of the Second World War, 1938-1939, by Donald Cameron Watt. (Pantheon, $17.95.) After spending two decades examining archives in Europe, the Soviet Union, the United States and Japan, a historian argues that Hitler's ruthlessness and the fecklessness of his opponents conspired to make World War II inevitable. " 'How War Came' is a demonstration that diplomatic history in the grand style -- with its assiduous compilation of documents from every government involved and meticulous concern for the personal qualities and flaws of diplomats and their superiors -- is alive, well, worth reading," Gaddis Smith said here last year. "It is well-written history of the most serious sort, proceeding from the conviction that what was happening in small countries, as well as in the large ones, is necessary for an understanding of Europe's stumble toward suicide."   THE FINAL OPUS OF LEON SOLOMON, by Jerome Badanes. (Fireside/Simon & Schuster, $8.95.) An Auschwitz survivor, who ruined his career as a historian by stealing ancient Hebrew texts from the New York Public Library, checks into a hotel in midtown Manhattan, determined to kill himself. This is "a masterly piece of fiction," Edith Milton said in The Book Review last year. "For all its darkness, this is a novel filled with illumination."   FARM: A Year in the Life of an American Farmer, by Richard Rhodes. (Touchstone/Simon & Schuster, $9.95.) In 1986, the man who wrote "A Hole in the World" and "The Making of the Atomic Bomb" spent most of the year on a Missouri farm, learning that it now takes a mastery of technology as well as a stoic tolerance for bureaucracy to live off the land. "Mr. Rhodes brings empathy and intelligence to his subject," Maxine Kumin said here last year, "and he projects for the reader that continuing identification with the day-to-day complexities, disappointments and gratifications encountered by his pseudonymous family, the Bauers." In BIRD, KANSAS (Avon, $8.95), Tony Parker, a British writer, studies the inhabitants of a small Midwestern town. This is "a first-rate example of oral history," Herbert Mitgang said in The Times last year. "Hearing the scores of voices skillfully assembled by Mr. Parker, a reader is inclined to conclude that they may talk funny, but there are no hayseeds in the so-called hick towns of America."   SALAZAR BLINKS, by David R. Slavitt. (Collier/Macmillan, $8.95.) In a novel based on the last days of the Portuguese dictator Antonio Salazar, his aides plot to convince the dying leader that he is still in control. Last year our reviewer, Deborah A. Hofmann, called this "an ironic burlesque," with "politicians, journalists and their lovers all manipulating the truth, all busily crafting their own notions about freedom and power."    THE WRITING LIFE, by Annie Dillard. (Harper Perennial, $8.95.) The author tells why there is nothing more satisfying than being alone in a room with a work in progress, making those thousands of tiny decisions that go into the shaping of a book. Last year our reviewer, Sara Maitland, said, "Annie Dillard is a wonderful writer and 'The Writing Life' is full of joys." The publisher has also reissued this book as part of THREE BY ANNIE DILLARD ($15.95). The anthology also includes her 1974 collection of essays, "Pilgrim at Tinker Creek," and "An American Childhood," which Noel Perrin in 1987 called "an autobiography in semimystical prose about the growth of her own mind."   GOD'S DUST: A Modern Asian Journey, by Ian Buruma. (Noonday/Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $8.95.) On a journey through Asia, Ian Buruma reflects on the nationalistic and religious forces that keep the continent divided. Last year our reviewer, James Fallows, praised the author for his "fair-mindedness, which in practice means his willingness to criticize all societies with equal gusto."   THE NEW YORK DETECTIVE, by William Marshall. (Mysterious Press, $4.95.) In a mystery story that reaches its climax at the grand opening of the Brooklyn Bridge, an investigator known to his peers as "the Thinking Detective" seeks the murderers of a group of Civil War veterans. "The author is powerfully drawn to the cruel and seamy side of life among the tangled masses," Marilyn Stasio said here in 1989. "Leaving the gentrified precincts of Manhattan to more genteel writers, he plunges into the squalid tenement-lined streets below 14th Street for his garish but quite poignant Hogarthian portraits of whores and cutpurses, ratcatchers and rats." In MENACING GROVES (Ballantine, $3.95) a British botanist named Celia Grant solves a double murder that occurs on a lavish garden tour in Italy. "The events, perforce, are a bit farfetched," Ms. Stasio said last year, "but the botanical lore is fascinating, and Celia deserves a bouquet for her original detecting methods. There is something irresistible about a sleuth who eliminates suspects because she admires their gardens."   THE BEST JAPANESE SCIENCE FICTION STORIES, edited by John L. Apostolou and Martin H. Greenberg. (Dembner, $9.95.) When these 13 imaginative stories were published last year, our reviewer, Gerald Jonas, called them "a welcome addition to the small shelf of quality science fiction translated from other languages."

snippet: This book, subtitled “The March to World War I & Revolution,” looks to place Russia “where it belongs, at the very center” of the war.
lead_paragraph: Dominic Lieven’s stated reason for this contribution to the centenary literature on World War I is to place Russia “where it belongs, at the very center” of the war’s history. Certainly the war proved to be at the center of Russian history, leading to revolution, dictatorship, repression and more war.

snippet: In this novel, three Britons struggle with the psychological wounds left by war and death.
lead_paragraph: We already know one legacy of our continued presence in Iraq — twice the number of amputees among American veterans than in either world war, thanks to advances in both improvised bombs and battlefield medicine. Perhaps the sight of missing limbs will underscore a universal truth: no one comes home from combat intact, and the psychological devastation of warfare is as crippling as the physical.

snippet: Unknown
lead_paragraph: The pompous new head of a British intelligence service sends a top deskman to make a tour of various installations and pep them up. This is against all rules. Top deskmen are not supposed to be in the field. They know too much, and if they are captured and tortured, operatives may die and services may be compromised. Sure enough, the deskman is kidnapped by Iranians and put through the mill. How long can he hold out?
abstract: LEAD: The pompous new head of a British intelligence service sends a top deskman to make a tour of various installations and pep them up. This is against all rules. Top deskmen are not supposed to be in the field. They know too much, and if they are captured and tortured, operatives may die and services may be compromised.

lead_paragraph: Open Heart By A. B. Yehoshua. Translated by Dalya Bilu. 498 pp. New York: Doubleday. $24.95. THE pre-eminence of A. B. Yehoshua in Israeli literature rests on a series of stories and novels that describe, with a very this-worldly psychological realism, the way Israelis live their daily lives within the immediate actualities of war and political turmoil. His most recent book, the extraordinary "Mr. Mani," was an exploration of five generations of a Sephardic family.

snippet: Unknown
lead_paragraph: Novels about flying are frequently written by authors who know everything about the subject and very little about writing. Here are two agreeable exceptions: ANGLE OF ATTACK by Robin A. White (Crown, $20) and COYOTE BIRD by Jim DeFelice (St. Martin's, $18.95).
abstract: Novels about flying are frequently written by authors who know everything about the subject and very little about writing. Here are two agreeable exceptions: ANGLE OF ATTACK by Robin A. White (Crown, $20) and COYOTE BIRD by Jim DeFelice (St. Martin's, $18.95).   Mr. White's book starts just before the beginning of the Persian Gulf war, with American naval forces off Libya, with the Soviets developing a new weapon, with the Americans also coming up with something new, with Iraq in possession of an intercontinental ballistic missile and with Israel targeted for destruction.

snippet: On the fourth anniversary of the attacks on the World Trade Center and the Pentagon, we feature two essays about terrorist fiction. On Page 14, Benjamin Kunkel, an editor at the literary journal n+1 whose first novel, ''Indecision,'' was recently ...
lead_paragraph: On the fourth anniversary of the attacks on the World Trade Center and the Pentagon, we feature two essays about terrorist fiction. On Page 14, Benjamin Kunkel, an editor at the literary journal n+1 whose first novel, "Indecision," was recently reviewed in these pages, explores the ways in which novelists and terrorists sometimes share a revolutionary fervor. "In the fantasy-nightmare of the terrorist novel, the terrorist was the public symbol maker the novelist wished and failed to be," he writes.
abstract: On the fourth anniversary of the attacks on the World Trade Center and the Pentagon, we feature two essays about terrorist fiction. On Page 14, Benjamin Kunkel, an editor at the literary journal n+1 whose first novel, ''Indecision,'' was recently reviewed in these pages, explores the ways in which novelists and terrorists sometimes share a revolutionary fervor. ''In the fantasy-nightmare of the terrorist novel, the terrorist was the public symbol maker the novelist wished and failed to be,'' he writes.

lead_paragraph: DAISY-HEAD MAYZIE. Written and illustrated by Dr. Seuss. Random House. $15. (All ages) A story based on a manuscript from the 1960's, discovered in Dr. Seuss' papers, gives new meaning to flower power. The heroine, who sprouts a daisy right on the top of her head, is rescued from invasive, impersonal worldwide fame by the Cat in the Hat.

snippet: “The Name of God Is Mercy” renews the pope’s call for a Roman Catholic Church that responds to a wounded humanity.
lead_paragraph: During his training as a Jesuit priest in the 1960s, Jorge Mario Bergoglio — who, decades later, would become Pope Francis — spent three years teaching literature and psychology in his native Argentina. He taught the classics, like “El Cid,” but when his students expressed an interest in authors like Antonio Machado and Fernando de Rojas, he taught them, too, as a way of nurturing a love of literature in his pupils. He also encouraged his students to write, and had his friend Jorge Luis Borges read their stories.

SHAMELESS

lead_paragraph: SHAMELESS By Judy Collins.Pocket Books, $23.
abstract:
SHAMELESS 
By Judy Collins.
Pocket Books, $23. 

 Catherine is a photojournalist, big in the music world. She has a stunning list of credits and friends, a virile financier lover, an apartment on Central Park West, an addiction to nicotine, a motley sexual past and a $5 million bank account. Childhood on a Kansas ranch is a long way behind her. Unfortunately death, in the shape of threats in the mail and on her answering machine, is right there at her side. Ostensibly a detective yarn, the singer Judy Collins's first novel is actually an excuse for a wallow in glamour. Despite its flashbacks and dream sequences, sightings of the gods of music and film are its raison d'etre. En route to her denouement, Ms. Collins also gives us a middle-aged, world-famous singer seeking the baby she once gave up for adoption, an attractive soft-spoken New York police detective (with whom Catherine will find happiness and quit smoking), a randy psychotherapist, a murder and a drug-related suicide attempt. Ms. Collins's latest album is called "Shameless" too, and a CD of two tracks is included with the book. So is it a novel or is it a promotion? It doesn't really matter. Either way, Ms. Collins is having fun.
VICKI WEISSMAN

LEAD: 

I GET ON THE BUS. By Reginald McKnight. (Little, Brown, $17.95.) Behind the deceptively simple title of Reginald McKnight's first novel brews a picaresque tale of self-examination in which the narrator struggles to balance his American and...
lead_paragraph: LEAD:
abstract:
LEAD: 

I GET ON THE BUS. By Reginald McKnight. (Little, Brown, $17.95.) Behind the deceptively simple title of Reginald McKnight's first novel brews a picaresque tale of self-examination in which the narrator struggles to balance his American and African selves. The adventures of 29-year-old Evan Norris, who exchanges his middle-class life in Denver for a stint in the Peace Corps in Senegal, do not occur on land but in his mind.

headline: {'main': 'Darkness at Noon', 'kicker': 'BOOKS IN BRIEF: FICTION', 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'BOOKS IN BRIEF: FICTION; Darkness at Noon', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

keywords: [{'name': 'persons', 'value': 'JELLOUN, TAHAR BEN', 'rank': 1, 'major': 'N'}, {'name': 'subject', 'value': 'Reviews', 'rank': 2, 'major': 'N'}, {'name': 'subject', 'value': 'Books and Literature', 'rank': 3, 'major': 'N'}, {'name': 'creative_works', 'value': 'THIS BLINDING ABSENCE OF LIGHT (BOOK)', 'rank': 4, 'major': 'N'}]
snippet: William Ferguson reviews book This Blinding Absence of Light by Tahar Ben Jelloun; drawing (S)
lead_paragraph: In his new novel, THIS BLINDING ABSENCE OF LIGHT (New Press, $22.95), the Moroccan writer Tahar Ben Jelloun (who emigrated to France in 1961) presents a moving story based on the experiences of a real-life soldier, whom he calls Salim, after he takes part in an abortive attempt to overthrow King Hassan II of Morocco in 1971. For his role in the rebellion, Salim is sent to prison for nearly two decades, most of the time spent in the dungeons at Tazmamart, a honeycomb of underground cells with a regimen designed to kill the occupants as slowly and painfully as possible. Salim survives many tortures, but the worst of these is perpetual darkness. ''This Blinding Absence of Light,'' fluently translated from the French by Linda Coverdale, is a kind of gloss on suffering, with some passages achieving an almost mystical beauty (''My survival, my wretchedness, my agony were inscribed on the veil of night''). Salim entertains his fellow prisoners by reciting from memory long passages from favorite books -- notably the Koran and Camus's novel ''The Stranger'' -- but at length he succumbs to the idea that he himself has become ''a book no one would ever open.'' This novel sold well in France last year; it seems that people did indeed want to hear Salim's story just as it is presented in this sad and splendid book. William Ferguson
abstract: William Ferguson reviews book This Blinding Absence of Light by Tahar Ben Jelloun; drawing (S)

headline: {'main': "No Callers, Please -- We're Poets", 'kicker': 'THE CLOSE READER', 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': "THE CLOSE READER; No Callers, Please -- We're Poets", 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

keywords: [{'name': 'subject', 'value': 'Poetry and Poets', 'rank': 1, 'major': 'N'}, {'name': 'subject', 'value': 'Victorian Era', 'rank': 2, 'major': 'N'}, {'name': 'subject', 'value': 'Books and Literature', 'rank': 3, 'major': 'N'}, {'name': 'subject', 'value': 'Women', 'rank': 4, 'major': 'N'}]
snippet: Judith Shulevitz The Close Reader column on female Victorian poets; says while they suffered from diminished mobility and exclusion from society, they made more ingenious use of the restrictions imposed on them than was previously realized; drawin...
lead_paragraph: It was inevitable that halfway through the movie ''Possession'' the elusive Victorian poetess Christabel LaMotte would strip to her petticoats and be deflowered. Few figures in literary history frustrate the modern sensibility the way the female Victorian poets do, with their maidenly longueurs, coquettish letters deflecting would-be visitors and long hours in darkened rooms that resulted in inexplicably fiery, sexy, sharp-witted verse. How did that get written? The movie and the novel by A. S. Byatt on which it is based posit an illicit affair between the poetess and a married poet, discovery of which makes it possible to root her Gothic fantasies in lived experience. The archives of the poets on whom Byatt modeled LaMotte -- Christina Rossetti, Emily Dickinson and Elizabeth Barrett Browning, with a smattering of Emily Brontë -- offer nothing so explanatory. All these writers lived in their parents' homes for most or all of their careers (Elizabeth Barrett married Robert Browning at the age of 40, after she had established her reputation). None had much formal schooling. All were acutely shy and often sick. All refused callers.
abstract: Judith Shulevitz The Close Reader column on female Victorian poets; says while they suffered from diminished mobility and exclusion from society, they made more ingenious use of the restrictions imposed on them than was previously realized; drawing (M)

snippet: Elsa Dixler Fiction Chronicle article on books From a Crooked Rib by Nuruddin Farah, Exiles in America by Christopher Bram, Disobedience by Naomi Alderman, Piece of Work by Laura Zigman and Famous Writers School by Steven Carter; photo from book A...
lead_paragraph: FROM A CROOKED RIB. By Nuruddin Farah. (Penguin Books, paper, $14.) A Somali novelist who now lives in Cape Town, Farah is frequently mentioned as a candidate for the Nobel Prize. The most recent of his nine novels, "Links," about an exile who returns to a hellish Mogadishu, was published here to favorable reviews in 2004, but this one, written in 1968 when he was a 23-year-old university student in India, was his first. Published in Britain in 1970 but not widely read until the success of Farah's later books, it tells the story of an 18-year-old orphan who flees her desert encampment to escape a forced marriage to a much older man. Ebla travels first to the nearest town, where she becomes a put-upon servant, and then to Mogadishu, where she marries a low-level bureaucrat who soon leaves for Italy (it is the eve of Somali independence), then becomes the secret second wife of a married man who pays her after their trysts. Once so sheltered and inexperienced that she had never seen a white man, a more world-weary Ebla comes to view her body as "my only treasure, my bank, my money, my existence." "From a Crooked Rib" is a young writer's novel, with an intermittently shaky point of view and language that can be awkward, but it demonstrates Farah's extraordinary ability to enter the consciousness of an unsophisticated woman. Supposedly, the book's original British editor was surprised to discover the author was a man.

snippet: Barton Gellman’s biography paints Dick Cheney as the master manipulator of the Bush administration.
lead_paragraph: In 1992 Paul Wolfowitz, then the under secretary of defense for policy, presided over the drafting of a 46-page document called the Defense Planning Guidance. It was essentially a blueprint for American unilateral dominance in the post-cold-war era and created such a furor that Defense Secretary Dick Cheney had to withdraw its most extreme provisions. Read one way, the document looks like a dress rehearsal for the bellicose policies pursued a decade later by the Bush administration. But looked at another way, it also seems like a valuable window into Cheney’s operational code.

snippet: Eric Lax’s new book of interviews with Woody Allen, along with recent collections of Allen’s fiction and prose, helps burnish the director’s legacy.
lead_paragraph: Not only does Woody Allen profess not to care one whit about his legacy as a filmmaker; he’s also fashioned some choice Woodyisms on the topic. Here’s one: “I’m a firm believer that when you’re dead, naming a street after you doesn’t help your metabolism.” Here’s another: “Rather than live on in the hearts and minds of my fellow man, I’d prefer to live on in my apartment.”

snippet: Julie Klam’s doting mother wanted nothing more than to be her best friend.
lead_paragraph: Let us begin by eradicating all suspicion: Julie Klam’s memoir of growing up a coddled daughter of Westchester County bears no sign of narrative inauthenticity. In “Please Excuse My Daughter,” there are no discernable lies masking dark hopes of literary recognition.

keywords: [{'name': 'persons', 'value': 'Sargent, John Singer', 'rank': 1, 'major': 'N'}, {'name': 'persons', 'value': 'ORMOND, RICHARD', 'rank': 2, 'major': 'N'}, {'name': 'persons', 'value': 'KILMURRAY, ELAINE', 'rank': 3, 'major': 'N'}, {'name': 'subject', 'value': 'Reviews', 'rank': 4, 'major': 'N'}, {'name': 'subject', 'value': 'Books and Literature', 'rank': 5, 'major': 'N'}, {'name': 'creative_works', 'value': 'JOHN SINGER SARGENT: THE LATER PORTRAITS (BOOK)', 'rank': 6, 'major': 'N'}]
snippet: Hilarie M Sheets reviews book John Singer Sargent: The Later Portraits by Richard Ormond and Elaine Kilmurray; photo (S)
lead_paragraph: ''I hate to paint portraits! . . . Youth can better stand the exactions of a personal kind that are inseparable from portraiture,'' John Singer Sargent (1856-1925) confided late in life to the artist Walter Tittle. The irony is that Sargent was the most celebrated portrait painter of his time, commanding the best clientele, prices and reviews. Between 1900 and 1907, Sargent averaged 17 monumental portraits a year, primarily of British aristocrats and arrivistes eager to promote their lineage or wealth; even after officially retiring from portraiture in 1907, he turned out some 20 more as he was continually prevailed upon by friends and prominent people, including Woodrow Wilson and John D. Rockefeller. JOHN SINGER SARGENT: The Later Portraits (Yale, $65), by Richard Ormond, an art historian, and Elaine Kilmurray, research director of the John Singer Sargent catalogue raisonné project, scrupulously plumbs the artist's last 25 years and interestingly does not attempt to cast him as a great modernist innovator but rather as a technically superb commercial artist who understood -- and ultimately tired of -- the demands of pleasing his patrons. If he was criticized by the avant-garde for being formulaic -- Sargent himself praised Whistler for never doing the same thing twice -- the authors exhibit that his best work brilliantly captures his sitters' physicality and temperament. In 1900, the critic Roger Fry wrote of Sargent: ''Such works must have an enduring interest to posterity simply as perfect records of the style and manners of a particular period.'' Hilarie M. Sheets
abstract: Hilarie M Sheets reviews book John Singer Sargent: The Later Portraits by Richard Ormond and Elaine Kilmurray; photo (S)

snippet: How the U.S. blundered after victory in the Pacific, and what history may repeat.
lead_paragraph: An unidentified British officer observed in late 1945 that “all the blood spilt in Java since the Japanese occupation will never be known.” But some of the worst was still to come. When the Japanese formally laid down their arms in mid-August 1945, the entire continent of Asia immediately became shrouded in a thick fog of peace, its new geopolitics distinguished more by confusion, mixed signals and lost opportunities than by wise diplomacy. And as new alliances took shape around old enmities, chaos, mayhem and anarchy engulfed the region. A generation of new wars followed.

snippet: What led an investment banker’s glamorous wife to murder him?
lead_paragraph: Joe McGinniss’s new book, about the November 2003 murder of a Hong Kong-based investment banker named Robert Kissel, expands his true-crime oeuvre from bloody trilogy to bloody quartet. “Never Enough” begins with a cluster of hard-boiled clichés that create a cartoonish first impression. Kissel’s father “played to win” but “knew how to catch flies with honey.” Kissel’s own “killer instinct slumbered” during high school in New Jersey; he would gaze across the Hudson at the Manhattan skyline like a “kid with his face pressed against the glass of the candy store window.” Meanwhile “it was her way or the highway” for Nancy Keeshin, the selfish woman Kissel would marry. New York City is “the land of hopes and dreams, the fast track, the big league.”

snippet: Irvine Welsh’s new story collection features boorish men and the women in their orbits.
lead_paragraph: THERE’S nothing more wonderful in literature than when a writer makes us feel deeply for a distasteful character. And there’s nothing more hateful in literature than when a writer goes out of his way to make sure we know he’s better — smarter, more sensitive, less boorish — than the characters he’s writing about. The Scottish writer Irvine Welsh’s “If You Liked School, You’ll Love Work …” is a collection of short stories (his first since “The Acid House” in 1995 ) largely about lamebrained men and the women who turn their heads — not a bad subject by itself, necessarily. But Welsh is the kind of writer who floats above the world scribbling passionately in his notebook, observing with great fascination the direction less, antlike creatures below him. He’s a wry observer but rarely a sympathizer: he’s happy to describe the flaws of his fictional creations, but mostly, he seems happy he’s not them. Or, to quote one of his Scottish characters: “Good tae see yis, dinnae want tae be yis!”

lead_paragraph: Memoirs of a Geisha
abstract: Memoirs of a Geisha  By Arthur Golden. Vintage Contemporaries, $14.    This first novel is an audacious ventriloquist act, assuming the voice of a Japanese woman born in the 1920's who recalls her metamorphosis from ugly duckling to luminous geisha and kept mistress. In 1997 our reviewer, John David Morley, found the heroine flatly drawn but said the period details and ''colorful nuggets of information . . . serve to enrich'' the book.

lead_paragraph: What was the first "forbidden" book you read and what were the circumstances under which you read it? The editors of the Book Review asked 14 men and women to share their secrets of fantasies inspired, expectations dashed, wisdom gained and the lonely knowledge that only comes in the dead of night with a flashlight in hand and a head under the covers. Here are the responses. Elmore Leonard
abstract: What was the first "forbidden" book you read and what were the circumstances under which you read it? The editors of the Book Review asked 14 men and women to share their secrets of fantasies inspired, expectations dashed, wisdom gained and the lonely knowledge that only comes in the dead of night with a flashlight in hand and a head under the covers. Here are the responses. Elmore Leonard    In the seventh or eighth grade a friend of mine who also read books told me that "Anthony Adverse," by Hervey Allen, had dirty parts in it; and I remember looking but don't recall if I found any. It's not that I was forbidden to read the novel -- it was on the shelf at home, I think a Book-of-the-Month-Club selection -- but I did probably look through it on the sly, making the act feel forbidden.

snippet: Zbigniew Brzezinski’s book “Strategic Vision” surveys current global affairs and assesses a hinge moment in time when the world’s center of gravity is shifting from the West to the East.
lead_paragraph: The 2008 crash and America and Europe’s continuing economic woes; the rise of China and worries about the decline of the West; and technology-fueled uprisings around the world from the Arab Spring protests to anti-Putin demonstrations in Russia — such developments underscore just how prescient Zbigniew Brzezinski has been in his earlier writings.

snippet: Unknown
lead_paragraph: SISTER BROTHER Gertrude and Leo Stein. By Brenda Wineapple. Illustrated. 514 pp. New York: G. P. Putnam's Sons. $35. IN "The Autobiography of Alice B. Toklas," Gertrude Stein purloined the voice of her devoted secretary and lover to memorialize herself as the center of avant-garde Paris at the turn of the century. Stein described herself as the pre-eminent proponent of modernism, as well as a cultural revolutionary whose unconventional prose inspired writers like Ernest Hemingway and Sherwood Anderson. Lionized by subsequent generations as the grande dame of the expatriate literati in the Paris of the 1920's, she became a cult figure, an icon whose radical credo and hermetic writing style were the very symbol of modernist experimentation.
abstract: SISTER BROTHER Gertrude and Leo Stein. By Brenda Wineapple. Illustrated. 514 pp. New York: G. P. Putnam's Sons. $35.    IN "The Autobiography of Alice B. snippet: In Ehud Havazelet’s novel, a man travels to California after his brother is killed in what may have been a drug transaction.
lead_paragraph: Several times while reading “Bearing the Body,” I found myself recalling Virginia Woolf’s remark that “Middlemarch” was one of the few English novels written for grown-ups. I’d always assumed I knew what Woolf meant, but “Bearing the Body,” Ehud Havazelet’s extraordinary first novel, made me consider what might be involved in writing for adults at our own cultural moment — adults who may have noticed that life in general, and people in particular, can be difficult, complicated and strange.

keywords: [{'name': 'persons', 'value': 'Hailey, Arthur', 'rank': 1, 'major': 'N'}, {'name': 'subject', 'value': 'BOOK REVIEWS', 'rank': 2, 'major': 'N'}, {'name': 'creative_works', 'value': 'EVENING NEWS, THE (BOOK)', 'rank': 3, 'major': 'N'}]
snippet: Unknown
lead_paragraph: THE EVENING NEWS. By Arthur Hailey. (Doubleday, $21.95.) Arthur Hailey's 10th novel is a literary example of an old boxing adage: if you don't have the fistic power, dazzle them with footwork. ''The Evening News'' is painstakingly researched, convolutedly plotted, peopled with poster-paint characters and written in a relentlessly breathless style. Its central characters are a television anchorman, Crawford Sloane, and his wife, Jessica, who live an opulent Ken-and-Barbie life in Larchmont, N.Y., until some nasty Shining Path terrorists come north to stage a kidnapping. The plot revolves around the efforts of the network folks to free Sloane's captive family. The settings are the New York corporate offices and newsrooms of the network and the Peruvian jungle, with flashbacks to Vietnam thrown in for good measure. There are the obligatory steamy sex scenes (one between a network correspondent and a flight attendant on the papal aircraft, no less) and a couple of plugs for Mr. Hailey's favorite Manhattan restaurants. So far, so good: at first ''The Evening News'' looks like yet another quick-paced novel written with an eye on movie or mini-series rights. But Mr. Hailey irks as he embellishes the telling of a reasonably good story that has some reasonably interesting characters. He manages to condescend to nearly all his women (the head of the network, for example, makes Medea look like Mary Poppins) and he downshifts into low stylistic gear with depressing regularity. We learn, whether we want to know it or not, how Opa Locka, Fla., and White Plains, N.Y., got their names. We also get, between quotation marks, lectures on the past, present and future of the television and print news business, including a prediction that The New York Times will soon be using full-color photographs on page 1.
abstract: LEAD:    THE EVENING NEWS. By Arthur Hailey. (Doubleday, $21.95.) Arthur Hailey's 10th novel is a literary example of an old boxing adage: if you don't have the fistic power, dazzle them with footwork. ''The Evening News'' is painstakingly researched, convolutedly plotted, peopled with poster-paint characters and written in a relentlessly breathless style.
