byline: {'original': 'By Scott Veale', 'person': [{'firstname': 'Scott', 'middlename': None, 'lastname': 'Veale', 'qualifier': None, 'title': None, 'role': 'reported', 'organization': '', 'rank': 1}], 'organization': None}
snippet: Unknown
lead_paragraph: NO PICNIC ON MOUNT KENYA
abstract: NO PICNIC ON MOUNT KENYA  By Felice Benuzzi. Lyons, $14.95.  n 1943 the author and two Italian compatriots escaped from a British P.O.W. camp and embarked on a loony quest to scale Mount Kenya and plant their nation's flag on its summit, knowing they would eventually wind up in solitary. This lively account is both a ripping yarn and a self-mocking survival tale. ''Gay adventure, this, with the quality of truth,'' Robert Payne wrote here in 1953.    THIS SIDE OF BRIGHTNESS  By Colum McCann. Owl/Holt, $13.  This gritty, intense novel by a young Irish writer chronicles the eroding fortunes of three generations of a disturbed family whose members once helped to build the New York City subway system but now live in its darkened tunnels. ''This Side of Brightness'' is a ''deft feat of balance and fancy footwork,'' David Willis McCullough wrote in the Book Review last year. ''It is also a disturbingly beautiful portrait of a family whose dreams are never quite able to stave off the painful reality of their circumstances, a portrait that ends without sentimentality and yet with renewed hope.''    THE UNFINISHED PRESIDENCY:  Jimmy Carter's Journey Beyond the White House  By Douglas Brinkley. Penguin, $15.95.  This account of the ex-President's second career as poet, teacher and crusader for human rights also explores the two sides of his personality: his Christian values and his fierce egotism. ''Even Carter's severest critics . . . will find it hard to be unmoved by his blend of idealism and practicality,'' Godfrey Hodgson wrote here in 1998.    WHERE OR WHEN  By Anita Shreve. Harvest/Harcourt Brace, $13.  Thirty-one years after a brief teen-age romance, an insurance broker and a lonely poet rekindle their affair, first through letters and then in the flesh. ''Throughout this finely wrought book, Ms. Shreve manages to keep the reader suspended between despair and hope'' for her characters, Susan Isaacs wrote here in 1993.    THE RINGS OF SATURN  By W. G. Sebald. New Directions, $14.  This hybrid of fiction, travel, biography, myth and memoir follows the writer on a walking tour of the English coast but mostly sails through space and time as he ruminates on everything from silk to Joseph Conrad. ''The book is so natural and accessible . . . that one is left enchanted,'' Roberta Silman wrote here last year.    THE HOUSE OF SLEEP  By Jonathan Coe. Vintage Contemporaries, $13.  This intricate novel follows the loosely connected lives of four characters -- among them a narcoleptic woman and a dream addict who sleeps at least 14 hours a day -- and their shared preoccupation with dreamland. ''Coe has written a witty, engaging romance,'' Suzanne Berne wrote here in 1998.    THE BOURGEOIS EXPERIENCE: VICTORIA TO FREUD.  Volume 1: Education of the Senses  By Peter Gay. Norton, $16.  The first of five volumes in the author's provocative study of the American and European middle classes from the 1820's to World War I focuses on Victorian sexuality in all its extravagant and surprising variety. He calls his approach ''history informed by psychoanalysis,'' and he goes a long way toward disproving stereotypes about the era's sexless femininity. ''There has been no inquiry of this majestic import and ambition before,'' Neil McKendrick wrote here in 1984. In Volume 2: The Tender Passion ($16), Gay takes on 19th-century attitudes toward love and argues that bourgeois marriages were more stable and rewarding (for men and women) than most people believe. Gay ''shows himself splendidly resourceful in conjuring up the intimate worlds of these individuals,'' Paul Robinson said here in 1986.    THE BALLAD OF PECKHAM RYE  By Muriel Spark. New Directions, $11.95.  Set in a working-class London suburb, this frothy comic novel describes the havoc caused when a textile company hires a young Scottish consultant ''to bring vision into the lives of the workers.'' In 1960 our reviewer, Gerald Sykes, called this a ''genial popular entertainment of, imaginably, the Alec Guinness kind.''    THE BIRTH OF BEBOP: A SOCIAL AND MUSICAL HISTORY  By Scott DeVeaux. University of California, $18.95.  This scholarly study traces the shift from swing to be-bop in New York in the 1940's, focusing on musicians like Charlie (Bird) Parker, Dizzy Gillespie and others who transformed the jazz landscape. The book discusses jazz ''the way musicians have talked about it, not as a matter of schools and eras but as a slow-boiling stew of experience,'' Ben Ratliff wrote last year in The Times. CELEBRATING BIRD: The Triumph of Charlie Parker, by Gary Giddins (Da Capo, $17.95), is an incisive portrait of the legendary saxophonist that addresses both his musical genius and his tragic life. In 1987 our reviewer, Jason Berry, called this ''as penetrating a character study of Bird as any yet written.''    LAMBS OF GOD  By Marele Day. Riverhead, $12.95.  Three nuns living in a crumbling convent on a remote island find their solitude threatened by a young priest who arrives out of nowhere with plans to turn the property into a luxury resort. The result is a ''marvelous novel'' that is ''affecting and humorous and always absorbing,'' Julie Gray wrote here last year.   SCOTT VEALE

snippet: Unknown
lead_paragraph: THE GOOD GERMAN, by Joseph Kanon. (Picador USA, $14.) An American journalist searching for his former lover in postwar Berlin, a ravaged city where everything is for sale, stumbles onto a murder linked to a secret program that protects Nazi criminals from being brought to justice. The result is ''a novel that brings to life the ambiguities at the heart of our country's moral legacy,'' Neil Gordon said here last year. ''It also offers the promise of a writer who is fast approaching the complexity and relevance not just of le Carré and Greene but even of Orwell: provocative, fully realized fiction that explores . . . the reality of history as it is lived by individual men and women.''
abstract: THE GOOD GERMAN, by Joseph Kanon. (Picador USA, $14.) An American journalist searching for his former lover in postwar Berlin, a ravaged city where everything is for sale, stumbles onto a murder linked to a secret program that protects Nazi criminals from being brought to justice. The result is ''a novel that brings to life the ambiguities at the heart of our country's moral legacy,'' Neil Gordon said here last year. ''It also offers the promise of a writer who is fast approaching the complexity and relevance not just of le Carré and Greene but even of Orwell: provocative, fully realized fiction that explores . . . the reality of history as it is lived by individual men and women.''    SHEBA: Through the Desert in Search of the Legendary Queen, by Nicholas Clapp. (Mariner/Houghton Mifflin, $14.) A documentary filmmaker journeys to Israel, Syria, Saudi Arabia, Ethiopia and Yemen to track down historical evidence of the queen, who would have lived during the 10th century B.C. ''In the course of his research, Clapp uncovers some delicious tidbits,'' Michael Upchurch wrote here in 2001. ''He's just as engaging in describing his own adventures.''    GETTING A LIFE: Stories, by Helen Simpson. (Vintage Contemporaries, $12.) These acerbic British tales, populated by suffering housewives and harried working mothers, are resolutely unsentimental about the mixed blessings of the mommy track. Last year our reviewer, Jay McInerney, praised Simpson's ''playful stylistic facility and her acute powers of observation and characterization,'' adding that ''her quirky humor and linguistic dexterity may remind you of Lorrie Moore with a BBC accent.''    WASHINGTON, by Meg Greenfield. (PublicAffairs, $14.) A journalist who covered politics for nearly 40 years as a correspondent, Washington Post editor and Newsweek columnist casts a tough, principled eye on the inner workings of the capital. Her memoir, completed by Michael Beschloss after her death in 1999, is not personal, but it offers ''a new way of looking at a flawed Washington, one that is scathing in import if not in tone, a useful framework even to those who think of government people as more real, more human and even more truthful than she does,'' Adam Clymer wrote here in 2001. In Staying Tuned: A Life in Journalism, by Daniel Schorr (Washington Square/Pocket Books, $14), the former CBS correspondent (and current NPR commentator) best known for his tenacious coverage of the Watergate scandals reflects on his long career. ''One strength of this book is its evocation of an age of journalism long gone, when television truly covered the world and treated the viewer as if he had a brain,'' Clyde Haberman said here last year.    MOTHERLAND, by Vineeta Vijayaraghavan. (Soho, $12.) In this tender and unexpectedly fresh coming-of-age novel, a sullen, Americanized teenager blossoms into self-assured maturity when she is sent to spend the summer with her extended family in India. The tale ''has a gutsy air of daring'' and ''abundant charm,'' Mary Elizabeth Williams wrote in these pages in 2001. ''It teems with sumptuous, loving details of everyday life.''    THE RACKETS, by Thomas Kelly. (Plume, $14.) The Cosa Nostra, corrupt union officials and federal agents muscle one other for position in this gritty New York story written by a veteran of the construction trades. The novel ''feels lived and true,'' Colin Harrison wrote in the Book Review last year. '' 'The Rackets' is not just a well-paced, violent thriller or an insider's look at construction unions -- it's an elegy for the city's old Irish working class, and even for its tangled, unavoidable dealings with the Mafia.''    AUGUSTA, GONE: A True Story, by Martha Tod Dudman. (Perennial/HarperCollins, $12.95.) A single mother tells of her agonizing relationship with her wild, abusive teenage daughter and her encounters with the subculture of problem children. The result is ''an unflinching description of an adolescent rebellion that nearly destroyed a family,'' Martha Beck said here in 2001, one that ''shows parenthood at its worst and memoir at its best.''    THE LAST SAMURAI, by Helen DeWitt. (Talk Miramax, $14.95.) This literate first novel revolves around a woman of scary intellectual intensity, her brainiac son (who reads the ''Odyssey'' at 4 -- in Greek) and his seven potential fathers. ''The writing is playful and engaging'' and the author's ''intelligence provides sparkle as well as promise,'' Myla Goldberg wrote here in 2000.   Scott Veale

snippet: An interpretive biography of Muhammad sheds light on the political philosophy of its controversial author.
lead_paragraph: For some years now, the Swiss philosopher and Muslim intellectual Tariq Ramadan has been saying he wants to reconcile Islamic tradition with Western democracy, conservative religious values with liberal political ones. But not everyone finds him credible. And being the grandson of Hassan al-Banna, the founder of the Muslim Brotherhood in Egypt, doesn’t help. Skeptics say he is a radical in disguise — a Janus-faced rhetorician who presents a moderate’s face to Western audiences and a reactionary’s to Muslim ones.

lead_paragraph: HYPERION (Foundation/Doubleday, Cloth, $18.95; Paper, $8.95; Spectra/Bantam, Paper, $4.95) and THE FALL OF HYPERION (Foundation/Doubleday, Cloth, $18.95; Paper, $8.95) by Dan Simmons make up a single thousand-page novel about the last days of a vibrant yet self-destructive galactic civilization called the Hegemony. If the Hegemony is doomed, it is because, in exchange for the knowledge needed to conquer the stars, the human species has sold its soul to a hive of machine-based intelligences known as the Technocore. If there is any hope for human redemption, it is to be found on the planet Hyperion.

snippet: “The Widows of Eastwick,” while deeply flawed, is a less tendentious, more emotionally credible work than its predecessor.
lead_paragraph: John Updike once described his 1984 novel, “The Witches of Eastwick,” as an attempt by him to “make things right with my, what shall we call them, feminist detractors,” who complained, he said, that he tended to portray women as “wives, sex objects and purely domestic creatures.”

lead_paragraph: ADAM ZIGZAG. By Barbara Barrie. Delacorte. $14.95. (Ages 10 to 14) Adam Brody is growing up in upper-middle-class Manhattan, but his problems confronting dyslexia, the ways things zigzag on the page in front of him, are not bound by class or place. Adam and his sister Caroline tell the story. OUR GRANNY. By Margaret Wild. Illustrated by Julie Vivas. Ticknor & Fields. $13.95. (Ages 4 to 7) Two preschoolers tell about their beloved granny, who has a wobbly bottom, wears a funny bathing suit, marches in demonstrations and, best of all, lives with them. The funny, fuzzy, watercolor illustrations are wonderfully affectionate.

keywords: [{'name': 'persons', 'value': 'AYNSLEY, JEREMY', 'rank': 1, 'major': 'N'}, {'name': 'subject', 'value': 'Reviews', 'rank': 2, 'major': 'N'}, {'name': 'subject', 'value': 'Books and Literature', 'rank': 3, 'major': 'N'}, {'name': 'creative_works', 'value': 'GRAPHIC DESIGN IN GERMANY, 1890-1945 (BOOK)', 'rank': 4, 'major': 'N'}]
snippet: Steven Heller reviews book Graphic Design in Germany, 1890-1945, by Jeremy Aynsley; drawings (S)
lead_paragraph: Germany was a center of modern advertising, typography and book production between 1900 and 1933. Before the rise of the Nazis, German graphic arts were the most progressive of any industrialized nation and the most influential elsewhere in Europe. Designers ''sought to raise the standards of printed culture by integrating experimental ideas from avant-garde art,'' Jeremy Aynsley writes in GRAPHIC DESIGN IN GERMANY, 1890-1945 (University of California, $60), the first comprehensive study of German commercial graphics. The field of graphic design (which includes logo, poster, typeface, magazines and books) owes its stature to three German designers. Peter Behrens, the father of modern corporate identity, developed the first standardized corporate logo system for AEG, the leading German electrical company. Lucian Bernhard invented a new advertising method known as the sachplakat, or ''object poster,'' which emphasized the simple eye-catching rendering of a product rather than the turgid texts and uninspired images so common in advertising at that time. Jan Tschichold codified the neue Typographie, or ''new typography,'' characterized by asymmetrical composition, the use of bold, sans-serif letter forms and primary colors. These ideas forever altered commercial art's form and function through the rest of the century and led directly to the International style after World War I. The Bauhaus, the innovative design academy the Nazis would close down in 1933, flourished, and contemporary design styles were adopted by German industry. Germany was a magnet for iconoclastic applied artists from Russia, Eastern Europe and Italy. And Aynsley artfully details the rise and fall of the German graphic profession from the early period of decorative jugendstil (art nouveau) to the introduction of Nazi propaganda, which assailed progressive design as ''degenerate art.'' Steven Heller
abstract: Steven Heller reviews book Graphic Design in Germany, 1890-1945, by Jeremy Aynsley; drawings (S)

snippet: Marilyn Stasio reviews books The Remorseful Day by Colin Dexter, Blue Deer Thaw by Jamie Harrison, Night Work by Laurie R King, Drumsticks by Charlotte Carter and Nineteen Seventy-Four by David Peace; drawing (M)
lead_paragraph: When it comes time for a great detective to pack up and go, he deserves a decent elegy, and that's what Colin Dexter has given Inspector Morse in THE REMORSEFUL DAY (Crown, $24), the 13th and final book in a series that raised the bar for genre writing. Not since Nero Wolfe has a detective of Morse's ratiocinative skills, refined tastes and tetchy temperament held court in such magisterial fashion.

snippet: Judith Shulevitz column on her excursions in world of Weblogs; says she found as many voicing left-wing opinion as right-wing opinion; questions whether they pose threat to mainstream media; says bloggers like Andrew Sullivan, who frequently dwell...
lead_paragraph: JORGE LUIS BORGES dreamed of a library the size of a universe, whose wealth of books would induce first delirium, then despair, then breakdown of the social order. Since we first became aware of the Web, we have ricocheted between similar feelings over a universe far more disruptive: one of unbounded, uncensorable streams of text. The current craze is for something called a blog. The name is the diminutive of ''Weblog,'' an online news commentary written, usually, by an ordinary citizen, thick with links to articles and other blogs and studded with non sequiturs and ripostes in sometimes hard-to-parse squabbles.
abstract: Judith Shulevitz column on her excursions in world of Weblogs; says she found as many voicing left-wing opinion as right-wing opinion; questions whether they pose threat to mainstream media; says bloggers like Andrew Sullivan, who frequently dwells on personal obsessions, provide counterweight to the increasing unreality of mass journalistic culture; drawing (M)

snippet: A biography of Clark Gable doesn’t skimp on the seamy bits.
lead_paragraph: David Bret’s angle on Clark Gable is this: Gable was “gay for pay” and “rough trade,” and he enjoyed having sex “for bucks.” In addition, he “would sometimes scrub his penis until it bled” and used a device to prolong erections. If these tidbits from the book’s first few pages aren’t too much information for you, you’re in luck. This breathtakingly trashy biography does not skimp on sordid anecdotes.

snippet: In Richard Price’s eighth novel, class and color collide on the tangled, once tenement-lined streets of New York City’s Lower East Side.
lead_paragraph: No matter how shiny and safe a city gets, no matter how high its housing prices climb, how fast its crime rates fall and how many of its corner stores are turned into buzz-before-entering boutiques dedicated to clothing the “urban baby” or are replaced by franchised coffee shops with WiFi hot spots for laptop-toting Beat poets, there is one sort of room at the city’s very core whose design schemes rarely shift upscale and whose typical occupants  be they real or fictional  resist much gentrification of the soul, let alone beautification of the hair. The walls of such rooms are dull, their lights are harsh, and hunkered down in most of them are a jittery suspect and two clever cops, one of whom tends to act hostile and volatile, the other one solicitous and calm. Over this trio hangs a plain round clock.

lead_paragraph: THE WAR AGAINST CLICHÉ: Essays and Reviews, 1971-2000, by Martin Amis. (Vintage International, $16.) Among the highlights of this collection of book reviews and longer essays by the British author are a spirited defense of the poet Philip Larkin and celebrations of writers as varied as Elmore Leonard and Saul Bellow. ''Amis's work is distinguished by its hothouse intensity, its singleness of purpose, its nippy aggression -- and its stylishness,'' Jenny Turner wrote here last year.
abstract: THE WAR AGAINST CLICHÉ: Essays and Reviews, 1971-2000, by Martin Amis. (Vintage International, $16.) Among the highlights of this collection of book reviews and longer essays by the British author are a spirited defense of the poet Philip Larkin and celebrations of writers as varied as Elmore Leonard and Saul Bellow. ''Amis's work is distinguished by its hothouse intensity, its singleness of purpose, its nippy aggression -- and its stylishness,'' Jenny Turner wrote here last year.    THE SUPPER OF THE LAMB: A Culinary Reflection, by Robert Farrar Capon. (Modern Library, $11.95.) The author -- an Episcopal priest as well as a talented chef -- serves up an unlikely stew of theology, metaphysics and old-fashioned culinary wisdom. And yes, there are recipes. To call this a cookbook ''would be like calling 'Moby-Dick' a whaling manual,'' Frederick Buechner said here in 1969. It is an ''awesomely funny, wise, beautiful, moving'' book.    HOSTAGE, by Robert Crais. (Ballantine, $7.99.) In this thriller, three young toughs decide to rob a minimart in suburban Los Angeles. Bad move, because before long they're holed up in the home of an accountant named Smith, keeping him and his children hostage while the police, the F.B.I., a team of hit men and a tormented cop circle outside. The result is ''a lesson in chaos theory delivered in criminally entertaining style,'' Marilyn Stasio wrote here in 2001.    THE FLIGHT OF THE MAIDENS, by Jane Gardam. (Plume, $13.) Set in 1946, this coming-of-age novel follows the fates of three English girls trying to navigate their way to adulthood in the aftermath of World War II, and of their families, many of whose members are scarred or missing. The tale ''is as much about one generation closing down as it is about a new one opening up,'' Jacqueline Carey said here last year. Gardam ''can see deep into the hearts of both parents and children as the balance of power tips.''    ANDREW JACKSON AND HIS INDIAN WARS, by Robert V. Remini. (Penguin, $15.) A Jacksonian scholar defends Old Hickory's much-criticized record on the treatment of Indians, particularly the campaign during his presidency to expel all Indians living east of the Mississippi River. Even though the argument that Jackson was a creature of his times and mellowed with age seemed one-sided to our reviewer, Andrew R. L. Cayton, last year, Remini is ''as tenacious a champion as any president could ever hope to have.''    RIDERS IN THE CHARIOT, by Patrick White. (New York Review, $16.95.) This 1961 Australian novel, set in a Sydney suburb, revolves around four visionary characters -- a half-mad spinster, a housekeeper, a German Holocaust survivor and an aboriginal artist -- who are ''joined one to the other'' in their spiritual incorruptibility, for better or for worse. The result is a ''monumental work'' of more than ''half a thousand pages -- almost every one of which cries out for quotation,'' James Stern said in the Book Review.    FAITHLESS: Tales of Transgression, by Joyce Carol Oates. (Ecco/HarperCollins, $14.95.) The prolific author, as confrontational and vivid as ever, spins 21 tales of terror, female passion, shaky male identity, loneliness, divorce, revenge and gun ownership. As usual, death is always hovering nearby. ''Again and again she finds new language to describe the immensity of desire,'' Colin Harrison said in these pages last year. ''As ever, and nearly alone in her protean accomplishments, she twists back against our assumptions, seeking always the gristly pop of revelation.''    FILTHY RICH, by Dorothy Samuels. (Avon, $13.95.) In this frothy first novel, which tells of a 30-something ''personal life coach'' who becomes an instant celebrity after her boyfriend dumps her on TV in front of 20 million people, Samuels (who writes editorials for The New York Times) ''delivers a message about the coarsening of contemporary culture in a nimble and engaging fashion,'' Betsy Groban wrote here in 2001.    OUR BAND COULD BE YOUR LIFE: Scenes From the American Indie Underground 1981-1991, by Michael Azerrad. (Back Bay/Little, Brown, $15.95.) A longtime music journalist offers tribute to one of rock's most influential and least understood eras by resurrecting 13 punk-inspired indie groups like Black Flag and Hüsker Dü, who proved that great music can be created outside corporate structures. Azerrad is ''adept at drawing out musicians' war stories -- and this bare-bones movement was full of them,'' Eric Weisbard said here last year.   Scott Veale

snippet: Michael Dibdin’s Aurelio Zen novels capture regional Italy — and the gloriously unruly national character.
lead_paragraph: Donna Leon has staked out Venice, Magdalen Nabb knows every narrow street in Florence, and Andrea Camilleri holds Sicily in the palm of his hand. But only Michael Dibdin, in the clever and exuberantly witty police procedurals he created for a dyspeptic cop named Aurelio Zen, tried to wrap his arms around the whole of Italy. Braving his way province by province — from the mountains of Alto Adige (in “Medusa”) to the caves of Sardinia (in “Vendetta”) — the British-born author produced crime stories that capture the idiosyncratic essence of each region while contributing to a dynamic study of the Italian national character in all its unruly glory.

lead_paragraph: The atmosphere in Edward Sklepowich's DEATH IN A SERENE CITY (Morrow, $18.95), a mystery set in Venice, rises thicker than the predawn fog that rolls off the Grand Canal. Among the gaudy characters are artists and aristocrats, glass blowers and mask makers, pious priests and humble washerwomen -- even the desiccated corpse of a saint. The action glides (rather too languidly at times) from the cobbled streets and ancient buildings of the living city to the city of the dead that lies across the lagoon on Sant'Ariano, a tour that allows plenty of time for espresso at Florian's.
abstract: The atmosphere in Edward Sklepowich's DEATH IN A SERENE CITY (Morrow, $18.95), a mystery set in Venice, rises thicker than the predawn fog that rolls off the Grand Canal. Among the gaudy characters are artists and aristocrats, glass blowers and mask makers, pious priests and humble washerwomen -- even the desiccated corpse of a saint. The action glides (rather too languidly at times) from the cobbled streets and ancient buildings of the living city to the city of the dead that lies across the lagoon on Sant'Ariano, a tour that allows plenty of time for espresso at Florian's.   Despite occasional lapses into guidebook prose, the first-time author takes care to plot a pretty mystery in the orderly classical manner and to resolve it with a nice, macabre touch. At the center of the story is Urbino Macintyre, an American biographer with a keen interest in dead subjects, including such recently departed souls as an expatriate writer who jumped into a canal and a local washerwoman who was murdered in church, presumably by the thief who stole the bones of its resident saint. Sad affairs, if hardly mysterious.

snippet: Unknown
lead_paragraph: HUNTING HUMANS: An Encyclopedia of Modern Serial Killers. By Michael Newton. (Loompanics Unlimited, $34.95.) Why an encyclopedia of serial killers? There is probably no satisfactory answer, and perhaps a publisher whose previous efforts include a manual of bodyguarding and a catalogue of poisons (''sold for informational purposes only'') doesn't need one. Still, for anybody with a taste for this sort of thing, Michael Newton's ''Hunting Humans'' appears to be relatively complete. The entries number 544, covering approximately 750 individuals who committed every imaginable variety of mayhem: mutilation, necrophilia, cannibalism, dismemberment, vampirism, human sacrifice. Only 20th-century serial killers are dealt with; absent are such earlier monsters as Gilles de Rais and Jack the Ripper - though the book does have two Jack the Rippers of its own, as well as a Jack the Stripper. Many of the murderers fit the stereotype of the rootless male drifter, but by no means all. At least two had been Eagle Scouts; one was a Sunday school teacher. About 8 percent are women, and they tended to stay close to home, doing away with husbands, children, boarders - almost invariably by poison. Without the contexts true-crime books provide, the entries often consist of little more than lists of killings, and a reader who proceeds from cover to cover is likely to start skipping around, searching out oddities in this already odd crowd: the man who fed the corpses to his pet alligators, the fellow who ''developed a bizarre, abiding hatred'' for the Domino's Pizza chain. Nonetheless, reading through the entries from A to Z is the best approach, since the volume's main impact is cumulative. There are so many! Serial killing is not an uncommon phenomenon that occasionally erupts into headlines with the apprehension of a Charles Manson or a Theodore Bundy. As this book makes abundantly and depressingly clear, it is something going on all the time and, apparently, with increasing frequency.
abstract: LEAD:    HUNTING HUMANS: An Encyclopedia of Modern Serial Killers. By Michael Newton. (Loompanics Unlimited, $34.95.) Why an encyclopedia of serial killers? There is probably no satisfactory answer, and perhaps a publisher whose previous efforts include a manual of bodyguarding and a catalogue of poisons (''sold for informational purposes only'') doesn't need one.

lead_paragraph: THE LONG SEASON OF RAIN. By Helen Kim. Holt. $15.95. (Ages 12 and up) This impressive first novel, set in Seoul in the 1960's, is about the tensions and secrets in Junehee Lee's family. The observant child is well aware that her father is constantly absent, and the relationships between the adult women -- her mother, grandmother and aunts -- are as strained as those among her siblings.

snippet: Gerald Jonas reviews following books: The Skinner by Neal Asher; Beyond Infinity by Gregory Benford; and The Fourth Circle by Zoran Zivkovic (M)
lead_paragraph: Every age gets the science fiction it deserves. Neal Asher's grimly assured novel THE SKINNER (Tor/Tom Doherty, $26.95) projects the terror-haunted sensibility of our time into a future of limitless brutality. Like his fellow Brit Richard K. Morgan in his Takeshi Kovacs novels, Asher assumes that science's success in extending life will only multiply the opportunities for inflicting pain.
abstract: Gerald Jonas reviews following books: The Skinner by Neal Asher; Beyond Infinity by Gregory Benford; and The Fourth Circle by Zoran Zivkovic (M)

keywords: [{'name': 'subject', 'value': 'BOOK REVIEWS', 'rank': 1, 'major': 'N'}]
snippet: Unknown
lead_paragraph: NOBODY NOWHERE: The Extraordinary Autobiography of an Autistic By Donna Williams. Avon, $10. The author describes the tortured inner world she lived in for years, unable to accept human contact and yet longing for it. Detailing her fitful progress toward an independent life and also including advice for families of autistic people, the book offers "fascinating testimony to an intelligence undimmed by mental turmoil," Daniel Goleman said here last year. OPERATION SHYLOCK: A Confession By Philip Roth. Vintage International, $12. In this novel, a writer who just happens to be named Philip Roth and who is recovering from a breakdown discovers that another man is impersonating him quite successfully in Israel. His confrontation with his doppelganger forms the substance of the plot, which involves both men in Israeli politics and a debate over the future of the Jews. Last year our reviewer, D. M. Thomas, said: "Despite the seriousness of its theme, the book carries the feeling of creative joy. One feels that Mr. Roth feels that he's let rip." Vintage has also reissued two of the author's earlier books, both with autobiographical elements. MY LIFE AS A MAN ($11) concerns the obsessive and disastrous early marriage of a writer named Peter Tarnopol. Mr. Roth "can be not only funny but lyrical," Morris Dickstein said here in 1974. GOODBYE, COLUMBUS: And Five Short Stories ($11), Mr. Roth's first book, comprises the now famous love affair of Neil Klugman and Brenda Patimkin, as well as various meditations on American Jewish life. In 1959 The New York Times's reviewer, William Peden, called the author "a keen recorder of an indecisive generation."

snippet: Cullen Murphy examines parallels between the United States today and the world of ancient Rome.
lead_paragraph: The only sure thing that can be said about the past is that anyone who can remember Santayana’s maxim is condemned to repeat it. As a result, the danger of not understanding the lessons of history is matched by the danger of using simplistic historical analogies. Those who have learned the lessons of Munich square off against those who have learned the lessons of Vietnam, and then they both invoke the bread-and-circus days of the overstretched Roman empire in an attempt to sound even more subtle and profound.

keywords: [{'name': 'persons', 'value': 'Golding, William', 'rank': 1, 'major': 'N'}, {'name': 'subject', 'value': 'Reviews', 'rank': 2, 'major': 'N'}, {'name': 'subject', 'value': 'Books and Literature', 'rank': 3, 'major': 'N'}, {'name': 'creative_works', 'value': 'DOUBLE TONGUE, THE (BOOK)', 'rank': 4, 'major': 'N'}]
snippet: Unknown
lead_paragraph: THE DOUBLE TONGUE By William Golding. Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $20.
abstract: THE DOUBLE TONGUE  By William Golding. Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $20.     This unfinished novella set in ancient Greece had been through two drafts at the time of William Golding's death in 1993, as we learn in an introductory note from the publisher. At least one more was apparently planned, and is much needed. The publisher's note also says that the author had not settled on a title. The one selected from several he used appears early in the text, when the narrator, Arieka, picked as a 15-year-old to be a handmaid of Apollo at Delphi, notes that the god "speaks with a double tongue." This is a good choice, since the book as it stands is very much about speech and the sound of speech. For more than 60 years, Arieka has been the Pythia, the human mouthpiece of the oracle. It is a debased time. Greece is now dominated by Rome (a young Julius Caesar appears, briefly, to get a typically opaque reading of his career prospects), and Delphi has become little more than a tourist trap. One of Arieka's more entertaining notions is that a god becomes trivial when his worshipers make only trivial demands of him. To put a better face on things, she learns to speak in hexameters, so that Apollo will sound like Homer -- which, everyone knows, is how gods sounded in the good old days. While the plot is thin to the point of nonexistence and has its ragged points and omissions, Arieka's wry voice is a resounding success. She speaks to us as a very old woman looking back over a gilded career that she respects but has never been able to take seriously. One of the perks -- or plagues -- of being a Nobel Prize winner is that your heirs get to publish whatever they find on your desk. It is hard to believe that William Golding would be altogether pleased with this particular book, but Arieka's voice saves him from embarrassment. DAVID WILLIS MC CULLOUGH

ENGLAND, BLOODY ENGLAND: An Expatriate's Return. By Lesley Hazleton. (Atlantic Monthly, $19.95.) This is a book about prejudice, but not perhaps the kind that the author had in mind. After a 20-year absence, Lesley Hazleton, the author of ''Jerusalem, Jerusalem,'' returned to England to complete formalities for immigration to the United States.

lead_paragraph: THE GREAT FIRE. By Jim Murphy. Scholastic. $16.95. (Ages 10 and up) Here's an engrossing account of the 1871 fire in Chicago, a disaster that drove 100,000 people from their homes. The book is handsomely illustrated with photographs and drawings. The engaging text draws heavily on the recollections of four survivors. NO! NO! NO! Written and illustrated by Anne Rockwell. Macmillan. $14. (Ages 3 to 6) A little boy tells us about a miserable day -- even the toothpaste was awful, and his blocks fell down. What he wants us to know is that he heard a good story at bedtime, had a wonderful dream, and has woken up to a better day.

snippet: Neil Genzlinger reviews book Presidential Doodles: Two Centuries of Scribbles, Scratches, Squiggles and Scrawls From the Oval Office by David Greenberg; photo (M)
lead_paragraph: This provision isn't in the Constitution but probably ought to be: All tomes by highfalutin presidential scholars shall be sold only as a package with Presidential Doodles: Two Centuries of Scribbles, Scratches, Squiggles and Scrawls From the Oval Office (Basic Books. $24.95). Whatever president is sitting at the moment is of course a national punch line, but once history's blur takes over, former presidents begin to be transformed into semi-mythic beings worthy of thousand-page biographies, and we start to forget what boneheads, blowhards and/or con men they actually were. When Robert A. Caro writes of "the dominance of Lyndon Johnson, face to face, over other men, even over 10 other men, even over 10 famous and respected men," it would be useful to be able to remind ourselves that the same guy once drew a doodle of a three-headed mammal in a dress. On White House stationery.
abstract: Neil Genzlinger reviews book Presidential Doodles: Two Centuries of Scribbles, Scratches, Squiggles and Scrawls From the Oval Office by David Greenberg; photo (M)

snippet: The medieval meets the modern in Nicola Barker’s multilayered new novel.
lead_paragraph: Right from its perplexing title and mysterious 16th-century epigraph  “These demanders for glimmer be for the most part women; for glimmer, in their language, is fire”  Nicola Barker’s latest novel, “Darkmans,” is difficult to grasp. The narrative has barely begun before you’re plunged into a detailed (and somewhat bewildering) exploration of the history of Ashford, in Kent, and the impact of the Channel Tunnel on the region. Yet once you’re in the grip of this broad, funny, deeply strange book  once you and “Darkmans” are grappling with each other  neither you nor the novel is likely to let go.

snippet: In this biography, a novelist imagines her way into the life of the woman John Brown called “General Tubman.”
lead_paragraph: Best known as a hero of the Underground Railroad, Harriet Tubman has been the subject of hundreds of books for young people. Full-scale biographies, however, have been scarce, though three — by Jean Humez, Catherine Clinton and Kate Clifford Larson — have appeared since the year 2000. “Harriet Tubman,” the novelist Beverly Lowry’s contribution, is labeled a biography, but the subtitle, “Imagining a Life,” qualifies that claim. In an author’s note, Lowry painstakingly explains her decision “to emphasize the visual elements of Harriet’s story — what things looked like, places and clothes, faces, plants, the sky — and to thread information from the sources” listed in her bibliography “in order to come up with one version of what life might have been like for the American hero Harriet Tubman.” She also makes us aware that Tubman was one of the first American celebrities to market her own story for profit, so the first full record of her life contains material that she and her original biographer, Sarah Hopkins Bradford, thought would sell.

snippet: Unknown
lead_paragraph: THE LOOK OF HORROR: Scary Moments From Scary Movies. By Jonathan Sternfield. (Courage Books/Running Press, $14.98.) Covering a genre of movies that runs from "The Cabinet of Dr. Caligari" to "Little Shop of Horrors," "The Look of Horror" is a compressed history that is long on images and short on words, a well-illustrated, smartly written recap of some of the more frightening moments in movie history -- and the faces that make those moments memorable. This is a fan's book and never pretends to be a groundbreaking study of horror films. No long-winded theories or footnotes about What It All Means, just page after page of the bright, fantastic visions from the classics we know so well (and some we may have forgotten). Jonathan Sternfield, a freelance writer and photographer, breaks his study into different sections, covering aliens, creatures, ghosts and the demons among us -- the bad seeds, the ordinary people who can be the most terrifying monsters around. The author wisely keeps his opinions short, crisp and to the point. His text amounts to plot summaries and critical commentaries on the quality of the films. What animates this book are the photos of these scary monsters and super freaks. Mr. Sternfield has some interesting inclusions: in a book rife with werewolves, blobs and tarantulas the size of 747's, for example, he has included "Fatal Attraction" as a horror film for a new generation. We cover the gamut here, from monsters alien and otherwise to seemingly innocent demonic devices (the car in John Carpenter's "Christine," the red-headed doll in "Child's Play"). Mr. Sternfield delivers what he promises and does it in a loose, readable style. And the coffeetable format makes it effective; the pictures are large and lurid -- the better to frighten you with, my dear.

Covering a genre of movies that runs from "The Cabinet of Dr. Caligari" to "Little Shop of Horrors," "The Look of Horror" is a compressed history that is long on images and short on words, a well-illustrated, smartly written recap of some of the more frightening moments in movie history -- and the faces that make those moments memorable. snippet: Unknown
lead_paragraph: MASTER OF THE sENATE: The Years of Lyndon Johnson, by Robert A. Caro. (Vintage, $19.95.) In the third volume of his mammoth life of Johnson, Caro presents a more rounded version of his subject than before, conjuring a tyrannical politician who worked his magic in the Senate from 1949 to 1961, wheedling, bullying and stroking egos while pushing through landmark civil rights legislation. This Pulitzer Prize-winning account is ''a wonderful, a glorious tale,'' Anthony Lewis wrote here in 2002. ''Not even Trollope explored the ambitions and the gullibilities of men as deliciously as . . . Caro.''
abstract: MASTER OF THE sENATE: The Years of Lyndon Johnson, by Robert A. Caro. (Vintage, $19.95.) In the third volume of his mammoth life of Johnson, Caro presents a more rounded version of his subject than before, conjuring a tyrannical politician who worked his magic in the Senate from 1949 to 1961, wheedling, bullying and stroking egos while pushing through landmark civil rights legislation. This Pulitzer Prize-winning account is ''a wonderful, a glorious tale,'' Anthony Lewis wrote here in 2002. ''Not even Trollope explored the ambitions and the gullibilities of men as deliciously as . . . Caro.''    A CHILD'S BOOK OF TRUE CRIME, by Chloe Hooper. (Scribner, $13.) A young Tasmanian schoolteacher has an adulterous affair with a student's father that has creepy parallels with another affair in a nearby town decades earlier that ended in murder. Worse, her lover's wife has just written a true-crime account of the killing, and the teacher becomes dangerously obsessed with the case. Last year our reviewer, Jennifer Egan, found this ''a striking, ambitious first novel.''    WRITING IN THE DARK, DANCING IN THE NEW YORKER, by Arlene Croce. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $20.) This huge anthology of columns from The New Yorker showcases an acclaimed critic who believes that great art is not about ideas but beauty, and whose greatest gift is ''her ability to write vividly and indelibly about what dances and dancers look like,'' Terry Teachout said here in 2000. The collection ''will be ranked among the half-dozen indispensable books about dance to have been written in the 20th century.''    LIFE OF PI, by Yann Martel. (Harvest/ Harcourt, $14.) It sounds like the setup to a barroom joke, but here's the premise of this allegorical Canadian novel: a Hindu, a Muslim and a Christian are trapped on a lifeboat for 227 days with a Bengal tiger. Actually, the humans are one amiable Indian teenager who practices all three religions and is stranded with the tiger (named Richard Parker) after his family's private zoo is lost in a shipwreck. Last year in these pages, Gary Krist said the tale ''could renew your faith in the ability of novelists to invest even the most outrageous scenario with plausible life.''    JIMMY CORRIGAN: The Smartest Kid on Earth, by Chris Ware. (Pantheon, $17.95.) This graphic novel -- about a pathetic 36-year-old man who is reunited with his long-absent father -- is bleak, but the artwork, both meticulous and utterly free, lifts the mood. Praising the book's ''sheer aesthetic virtuosity'' in these pages in 2000, Dave Eggers said, ''Ware is the most versatile and innovative artist the medium has ever known.''    PAPERBOY: Confessions of a Future Engineer, by Henry Petroski. (Vintage, $14.) An engineering professor at Duke University tells of his Sputnik-era youth in an outlying section of Queens, where he learned some early lessons about life and people as a bike-riding paperboy. Though short on drama and long on memories of stickball and mild hooliganism, his memoir is ''a fond but cleareyed glance back at what it was like growing up middle-class and upwardly striving,'' Clyde Haberman said here last year.    THREE JUNES, by Julia Glass. (Anchor, $14.) This first novel, set mainly on Manhattan, Long Island and other islands in Scotland and Greece, examines the costs of emotional isolation as it follows the members of a scattered Scottish family over the course of three Junes (in 1989, 1995 and 1999). Winner of a National Book Award, '' 'Three Junes' brilliantly rescues, then refurbishes, the traditional plot-driven novel,'' Katherine Wolff wrote here last year. ''Glass has written a generous book about family expectations -- but also about happiness, luck and, as she puts it, 'the generosity of genes.' ''    MY RACING HEART: The Passionate World of Thoroughbreds and the Track, by Nan Mooney. (Perennial/HarperCollins, $12.95.) A lifelong horse lover recounts her own unshakable enthusiasm for thoroughbred racing as she delves into the sport's history and profiles the jockeys, grooms, trainers and others who make it run. Last year in these pages, Bill Barich said Mooney ''never gives it less than her all.'' Stud: Adventures in Breeding, by Kevin Conley (Bloomsbury, $14.95), is an inside look at the complex, high-stakes business of breeding racehorses, an inquiry pursued with relentless curiosity and good humor. ''His touch is light, sure and charming, and his style is clear and intelligent,'' Barich wrote.   Scott Veale

keywords: [{'name': 'persons', 'value': 'Olafsson, Olaf', 'rank': 1, 'major': 'N'}, {'name': 'subject', 'value': 'Reviews', 'rank': 2, 'major': 'N'}, {'name': 'subject', 'value': 'Books and Literature', 'rank': 3, 'major': 'N'}, {'name': 'creative_works', 'value': 'WALKING INTO THE NIGHT (BOOK)', 'rank': 4, 'major': 'N'}]
snippet: Samina Ali reviews book Walking Into the Night by Olaf Olafsson; drawing (M)
lead_paragraph: Olaf Olafsson's quietly moving new novel, WALKING INTO THE NIGHT (Pantheon, $23), is the story of Kristjan Benediktsson, a successful businessman in Iceland who, one night, packs his bag and deserts his wife and children for an actress in New York. The novel opens years later in San Simeon, William Randolph Hearst's fabulous estate on the California coast, where a guilt-ridden Kristjan -- now Christian -- is the butler to Hearst himself. Though it is unclear whether Kristjan renamed himself, his deep yearning to be unshackled from his past -- relatively poor parents, a lack of education, a sense of inferiority -- is palpable. Through letters he never sends to his abandoned wife, we learn that he first reinvented himself, earlier in life, in Copenhagen, where as a young man he waited on tables and cleaned classrooms. He meets his wife there and, from the start, Kristjan feels that in her presence he ''never knew which leg to stand on.'' He lies and tells her that he is working toward his business degree. They wed in Iceland, where Kristjan confronts who he truly is, and the pretenses on which he has built his life ultimately cause him to flee. He eventually lands in San Simeon, and even as he tries to ward off his memories by consuming himself in the details of caring for Hearst's castle, he is like one of the caged animals on the property: a sad and displaced prisoner. Olafsson, who writes in English -- he is the founder and former president and C.E.O. of Sony Interactive Entertainment -- based this novel on a true story. It is an evocative tale of grief and hope. Samina Ali
abstract: Samina Ali reviews book Walking Into the Night by Olaf Olafsson; drawing (M)

snippet: Unknown
lead_paragraph: THE FEAST OF THE GOAT, by Mario Vargas Llosa. (Picador USA, $14.) Loads of bad guys stomp, sneak and scheme their way through this novel about Gen. Rafael Trujillo, the dictator of the Dominican Republic for 30 years, and those jousting to fill his boots after his assassination in 1961. ''Trujillo is a riveting creation -- a corked volcano of vulgar, self-pitying rage,'' Walter Kirn wrote in the Book Review in 2001. He is ''a Nietzschean vampire, sucking up others' wills into his own.''
abstract: THE FEAST OF THE GOAT, by Mario Vargas Llosa. (Picador USA, $14.) Loads of bad guys stomp, sneak and scheme their way through this novel about Gen. Rafael Trujillo, the dictator of the Dominican Republic for 30 years, and those jousting to fill his boots after his assassination in 1961. ''Trujillo is a riveting creation -- a corked volcano of vulgar, self-pitying rage,'' Walter Kirn wrote in the Book Review in 2001. He is ''a Nietzschean vampire, sucking up others' wills into his own.''    THE AGE OF HOMESPUN: Objects and Stories in the Creation of an American Myth, by Laurel Thatcher Ulrich. (Vintage, $16.) A Harvard historian uses 14 objects -- including baskets, spinning wheels, a yarn winder, a rug and a tablecloth -- as documents to explore the cultural history of a pastoral, preindustrial era whose virtues were simplicity, self-reliance and domestic harmony. ''Ulrich is a supremely gifted scholar and writer'' and ''a hugely accomplished prose stylist,'' John Demos said here last year.    TROUBLES, by J. G. Farrell. (New York Review, $16.95.) Returning to Ireland after World War I to reclaim his fiancée, Maj. Brendan Archer turns up at her family's once-grand seaside hotel, whose pervasive decay and menagerie of peculiar souls echo the Irish ''troubles'' of 1919. Every character in this 1971 novel is ''a gargoyle of exquisite detail,'' Martin Levin wrote in these pages. The result is ''a garden of original delights.''    POEMS SEVEN: New and Complete Poetry, by Alan Dugan. (Seven Stories, $18.95.) Winner of a National Book Award, this large collection of verse displays Dugan's stubborn, unornamented determination to be truthful, ''to walk out bravely into the daily accident.'' His great lyric theme is human pettiness exposed yet dignified by mortality. ''Dugan's remarkable achievement is to see into mean or mundane materials with all the profundity and force of poetry,'' Robert Pinsky said here last year.    THE FUTURE OF IDEAS: The Fate of the Commons in a Connected World, by Lawrence Lessig. (Vintage, $15.) A law professor argues that America's concern with copyright protection has become an oppressive obsession that silences creative expression and undermines the innovative potential of the Internet. Last year in these pages, Daniel Zalewski called this ''a manifesto that shakes you up, making you aware of how much is lost when a culture turns 'ideas' into 'intellectual property.' ''    LUCKY, by Alice Sebold. (Back Bay/Little, Brown, $11.95.) Before reaching the best-seller list with her first novel, ''The Lovely Bones,'' the author wrote this harrowing memoir about her rape as a freshman at Syracuse University, and her struggle to recover from the attack and its aftermath. ''Told with mettle and intelligence, Sebold's story of fierce determination to wrest back her life from her rapist will inspire and challenge,'' one critic wrote in 1999.    THIS ORGANIC LIFE: Confessions of a Suburban Homesteader, by Joan Dye Gussow. (Chelsea Green, $16.95.) A respected health writer and passionate believer in locally grown foods recounts her efforts to reclaim the gardens of an overgrown property she bought with her husband (who died in the midst of their labors) on the banks of the Hudson River. Her account ''has an uncommon depth of feeling,'' Verlyn Klinkenborg said in these pages last year. ''There is something happily, almost chaotically jumbled -- and thus lifelike -- about the way this book proceeds: a flood, a recipe, a death, a recipe, a community garden, a recipe.''    FIERCE PAJAMAS: An Anthology of Humor Writing From The New Yorker. Edited by David Remnick and Henry Finder. (Modern Library, $14.95.) From E. B. White, James Thurber and Groucho Marx to Garrison Keillor and Woody Allen, The New Yorker has a rich history of spoofs, parodies and other comic gambits. This collection is ''a complete delight from beginning to end,'' Janet Maslin wrote in The Times in 2001.    THE COLUMNIST, by Jeffrey Frank. (Harvest/Harcourt, $13.) This satirical swipe at Beltway types and the vanities that motivate them takes the shape of a fictional memoir by an insufferable columnist and TV personality who blackmails his way to power before crashing in a lurid scandal. The novel's ''greatest triumph is its narrator's voice: a brilliantly odious blend of cliché, double talk and name-dropping,'' Robert Worth said here last year.   Scott Veale

lead_paragraph: FURTHER FRIDAYS Essays, Lectures,and Other Nonfiction, 1984-94.By John Barth.Little, Brown, $27.95.
abstract:
FURTHER FRIDAYS 
Essays, Lectures,
and Other Nonfiction, 1984-94.
By John Barth.
Little, Brown, $27.95. 

 For years, the novelist John Barth has devoted his Fridays to the writing of nonfiction. "Further Fridays" offers a selection of Mr. Barth's literary essays, along with pieces exploring the mystery of writing creatively, lectures on literary theory and memoirs of those who have most influenced his life and work. The writing oscillates between the straightforward focus of the professor or literary critic immersed in textual exegesis and the self-induced (at times self-indulgent) flights of the poet's fancy. Among the more engaging entries are those tracing the influence of Spanish and Latin American fiction on Mr. Barth's own work, and one investigating the intellectual and social sources and meanings of minimalism as a major 20th-century genre.
ANDY BRUMER

snippet: Ms. Macy’s second book explores the true story of George and Willie Muse, black men in the Jim Crow South who were paraded in circuses.
lead_paragraph: As she did her prodigious reporting for “Truevine,” her second expert work of nonfiction, Beth Macy came across a shocking picture. It seemed to depict George and Willie Muse, the brothers around whom “Truevine” revolves, sitting with shackles binding their legs to their chairs. Ms. Macy glimpsed this photo during a late-night web search, but when she called it up again the next day she realized she’d been mistaken.

snippet: Unknown
lead_paragraph: THE ALDO MORO MURDER CASE By Richard Drake. Illustrated. 318 pp. Cambridge, Mass.: Harvard University Press. $45. ON the morning of March 16, 1978, Aldo Moro, the leader of the Christian Democratic Party, headed off to Parliament for the inauguration of the first Italian Government to be actively supported by the Communist Party. It was the beginning of the "historic compromise" between left and right of which Moro himself was the chief architect. But before he could reach Parliament, a squad of Red Brigades terrorists blocked his motorcade, murdered his five bodyguards and spirited him off to a so-called people's prison in a Rome apartment. Fifty-five days later, after the Italian Government refused to negotiate for Moro's release, the Red Brigades executed him and placed his dead body in the trunk of a car abandoned halfway between the headquarters of the Christian Democratic and Communist parties.
abstract: THE ALDO MORO MURDER CASE By Richard Drake. Illustrated. 318 pp. Cambridge, Mass.: Harvard University Press. $45.    ON the morning of March 16, 1978, Aldo Moro, the leader of the Christian Democratic Party, headed off to Parliament for the inauguration of the first Italian Government to be actively supported by the Communist Party. It was the beginning of the "historic compromise" between left and right of which Moro himself was the chief architect. But before he could reach Parliament, a squad of Red Brigades terrorists blocked his motorcade, murdered his five bodyguards and spirited him off to a so-called people's prison in a Rome apartment. Fifty-five days later, after the Italian Government refused to negotiate for Moro's release, the Red Brigades executed him and placed his dead body in the trunk of a car abandoned halfway between the headquarters of the Christian Democratic and Communist parties.

byline: {'original': 'By Claire Messud', 'person': [{'firstname': 'Claire', 'middlename': None, 'lastname': 'Messud', 'qualifier': None, 'title': None, 'role': 'reported', 'organization': '', 'rank': 1}], 'organization': None}
keywords: [{'name': 'subject', 'value': 'Books and Literature', 'rank': 1, 'major': 'N'}]
snippet: In Dalia Sofer’s first novel, a father is separated from his Jewish family in Iran shortly after the revolution.
lead_paragraph: A memorable title will surely attract readers, but when a book becomes a classic, it’s hard to say whether the title has been part of its canonization or has merely become retroactively canonical. Would “Trimalchio in West Egg,” one of Fitzgerald’s initial choices, have in time accrued the same force as “The Great Gatsby”? “The Septembers of Shiraz,” poignant once you’ve read this first novel by Dalia Sofer, is, on its own, a title at once overly poetic and misleading. An American reader might be forgiven for thinking Sofer has written a romance set in the Napa Valley, “Sideways” with Vaseline on the lens. And that would be a great shame because “The Septembers of Shiraz” is a remarkable debut: the richly evocative, powerfully affecting depiction of a prosperous Jewish family in Tehran shortly after the revolution. In this fickle literary world, it’s impossible to predict whether Sofer’s novel will become a classic, but it certainly stands a chance.

keywords: [{'name': 'persons', 'value': 'Swanson, James L', 'rank': 1, 'major': 'N'}, {'name': 'persons', 'value': 'Grogan, John', 'rank': 2, 'major': 'N'}, {'name': 'subject', 'value': 'Books and Literature', 'rank': 3, 'major': 'N'}]
snippet: DOG'S LIFE: John Grogan's ''Marley & Me,'' about the misadventures of ''the world's worst dog,'' and James L. Swanson's ''Manhunt,'' about the search for Lincoln's assassin, continue to move serious units -- Grogan's book is No. 1 on the hardcover...
lead_paragraph: DOG'S LIFE: John Grogan's "Marley & Me," about the misadventures of "the world's worst dog," and James L. Swanson's "Manhunt," about the search for Lincoln's assassin, continue to move serious units -- Grogan's book is No. 1 on the hardcover nonfiction list for the sixth consecutive week, and Swanson's is No. 4. Careful students of the best-seller list won't be surprised: dog books and Lincoln books are longtime regulars on this page. (Asked to come up with a surefire best-seller title, the Random House co-founder Bennett Cerf is said to have replied: "Lincoln's Doctor's Dog.") As it happens, the Book Review hasn't reviewed Grogan's book, or Swanson's. Why not? The long answer: Both books were read carefully by editors here, and their merits were weighed against the hundreds of other books we receive each month. The short answer: We get a lot of books about dogs and Lincoln. I finally bought a copy of "Marley & Me" last week, not long after my son's puppy ate, in two sickening gulps, the decomposed body of a car-flattened squirrel. (I wanted to see if Marley could top that -- the answer, basically, is yep.) The prose in Grogan's book is as friendly and as sloppy -- and, ultimately, as annoying -- as a golden retriever who won't get his head out of your lap. It's easy to see why some of Grogan's colleagues at The Philadelphia Inquirer, where he is a columnist, are puzzled about, and envious of, his success. (Philadelphia magazine recently printed a story about Grogan filled with mean, and unattributed, comments from his co-workers about his "cutesy-poo" writing.) Grogan is having the last laugh, however. More than a million copies of "Marley & Me" are in print, and film rights have been sold to the producer of "Dude, Where's My Car?"

snippet: Jennifer 8. Lee’s obsession with Chinese food takes her on a three-year, 23-country odyssey.
lead_paragraph: Chinese restaurants are more American than apple pie, says Jennifer 8. Lee in “The Fortune Cookie Chronicles: Adventures in the World of Chinese Food.” There are twice as many of these restaurants as there are McDonald’s franchises, and the food they serve is every bit as predictable. “What Chinese restaurant menu doesn’t offer beef with broccoli, sesame chicken, roast pork lo mein, fried wontons, egg rolls and egg drop soup?” asks the author, an “American-born Chinese” who cheerfully admits to an obsession with Chinese restaurants.

snippet: Unknown
lead_paragraph: CULT BASEBALL PLAYERS: The Greats, the Flakes, the Weird, and the Wonderful. Edited by Danny Peary. (Fireside/Simon & Schuster, Paper, $9.95.) Bait-and-switch alert: Willie Mays is not a cult baseball player. Neither are Babe Ruth, Mickey Mantle, Duke Snider, Ted Williams, Henry Aaron or Lou Gehrig, though all appear in ''Cult Baseball Players,'' an uneven collection of 60 hero-worshiping essays by writers of large and small repute. The title whets the appetite for an anthology flush with one-game wonders, flamboyant flameouts, assorted oddballs and box-score cameos; the subtitle backs off that promise, allowing the aforementioned Hall of Famers to horn in. In fact, the only one-game wonder in the book is one of the writers: Larry Colton, who pitched two innings for the Philadelphia Phillies in 1968. But yes, the expected eccentrics do make the lineup: blunderful Marv Throneberry, Dick (Dr. Strangeglove) Stuart, Mark (The Bird) Fidrych, the minor-league fireballer Steve Dalkowski, the backward baserunner Jimmy Piersall, the starlet-struck Bo Belinsky, the catcher turned World War II spy Moe Berg. The best profiles establish a personal connection between writer and subject. The Washington Post sportswriter Thomas Boswell enjoyed two unblemished encounters with his hero, Roy Sievers. The film director John Sayles tells why he adopted Dick Stuart as his soul mate in fielding futility. The actor John Lithgow says he ''first encountered the entire concept of 'biceps' in connection with Big Klu,'' the sleeveless Cincinnati slugger Ted Kluszewski. The book's editor, Danny Peary, the author of ''Cult Movies,'' waxes long-winded about his own idol, Vic Power, then appends a 22-page transcript of an interview he did with the slick-fielding first baseman. Mr. Power's comments on life as a black-skinned Puerto Rican big-leaguer in the 1950's make some of the best reading in the book. They will enlighten a generation of fans who never saw him play. They don't, however, make him a cult baseball player.
abstract: LEAD:    CULT BASEBALL PLAYERS: The Greats, the Flakes, the Weird, and the Wonderful. Edited by Danny Peary. (Fireside/Simon & Schuster, Paper, $9.95.) Bait-and-switch alert: Willie Mays is not a cult baseball player. Neither are Babe Ruth, Mickey Mantle, Duke Snider, Ted Williams, Henry Aaron or Lou Gehrig, though all appear in ''Cult Baseball Players,'' an uneven collection of 60 hero-worshiping essays by writers of large and small repute.

headline: {'main': 'And Bear In Mind', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'And Bear In Mind', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}
byline: {'original': None, 'person': [], 'organization': None}
snippet: Unknown
lead_paragraph: (Editors' choices of other recent books of particular interest)
abstract: (Editors' choices of other recent books of particular interest)    BY THE LAKE, by John McGahern. (Knopf, $24.) The sixth novel in 40 years of careful, lapidary production by this elegant Irish writer concerns the passage of a year in an unnamed Irish village, a couple who have returned to it, and a community for which the biggest event of the year is the arrival of a telephone pole.    WHAT KIND OF NATION: Thomas Jefferson, John Marshall, and the Epic Struggle to Create a United States, by James F. Simon. (Simon & Schuster, $27.50.) A professor of law examines the angry dialogue of several decades between Jefferson, who thought the 13 colonies made 13 sovereignties, and Marshall, who thought the Constitution made them one.    A MULTITUDE OF SINS: Stories, by Richard Ford. (Knopf, $25.) Quite a few wrongs are done in these elegantly worded stories, although what prevails is generally adultery, often depicted at the end of an affair or later, when it's too late to throw those dice again.    OAXACA JOURNAL, by Oliver Sacks. (National Geographic, $20.) An organized excursion for fern lovers became a discovery of Mexico for the endlessly curious Dr. Sacks, first shocked by the third-world poverty of rural Mexico, then entirely absorbed in the visit to another time provided by its pre-Hispanic remains.    THE DOCTOR'S HOUSE, by Ann Beattie. (Scribner, $24.) Does less of minimalism mean more of something else? Beattie's novel explores at length, in a prose that owes much to the language of therapy, a fraught relationship between a 40-ish woman whose husband is dead and her brother, a flagrant womanizer.    ATONEMENT, by Ian McEwan. (Nan A. Talese/Doubleday, $26.) The idyllic situation of an English family in 1935 disintegrates, starting with a crime; World War II is no help either in this novel by a writer who has the power to convey obsession and also to step outside and see how obsession looks to others.    AT SWIM, TWO BOYS, by Jamie O'Neill. (Scribner, $28.) Two great causes -- free Ireland and a free gay nation -- coincide in this polished but energetic novel built on the hazards of love, heroism, history and tenderness, and placed in political and moral history by the Easter Rising of 1916.    2182 KHZ, by David Masiel. (Random House, $22.95.) A confidently anarchic first novel whose title refers to the international distress channel for mariners in trouble; most of it happens at sea, off Alaska's North Slope, and the chief victim of the happenings is a likable unfortunate who has spent a decade working the Arctic and becomes the only survivor of a disaster wrought by a captain who screams at his crew, ''Do Things!''    SOLDIERS: Fighting Men's Lives, 1901-2001, by Philip Ziegler. (Knopf, $26.) Ziegler, well known as a biographer of royalty and celebrities, concentrates here on the ashes of empire by talking to residents of London's Royal Hospital Chelsea, veterans of Britain's wars from Flanders to Cyprus and Aden, men who had little to lose in life and little to gain but whose fidelity never came into question.

snippet: Cristina García’s novel is about estrangement — geographic, cultural and political.
lead_paragraph: In her first three novels, including her marvelous debut, “Dreaming in Cuban,” Cristina García amply demonstrated her literary gifts, delineating fine gradations of love and hatred, madness and obsession, while juggling multiple narratives. Although she demonstrated a fondness for excess and magic, her stories remained firmly grounded in the insistent claims of the body — and in the recent history of her native country, Cuba. Her characters — whether good or bad, in exile or in Havana — also remained strongly linked to that small island nation.

snippet: Andrea Higbie reviews Hidden in Plain View: The Secret Story of Quilts and the Underground Railroad, by Jacqueline L Tobin and Raymond G Dobard; photo (S)
lead_paragraph: In HIDDEN IN PLAIN VIEW: The Secret Story of Quilts and the Underground Railroad (Doubleday, $27.50), Jacqueline L. Tobin and Raymond G. Dobard present the fascinating theory that slaves created quilts coded with patterns to help one another flee to freedom. Though Quakers and other congregations, black fraternal organizations and American Indians helped slaves to escape, Tobin and Dobard state that ''far from being passive victims waiting to be rescued, enslaved blacks never ceased in their struggle for freedom.'' What seemed to be their simple quilting was much more: ''Since it was the law that slaves were not allowed to be taught to read or write, other methods were needed to insure successful efforts for escape.'' Quilts were set out in windows or on fences in front of slave cabins to signal trustworthy slaves to take particular actions. Despite its clunky academic writing and the lack of a much-needed index, ''Hidden in Plain View'' is mesmerizing. In 1994 in the Old Marketplace of Charleston, S.C., Tobin met an elderly black quilter, Ozella McDaniel Williams, who alluded to the role of quilts in the underground railroad to freedom. Tobin, who teaches women's studies at the University of Denver, and Dobard, a quilter and art history professor at Howard University, devoted themselves to cracking the code of the quilts. The Underground Railroad Quilt Code, they write, comprises 10 patterns. The Monkey Wrench pattern quilt, for instance, told slaves to begin their escape preparations by collecting tools for their journey; the Tumbling Boxes pattern indicated that it was time for ''packing up and moving on.'' Five square knots indicated distance and invoked the protection of God and the ancestors, something the slaves needed most of all. Andrea Higbie
abstract: Andrea Higbie reviews Hidden in Plain View: The Secret Story of Quilts and the Underground Railroad, by Jacqueline L Tobin and Raymond G Dobard; photo (S)

keywords: [{'name': 'persons', 'value': 'BERNAU, GEORGE', 'rank': 1, 'major': 'N'}, {'name': 'subject', 'value': 'BOOK REVIEWS', 'rank': 2, 'major': 'N'}, {'name': 'creative_works', 'value': 'CANDLE IN THE WIND (BOOK)', 'rank': 3, 'major': 'N'}]
snippet: Unknown
lead_paragraph: CANDLE IN THE WIND. By George Bernau. (Warner, $19.95.) If dragging defenseless Marilyn Monroe's already tattered reputation further down in a sleazy sex novel is your idea of reading fun, then George Bernau's second novel may be for you. ''Candle in the Wind is a work of fiction,'' says the author's note. ''Although it is set in what may seem to some readers as a recognizable historical context, its characters - their actions, dialogue and motivations as portrayed by the novel - are entirely imaginary.'' Oh sure; all fiction. Marilyn, the blond sex goddess who is found near death in her Brentwood, Calif., home in August 1962, is called Marilyn Lane. The young, handsome President of the United States is John (Jack) Kerrigan. The Attorney General is his younger brother Tommy, and their Hollywood connection is their brother-in-law, the British-born, alcoholic actor Paul Townsend. It is Townsend who finds Marilyn as she lies dying of an apparent drug overdose; he hires a private eye, Frank Galvan, ostensibly to learn who might have wanted her dead. Galvan and Marilyn (who, thanks to Galvan, has miraculously survived) then set off on a global junket that involves the C.I.A., Chicago Mafiosi and the occupants of the White House, as well as a plot to overthrow the American Government - and, of course, the requisite dose of mostly gratuitous sex. Mr. Bernau, a lawyer and a former film executive, is a proponent of the smash cut; his intricate plot shifts back and forth so fast that one might as well be reading 3-by-5 cards. All this would provide harmless escapism if it were not for the book's ethical ramifications. Even writers are entitled to make a buck, but to do so by exploiting someone who was so troubled is distasteful. Those wishing to read something trenchant about Marilyn Monroe should turn instead to Simone Signoret's memoir, ''Nostalgia Isn't What It Used to Be.'' The French actress, a powerful writer, was married to the actor Yves Montand, who was for a time one of Monroe's lovers.
abstract: LEAD:    CANDLE IN THE WIND. By George Bernau. (Warner, $19.95.) If dragging defenseless Marilyn Monroe's already tattered reputation further down in a sleazy sex novel is your idea of reading fun, then George Bernau's second novel may be for you. ''Candle in the Wind is a work of fiction,'' says the author's note.

snippet: Memoirs by Deborah Mitford and Ivana Lowell, women of very different generations, have some overlap in the famous-names department.
lead_paragraph: As a girl Deborah Mitford weathered the Great Depression with her parents and was forced to leave Swinbrook House, the Oxfordshire manse that she loved. “I minded more than I can say,” she says about this transition. At Swinbrook “the woods belonged to my father and we never met a soul.” At a more modest family home, Old Mill Cottage in High Wycombe, outside London, the Mitfords had to take walks on footpaths that were open to the public.

snippet: David Leavitt, who was born in 1961, got off to an early start as a writer of fiction. At 20, he published his first story in The New Yorker; when he was 23, his first collection, ''Family Dancing'' (1984), put him at the forefront of a new genera...
lead_paragraph: David Leavitt, who was born in 1961, got off to an early start as a writer of fiction. At 20, he published his first story in The New Yorker; when he was 23, his first collection, "Family Dancing" (1984), put him at the forefront of a new generation of writers. Like many of Leavitt's subsequent books, "Family Dancing" dealt with homosexuality, and in this week's issue he contributes an essay about the demise of many of this country's gay bookstores. The buying and selling of gay-themed books has come a long way in two decades, he said in a telephone interview. "When I was growing up in Northern California, there was -- and still is -- a great bookstore in Menlo Park called Kepler's, and it had a gay shelf tucked way in the back of the store. I remember sneaking back there, very furtively, and I was always terrified someone would see me. There was a lot of anxiety and fear about these books, particularly for a young person, even in California in the 1970's. It's hard to believe how much things have changed." Leavitt, who lives in Gainesville, Fla., and teaches creative writing at the University of Florida, said that, on some level, gay bookstores have simply become irrelevant. "These stores no longer serve the function they once did. They were community centers, they were sources of information. These days, young readers are more likely to seek out community -- and books -- on the Internet." The Editors
abstract: David Leavitt, who was born in 1961, got off to an early start as a writer of fiction. At 20, he published his first story in The New Yorker; when he was 23, his first collection, ''Family Dancing'' (1984), put him at the forefront of a new generation of writers. Like many of Leavitt's subsequent books, ''Family Dancing'' dealt with homosexuality, and in this week's issue he contributes an essay about the demise of many of this country's gay bookstores. The buying and selling of gay-themed books has come a long way in two decades, he said in a telephone interview. ''When I was growing up in Northern California, there was -- and still is -- a great bookstore in Menlo Park called Kepler's, and it had a gay shelf tucked way in the back of the store. I remember sneaking back there, very furtively, and I was always terrified someone would see me. There was a lot of anxiety and fear about these books, particularly for a young person, even in California in the 1970's. It's hard to believe how much things have changed.'' Leavitt, who lives in Gainesville, Fla., and teaches creative writing at the University of Florida, said that, on some level, gay bookstores have simply become irrelevant. ''These stores no longer serve the function they once did. They were community centers, they were sources of information. These days, young readers are more likely to seek out community -- and books -- on the Internet.''   The Editors    On the Web    Featured Author: A retrospective on the career of John Irving, the author of ''Until I Find You.''

headline: {'main': 'And Bear In Mind', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'And Bear In Mind', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}
byline: {'original': None, 'person': [], 'organization': None}
snippet: Unknown
lead_paragraph: (Editors' choices of other recent books of particular interest)
abstract: (Editors' choices of other recent books of particular interest)    THE PIECES FROM BERLIN, by Michael Pye. (Knopf, $24.) A tough, mature, difficult but brilliantly paced novel in which a woman in Nazi Berlin accepts Jews' valuable possessions to safeguard them, then appropriates them and slopes off to Switzerland. Nemesis arrives 60 years later when a woman spots a piece of family furniture.    PROPERTY, by Valerie Martin. (Nan A. Talese/Doubleday, $23.95.) In and around antebellum New Orleans, this novel turns on sexual rivalry and power struggle among a boorish planter, his enraged wife, who hates him, and a beautiful, accomplished slave woman who belongs to the wife but has borne a child to the husband.    ANY HUMAN HEART, by William Boyd. (Knopf, $24.95.) A novel whose hero, a minor British writer and art dealer (and secret agent), becomes a sort of stoic Everyman for the 20th century, meeting almost everyone (Ian Fleming, Picasso, Hemingway, the Duke of Windsor, Virginia Woolf) and traveling to almost everywhere; he has many successes in life, each one closely attended by yet another fall.    THE INQUISITORS' MANUAL, by António Lobo Antunes. (Grove, $25.) Portugal's long fascist regime haunts this novel as it anatomizes a society permeated by meanness and arrogance; the fall of the regime happens over and over from the viewpoints of many characters, each of them complementing or contradicting the rest.    DROP CITY, by T. Coraghessan Boyle. (Viking, $25.95.) This novel's late-blooming hippies in a Northern California commune, sensing that the end is near (or maybe even behind them), migrate to Alaska, where they encounter some tough real isolates who wonder aloud about the virtues of face paint and LSD.    CLARA, by Janice Galloway. (Simon & Schuster, $25.) The virtuoso pianist Clara Schumann (wife of the composer Robert, mother of eight) left 47 volumes of diaries. Undaunted, Galloway imagines a way into Clara's life in this novel whose up-to-date concerns do not obstruct its heroine's passionate voice.    JARHEAD: A Marine's Chronicle of the Gulf War and Other Battles, by Anthony Swofford. (Scribner, $24.) A hair-raising memoir that captures the hilarity, tedium and loneliness of the prewar deployment, followed by the appalling, astonishing experience of combat itself, in which terror and joy were one.    THE GROWING SEASONS: An American Boyhood Before the War, by Samuel Hynes. (Viking, $24.95.) A memoir, by the author of ''Flights of Passage,'' of his Midwestern youth, in which he trained to be a man by being first a boy; it ends with the 18-year-old Hynes saying farewell to his father and waiting for the train that will carry him to war.    IRVING HOWE: A Life of Passionate Dissent, by Gerald Sorin. (New York University, $32.95.) A life of the eminent critic and socialist who died in 1993, after a youth of rigid Trotskyism and a maturity that widened his perspectives but preserved his intensity intact.
