snippet: Unknown
lead_paragraph: JOYCE ANN BROWN: Justice Denied. By Joyce Ann Brown with Jay Gaines. (Noble Press, 213 West Institute Place, Suite 508, Chicago, Ill. 60610, Paper, $11.95.) In 1980, Joyce Ann Brown walked into a nightmare from which she did not emerge for nine years. Arrested and convicted of robbery and murder in connection with the holdup of a Dallas furrier, Ms. Brown was sentenced to life imprisonment. That she was innocent, that co-workers testified that she was at work during the crime, counted for nothing. The furrier's wife identified Ms. Brown in a lineup as one of two black women who had robbed the store and killed her husband; during her trial, an inmate Ms. Brown had befriended in jail after her arrest testified that Ms. Brown had bragged to her about the robbery. An all-white jury convicted Ms. Brown despite inconsistencies in testimony and a lack of fingerprints and other evidence linking her to the crime. In ''Joyce Ann Brown: Justice Denied,'' Ms. Brown and the freelance writer Jay Gaines outline her life before and during prison, the banal indignities guaranteed to dehumanize prisoners, and her survival through faith in God and a constant assertion of her innocence. Readers get a kind of crash course in life in a women's prison; what Ms. Brown does not voice is an obviously very controlled woman's inner feelings about being caught in a sinkhole in the justice system. Only once, when she is waiting to hear the verdict that will put her in prison for nine years, does she reveal her feelings: ''They wanted to find me guilty. I could see it in their eyes. I saw hatred for me on their faces.'' The Texas Court of Criminal Appeals overturned Ms. Brown's conviction in 1989, after her lawyers filed a writ alleging that prosecutors suppressed evidence and presented perjured testimony. Eventually, charges were dropped and Joyce Ann Brown was a free woman - minus nearly a decade of her life taken from her by the State of Texas.

snippet: A German scholar argues that Muslim anti-Semitism can be traced to a project of the Nazi Party.
lead_paragraph: One day in Damascus not long ago, I visited the understocked gift shop of the Sheraton Hotel, looking for something to read. There wasn’t much: pre-owned Grishams, a hagiography of Hafez al-Assad, an early Bill O’Reilly (go figure) and a paperback copy of “The International Jew,” published in 2000 in Beirut. “The International Jew” is a collection of columns exposing the putative role of Jews in such fields as international finance, world governance and bootlegging. “Wherever the seat of power may be, thither they swarm obsequiously,” the book states. These columns, which are based on the “Protocols of the Elders of Zion”  they are a plagiary of a forgery, in other words  were first published in Henry Ford’s Dearborn Independent more than 80 years ago.

keywords: [{'name': 'subject', 'value': 'Books and Literature', 'rank': 1, 'major': 'N'}, {'name': 'subject', 'value': 'PAPERBACK BOOKS', 'rank': 2, 'major': 'N'}]
snippet: Unknown
lead_paragraph: DISAPPEARING THROUGH THE SKYLIGHT: Culture and Technology in the Twentieth Century, by O. B. Hardison Jr. (Penguin, $12.95.) Drawing on some of the most provocative new ideas in mathematics, computer science, architecture, poetry and the visual arts, the author argues that human civilization and culture are on the verge of epochal change. Last year our reviewer, Malcolm Bradbury, called this a "polymathic and brilliant new book."
abstract: DISAPPEARING THROUGH THE SKYLIGHT: Culture and Technology in the Twentieth Century, by O. B. Hardison Jr. (Penguin, $12.95.) Drawing on some of the most provocative new ideas in mathematics, computer science, architecture, poetry and the visual arts, the author argues that human civilization and culture are on the verge of epochal change. Last year our reviewer, Malcolm Bradbury, called this a "polymathic and brilliant new book."   FOUCAULT'S PENDULUM, by Umberto Eco. Translated by William Weaver. (Ballantine, $6.95.) By feeding into a computer every crank conspiracy theory they can dredge up, a group of Milanese intellectuals uncovers the conspiracy to end all conspiracies: a plot by Freemasons, Rosicrucians, Knights Templar, Jesuits, Nazis and the other usual suspects to take over the earth using a mysterious new form of energy called telluric currents. Last year our reviewer, Anthony Burgess, called this "a truly formidable gathering of information delivered playfully by a master manipulating his own invention -- in effect, a long, erudite joke. . . . If you want to know about the Gregorian calendar, or the theory that the Holy Grail is really St. Mary Magdalene, you will find it here."   THE EXAMINED LIFE: Philosophical Meditations, by Robert Nozick. (Touchstone/Simon & Schuster, $10.95.) A philosopher turns his sights to one of the most compelling questions in philosophy: what are the qualities that make for a meaningful life? "He has had the courage to think broad and large," Willard Gaylin said here last year. "What one encounters throughout 'The Examined Life' is true grit in both senses of the word."   THE CHINCHILLA FARM, by Judith Freeman. (Vintage Contemporaries, $9.95.) When her husband leaves her for a Miss Wyoming runner-up, Verna Flake turns her back on her Mormon upbringing near the Great Salt Lake and heads for Los Angeles. Last year our reviewer, Tim Sandlin, praised the novel for "an almost Tolstoyan insight into the human plight. . . . Judith Freeman has written a beautiful book, beautiful because of the compassion of Verna Flake."    LOUISE BROOKS, by Barry Paris. (Anchor/Doubleday, $14.95.) "Love is a publicity stunt," Louise Brooks, the hedonistic flapper who played Lulu in "Pandora's Box," once said. "I don't think I ever loved any man." Last year our reviewer, Neal Gabler, said this biography takes the actress much too seriously, but he found her story "frequently fascinating."   DADDY BOY, by Carey Cameron. (Ivy, $4.95.) A 10-year-old girl tells about the weird ways her life changed when her childish playboy of a father struck it rich and moved to California. Last year our reviewer, William J. Harding, called this "a restrained, modestly engaging account of growing up rich and spoiled in Hollywood in the early 1960's."   AND THE WALLS CAME TUMBLING DOWN: An Autobiography, by Ralph David Abernathy. (Harper Perennial, $12.95.) The minister who was once Martin Luther King's right-hand man gives a firsthand account of the civil rights movement. "When Mr. Abernathy sticks to accounts of his own direct involvement, his storytelling is gripping, even moving," Henry Hampton said here last year.   OBSCENE GESTURES FOR WOMEN, by Janet Kauffman. (Vintage Contemporaries, $8.95.) When these short stories, many set in the bleak flatland of the Midwest, were published in 1989, our reviewer, Robert Kelly, said he was impressed by their "spare elegance, revealing crannies full of unexpected details. A tractor ride in the dark, a woman staring idly at a city street, a wife cooling her feet in a gully -- ordinary events blossom with images that seduce the reader to mysterious destinations off the common path."   A PLACE FOR US, by Nicholas Gage. (Touchstone/ Simon & Schuster, $10.95.) The author of "Eleni" tells what happened when, after his mother was murdered by Communist guerrillas in Greece, he and his sisters moved to the United States. Last year our reviewer, Cyra McFadden, called this memoir "a warm-hearted, likable contribution to its genre."   PROFESSOR ROMEO, by Anne Bernays. (Penguin, $7.95.) A middle-aged Harvard psychology professor, with a habit of trying to seduce his students, is charged with sexual harassment. The novel is "a rewriting of the Don Juan myth, with plenty of bite, good Cambridge atmosphere and a nice line in social and emotional observation," Malcolm Bradbury said in The Book Review in 1989. It is "a work of sharp irony, standing back from making simple or fashionable judgments and taking a nicely jaundiced view of our contemporary sexual skirmishes."   TRAVELS WITH ALICE, by Calvin Trillin. (Avon, $7.95.) In these travel essays, Calvin Trillin continues his impassioned pursuit of the offbeat. "Who else would tackle every 'fastfoude' (Le Monde's term) outlet on the Champs Elysees and Boulevard St. Germain, kids in tow, to do a comparative survey of the hamburger    a l'americain   ?" Molly Haskell said here last year. "As a comic Magellan, squeezing through the straits between official culture and down-home tastes or heading once again to the Caribbean in the hopes of discovering Italian cuisine in the West Indies, Mr. Trillin is one of the classiest and funniest essay writers."   THE WIDOW'S TRIAL, by John Ehle. (Harper Perennial, $8.95.) Twenty-two years old and pregnant, a North Carolina woman named Winnette King Plover stands accused of murdering her abusive husband, Lloyd. Last year our reviewer, Richard Fuller, called this an "unusual and imaginatively narrated novel."

snippet: Marilyn Stasio reviews mysteries: Heartwood by James Lee Burke, The Devil's Teardrop by Jeffrey Deaver, The Hours of the Virgin by Loren D Estleman, Shallow Grave by Cynthia Harrod-Eagles, Saint's Rest by Keith Miles and The Wanton Angel by Miles ...
lead_paragraph: The themes that stalk Dave Robicheaux through the swamps in James Lee Burke's Louisiana mysteries -- the arrogance of wealth, the corruption of power and the price a man must pay for the sins of his past -- trail Burke's new series hero, a country lawyer named Billy Bob Holland, out to Texas hill country. HEARTWOOD (Doubleday, $24. 95) takes up the burden with a bruising narrative about the lawlessness that erupts in Deaf Smith, Tex., when Earl Deitrich, a rich, cruel man who thinks he can boss or buy everyone in town, tries to cheat a farmer out of his oil-rich land. ''Ain't right,'' one of his victims observes. ''Law punishes a poor man. Rich man don't have to account.''
abstract: Marilyn Stasio reviews mysteries: Heartwood by James Lee Burke, The Devil's Teardrop by Jeffrey Deaver, The Hours of the Virgin by Loren D Estleman, Shallow Grave by Cynthia Harrod-Eagles, Saint's Rest by Keith Miles and The Wanton Angel by Miles under pen name Edward Marston (S)

lead_paragraph: (Editors' choices of other recent books of particular interest)
abstract: (Editors' choices of other recent books of particular interest)    A PLACE IN THE COUNTRY, by Laura Shaine Cunningham. (Riverhead, $24.95.) Years of fruitless wishing for the great good place finally paid off for the author with a gracious old house upstate; her wisdom is shown by acknowledging that snakes and bad neighbors go with the territory just as flowers and moonbeams do.    BEN, IN THE WORLD: The Sequel to ''The Fifth Child,'' by Doris Lessing. (HarperCollins, $23.) This spectacularly disturbing story, about a monster born to a happy, middle-class family in England, adopts the monster's point of view; 18 and looking 40, he becomes a drug courier, an experimental subject in a nasty research institute and a disturbing relative of humans who read books.    MILLIONAIRE: The Philanderer, Gambler, and Duelist Who Invented Modern Finance, by Janet Gleeson. (Simon & Schuster, $24.) A life of John Law, the 18th-century playboy who showed Frenchmen that a piece of paper entitling its bearer to money was itself money, and who organized a speculative corporation that collapsed grandly.    A RUM AFFAIR: A True Story of Botanical Fraud, by Karl Sabbagh. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $24.) A grave and witty account of a British amateur botanist who in the late 1940's caught a professor faking evidence to suit his theory about the last ice age and the Hebridean island of Rum, then sealed his report of the fraud in his college library (it leaked anyhow).    MOUNTAIN CITY, by Gregory Martin. (North Point/Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $21.) This memoir of summers spent with the author's grandparents in the desert of northern Nevada deals with the graces of courage and humor, battered by repeated failure in a terrain that virtually forbids success.    THE QUESTION OF BRUNO, by Aleksandar Hemon. (Nan A. Talese/Doubleday, $22.95.) Mostly fictional (but who can say for sure?) stories and a novella, invoking both the terrible facts of Bosnia and Yugoslavia and the years of the author's childhood, when there was yet hope for both.    THE GENTLEMAN FROM NEW YORK. Daniel Patrick Moynihan: A Biography, by Godfrey Hodgson. (Houghton Mifflin, $38.) A life of the right's favorite liberal, or the left's favorite neocon, always intelligent, usually correct and at peace with his impending retirement; by a British journalist and longtime friend.    DRIVING MR. ALBERT: A Trip Across America With Einstein's Brain, by Michael Paterniti. (Dial, $18.95.) A journalist and the pathologist who acquired Einstein's brain in 1955 take off with it, but with no clear idea what to do with it; then they keep going for quite a while.    LITTLE SAINT, by Hannah Green. (Random House, $25.95.) An evocation of place and time that is also a spiritual biography, about the author and her husband's discovery of Conques in France on the Santiago pilgrimage route and of her growing acquaintance with St. Foy, the girl, martyred in 303, whose amazing reliquary survived the revolution.

lead_paragraph: T-BACKS, T-SHIRTS, COAT, AND SUIT. By E. L. Konigsburg. Jean Karl/Atheneum. $13.95. (Ages 9 to 13) It's summertime in this sharp, funny novel, and T-back bathing suits are the issue in the city of Peco, Fla., where Chloe is spending the season. DUMPLING SOUP. By Jama Kim Rattigan. Illustrated by Lillian Hsu-Flanders. Little, Brown. $15.95. (Ages 4 to 8) On New Year's Eve, Marisa's whole extended Asian-American family, which lives on Oahu, goes to Grandma's for dumpling soup. Since everyone loves dumplings, they have to make a lot. The ebullient story won the publisher's New Voices, New World contest. The text has a glossary of English, Hawaiian, Japanese and Korean words.

lead_paragraph: A VOICE OF ONE'S OWN: Conversations With America's Writing Women, by Mickey Pearlman and Katherine Usher Henderson. (Houghton Mifflin, $8.95.) Interviews with 28 authors, ranging from Joyce Carol Oates to Amy Tan, illuminate how these women became writers and what shapes their work. In 1990, when the book was published as "Inter/View: Talks With America's Writing Women," our reviewer, Alexandra Johnson, noted that "the merit of this collection is how it charts the passages, often circuitous, in the complex life process that finally yields the literary product."
abstract: A VOICE OF ONE'S OWN: Conversations With America's Writing Women, by Mickey Pearlman and Katherine Usher Henderson. (Houghton Mifflin, $8.95.) Interviews with 28 authors, ranging from Joyce Carol Oates to Amy Tan, illuminate how these women became writers and what shapes their work. In 1990, when the book was published as "Inter/View: Talks With America's Writing Women," our reviewer, Alexandra Johnson, noted that "the merit of this collection is how it charts the passages, often circuitous, in the complex life process that finally yields the literary product."   COLLECTED SHORT STORIES, by Aldous Huxley. (Elephant/Ivan R. Dee, $14.95.) Although probably best known for the horrifying vision of the future he created in his novel "Brave New World," Aldous Huxley was also a writer of short fiction. This collection, first published in 1957, encompasses 21 of his works. "Within a few brief pages," one critic said, "this master satirist conveys the essences of characters in revealing situations, covering a wide range of both settings and plots, from murder to ghostwriting, from 18th-century England to the 20th-century Riviera. This book is essential for all fiction collections, containing as it does all the stories in five previously published Huxley volumes."

keywords: [{'name': 'organizations', 'value': 'Associated Press', 'rank': 1, 'major': 'N'}, {'name': 'subject', 'value': 'Reviews', 'rank': 2, 'major': 'N'}, {'name': 'subject', 'value': 'Books and Literature', 'rank': 3, 'major': 'N'}, {'name': 'creative_works', 'value': 'FLASH! THE ASSOCIATED PRESS COVERS THE WORLD (BOOK)', 'rank': 4, 'major': 'N'}]
snippet: Rosemary Ranck reviews book Flash! The Associated Press Covers the World by AP staff members; photo (S)
lead_paragraph: Getting there, seizing the drama and grabbing the shot: that is what sells newspapers and attracts prizes -- in the case of The Associated Press, 25 Pulitzer prizes for photography. From Pol Pot's corpse laid out in a jungle hut to the debris of tornado-wrecked houses in Alabama, A.P. images are part of our daily fare. Since the cooperative started in 1848, technological advances have transformed news transmission into an instantaneous electronic process. But gathering the material from wars, natural disasters, and social and political upheavals remains arduous and often dangerous. Six A.P. staff members have been killed on duty during this decade alone. FLASH! The Associated Press Covers the World (The Associated Press/Abrams, $39.95) celebrates the news service's 150th anniversary with 170 photographs, introduced by the war correspondent Peter Arnett. Some of the images are among the world's best known, like Joe Rosenthal's picture of marines raising the flag at Iwo Jima during World War II. Vietnam yielded Eddie Adams's shot of the impromptu execution of a suspected Vietcong member and Huynh Cong Ut's horrific image of burned children fleeing napalm. Most images reproduced here reach for a peak moment, whether of a fiery crash or a perfect dive. So many diverse images make for a rather disjointed and unsatisfying book, and its pedestrian layout does nothing to enhance its photos. Nonetheless, the book does record much of the fury and folly of the 20th century and pays tribute to the intrepid photographers who showed up to record the spectacle. Rosemary Ranck
abstract: Rosemary Ranck reviews book Flash! The Associated Press Covers the World by AP staff members; photo (S)

snippet: ''CIVILIZATION AND ITS DISCONTENTS'' first appeared in 1930, and on the occasion of its 75th anniversary has been reissued by Norton ($19.95). A new edition of a classic text of Western culture is a happy occasion, not least because it offers the ...
lead_paragraph: "CIVILIZATION AND ITS DISCONTENTS" first appeared in 1930, and on the occasion of its 75th anniversary has been reissued by Norton ($19.95). A new edition of a classic text of Western culture is a happy occasion, not least because it offers the opportunity to debate the book's effect on the way we see the world -- or whether it has any effect at all. "Classic" can mean that an intellectual work is indisputably definitive in its realm, or it can mean that its prestige has outlived its authority and influence. Being leatherbound is sometimes synonymous with being timebound.
abstract: ''CIVILIZATION AND ITS DISCONTENTS'' first appeared in 1930, and on the occasion of its 75th anniversary has been reissued by Norton ($19.95). A new edition of a classic text of Western culture is a happy occasion, not least because it offers the opportunity to debate the book's effect on the way we see the world -- or whether it has any effect at all. ''Classic'' can mean that an intellectual work is indisputably definitive in its realm, or it can mean that its prestige has outlived its authority and influence. Being leatherbound is sometimes synonymous with being timebound.     Freud's essay rests on three arguments that are impossible to prove: the development of civilization recapitulates the development of the individual; civilization's central purpose of repressing the aggressive instinct exacts unbearable suffering; the individual is torn between the desire to live (Eros) and the wish to die (Thanatos). It is impossible to refute Freud's theses, too. All three arguments have died in the minds of many people, under the pressure of intellectual opposition, only to remain alive and well in the minds of many others. To clarify the status of Freud's influence today is to get a better sense of a central rift running through the culture we live in.

snippet: Robin Tzannes reviews book The Man Who Walked Between the Towers by Mordicai Gerstein; drawing (S)
lead_paragraph: In 1974, the aerialist Philippe Petit performed a breathtaking feat: he walked a tightrope between the towers of the World Trade Center. Mordicai Gerstein's book about this event, THE MAN WHO WALKED BETWEEN THE TOWERS (Roaring Brook, $17.95; ages 5 and up), reaches its climax with two dramatic foldout spreads. When I opened the first for a kindergarten class, the 5-year-olds gasped with amazement. In imitation of the feat itself, the stunning image took their breath away.

lead_paragraph: Fiction writers accept the notion that they follow in the footsteps of their predecessors. For travel writers, however, the metaphor suggests a serious problem. The whole point of travel writing is -- or was -- to describe a place few people have visited before.
abstract: Fiction writers accept the notion that they follow in the footsteps of their  predecessors. For travel writers, however, the metaphor suggests a serious problem. The whole point of travel writing is -- or was -- to describe a place few people have visited before.         Until quite recently, the earth offered many such places, unworked mines whose fat, tempting seams promised treasures to any brave soul with a strong back and a pick. Airplane travel and the cheap package tour put an end to all that. Now Tashkent, Nairobi and Kuala Lumpur all lie within a day's reach of New York. As Kingsley Amis pointed out in a tart little essay, travel's democratic age has spoiled things for a certain breed of writer, "the sort who for decades  had been getting away with calling Spain a harsh, bitter land" or with nattering on about "the civilization of the delicate olive at the other end of the Mediterranean."

headline: {'main': '  Living Ruins', 'kicker': 'IN SHORT: NONFICTION', 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'IN SHORT: NONFICTION;   Living Ruins', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}
byline: {'original': 'By Steve Coates', 'person': [{'firstname': 'Steve', 'middlename': None, 'lastname': 'Coates', 'qualifier': None, 'title': None, 'role': 'reported', 'organization': '', 'rank': 1}], 'organization': None}
keywords: [{'name': 'persons', 'value': 'SCHEZEN, ROBERTO', 'rank': 1, 'major': 'N'}, {'name': 'subject', 'value': 'BOOK REVIEWS', 'rank': 2, 'major': 'N'}, {'name': 'creative_works', 'value': 'VISIONS OF ANCIENT AMERICA (BOOK)', 'rank': 3, 'major': 'N'}]
snippet: Unknown
lead_paragraph: In VISIONS OF ANCIENT AMERICA (Rizzoli, $50), the photographer Roberto Schezen turns his lens on archeological sites in Mexico and Central America. The cities he records were built by Aztecs, Toltecs, Olmecs and Mayans, but it is nearly impossible to imagine human creatures living amid these desolate twilight landscapes. The ruins seem to have been set down directly out of angry skies by brutal but dazzling gods; they could be inhabited only by the jungle demons that snarl from the facades, or by hollow-eyed and solitary stone giants like those carved at Tula, north of Mexico City. The choice of a stark and coarse-grained black-and-white format is startling and paradoxical. Many of the actual sites are half-consumed by humid, emerald jungle, but the terrain of ''Visions of Ancient America'' has the luminous and cold-shadowed texture of a lunar surface. Mr. Schezen's photographs reveal three main levels of compositional interest: on the smallest scale, the tantalizingly elusive patterns formed by masses of repeated three-dimensional shapes, often of stylized plant and animal form; the almost miraculous resolution of that intricate tangle into the large and simple geometries that form the individual monuments, and, finally, the numinous symbiosis of architecture, sky and horizon. The mode of presentation - site by site, with diagrams and thumbnail historical sketches - seems to be a sly wink at those collections of photographs of classical Roman ruins that exude a mysterious drama despite the scholarly intentions of their authors. Mr. Schezen, who lives and works in Milan, is surely familiar with that tradition, but his purpose is far from scientific. Even the names of those forlorn cities - Sayil, Tikal, Uxmal, Yaxchilan, Teotihuacan - echo the photographs' haunting esthetic, which like the architecture itself is shockingly alien to the Western classical tradition.
abstract: LEAD: In VISIONS OF ANCIENT AMERICA (Rizzoli, $50), the photographer Roberto Schezen turns his lens on archeological sites in Mexico and Central America. The cities he records were built by Aztecs, Toltecs, Olmecs and Mayans, but it is nearly impossible to imagine human creatures living amid these desolate twilight landscapes.

snippet: In Dermot Bolger’s fiercely beautiful novel, a group of young suburban Dubliners can’t get a grip on what it means to be Irish anymore.
lead_paragraph: “We came from nowhere and found we belonged nowhere else,” says Francis Hanrahan, the troubled young hero of Dermot Bolger’s fiercely beautiful novel “The Journey Home.” The nowhere he’s referring to is the Dublin suburb he reluctantly, often bitterly, calls home. Francis  who occasionally goes by “Francy,” more frequently by “Hano”  lives there sometimes with his parents and sometimes with his rakish pal, Shay, who likes to refer to the youth of this grim town as “the children of limbo.” Nowhere? Limbo? What ever happened to the Old Sod, the homeland cherished in the romantic imaginations of Irish emigrants to the United States, England, the Continent, wherever in the world they go? Is it nowhere John Wayne comes back to in “The Quiet Man,” for pity’s sake?

snippet: Nick Hornby’s “Juliet, Naked” is a taste-based comedy that revolves around a reclusive American singer-songwriter from the 1980s.
lead_paragraph: Nick Hornby’s “Juliet, Naked” is a taste-based comedy that revolves around a reclusive American singer-songwriter from the 1980s. His name is Tucker Crowe, and he has inspired a small but disproportionately rabid band of followers. One such Crowologist is a middle-aged Englishman named Duncan. The novel begins with Duncan on a fact-finding expedition to Minneapolis, where he makes a pilgrimage to the bathroom that Crowe visited on a night that apparently changed his life.

snippet: Arnold Rampersad turns his lens on Ralph Ellison, who was trapped in a monster of a novel he must have known deep down he would never bring home.
lead_paragraph: Ralph Ellison burned out as an artist under excruciating circumstances. His failure to complete a second novel after his landmark book, “Invisible Man,” exploded onto the scene in 1952 was already a source of pain just six years later, when he wrote to Saul Bellow about having a “writer’s block as big as the Ritz.” His suffering intensified as the years rolled by and contemporaries like Bellow (Ellison’s onetime housemate), John Cheever and Bernard Malamud all capitalized on their talents and moved on into prolific maturity. His predicament was worsened by the feeling that he had failed not only himself but the broader black society whose aesthetic he had hoped to champion in a great book that would rival “Moby-Dick.”

snippet: Why has Goldman Sachs survived as its peers crumble around it? In this corporate history, Charles D. Ellis credits its culture.
lead_paragraph: SAVVY investors relish “pairs trading.” They pick two companies in similar businesses, like Nike and Reebok. Then they buy shares of the one judged to be a better value, while making an equal-size bet against the weaker one. Get it right, and tidy profits ensue.

snippet: ALOFT, by Chang-rae Lee. (Riverhead, $14.) Set in the newer developments and subdivisions of Long Island, Lee's third novel is an affecting tale of one man's disaffection with the American dream. Approaching his 60th birthday, Lee's affable, semir...
lead_paragraph: ALOFT, by Chang-rae Lee. (Riverhead, $14.) Set in the newer developments and subdivisions of Long Island, Lee's third novel is an affecting tale of one man's disaffection with the American dream. Approaching his 60th birthday, Lee's affable, semiretired hero, Jerry Battle (descended from Battaglias), faces a series of family crises and is shadowed by the mental illness and early death of his Korean-American wife. Piloting a small plane aimlessly over the Long Island Sound is Jerry's only escape from life's complications. "Lee has dreamed up an intricate, ingratiating character" in this "large-spirited American novel," A. O. Scott wrote in the Book Review.
abstract: ALOFT, by Chang-rae Lee. (Riverhead, $14.) Set in the newer developments and subdivisions of Long Island, Lee's third novel is an affecting tale of one man's disaffection with the American dream. Approaching his 60th birthday, Lee's affable, semiretired hero, Jerry Battle (descended from Battaglias), faces a series of family crises and is shadowed by the mental illness and early death of his Korean-American wife. Piloting a small plane aimlessly over the Long Island Sound is Jerry's only escape from life's complications. ''Lee has dreamed up an intricate, ingratiating character'' in this ''large-spirited American novel,'' A. O. Scott wrote in the Book Review.    NAME ALL THE ANIMALS: A Memoir, by Alison Smith. (Scribner, $13.) In 1984, when Smith was 15, her adored older brother was killed in a car accident. The author's graceful memoir captures her family's grief, the wavering of her faith and the rift this caused in a deeply religious home.

snippet: Unknown
lead_paragraph: The Last King of Scotland
abstract: The Last King of Scotland   By Giles Foden. Vintage International, $13.    Nicholas Garrigan, a young Scottish doctor in the employ of the Ugandan dictator Idi Amin, is anything but heroic: he's weak and indecisive and easily manipulated. ''Therein lies the admirable risk'' of this ambitious first novel, Michael Upchurch wrote here last year, and despite the doctor's moral failings he emerges as an oddly sympathetic protagonist.    At Home With the Marquis de Sade: A Life   By Francine du Plessix Gray. Penguin, $14.95.    Talk about standing by your man: Renee-Pelagie de Montreuil de Sade, the wife of the legendary 18th-century sexual rogue, persevered through sex scandals, police raids and prison terms (the marquis spent 15 of the 27 years they were married in jail or on the run). In fact he might never have written a word had it not been for her saintly servitude, according to this biography, which effectively defangs Sade while suggesting that perhaps a bit of the scoundrel's unfettered narcissism lurks deep in every psyche. The result is a ''bold, imaginative'' book, Emily Eakin wrote in these pages in 1998.    The Tale of the 1002nd Night   By Joseph Roth. Picador USA, $14.    The Austrian writer's final work of fiction, published in 1939, is an erotic fairy tale set in Hapsburg Vienna, featuring the shah of Persia and a string of pearls that dooms everyone who gets near them. Last year our reviewer, Iain Bamforth, praised Roth's ''wonderful style . . . for the way it plunges us into the swim of time.''    The Bible as It Was  By James L. Kugel.   Belknap/Harvard University, $19.95.    The author draws on diverse sources to explain how the Torah, the first five books of the Bible, was understood by ancient peoples and how the interpretations of early scholars altered our perceptions of biblical teachings. In 1997 in these pages, Phyllis Trible called this a ''fascinating study'' handled ''with erudition and enthusiasm.'' In The Hidden Jesus: A New Life, by Donald Spoto (St. Martin's Griffin, $14.95), a theologian (and celebrity biographer) examines the life of Jesus of Nazareth and argues that his true vision remains alive and active today. The result is ''a personal statement of faith'' that ''thoughtfully challenges some of Christianity's traditions,'' Alexandra Hall wrote here last year. Jesus Through the Centuries: His Place in the History of Culture, by Jaroslav Pelikan (Yale University, $13.95), is a celebratory study of Jesus' impact on Western art, thought and culture over the last 2,000 years. ''Believers and skeptics alike will find it a sweeping visual and conceptual panorama,'' John Koenig wrote here in 1985.    Where She Went: Stories   By Kate Walbert. Penguin, $12.95.    In these 14 linked tales, a lonely company wife moves from place to place, a journey echoed years later by her adult daughter, who travels the world in search of fulfillment. ''Their stories are small, elegiac and inconclusive,'' Molly Giles wrote here in 1998. '' 'Where She Went' contains many quick flashes of beauty.''    A High Wind in Jamaica   By Richard Hughes. New York Review, $12.95.    This dreamlike 1929 novel explores the tangled fates of a group of children en route from the West Indies to England and the ragtag crew of pirates that reluctantly captures them. ''There is an air of fantastic credibility about this odyssey,'' the Book Review wrote, and it is a fascinating study in child psychology.    The Doctor Stories   By Richard Selzer. Picador USA, $14.    These tales by a former surgeon, culled from three decades of short fiction, explore lives on both ends of the scalpel and are carefully imbued with the language of sickness. ''Selzer's fiction is refreshingly old-fashioned: his prose is formal, his ironies straightforward,'' Tobin Harshaw wrote here in 1998.    Dossier: The Secret History of Armand Hammer   By Edward Jay Epstein. Carroll & Graf, $15.95.    The larger-than-life oil magnate (1898-1990), who courted world leaders from Lenin to George Bush, emerges in this well-researched biography as ''a morbidly fascinating compound of ambition, greed, unscrupulousness and power hunger,'' Joseph E. Persico wrote here in 1996. ''It is hard to imagine a sharper picture of how a tycoon is both born and made.''    Oh, Jackie   By Maudy Benz. Berkley, $12.95.    The 15-year-old narrator of this first novel, left by her parents to spend the summer of 1963 with her wealthy cousins in Michigan, tries to imagine what her idol, Jackie Kennedy, would do to escape the clutches of her lecherous uncle. Benz tells the story ''with tenderness and impressive control,'' Sally Eckhoff said in the Book Review last year.    Breaking News   By Robert MacNeil. Harvest/Harcourt, $13.    This lively novel by the former PBS news anchor centers on a 60-ish network anchorman grappling with both a life crisis and a career crisis. The result is ''a provocative cri de coeur aimed at what one character calls 'information/entertainment television,' ''Eric Alterman wrote here in 1998.   Scott Veale

snippet: Patricia and Walter Wells look back on a quarter-century of life in France.
lead_paragraph: Many culturally hungry Americans dream about moving to France. “We’ve Always Had Paris ... and Provence” is the story of two who did so and have lived happily ever after. Patricia Wells, known best for her seminal “Food Lover’s Guide to Paris,” and Walter Wells, a high-ranking editor of The International Herald Tribune from 1980 to 2005, have written a he-said, she-said memoir, volleying back and forth to tell how a girl from Wisconsin and a boy from South Carolina met while working at The New York Times and went to France in 1980 on what they assumed would be temporary journalistic assignments. They found their lives’ calling as expatriates, transcending prejudice to be accepted and even revered by the foreign culture they embraced. Walter was awarded the French Legion of Honor. Patricia recounts with no small measure of self-amazement the time she showed the Frenchman Joël Robuchon, “the greatest chef in the world,” how to make her special bouillabaisse.

snippet: Kitty Kelley’s biography of Oprah Winfrey relies on her own words, but not current ones.
lead_paragraph: Kitty Kelley’s name will not be showing up on any of Oprah Winfrey’s lists of her favorite things. Here’s one reason: If Ms. Kelley’s cage-match Winfrey biography is to be believed, Ms. Winfrey has begged to learn the identity and background of her biological father. Her relatives won’t tell her. But on July 30, 2007, Ms. Kelley pried it out of one of them. This coup, the only real “Gotcha!” in Ms. Kelley’s “Oprah,” is the kind of reportorial discovery on which Ms. Kelley has built her giant-killer reputation.

lead_paragraph: Sunny, funny Kinsey Millhone takes a stroll on the dark side in Sue Grafton's intriguingly offbeat new alphabet mystery, "K" IS FOR KILLER (Holt, $22.95), when the California private eye answers a mother's appeal to resolve the mystery of her daughter's death. "We're not like regular people anymore," says the woman, a diner waitress on the graveyard shift who describes herself as "a zombie, the living dead, maybe a little bit cracked."
abstract: Sunny, funny Kinsey Millhone takes a stroll on the dark side in Sue Grafton's intriguingly offbeat new alphabet mystery, "K" IS FOR KILLER (Holt, $22.95), when the California private eye answers a mother's appeal to resolve the mystery of her daughter's death. "We're not like regular people anymore," says the woman, a diner waitress on the graveyard shift who describes herself as "a zombie, the living dead, maybe a little bit cracked."   Unable to resist this aching expression of survivor's grief, Kinsey turns herself into a night person in order to learn more about the victim, whose after-hours profession as a classy hooker is the first of many secrets to surface in the light of the investigation. In an impressive piece of character building, this shady young woman gradually comes to life, a year after her literal death, as a person of unexpected depths and contradictions.

snippet: Paulina Porizkova’s novel concerns a young model in Paris.
lead_paragraph: With the publication of “A Model Summer,” Paulina Porizkova makes her own contribution to a literary sub-sub-genre, books by supermodels. Most of these get bad reviews, either because they’re truly awful, like Naomi Campbell’s “Swan,” which won Seventeen magazine’s Super-Cheesy Award, or — call me a conspiracy theorist — because jealous book critics aren’t tall and gorgeous, so they try to wield their puny amount of power to establish some sort of moral order.

headline: {'main': 'And Bear In Mind', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'And Bear In Mind', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}
byline: {'original': None, 'person': [], 'organization': None}
snippet: Unknown
lead_paragraph: (Editors' choices of other recent books of particular interest)
abstract: (Editors' choices of other recent books of particular interest)    WAVEMAKER II, by Mary-Beth Hughes. (Atlantic Monthly, $23.) The title of this politically imaginative first novel is the name of a boat belonging to Roy Cohn, who appears, impetuous and sentimental, human and controversial, at the top of a pyramid of enterprise supported, to his cost, by Will Clemens, a loyal young executive, and his loyal wife.    AT SWIM, TWO BOYS, by Jamie O'Neill. (Scribner, $28.) Two great causes -- free Ireland and a free gay nation -- coincide in this polished but energetic novel built on the hazards of love, heroism, history and tenderness, and placed in political and moral history by the Easter Rising of 1916.    2182 KHZ, by David Masiel. (Random House, $22.95.) A confidently anarchic first novel whose title refers to the international distress channel for mariners in trouble; most of it happens at sea, off Alaska's North Slope, and the chief victim of the happenings is a likable unfortunate who has spent a decade working the Arctic and becomes the only survivor of a disaster brought on by a captain who screams at his crew, ''Do Things!''    AMBLING INTO HISTORY: The Unlikely Odyssey of George W. Bush, by Frank Bruni. (HarperCollins, $23.95.) Bruni, who covered the Bush candidacy at length for The Times, concentrates on Bush's personality and mannerisms, which he renders as oddly prankish and frivolous for a politician, at least until grounded by the events of Sept. 11.    INSECT DREAMS: The Half Life of Gregor Samsa, by Marc Estrin. (BlueHen/Putnam, $26.95.) Rescued by Estrin, a first novelist, from the end of Kafka's ''Metamorphosis,'' the bug of the century works hard to readapt himself to the world of humanity.    BY THE LAKE, by John McGahern. (Knopf, $24.) The sixth novel in 40 years of careful, lapidary production by this elegant Irish writer concerns the passage of a year in an unnamed Irish village, a couple who have returned to it, and a community for which the biggest event of the year is the arrival of a telephone pole.    THE ROTTERS' CLUB, by Jonathan Coe. (Knopf, $24.95.) A fictional British panorama of the early stages of the political, social and cultural transformation wrought on Britain by Margaret Thatcher (another volume is to come); its central figures, not quite finished, are chiefly university-bound students at a private school in Birmingham.    THE DARTS OF CUPID: And Other Stories, by Edith Templeton. (Pantheon, $23.) The minutely observed social transactions and discriminating aperçus in these stories by a writer who is now 85 are set in train by a kind of erotic attraction that the clinically minded would not hesitate to call sadomasochism.  THE SHORT SWEET DREAM OF EDUARDO GUTIÉRREZ, by Jimmy Breslin. (Crown, $22.) A true-life account of an illegal Mexican immigrant who died on a New York construction site, and of the dreary lives and modest ambitions common to Mexicans in this country.

snippet: OFF THE GRID: No one seems to know very much about the writer who calls himself John Twelve Hawks -- he's publishing's new international man of mystery. According to the terse biographical sketch on the dust jacket of his first novel, ''The Travel...
lead_paragraph: OFF THE GRID: No one seems to know very much about the writer who calls himself John Twelve Hawks -- he's publishing's new international man of mystery. According to the terse biographical sketch on the dust jacket of his first novel, "The Traveler," Twelve Hawks is simply a man who "lives off the Grid." No book tour for this literary Unabomber. His agent and editor say they've never met him. Twelve Hawks communicates with them by satellite phone, and employs spy-store technology: a voice scrambler that can make him sound like Darth Vader or, presumably, Umberto Eco after a 10K sprint. Twelve Hawks's publisher, Doubleday, is trying to make this game of hide-and-go-seek work for them in the summer of Deep Throat Redux, and perhaps it is -- The Traveler" enters this week's hardcover fiction list at No. 13. Twelve Hawks's book is a "Matrix"-like thriller set in a society where "the Vast Machine" watches everything people do; it's about "a fierce group of warriors" who try to protect "a select few" known as Travelers. As a sci-fi entertainment machine, "The Traveler" skims along, but it's studded with op-ed pronouncements about the end of privacy that quickly become leaden. The more we learn about Twelve Hawks, the less spooky he seems. According to USA Today, he likes wine and lives in New York, London and Los Angeles. In a Q. & A. posted on Doubleday's Web site, the author sounds more like Chuck Norris than Thomas Pynchon: "I studied martial arts for several years," he intones, Vaderishly, "and have fought both in tournaments and on the street." He isn't laconic about his own gifts: "There are a great many provocative ideas in this novel. Everyone who reads 'The Traveler' is going to be entertained by an exciting story." Who is this guy? Patrick Anderson, writing in The Washington Post Book World, floated a rumor that Twelve Hawks is actually "fat, 40 and named Bernie Broadbeam."
abstract: OFF THE GRID: No one seems to know very much about the writer who calls himself John Twelve Hawks -- he's publishing's new international man of mystery. According to the terse biographical sketch on the dust jacket of his first novel, ''The Traveler,'' Twelve Hawks is simply a man who ''lives off the Grid.'' No book tour for this literary Unabomber. His agent and editor say they've never met him. Twelve Hawks communicates with them by satellite phone, and employs spy-store technology: a voice scrambler that can make him sound like Darth Vader or, presumably, Umberto Eco after a 10K sprint. Twelve Hawks's publisher, Doubleday, is trying to make this game of hide-and-go-seek work for them in the summer of Deep Throat Redux, and perhaps it is -- The Traveler'' enters this week's hardcover fiction list at No. 13. Twelve Hawks's book is a ''Matrix''-like thriller set in a society where ''the Vast Machine'' watches everything people do; it's about ''a fierce group of warriors'' who try to protect ''a select few'' known as Travelers. As a sci-fi entertainment machine, ''The Traveler'' skims along, but it's studded with op-ed pronouncements about the end of privacy that quickly become leaden. The more we learn about Twelve Hawks, the less spooky he seems. According to USA Today, he likes wine and lives in New York, London and Los Angeles. In a Q. & A. posted on Doubleday's Web site, the author sounds more like Chuck Norris than Thomas Pynchon: ''I studied martial arts for several years,'' he intones, Vaderishly, ''and have fought both in tournaments and on the street.'' He isn't laconic about his own gifts: ''There are a great many provocative ideas in this novel. Everyone who reads 'The Traveler' is going to be entertained by an exciting story.'' Who is this guy? Patrick Anderson, writing in The Washington Post Book World, floated a rumor that Twelve Hawks is actually ''fat, 40 and named Bernie Broadbeam.''    NEW FICTION: In addition to Twelve Hawks's book, four other novels make their debuts on this week's hardcover fiction list. Danielle Steel's ''Miracle'' is No. 3; Kathy Reichs's ''Cross Bones,'' her eighth novel about the forensic anthropologist Temperance Brennan, is No. 9; ''Fire Sale,'' Sara Paretsky's 12th V. I. Warshawski novel, is No. 10; and ''72 Hour Hold,'' the new novel by Bebe Moore Campbell (left), is No. 11. ''72 Hour Hold'' is about a mother whose Ivy League-bound daughter becomes mentally ill, and its movie-of-the-week quality is redeemed by its grace and candor. When a doctor tells the narrator her daughter is bipolar, she thinks: ''That was the scariest part, the way he said it. She is bipolar, not she has bipolar disorder. You are cancer. You are AIDS. Nobody ever said that.''   Dwight Garner

snippet: Unknown
lead_paragraph: THE STORIES OF PAUL BOWLES. (Ecco, $19.95.) As was the case with his 1949 novel, ''The Sheltering Sky,'' this collection of shorter fiction explores the Muslim experience and sensibility, and the Western fascination with an exotic Islamic culture. Written between 1946 and 1993 (when Bowles lived as an expatriate in Tangier), these stripped-down and ruthlessly unsentimental tales provide a ''map . . . of the author's development: the long contours and big shapes of the Bowles career are visible as we work through the pages and the decades,'' John Sutherland said here in 2001.
abstract: THE STORIES OF PAUL BOWLES. (Ecco, $19.95.) As was the case with his 1949 novel, ''The Sheltering Sky,'' this collection of shorter fiction explores the Muslim experience and sensibility, and the Western fascination with an exotic Islamic culture. Written between 1946 and 1993 (when Bowles lived as an expatriate in Tangier), these stripped-down and ruthlessly unsentimental tales provide a ''map . . . of the author's development: the long contours and big shapes of the Bowles career are visible as we work through the pages and the decades,'' John Sutherland said here in 2001.    A SMUGGLER'S BIBLE, by Joseph McElroy. (Overlook, $15.95.) While traveling aboard a trans-Atlantic liner to London, David Brooke, the tormented hero of McElroy's first novel, tries to connect eight jumbled manuscripts into a single narrative recounting the lives and sufferings of his family and friends. The book's chapters alternate between the manuscripts, or ''memories,'' and an account of Brooke's emotionally unnerving shipboard experiences. Our reviewer, James R. Frakes, called this a ''remarkable novel'' and admired the author's ''daring, range and brilliant subtlety.''    CICERO: The Life and Times of Rome's Greatest Politician, by Anthony Everitt. (Random House, $14.95.) The author traces the ascent of Marcus Tullius Cicero to the Senate, where he reigned as Rome's premier courtroom orator and a tactful persuader, and his later disappointment, exile and worse -- his execution -- as the republic slid toward autocracy. Last year in these pages, T. Corey Brennan said Everitt ''writes fluidly and has taken the trouble to look at many ancient sources relevant to his study, especially Cicero's own works.''    A PELICAN IN THE WILDERNESS: Hermits, Solitaries and Recluses, by Isabel Colegate. (Counterpoint, $15.95.) A British novelist's first nonfiction work is a series of meditations on extreme solitude and those hermits throughout history who have been driven from the flock by their disgust at the lack of spirituality in whatever culture they belong to. The cast runs from the Buddha to J. D. Salinger, and includes a fifth-century saint who lived for 36 years in a hut on top of a 60-foot pillar. Colegate's ''pace is civilized and leisurely, but she covers much ground and has clearly done a good deal of research and travel, some of it arduous,'' Frank Kermode said in the Book Review last year.    THINGS THAT FALL FROM THE SKY, by Kevin Brockmeier. (Vintage Contemporaries, $12.95.) Among the things that fall from above in this first collection of short fiction (much of it preoccupied with loss) are a deadly bucket that crashes through a schoolroom window, rain, turning leaves and a gigantic black spot that eclipses the sun and threatens to destroy an entire town. The result is a ''delightful, sad and often magical book,'' Hillary Frey wrote here in 2002. ''Brockmeier's small, carefully made worlds are like Steven Millhauser's; they are definitely fantastic and, miraculously, utterly human.''    SOMEBODY'S GOTTA TELL IT: The Upbeat Memoir of a Working-Class Journalist, by Jack Newfield. (St. Martin's, $15.95.) The feisty Brooklyn-born muckraker tells of his experiences in the tumultuous 60's, and of the era's wild characters from the worlds of politics, sports, crime and journalism. It's all brought ''fleetingly and vividly to life,'' Richard Lourie said here in 2002. ''Future historians will be glad to come across this book, which echoes the music of the times, a crazy jazz syncopated by gunshots.''    DEMON OF THE WATERS: The True Story of the Mutiny on the Whaleship Globe, by Gregory Gibson. (Back Bay/Little, Brown, $14.95.) The grisly 1824 mutiny aboard the Globe, a New England whaler, was the bloodiest in the history of American whaling, featuring ax murders, beatings, nasty encounters with Pacific islanders and the eventual murder of the chief mutineer, a Manson-like figure who dreamed of ruling his own tropical kingdom. Last year in the Book Review, Sara Wheeler, reviewing this account and Mutiny on the Globe: The Fatal Voyage of Samuel Comstock, by Thomas Farel Heffernan (Penguin, $14), found them both to be ''lively'' re-creations of the uprising and its aftermath (six crewmen managed to escape). The authors ''are scrupulous,'' she added, ''and both have produced a welcome addition to the canon of whaling literature.''   Scott Veale

snippet: Books
lead_paragraph: ''One advantage of a collection of film reviews spanning seven decades,'' Peter M. Nichols observes in his preface to THE NEW YORK TIMES GUIDE TO THE BEST 1,000 MOVIES EVER MADE, by Vincent Canby, Janet Maslin, and the film critics of The New York Times (Times Books/Random House, paper, $25), ''is that it reflects changing times as tellingly as it explores movies.'' Nichols, the editor of the volume, points out that many a movie now on anyone's list of the best went unrecognized by the critics at its release: he cites, among others, ''Grand Illusion,'' ''The Third Man,'' ''Bonnie and Clyde'' and ''Chinatown.'' Nevertheless, this collection offers 1,000 reviews -- talkies only -- just as they were written, beginning Oct. 7, 1927 (Mordaunt Hall on ''The Jazz Singer''). Each review is accompanied by a credit box, updated to current style. Intended especially for film buffs and renters of videos, the book includes appendixes on the critics' choice of the 10 best movies of each year from 1931 to 1998 and a roster of foreign films by origin.
abstract: Books

keywords: [{'name': 'persons', 'value': 'Wood, Grant', 'rank': 1, 'major': 'N'}, {'name': 'subject', 'value': 'Books and Literature', 'rank': 2, 'major': 'N'}, {'name': 'subject', 'value': 'Art', 'rank': 3, 'major': 'N'}]
snippet: Grant Wood’s most famous painting is the straightforward “American Gothic,” but Wood himself was much more mysterious.
lead_paragraph: The cover of R. Tripp Evans’s “Grant Wood: A Life” does not depict “American Gothic,” the painting for which Wood is best known. Instead it features a lush green landscape, replete with rolling hillside and curving country road. On that road is a truck colored so prettily, picturesquely red that it suggests a freshly painted barn. There is a naïve-looking simplicity to the way this image has been rendered.

snippet: In this novel, a poet (and former assassin) grapples with love and despair in late-1940s Italy.
lead_paragraph: It is Rome, 1948, and Dante Sabato, a poet and translator — having negotiated his own survival throughout the war — is ready to end it all. Contemplating a dive off the Ponte Sisto bridge and into the Tiber, he is interrupted by an American G.I., who escorts him straight to a party. There Dante meets the Godfrey sisters, Gladys and Prudence, American actresses trying to make it in the booming Italian film industry. Gladys is a sexual adventurer, self-possessed and assertive. She fulfills all her wants and needs and, along the way, some of Dante’s. She appreciates Dante’s fervent lovemaking and the fact that he’s a busy man, busy with his work, busy with his other women, and doesn’t have the time or inclination to control her. Prudence, rumored to be fleeing an unfortunate affair with the director Billy Wilder, is reserved, the more beautiful of the two. Shuttling between them both, Dante finds — in the sum — love.

snippet: “Just Kids” captures a moment when Patti Smith and Robert Mapplethorpe were young, inseparable, perfectly bohemian and completely unknown.
lead_paragraph: Patti Smith and Robert Mapplethorpe were both born in 1946, at a time when “the iceman” and “the last of the horse-drawn wagons” could still be seen on city streets. Ms. Smith points this out at the start of her tenderly evocative memoir, “Just Kids,” but there is even stronger evidence that this book dates back a long time.

snippet: The title of this book works as a pretty nifty plot summary.
lead_paragraph: Thirteen-year-old boys are mysteries. By and large, they don’t keep diaries and no, they don’t want to talk about it, thank you very much. According to booksellers and parents I’ve met, they don’t read books either, but this may be just a nasty rumor.

lead_paragraph: LEAD: IN THE SHADOW OF THE DOME: Chronicles of a Capitol Hill Aide. By Mark Bisnow. (Morrow, $20.95.) Abscam, Angola, the Iran-contra affair, Wedtech, record deficits, the Reagan revolution, the rise of political action committees - in the 12 years Mark Bisnow served as legislative aide to Senator Hubert Humphrey, Representative John Anderson, Senator Robert Dole and others, Capitol Hill rocked with political drama.

keywords: [{'name': 'persons', 'value': 'Jennings, Peter', 'rank': 1, 'major': 'N'}, {'name': 'persons', 'value': 'Brewster, Todd', 'rank': 2, 'major': 'N'}, {'name': 'subject', 'value': 'Reviews', 'rank': 3, 'major': 'N'}, {'name': 'subject', 'value': 'Books and Literature', 'rank': 4, 'major': 'N'}, {'name': 'subject', 'value': 'History', 'rank': 5, 'major': 'N'}, {'name': 'subject', 'value': 'TWENTIETH CENTURY', 'rank': 6, 'major': 'N'}, {'name': 'creative_works', 'value': 'CENTURY, THE (BOOK)', 'rank': 7, 'major': 'N'}]
snippet: David Walton reviews book The Century, by Peter Jennings and Todd Brewster; photo (S)
lead_paragraph: This ragtag century of ours is getting to seem like a garrulous uncle who keeps coming back with his same old stories: his great wars and his great depressions, evils daunted and lessons sorely learned. Crowds cheering the troops into World War I, the folly of the Treaty of Versailles, the masses on their feet in Nazi salute at the 1936 Olympics in Berlin -- and on and on. THE CENTURY (Doubleday, $60) is comprehensive, balanced, eminently readable and fairly onerous, taken cover to cover. The narrative by Peter Jennings, the broadcaster, and Todd Brewster, a former editor and writer at Life, is a good textbook history of the American experience of the 20th century, told from the perspective of the American 1990's, rather than what might have been more interesting, the century as seen from each of its successive eras. Important phases and events are captured in a series of first-person accounts, most filling a single page, with a boxed biography of the speaker and several photographs, often snapshots; together these form an effective, and in some ways more satisfying narrative, and are the real meat of this book. The photo selection of Katherine Bourbeau is excellent, with an eye for the unfamiliar image (John F. Kennedy and Richard M. Nixon in a handshake that separates rather than brings them together; students at Harvard mourning Kennedy's murder), while a familiar image like Dorothea Lange's ''Migrant Mother'' is treated as subject rather than illustration, and captioned with a quotation from the photographer, describing the circumstances of the shot. With so much to browse and relive, there will be something here for everyone. David Walton
abstract: David Walton reviews book The Century, by Peter Jennings and Todd Brewster; photo (S)

snippet: Neither Ellen Ruppel Shell’s “Cheap” nor Chris Anderson’s “Free” is as sharp as its one-word catchy title.
lead_paragraph: Consider Ellen Ruppel Shell’s “Cheap,” Chris Anderson’s “Free” and the story of the one-cent Hershey’s Kiss. This story appears in both books, but the versions are different. Both come from the same source, but these two authors can’t even agree on what to call him. He is Daniel Ariely to Ms. Shell, Dan Ariely to Mr. Anderson, and the author of “Predictably Irrational” to both of them.

headline: {'main': 'New & Noteworthy Paperbacks', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'New & Noteworthy Paperbacks', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}
byline: {'original': 'By Scott Veale', 'person': [{'firstname': 'Scott', 'middlename': None, 'lastname': 'Veale', 'qualifier': None, 'title': None, 'role': 'reported', 'organization': '', 'rank': 1}], 'organization': None}
snippet: Unknown
lead_paragraph: The Story of American Freedom
abstract: The Story of American Freedom   By Eric Foner. Norton, $15.95.    A historian argues that freedom is not a fixed set of principles but a ''complex of values'' that have evolved over time as various excluded groups have struggled for liberty. ''The book's strongest claim to distinction lies . . . in its succinct, information-packed, wonderfully readable account of the twists and turns in 20th-century American history,'' Pauline Maier wrote here in 1998.    The Poisonwood Bible   By Barbara Kingsolver. Harper Perennial, $14.    The story of a fanatical Baptist clergyman who uproots his Georgia family and sets them down in the Belgian Congo in 1959 is narrated by his wife and four daughters, each of whom abandons one faith and discovers another as their lives unravel in the jungle. This novel, selected as one of the best books of 1998 by the editors of the Book Review, also has much to say about America and its homegrown brand of missionary zeal. ''For all its portraiture of place'' the narrative is ''shaped by keen-eyed women contemplating themselves and one another and a village whose familiarity it takes a tragedy to discover,'' Verlyn Klinkenborg wrote here.    Cinderella & Company:   Backstage at the Opera With Cecilia Bartoli   By Manuela Hoelterhoff. Vintage, $14.    This profile of the Italian mezzo-soprano Cecilia Bartoli is also a withering look at modern opera: the industry's youth-obsessed star-making machinery, the intense egomania and raging insecurities, the brutal sniping. The result ''is a naughtily witty tell-almost-all book,'' Terry Teachout wrote here last year. Opera, or the Undoing of Women, by Catherine Clement (University of Minnesota, $17.95), is a scholarly critique by a European feminist who argues that opera is one long tale of male domination in which victimized women characters are consigned to a ''sung death.'' In 1989 our reviewer, Paul Robinson, called this ''a highly original interpretation.''    The Voyage of the Narwhal   By Andrea Barrett. Norton, $14.    A British naturalist embarks on a voyage of self-discovery when he boards a vessel searching for clues to the mysterious disappearance of Sir John Franklin's Arctic expedition of 1845. Last year our reviewer, Annette Kobak, called this novel a ''marvelous achievement.''    Too Cool   By Duff Brenna. Plume, $12.95.    In this raw novel about teen-age desperadoes in Colorado, a 16-year-old misfit named Triple E escapes from reform school and gets stranded with his girlfriend in a heavy snowstorm. The result is ''an unfaltering, unflinching, piercing look into a tormented youthful heart,'' Richard Bernstein wrote in 1998 in The Times.    The Nurture Assumption:  Why Children Turn Out the Way They Do   By Judith Rich Harris.   Touchstone/Simon & Schuster, $15.    Melding research from many fields, a former writer of textbooks on developmental psychology makes the provocative case that children are shaped more by their own temperament and peers than by the input of their parents. No matter which side of the argument readers come down on, ''Harris writes beautifully, in a tone both persuasive and conversational,'' Carol Tavris wrote here last year. The Lunch-Box Chronicles: Notes From the Parenting Underground, by Marion Winik (Vintage, $12), is a frontline report on child rearing by a commentator for National Public Radio. ''Take Erma Bombeck, add the obsessions of a single mother . . . and you have Marion Winik, as companionable a writer as a crazed parent ever found,'' Andrea Cooper wrote here in 1998.    Malina   By Ingeborg Bachmann. Holmes & Meier, $15.95.    A Viennese woman plagued by violent dreams navigates difficult relationships with two men, one of whom forces her to confront the pain of her childhood. ''This courageous and important novel,'' originally published in German in 1971, ''is equal to the best of Virginia Woolf and Samuel Beckett,'' Peter Filkins wrote here in 1991.    My Year Off   By Robert McCrum. Broadway, $13.    The author was 42 and the editor in chief of a major London publishing house when he suffered a paralyzing stroke. This ''lucid, heartfelt'' account of his arduous recovery ''is a testament to the parallel trials and the courage of the family members of stroke victims,'' Abraham Verghese wrote here last year.    Mackerel by Moonlight   By William F. Weld. Pocket Star, $6.99.    This mystery novel by the former Massachusetts Governor is about an assistant United States attorney from Brooklyn whose shadowy past resurfaces after he opts for a job in a white-shoe Boston law firm and a life in politics. Last year our reviewer, Donald E. Westlake, admired the ''deft and devious story-telling.''    Thirst   By Ken Kalfus.   Washington Square/Pocket Books, $12.95.    Many of these stories are brief and jarring fantasies, including one in which Marco Polo describes a series of indoor retail malls to the Emperor Kublai Khan. ''The displaced figures in 'Thirst' drift through worlds that are at once astonishing and familiar,'' Ron Carlson wrote here last year.   Scott Veale

lead_paragraph: SHEAR By Tim Parks. 211 pp. New York: Grove Press. $21. THERE is something irresistible about characters in fiction who complicate their lives through sexual adventure. We may laugh at their duplicity and divided attention, yet we often admire their daring. Their situation serves as both a wish fulfillment and a warning.
abstract: SHEAR By Tim Parks. 211 pp. New York: Grove Press. $21.    THERE is something irresistible about characters in fiction who complicate their lives through sexual adventure. We may laugh at their duplicity and divided attention, yet we often admire their daring. Their situation serves as both a wish fulfillment and a warning.

keywords: [{'name': 'persons', 'value': 'Home, Stewart', 'rank': 1, 'major': 'N'}, {'name': 'subject', 'value': 'Reviews', 'rank': 2, 'major': 'N'}, {'name': 'subject', 'value': 'Books and Literature', 'rank': 3, 'major': 'N'}, {'name': 'creative_works', 'value': '69 THINGS TO DO WITH A DEAD PRINCESS (BOOK)', 'rank': 4, 'major': 'N'}]
snippet: Matthew Flamm reviews book 69 Things to Do With a Dead Princess by Stewart Home; drawing (S)
lead_paragraph: Never mind the pornographic passages that appear every few pages in 69 THINGS TO DO WITH A DEAD PRINCESS (Canongate, paper, $13); the British writer Stewart Home, champion of ''proletarian'' postmodernism (which means forget about character and plot), is a surprisingly easy read. The graphically described couplings are among the novel's many sendups, as Home sets out to undermine the role of books as commodity (another of his obsessions) with the sort of goings-on you can't describe without sounding foolish. For instance: the efforts of the main characters, Alan and Anna, to test the ''credibility'' (ha!) of an obscure text called ''69 Things to Do With a Dead Princess,'' whose author claims to have taken Princess Diana's corpse on a tour of the local Neolithic stone circles ''as a means of luring tourists to the prehistoric delights of ancient Aberdeenshire.'' The pair retrace the journey, lugging a ventriloquist's dummy as a princess stand-in. Between sex scenes, Alan sounds off on a range of authors, with charming disregard for their relative prominence or obscurity. Home makes an agreeably deadpan ventriloquist himself, venting intellectual spleen through his transparently thin characters. It's only when he points out the illusion -- having Alan disappear into Anna, or letting the dummy narrate a chapter -- that the joke falters, and his absurd picaresque reveals itself as that tamer thing, a novel of ideas. Matthew Flamm
abstract: Matthew Flamm reviews book 69 Things to Do With a Dead Princess by Stewart Home; drawing (S)

lead_paragraph: THE ANT AND THE PEACOCK: Altruism and Sexual Selection From Darwin to Today By Helena Cronin. Cambridge University, $19.95. The author examines Darwinian philosophy in light of a problem that has always dogged it: if natural selection prevails, how can we explain such counterproductive traits as the altruism of ants and the gaudiness of peacocks? Last year our reviewer, Mark Ridley, called this a "fine book," in which "the subtlest and most original insights . . . concern differences between Darwin's ideas and modern ideas."

snippet: Unknown
lead_paragraph: I don't mind novels that are hard to read as long as the rewards are commensurate with the effort. Sentences that must be decoded as if readers were cryptographers, paragraphs that only divulge their full meaning the second time around, dialogue that deliberately misleads so as to point to some deeper truth -- these are some of the narrative tools that Gwyneth Jones, the author of WHITE QUEEN (Tor/Tom Doherty, $27.95), chooses to work with.
abstract: I don't mind novels that are hard to read as long as the rewards are commensurate with the effort. Sentences that must be decoded as if readers were cryptographers, paragraphs that only divulge their full meaning the second time around, dialogue that deliberately misleads so as to point to some deeper truth -- these are some of the narrative tools that Gwyneth Jones, the author of WHITE QUEEN (Tor/Tom Doherty, $27.95), chooses to work with.    Ms. Jones's fiction verges on incomprehensibility but repays close attention. Humanoid aliens have landed on a 21st-century Earth much changed by a socialist revolution in the United States, by a new computer technology and by a new pathogen, a "petrovirus" capable of infecting both humans and their machines. As Ms. Jones tells it, the first encounter between humans and aliens generates mutual bewilderment and little else.

snippet: Katie Roiphe surveys seven literary partnerships in early-20th-century London.
lead_paragraph: Here’s the perfect bedside book for an age like our own, when everything is known and nothing is understood. Marriage — especially other people’s — is as fascinating as it is mysterious. But it takes the prism of the past to turn high gossip into cultural insight. In choosing seven “marriages à la mode” in the British literary community between 1910 and the Second World War, Katie Roiphe has hit upon a strategy that allows her to probe the mysteries of marriage with a kind of forensic delicacy. At the end of her book we feel we know these couples as intimately as if we were part of their circle, but the ultimate nature of each relationship is left inviolate in its unknowability.

snippet: An insightful photographic portrait, VIENNA 1850-1930: Architecture (Rizzoli, $65) provides a panorama of Viennese architecture during an era when the city was one of the most important intellectual and cultural centers in Europe. An essay by Pete...
lead_paragraph: An insightful photographic portrait, VIENNA 1850-1930: Architecture (Rizzoli, $65) provides a panorama of Viennese architecture during an era when the city was one of the most important intellectual and cultural centers in Europe. An essay by Peter Haiko, an architectural historian who teaches at the University of Vienna, provides a competent and accessible introduction to the historical events and theoretical issues for those unfamiliar with the architecture of the period. The heart of the book, however, is the fine color and black-and-white photographs of more than 30 structures documenting the metamorphosis of Vienna from a Baroque capital draped in the mantle of historicist styles to the stern, uncompromising forms of the modern city. In addition to civic and religious structures, the building types surveyed include private villas, apartment buildings and municipal structures like gasworks, water towers and bridges. Like the finest examples of human portraiture, Roberto Schezen's photographs reveal character as well as physiognomy. While his treatment of facades and major interior spaces conveys the public decorum and grand scale of urban architecture, his photographs of building details and eccentric spaces reveal intriguing facets of his subjects. Mr. Schezen possesses a wonderful eye for decorative details. The result is an unusually subtle and nuanced description of architecture. This photographic paean to Vienna vividly testifies to architecture's ability to transcend the requirements of mere shelter and evoke the spirit of an age and the character of a place.

snippet: Marilyn Stasio reviews books Echo Park by Michael Connelly, Four Kinds of Rain by Robert Ward, Seeking Whom He May Devour by Fred Vargas and The Accomplice by Elizabeth Ironside; photo (M)
lead_paragraph: THE real tension in a Michael Connelly novel springs from our uncertainty about how the narrative will hold up once his Los Angeles homicide detective, Harry Bosch, has his inevitable meltdown. You never know with Bosch, who brings so much emotional baggage to his cases they can become self-help exercises in his personal psychodrama.

snippet: THE HUNGRY TIDE. By Amitav Ghosh. (Houghton Mifflin, $25.) From the Calcutta byways of ''The Shadow Lines'' to the royal Burmese backrooms of ''The Glass Palace,'' Ghosh has imbued his novels with rich social, historical, even anthropological deta...
lead_paragraph: THE HUNGRY TIDE. By Amitav Ghosh. (Houghton Mifflin, $25.) From the Calcutta byways of "The Shadow Lines" to the royal Burmese backrooms of "The Glass Palace," Ghosh has imbued his novels with rich social, historical, even anthropological detail. His latest is set in the Sundarbans, a magical, mythlike archipelago -- "the trailing threads of India's fabric, the ragged fringe of her sari" -- that's also a fragile ecosystem under siege. A young marine biologist, born in India but raised in Seattle, is investigating the few remaining freshwater dolphins in this alluring landscape, a vast string of islands and mangrove forests in the Bay of Bengal. She is accompanied by a local fisherman, stubbornly devoted to the old ways of life, who acts as her guide, and by a Delhi-based translator revisiting the region to help an aunt sort through some long-lost family papers. To each, the Sundarbans represent something different, but for all they become "a proliferation of small worlds . . . a meeting not just of many rivers, but a roundabout people can use to pass in many directions -- from country to country and even between faiths."
abstract: THE HUNGRY TIDE. By Amitav Ghosh. (Houghton Mifflin, $25.) From the Calcutta byways of ''The Shadow Lines'' to the royal Burmese backrooms of ''The Glass Palace,'' Ghosh has imbued his novels with rich social, historical, even anthropological detail. His latest is set in the Sundarbans, a magical, mythlike archipelago -- ''the trailing threads of India's fabric, the ragged fringe of her sari'' -- that's also a fragile ecosystem under siege. A young marine biologist, born in India but raised in Seattle, is investigating the few remaining freshwater dolphins in this alluring landscape, a vast string of islands and mangrove forests in the Bay of Bengal. She is accompanied by a local fisherman, stubbornly devoted to the old ways of life, who acts as her guide, and by a Delhi-based translator revisiting the region to help an aunt sort through some long-lost family papers. To each, the Sundarbans represent something different, but for all they become ''a proliferation of small worlds . . . a meeting not just of many rivers, but a roundabout people can use to pass in many directions -- from country to country and even between faiths.''       AN OUTLINE OF THE REPUBLIC. By Siddhartha Deb. (Ecco, $24.95.) The faraway corner of India that Deb describes -- the lawless northeast, along the Burmese border, a region of smugglers, insurgents and corrupt petty officials -- is a neglected, little-known land, even within India itself. But for Amrit Singh, a Sikh journalist, it might offer the best chance to revive his faltering career at a Calcutta newspaper. Inspired by a photograph of an anonymous sex worker abducted by local guerrillas, an image that seems to embody all ''the mystery and sorrow of India,'' he sets off in search of her story, embarking on a journey that will take him ever deeper into the countryside, through monsoons and landslides and towns ''dissolving bit by bit into a state of nothingness.'' It's a journey filled with fleeting encounters in small hotels and hasty revelations over roadside meals. Bustling with colorful characters and sudden confessions, ''An Outline of the Republic'' explores a provocative question: What, if anything, does India represent this far from the center of the nation's power?

snippet: Corby Kummer Holiday Books article notes best cookbooks of 2006; drawings; photos (L)
lead_paragraph: Molecular gastronomy, which uses science and technology to experiment with familiar textures and flavors, has been shaking up restaurant kitchens ever since the three-star chef Ferran Adrià began serving 30-course dinners using all manner of gizmos to thrill the patrons of El Bulli, his restaurant on the Costa Brava. Professionals with big budgets and even bigger appetites are avidly exploring post-space-age cuisine, but so far it has seemed way too weird for home cooks.

snippet: Thirty-six years after Henry Aaron broke Babe Ruth’s home run record, a proper full-dress biography has appeared.
lead_paragraph: I’m not sure what this says about America, or about publishing or baseball or sports writers, but it has taken 36 years for a proper full-dress biography of Henry Aaron, the man who, in 1974, broke Babe Ruth’s home run record, and did so as a black man playing for Major League Baseball’s first franchise in the Deep South. His is a great American life, and Howard Bryant’s “Last Hero: A Life of Henry Aaron” rises confidently to meet it.

keywords: [{'name': 'subject', 'value': 'Books and Literature', 'rank': 1, 'major': 'N'}, {'name': 'subject', 'value': 'Children and Youth', 'rank': 2, 'major': 'N'}, {'name': 'persons', 'value': 'Marcus, Leonard S', 'rank': 3, 'major': 'N'}]
snippet: Leonard S. Marcus tells the story of the pioneering collaboration between Western Publishing and Simon & Schuster to introduce a series of books priced at 25 cents.
lead_paragraph: Quick! What is the best-selling children’s picture book of all time? You might be surprised to learn it’s “The Poky Little Puppy,” by Janette Sebring Lowrey, originally published in 1942. One of the first 12 Little Golden Books, it has sold more than 15 million copies and is still in print. For her efforts, Lowrey was paid a fee of $75. This and many other delightfully entertaining nuggets of information are included in Leonard S. Marcus’s enthusiastic history of Golden Books.

snippet: In rejecting the Enlightenment for a hazy German Idealism, 19th-century Russian thinkers did their country no favors.
lead_paragraph: There is a joke about the Russians, sometimes told by Russians. A young man from the provinces, inspired by a local doctor, travels to St. Petersburg because he wants to study “life.” He reads, he writes and eventually he enters medical school. On the first day of class the professor enters the hushed auditorium and announces, “Gentlemen, today we will discuss the pancreas.” The young man leaps from his seat, enraged. “The pancreas? How dare you mention the pancreas! We are not here to study the pancreas, we are here to study ... LIFE!”
