headline: {'main': 'And Bear In Mind', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'And Bear In Mind', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}
byline: {'original': None, 'person': [], 'organization': None}
snippet: Unknown
lead_paragraph: (Editors' choices of other recent books of particular interest)
abstract: (Editors' choices of other recent books of particular interest)    BING CROSBY: A Pocketful of Dreams. The Early Years, 1903-1940, by Gary Giddins. (Little, Brown, $30.) A long, long book by an eminent jazz critic who scrupulously tracks the life and art of a very fine and immensely successful jazz singer and recording artist who suddenly became unknown in the 1960's.    THE BONESETTER'S DAUGHTER, by Amy Tan. (Putnam, $25.95.) A novel of multiple narratives that puts to use the experiences, in very different countries and ages, of daughter, mother and grandmother to construct a family story and find the place in it for the youngest generation.    THE BODY ARTIST, by Don DeLillo. (Scribner, $22.) A tiny, intimate metaphysical ghost story by a master creator of huge, panoramic fiction; it concerns a woman alone in a large seaside house, where a strange man appears in an unused room. DeLillo's pinpoint prose copes with big themes, like the structure of time and the artist's approach to calamity.    DEMONOLOGY: Stories, by Rick Moody. (Little, Brown, $24.95.) Accomplished, fearless short stories that examine the exchange of energy between language and loss; inhabited mostly by young people whose heads are smarter than their hearts, and illuminated, sometimes, by barrages of emotional and rhetorical fireworks.    ISLAND: The Complete Stories, by Alistair MacLeod. (Norton, $25.95.) The small but highly concentrated output of 33 years' work, all of it dealing with life in Nova Scotia, where generations of hardship and authenticity are on the cusp of yielding to prosperity, education and cultural impoverishment.    THE GLASS PALACE, by Amitav Ghosh. (Random House, $25.95.) A morally and psychologically complicated novel that examines the deceptions and self-deceptions of India's Anglicized elite, a tribe deliberately created by Britain to think and act Britishly, still going strong after 50 years of independence.    LOVE, ETC., by Julian Barnes. (Knopf, $23.) Barnes's ninth novel continues the adventures of ''Talking It Over'' (1991), exhibiting the further ups and downs of two nearly young men and the woman they both love; like other Barnes folk, they have the habit of addressing the reader, sharing secrets other characters don't know.    MARY AND O'NEIL, by Justin Cronin. (Dial, $21.95.) Eight graceful, reflective linked stories that together illustrate the particulars of the past, the events ordinary and painful, that shaped the title characters, a couple who met in their late 20's and seem miraculously right for each other.    GABRIEL'S STORY, by David Anthony Durham. (Doubleday, $23.95.) Fifteen years old and black in the post-Civil-War West, the hero of this novel is as outside as an outsider can be; he has every qualification for the self-sufficiency that enables the classic confrontations of cowboy, Indian and nester.

keywords: [{'name': 'persons', 'value': 'White, Evelyn C', 'rank': 1, 'major': 'N'}, {'name': 'subject', 'value': 'BOOK REVIEWS', 'rank': 2, 'major': 'N'}, {'name': 'creative_works', 'value': "BLACK WOMEN'S HEALTH BOOK, THE (BOOK)", 'rank': 3, 'major': 'N'}]
snippet: Unknown
lead_paragraph: THE BLACK WOMEN'S HEALTH BOOK: Speaking for Ourselves. Edited by Evelyn C. White. (Seal, Paper, $14.95.) Evelyn C. White has collected more than 40 poems, essays and personal memoirs in ''The Black Women's Health Book.'' Ms. White, a journalist at The San Francisco Chronicle, writes that ''over the past few years, I have observed a growing number of vibrant black women being devastated by a multitude of physical and emotional ailments, ranging from drug addiction to cancer.'' More than 50 percent of black women live in a state of emotional distress; most women with AIDS are black, and a black woman's chance of being murdered is three times higher than that of her white counterpart. Contributors, including the novelist Alice Walker, the social critic Angela Davis and the president of Planned Parenthood, Faye Wattleton, bring these statistics movingly to life. Though many of the topics - including diabetes, lupus, incest, cancer, alcoholism, AIDS, hypertension, sickle cell anemia and grief - are unavoidably depressing, the book also illustrates empowerment, hope and triumph. Some contributions, including a dry, academic piece on the history of black women physicians, do not measure up to the general quality of the writing. However, when the essays hit home, they hit hard. As Ms. White says: ''Painful though it may be, we must look at what ails us and how we can get better. . . . Please take this sisterly medicine and pass it on.''

snippet: Paul Fleischman and Julie Paschkis create a multicultural Cinderella. Rachel Isadora gives an unappealing Grimm fairy tale a face lift.
lead_paragraph: Whom would you invite to a dinner party if it could be anyone in the history of the world? Forget Copernicus and Karl Marx. Think of people who would actually be fun: the storytellers. They had their fingers on the pulse — the desires, customs and gossip — of their day and could spin a great yarn to boot.

snippet: Essays on the isolation, pain and heroics that come with ministering to loved ones.
lead_paragraph: “Caregiver” is a deceptively professional-sounding term for a role in which most of us are complete amateurs, and for one that is apt to descend upon us like a blow from fate, stunning and unforeseen. We have a great need to live with the illusion that we and those we love are immune to mortality, but inevitably, somewhere along the line, even if we ourselves are spared from illness, something cracks open  a father or a friend gets cancer, a mother succumbs to Alzheimer’s, a husband has a terrible accident, a child dies  and what Virginia Woolf once called “extreme reality” floods in. Like the 19 excruciatingly honest contributors to “An Uncertain Inheritance,” we may find ourselves tested to the limits of our endurance.

snippet: A hefty biography of Senator Jesse Helms, the hard-right leader who embodied conservatism in the 1980s and beyond.
lead_paragraph: Appearing on “Larry King Live” in 1995, Jesse Helms, then the senior senator from North Carolina, fielded a call from an unusual admirer. Helms deserved the Nobel Peace Prize, the caller gushed, “for everything you’ve done to help keep down the niggers.” Given the rank ugliness of the sentiment  the guest host, Robert Novak, called it, with considerable understatement, “politically incorrect”  Helms could only pause before responding. But the hesitation couldn’t suppress his gut instincts. “Whoops, well, thank you, I think,” he said. With prodding from Novak, he added that he’d been spanked as a child for using the N-word and noted (with a delicious hint of uncertainty), “I don’t think I’ve used it since.” As for the caller’s main point  the virtue of keeping down blacks  it passed without comment.

keywords: [{'name': 'persons', 'value': 'Arthur-Bertrand, Yann', 'rank': 1, 'major': 'N'}, {'name': 'persons', 'value': 'BAKER, DAVID', 'rank': 2, 'major': 'N'}, {'name': 'subject', 'value': 'Reviews', 'rank': 3, 'major': 'N'}, {'name': 'subject', 'value': 'Books and Literature', 'rank': 4, 'major': 'N'}, {'name': 'creative_works', 'value': 'EARTH FROM ABOVE (BOOK)', 'rank': 5, 'major': 'N'}]
snippet: D J R Bruckner reviews book Earth From Above, photographs of Yann Arthur-Bertrand, with text translated from French by David Baker; photo (M)
lead_paragraph: In a sense, the aerial photographs of Yann Arthus-Bertrand are happy accidents: he took them from aircraft in 60 countries, and composition on the fly is chancy. But the prints are proof that, if the earth itself is not alive, its whole surface is always moving. Wind, water, tectonic plates and people are slow agents, but the marks of change are vast; the images capture eons in a moment. Whether you look down on the Lakagigar volcanoes in Iceland or the man-made windbreaks of the Aran Islands, you know Galileo said more than he meant when he insisted, ''It moves.'' Almost 200 of Arthus-Bertrand's images are lavishly reproduced in EARTH FROM ABOVE (Abrams, $65). The project was sponsored by Unesco, and the book has commentaries by French scientists who worry about humanity covering the planet too fast. But the photographs undermine their eloquence; to paraphrase John Lyly, the pictures are honey though the words are gall. From above, acres of carpets laid out on the sands of Morocco or even the dumps of Mexico City are as gorgeous as the autumn forests of Quebec or the mineral ''forest'' of Madagascar. Shots of the sprawl of monstrous cities are not reassuring, but over all one marvels at how naturally humanity's endless sand-castling fits into nature. And what a work nature is! Everywhere -- in cosmic brush strokes of bacteria in the Grand Prismatic Spring of Yellowstone or minerals washed over by the Rio Carrao in Venezuela -- the earth creates color and patterns that reduce human art to its proper place. ''Earth From Above'' is translated from French (by David Baker), and here and there one is reminded of the pitfalls of translation, as when it tells us the Yankees are ''the most winningest team'' in baseball, and of how iffy proofreading is in any language, as when it says the Maldives are ''120 isles or islets, of which almost 420 are inhabited.'' But it is a terrific book to look at and think about. D. J. R. Bruckner
abstract: D J R Bruckner reviews book Earth From Above, photographs of Yann Arthur-Bertrand, with text translated from French by David Baker; photo (M)

headline: {'main': 'The Trail Boss Was a Rabbi', 'kicker': 'BOOKS IN BRIEF: FICTION', 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'BOOKS IN BRIEF: FICTION; The Trail Boss Was a Rabbi', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}
byline: {'original': 'By Sandee Brawarsky', 'person': [{'firstname': 'Sandee', 'middlename': None, 'lastname': 'Brawarsky', 'qualifier': None, 'title': None, 'role': 'reported', 'organization': '', 'rank': 1}], 'organization': None}
snippet: Unknown
lead_paragraph: Other writers have related the brave stories of Jewish immigrant pioneers who made their way from tiny villages in Eastern Europe to the vast open spaces and new possibilities of the American West, but Ruhama Veltfort, in her impressive first novel, THE PROMISED LAND (Milkweed, $23.95), recasts the tale in a spiritual dimension. She delves into the religious yearnings of a group of travelers, bound together by faith and family, who flee the pogroms and poverty of 19th-century Poland. Here the inner adventure is as striking as the landscape they navigate. Yitzhak, a gentle rabbi with mystical leanings and large visions, heads the group of migrants, which includes his wife, Chana, a woman of quiet piety whose practical bent balances her husband's loftiness; his twin sister, who is able to see his dreams; her husband, whose religious conviction is tested many times over; and a fiddler whose tunes take on American rhythms as they travel. In their ecstatic prayer they find solace, singing the songs of Yitzhak's enigmatic rebbe, whose deathbed message inspired their journey. After a sojourn in St. Louis with some wealthy Jewish merchants whose ownership of slaves surprises them, they set out for Oregon, hoping for freedom and a better future in the western wilderness. Veltfort, who is the granddaughter of the psychoanalyst Otto Rank, tells this story in chapters from Chana's and Yitzhak's alternating perspectives. Their path is filled with violence and loss, but comic moments also lighten the narrative; in one memorable scene, they are introduced to the earthly pleasures of watermelon. Sandee Brawarsky

headline: {'main': 'Books in Brief: Nonfiction; Glyphs From the Bauhaus', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Books in Brief: Nonfiction; Glyphs From the Bauhaus', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

keywords: [{'name': 'persons', 'value': 'Albers, Anni', 'rank': 1, 'major': 'N'}, {'name': 'subject', 'value': 'Books and Literature', 'rank': 2, 'major': 'N'}, {'name': 'subject', 'value': 'Biographical Information', 'rank': 3, 'major': 'N'}, {'name': 'creative_works', 'value': 'ANNI ALBERS (BOOK)', 'rank': 4, 'major': 'N'}]
snippet: Books in Brief:
lead_paragraph: When Anni Albers enrolled in 1922 at the Bauhaus, the German art-school-cum-laboratory of modern aesthetics, it wasn't quite progressive enough to admit a woman into the physically demanding painting workshop. Instead she was relegated to weaving. Yet doing something she considered ''as sissy as working with threads,'' Albers raised her textiles to the level of painting with spare abstract designs that were a radical departure from the decorative floral patterns or figural narratives of European tapestries. Her modular forms and improvisational glyphs echo the playful paintings of Paul Klee, who taught Albers a weaving course in which he encouraged students to exploit the innate checkerboard structure of the medium. Also inspirational were the Andean textiles that Albers collected on trips to Mexico and South America after coming to the United States in 1933 with her husband, Josef Albers, the acclaimed painter and color theorist. Her tactile masterpieces and later experiments with printmaking are beautifully presented in ANNI ALBERS (Guggenheim Museum/Abrams, $60), by Nicholas Fox Weber, the executive director of the Josef and Anni Albers Foundation, and Pandora Tabatabai Asbaghi, an independent curator. Weber's is the best of a handful of essays as succinct as the works they illuminate; he chronicles how he first met the aging couple in 1971, when he was 23, and became so close to Anni Albers that he would drive her to the cemetery to read her mail by her husband's grave (she outlived Josef by nearly two decades, dying in 1994 at the age of 94). Weber writes lovingly of how this devout modernist, who valued technology in everything from water-repellent fibers to plastic, and unexpectedly delighted in places like Sears and Kentucky Fried Chicken, would complain of ''craft people,'' saying ''they should simply look at what they were wearing to understand the value of mechanization.'' Hilarie M. Sheets

lead_paragraph: OTHER PEOPLE'S MONEY, by Arthur Lyons. (Mysterious Press, $4.95.) A bidding war over stolen artifacts convinces the private eye Jacob Asch that museum directors and art collectors aren't necessarily such cultured people after all. ''Mr. Lyons has hit upon a subject worthy of his detective's intelligence in this art-is-hell caper,'' Marilyn Stasio said here last year.

snippet: Marilyn Stasio reviews new crime novels: Never Street by Loren D Estleman; Scam by Parnell Hall; Past Tense by Stephen Greenleaf; Cold Case by Linda Barnes (S)
lead_paragraph: Amos Walker, who is on my short list of hard-boiled private eyes with staying power, makes his first appearance since 1990 in Loren D. Estleman's NEVER STREET (Mysterious Press/Warner, $23) -- just in time to smack a little sense into a genre that's getting dumber by the minute. Although the Detroit gumshoe cynically refers to himself as ''a redundancy,'' he's really the dependable, wide-bodied model in a classic line.
abstract: Marilyn Stasio reviews new crime novels: Never Street by Loren D Estleman; Scam by Parnell Hall; Past Tense by Stephen Greenleaf; Cold Case by Linda Barnes (S)

byline: {'original': 'By Susann Cokal', 'person': [{'firstname': 'Susann', 'middlename': None, 'lastname': 'Cokal', 'qualifier': None, 'title': None, 'role': 'reported', 'organization': '', 'rank': 1}], 'organization': None}
keywords: [{'name': 'subject', 'value': 'Books and Literature', 'rank': 1, 'major': 'N'}, {'name': 'persons', 'value': 'Chabon, Michael', 'rank': 2, 'major': 'N'}]
snippet: This gleeful tale of derring-do follows a pair of 10th-century soldiers of fortune bound together by the accident of birth that made them both Jewish.
lead_paragraph: In Michael Chabon’s gleeful new novel, a pair of 10th-century soldiers of fortune scramble up and down the trails and gorges of the Caucasus, engaging in a brawl or a boondoggle as regularly as they pause for a meal. Zelikman, a blond European scarecrow whose heart has “turned to stone,” and Amram, a towering African, are apt if unlikely companions on the Silk Road’s shifting social terrain. Each has his pet passions — Zelikman for his hat and his horse, Amram for a sword called Mother-Defiler — and they bicker like the two leads in a buddy film, in this case bound together by the accident of birth that made them both Jewish. But atypically for Jews of the medieval era, they look for the main chance while swinging their blades right and left.

keywords: [{'name': 'persons', 'value': 'Callanan, Liam', 'rank': 1, 'major': 'N'}, {'name': 'persons', 'value': 'Echenoz, Jean', 'rank': 2, 'major': 'N'}, {'name': 'subject', 'value': 'Books and Literature', 'rank': 3, 'major': 'N'}, {'name': 'subject', 'value': 'Reviews', 'rank': 4, 'major': 'N'}, {'name': 'creative_works', 'value': 'Big Blondes (Book)', 'rank': 5, 'major': 'N'}]
snippet: Liam Callanan reviews book Big Blondes by Jean Echenoz; drawing (S)
lead_paragraph: Delightful and decidedly goofy, Jean Echenoz's novel BIG BLONDES (New Press, $22) has one at its center -- the fleetingly famous chanteuse Gloria Stella (nee Gloire Abgrall), who fled from the public eye upon the suspicious demise of her agent-lover. Her seclusion is complete until a trash television producer named Paul Salvador picks up the trail while in pursuit of his two abiding interests: ''What ever happened to?'' celebrity stories and the blondes of the book's title. When Salvador's private detectives begin closing in, Gloire reacts with feral rage, hurling one of her pursuers off a cliff and leading the rest on a chase from Paris to Sydney to Bombay. In Mark Polizzotti's translation from the original French, Echenoz's modus operandi is parody played so broadly it occasionally borders on farce; he delights in savaging mass media cliches like television docudramas or action-adventure movies. Though these are not new or difficult targets, Echenoz dispatches them with gleeful silliness. He doesn't spare his own work in the process, using sporadic asides to treat his novel as cavalierly as any of his other subjects. ''We already know the deal,'' he writes at one point, ''so let's get this over with quickly and move on.'' What's not to like about such a considerate author? Liam Callanan
abstract: Liam Callanan reviews book Big Blondes by Jean Echenoz; drawing (S)

snippet: Memoirs of self-destruction from the rock stars Slash and Nikki Sixx.
lead_paragraph: Most rock biographies are about getting to the Good Part. There’s typically a bit of slogging through the star’s unhappy childhood, the revelation of music’s true power and a hard-fought rise to the top before the litany of debauchery and depravity begins  the part that fans actually want to read.

snippet: Marilyn Stasio reviews following books: Death Is Now My Neighbor by Colin Dexter; Notches by Peter Bowen; Death in the Palazzo by Edward Sklepowich; Survival Instincts by Marissa Piesman; and A Thin Dark Line by Tami Hoag; drawing (M)
lead_paragraph: DEATH IS NOW MY NEIGHBOR (Crown, $24), another deviously constructed Inspector Morse mystery from the masterly hand of Colin Dexter, opens with a lesson on the proper use of the pluperfect subjunctive in Latin. To this lovely piece of pedantry are added surprise quizzes (with multiple-choice answers), clues to impenetrable crosswords, Latin proverbs (''Initium est dimidium facti,'' or ''Once you've started, you're halfway there''), German lieder lyrics and the cryptic thoughts of everyone from Voltaire to tabloid gossip columnists. For good measure, the author also finds occasion to put Morse on a train to Paddington that passes Cholsey, the village where Agatha Christie is buried.
abstract: Marilyn Stasio reviews following books: Death Is Now My Neighbor by Colin Dexter; Notches by Peter Bowen; Death in the Palazzo by Edward Sklepowich; Survival Instincts by Marissa Piesman; and A Thin Dark Line by Tami Hoag; drawing (M)

byline: {'original': None, 'person': [], 'organization': None}
snippet: Unknown
lead_paragraph: (Editors' choices of other recent books of particular interest)
abstract: (Editors' choices of other recent books of particular interest)    SELDOM DISAPPOINTED: A Memoir, by Tony Hillerman. (HarperCollins, $26.) A disarming survey of his life by the author of the amazingly well-informed Jim Chee-Joe Leaphorn Navajo crime novels, who is not a Navajo, was for many years a newspaperman, and lost most of a foot and the sight of one eye in World War II.    AUSTERLITZ, by W. G. Sebald. (Random House, $25.95.) A middle-aged Welsh architectural historian discovers that he is really the son of Holocaust victims from Czechoslovakia in this rich, gloomy novel by a writer who has specialized in characters crippled by the past.    CULTIVATING DELIGHT: A Natural History of My Garden, by Diane Ackerman. (HarperCollins, $25.) The training of a poet and the methodical approach of a scientist issue in Ackerman's sensitivity to the garden she follows through 52 passages (a year's worth) of intense, joyful contemplation and enhanced horticultural description.    THE SAME SEA, by Amos Oz. (Harcourt, $24.) A lucid, transparently playful novel about sexual hanky-panky involving a man and his son and several women in contemporary Tel Aviv and Katmandu; the author himself steps in, perhaps to flirt with us. And most of the book is in verse. (The author collaborated with Nicholas de Lange on the translation.)    THE GOOD GERMAN, by Joseph Kanon. (Holt, $26.) The deepest considerations of right and wrong pervade this novel about an American journalist searching for his prewar lover in the ruined (and harrowingly described) Berlin of 1945, where everything is for sale and experience with rocket weapons commands a very high price.    CRESCENT AND STAR: Turkey Between Two Worlds, by Stephen Kinzer. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $25.) A lively account, by a correspondent for The Times, of a 99 percent Muslim country whose best regional friend is Israel and where democracy was introduced and is sometimes still enforced by generals.    THE BROTHER: The Untold Story of Atomic Spy David Greenglass and How He Sent His Sister, Ethel Rosenberg, to the Electric Chair, by Sam Roberts. (Random House, $35.) An absorbing account, by an editor at The Times, of the famous spy case as seen through the eyes of Greenglass, enriched by recently declassified information about American decoding of Soviet intelligence traffic.    ROOSEVELT'S SECRET WAR: FDR and World War II Espionage, by Joseph E. Persico. (Random House, $35.) A thoroughly informed account, from the Allied viewpoint, of the clandestine side of World War II, complicated by the difficulty of establishing what, at any given time, the spymasters and their putative bosses knew and when they knew it.    THE DEVIL'S LARDER, by Jim Crace. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $20.) Sixty-four brief fictions that require the reader to settle for not knowing exactly what is going on when tourists, for example, are tormented with snacks that induce ''chemical mirth.''

keywords: [{'name': 'persons', 'value': 'Hill, Susan', 'rank': 1, 'major': 'N'}, {'name': 'subject', 'value': 'BOOK REVIEWS', 'rank': 2, 'major': 'N'}, {'name': 'creative_works', 'value': 'FAMILY (BOOK)', 'rank': 3, 'major': 'N'}]
snippet: Unknown
lead_paragraph: FAMILY. By Susan Hill. (Viking, $18.95.) At the center of this absorbing story of an English mother's struggle to have a second child is a baby named Imogen. Born prematurely at 25 weeks in Oxford, Imogen lived for five weeks. She was tiny: she weighed one and a half pounds, and her entire hand was only as large as the top joint of her mother's thumb. As recorded here by her mother, the novelist Susan Hill, Imogen's was a staccato life of fits and starts: she was infected during delivery and required antibiotics and a blood transfusion; delicate surgery was required to remove an obstruction in the baby's bowels. Yet, like most preemies, Imogen was a conundrum - one day she was thriving, pink and wriggly, grasping her mother's finger; the next day she developed apnea and suddenly stopped breathing. Ms. Hill describes how she remained dauntless, eager to cling to the small chance that her baby would survive. In fact, Ms. Hill's determination is what drives ''Family'': her first pregnancy at the age of 35 was smooth, and her daughter was born healthy and on time. Ms. Hill tells how, attempting to conceive again, she encountered serious hurdles: she miscarried three times before giving birth prematurely to Imogen. A year and a half after Imogen's death, Clemency was born. Ms. Hill's detailed chronicle should inspire those women who have had problems with pregnancies or are starting families at an older age. Most especially, this book offers a telescopic look at one very young and courageous life.
abstract: LEAD:    FAMILY. By Susan Hill. (Viking, $18.95.) At the center of this absorbing story of an English mother's struggle to have a second child is a baby named Imogen. Born prematurely at 25 weeks in Oxford, Imogen lived for five weeks. She was tiny: she weighed one and a half pounds, and her entire hand was only as large as the top joint of her mother's thumb.

snippet: Starting from a slender legend, a historian recreates the story of a free black couple in antebellum New England.
lead_paragraph: David McCullough, the best-selling historian, insists that the secret to his craft is simple: tell stories. If we say, “The king died and then the queen died,” we have two events. If we add that the queen died of grief, we have a story, and a good one because the reader has a reason to care. This maxim (McCullough borrowed it from E. M. Forster) is less helpful when there’s no royal paper trail. Can history assume the queen’s grief because it makes a good story? A good story may stand in for a true one.
abstract: Starting from a slender legend, a historian recreates the story of a free black couple in antebellum New England.
